question: In the model inventory, what should you write about a model’s “operating boundaries,” and what should you note if the model is used outside those boundaries (for example, during stressed economic conditions)?
gold_answer: In the model inventory, you should include the model’s operating boundaries as part of the information describing the model’s purpose and use, including the boundaries under which model performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] You should describe those operating boundaries using the definition that they are the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of a statistical model, and in multivariate cases this includes the empirical variance-covariance relationships reflected in that sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] You should also connect this boundary description to how the model is actually being used by noting whether the use stays within the sample data range or goes beyond it (i.e., extrapolation). [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] If the model is used outside its operating boundaries—such as when macroeconomic indices reflect shock or stressed economic conditions—you should record that this kind of extrapolation should be assumed to increase model risk. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] Keeping this information in the inventory supports tracking related validation indicators and any outstanding remediation actions when boundary exceedances are relevant to model functioning. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]
source_text: c) The types of information the model inventory should capture include: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable; (ii) model assumptions and limitations. For example, risks not captured in model and limitations in the data used to calibrate the model; (iii) findings from validation. For example, indicators of whether models are functioning properly, the dates when those indicators were last updated, any outstanding remediation actions; and (iv) governance details. For example, the names of individuals responsible for validation, the dates when validation was last performed, and the frequency of future validation.
target_text: 7. Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model. While not a measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk.

question: For an institution that uses the methods in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, how must it determine and monitor the “size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business” when deciding whether it may calculate the exposure value of derivative positions using the method in Section 4, including the relevant calculation basis and assessment timing?
gold_answer: An institution that is considering using the Section 4 method to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions must ensure that it determines the “size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business” using the specific calculation approach referenced for institutions using the methods in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, namely the size as calculated under Article 273a(1) or Article 273a(2), as applicable. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] In addition, eligibility to use the Section 4 method is conditional on that size being at or below both thresholds specified for that purpose, and the institution must base this determination on a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of each month. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2] The practical linkage is that the monthly, month-end assessment required for the Section 4 eligibility test must use the Article 273a-based size metric that applies to institutions using Sections 4 to 5 methods, rather than an alternative sizing approach. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] This Section 4 permission is also framed as being subject to a restriction referenced in Article 273b(2), which must be taken into account when applying the monthly threshold test. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]
source_text: (m) for institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the size of their on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business as calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2) , as applicable.
target_text: Subject to the restriction set out in Article 273b(2) , an institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions in accordance with the method set out in Section 4 , provided that the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is equal to or less than both of the following thresholds on the basis of an assessment carried out on a monthly basis using the data as of the last day of the month :

question: Where a credit union plans to offer shares within an ISA tax-free wrapper and also intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, how should it treat HMRC approval and what baseline compliance expectation does the PRA set before the credit union begins the fixed-rate activity?
gold_answer: A credit union in this position should treat HMRC approval for offering shares in an ISA tax-free wrapper as relevant to the ISA wrapper context, but not as removing the need to comply with statutory requirements. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] In parallel, before it starts issuing fixed-rate shares or deposits, the credit union is expected by the PRA to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied prior to beginning that activity. [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] Put together, the compliance approach is that obtaining HMRC approval for ISA-related offerings does not create an exemption from statutory compliance, and the PRA’s expectation for fixed-rate issuance is explicitly framed as a pre-commencement obligation to meet statutory mandatory requirements. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] Practically, this means the credit union should (i) consult the relevant HMRC regulations when it wishes to offer ISA-wrapped shares, and (ii) ensure it has satisfied the applicable statutory mandatory requirements before beginning any fixed-rate shares or deposits activity, without assuming that HMRC approval changes those statutory obligations. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]
source_text: Credit unions that wish to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper are expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Credit unions should be aware that approval from HMRC does not provide any degree of exemption from compliance with the statutory requirements referred to above in paragraph 5.2 .
target_text: The PRA expects that any credit union that intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning such activity. 2

question: When an institution is calculating the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP using the approach in Article 308, how should it determine the exposure value of that pre-funded contribution, including any reduction for amounts already applied by the QCCP after a clearing member default?
gold_answer: In calculating the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP, the institution must apply the approach specified in Article 308, and that calculation must be based on an exposure value determined under the rule for DFi. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148] The exposure value for the institution’s pre-funded contribution to the QCCP default fund (DFi) is the amount the institution has paid in, or alternatively the market value of assets it has delivered, and this starting amount must be reduced by any portion of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb losses that arose after the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] Accordingly, the institution should (i) identify whether its contribution was made as cash paid in or as assets delivered and, if assets were delivered, use their market value, and (ii) subtract any amount of that same contribution that has already been applied by the QCCP to cover losses in the specified default scenario. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] This reduced DFi exposure value is the relevant measure to feed into the Article 308 approach when calculating the own funds requirement for the institution’s pre-funded default fund contribution. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]
source_text: (a) it shall calculate the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP in accordance with the approach set out in Article 308 ;
target_text: The exposure value for an institution's pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP (DFi) shall be the amount paid in or the market value of the assets delivered by that institution reduced by any amount of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb its losses following the default of one or more of its clearing members .

question: When a firm selects rates of interest for calculating the present value of future payments, how must it apply the cap on the assumed yield for an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business (including the specified reduction and the fact it is applied before any tax adjustment), and how does that cap interact with the requirement that rates be based on a prudent assessment of yields on existing and (as appropriate) future investments?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that the interest rates it uses to discount future payments do not exceed rates derived from a prudent assessment of relevant asset yields, and that any assumed yield used for an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business is additionally constrained by a specific quantitative cap. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] In particular, for the purposes of 11.1, the assumed yield on such an asset, before making any adjustment for the effect of taxation, cannot be higher than the yield on that asset calculated under the referenced yield-calculation provisions (11.3 to 11.13) after reducing that calculated yield by 2.5% of itself. [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8] This means the prudent-assessment process for setting discount rates must be anchored to yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business and, where appropriate, expected yields on future sums to be invested, but the assumed yield input for any particular attributed asset must still be tested against the “calculated yield minus 2.5% of that yield” ceiling, applied on a pre-tax-adjustment basis. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8] Operationally, the firm should (i) determine prudent yields for existing attributed assets and appropriate expected yields for future investments, (ii) calculate each asset’s yield under 11.3–11.13, and (iii) set the assumed yield used in the present value calculation at or below the reduced calculated yield, without first adjusting for taxation. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.
target_text: The rates of interest to be used in calculating the present value of future payments by or to a firm must be no greater than the rates of interest determined from a prudent assessment of the yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business and, to the extent appropriate, the yields which it is expected will be obtained on sums to be invested in the future.

question: If the PRA identifies defects that engage the Three Criteria and would otherwise prevent confirmation of a merger, what is the PRA permitted to require the society to do (including any meeting-related steps), and how does that sit with the PRA’s inability to judge the merger’s merits or alter its terms once members have approved them?
gold_answer: The PRA’s role on a confirmation application is limited to deciding, on the facts, whether any of the Three Criteria apply; it is not permitted to assess the commercial merits of the merger or the fairness of its terms, and once members have approved the merger and its terms the PRA cannot require changes to those terms. [#SRC:aba762e80d02874f] However, where defects falling within the Three Criteria would otherwise preclude confirmation, the PRA may direct the society to remedy those defects, including by requiring procedural steps such as calling a further meeting. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] In practice, a direction may require a re-vote at a further meeting after the society issues a revised Schedule 16 Statement that includes material information previously omitted, or after the society corrects defects in its systems for sending meeting notices and Statements and validates votes. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] After the society furnishes evidence of remediation, the PRA must confirm the merger if it is satisfied the defects have been substantially remedied; if it is not satisfied, it must refuse confirmation. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] This remedial direction power operates within (and does not expand) the PRA’s confined remit: it addresses defects relevant to the Three Criteria rather than revisiting the merger’s merits or rewriting member-approved terms. [#SRC:aba762e80d02874f]
source_text: The PRA’s powers in connection with applications for confirmation of a merger are confined to considerations of whether, in the light of the facts, any of the Three Criteria apply. It is not for the PRA to consider, or make judgements about, the merits of a proposed merger or the fairness of its terms; these matters are first for the board of a society, and then for its members to decide. Once the members have approved the merger and its terms, the PRA has no powers to require a society to make any changes to those terms. The PRA’s discretionary powers are similarly confined to the matters described in paragraphs 3.157 and 3.158 .
target_text: Where the PRA would be precluded from confirming a merger by reason of any of the defects specified in the Three Criteria, 37 Section 95(6) provides that it may direct a society to remedy the defects. A direction under that subsection may require a society to call a further meeting; for example, to vote again in the light of a revised Schedule 16 Statement containing material information previously omitted, or after correction of defects in the systems for sending notices of meeting and Statements and validation of votes. If the PRA is then satisfied, having considered evidence furnished by the society, that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger. If not, then confirmation must be refused.

question: When calculating the risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), how should an institution treat assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member that are bankruptcy remote upon insolvency of the CCP, the clearing member, or other clients—specifically, can those assets be assigned a zero exposure value and, if so, how does that affect the sum of exposure values that is multiplied by the applicable risk weight?
gold_answer: In calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), the institution’s baseline method is to add up the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (as calculated under the relevant paragraphs) and then apply the risk weight determined under the relevant paragraph to that summed amount. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] However, a specific derogation allows the institution, in defined circumstances, to set the exposure value to zero for certain counterparty credit risk exposures tied to collateral assets posted to a CCP or a clearing member. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] This zero-exposure treatment is available only where the posted collateral assets are bankruptcy remote if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] When the derogation applies and the institution attributes an exposure value of zero to those counterparty credit risk exposures, those zero-valued exposures would not increase the summed exposure values that form the basis for the subsequent multiplication by the applicable risk weight in the CCP trade exposure calculation. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The institution should therefore reflect the derogation at the exposure-value stage before performing the sum-and-multiply step used to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amount for its trade exposures with CCPs. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 1 , where assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member are bankruptcy remote in the event that the CCP, the clearing member or one or more of the other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, an institution may attribute an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for those assets.

question: If you are working out the solvency of a group, what do you do with the participating undertaking’s proportional share in related undertakings, and how do you treat related undertakings that are linked by a common management relationship given the rule that this applies despite point (4) of 11.1A and must follow points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A?
gold_answer: You must build the group solvency calculation so it reflects the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] When the related undertakings are linked by a common management relationship, their data must be brought into the calculation on that same proportional-share basis. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] In addition, the common-management inclusion is not blocked or changed just because point (4) of 11.1A exists; instead, the data is included notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A and by applying one of the specified routes in points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] Putting the two passages together: the proportional share is the required measurement for taking related undertakings into account in the group solvency calculation, and the common-management rule tells you exactly how to operationalize that measurement—include the relevant data proportionally and do it under the listed points of 11.1A even where point (4) might otherwise be thought to affect inclusion. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]
source_text: Notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship shall be included in accordance with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A on the basis of the proportional share as referred to in Chapter 8 .
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: When the PRA sets and updates the ultimate forward rate for a relevant currency using the methodology specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024, how should expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation be treated, and what does the ultimate forward rate exclude in relation to long-term investment risk?
gold_answer: In applying the methodology specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024, the PRA’s ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency is built from long-term expectations (where reliably determinable) and is not adjusted to add compensation for long-term investment risk. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] For each relevant currency, the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, but only to the extent those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] Separately, the ultimate forward rate is defined so that it does not include any term premium intended to reflect the additional risk of holding long-term investments. [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] In terms of change control, the PRA maintains stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only make changes where there are changes in long-term expectations, meaning updates are driven by shifts in those underlying expectations rather than by adding a term premium. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] Accordingly, when assessing whether and how the PRA may adjust the ultimate forward rate, the relevant inputs are reliably determined long-term expectations (real rate and inflation), while term-premium-style risk add-ons are excluded from the rate’s construction. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d]
source_text: For each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, provided those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. The PRA will maintain stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only make changes where there are changes in long-term expectations. The PRA uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024. 4
target_text: The ultimate forward rate does not include a term premium to reflect the additional risk of holding long-term investments.

question: If a firm has achieved SRT for a transaction, what should it keep checking over time, and how should its stress tests cover both (a) a possible downgrade of the protection provider for unfunded credit protection and (b) securitised assets coming back onto the balance sheet?
gold_answer: After achieving SRT for a transaction, the PRA expects the firm to keep monitoring the risks linked to that transaction that it may still be exposed to, and to continue regular stress testing of its securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures. [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] As part of that monitoring and stress-testing, originators are expected to assess the risk that the protection provider is downgraded and what that would mean for the effectiveness of the unfunded credit protection and whether the provider remains eligible to keep providing it, and then reflect those implications in capital planning. [#SRC:e7a6b6de3819019b] The PRA also expects firms to consider, in capital planning, what happens if securitised assets return onto their balance sheets, and to design stress tests that look at the firm-wide impact of stressed market conditions on securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures. [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] Those stress tests are expected to consider implications for other risk sources (such as credit, concentration, counterparty, market, liquidity and reputational risk), cover existing securitisations and pipeline transactions, and be supported by procedures to assess and respond to results, with an expectation that results are taken into account under Pillar 2. [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] In practice, this means the downgrade/eligibility check for the protection provider should be treated as a specific input into the broader securitisation stress-testing and capital planning cycle. [#SRC:e7a6b6de3819019b] [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607]
source_text: The PRA expects originators, as part of the monitoring and stress-testing mentioned in paragraph 2.11 of this SS, to assess the risk of a downgrade of the protection provider and the implications for the effectiveness of the unfunded credit protection and the eligibility of the provider to continue to provide the unfunded credit protection, and to reflect this in their capital planning.
target_text: Where a firm achieves SRT for a particular transaction, the PRA expects it to continue to monitor risks related to the transaction to which it may still be exposed. The PRA expects firms to consider the capital planning implications of securitised assets returning onto their balance sheets. The Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook requires firms to conduct regular stress testing of their securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures. 5 The PRA expects those stress tests to consider the firm-wide impact of stressed market conditions on those activities and exposures and the implications for other sources of risk, for example, credit risk, concentration risk, counterparty risk, market risk, liquidity risk and reputational risk. The PRA expects a firm’s stress testing of securitisation activities to take into account existing securitisations and pipeline transactions. The PRA expects a firm to have in place procedures to assess and respond to the results of that stress testing and would expect them to be taken into account under Pillar 2.

question: If an institution has put money or assets into a QCCP default fund, what number should it use as the “exposure value” for that contribution when it works out its own funds requirement under Article 308, and when does that number get reduced?
gold_answer: For the institution’s own funds requirement calculation for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP, the institution must perform the calculation using the approach in Article 308 and therefore needs an exposure value for the contribution as an input to that approach. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148] The exposure value (DFi) is set as the amount the institution paid into the QCCP default fund, or, if it delivered assets instead of paying cash, the market value of those delivered assets. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] That exposure value is not always the full paid-in amount or full market value: it must be reduced by any part of the institution’s contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb losses, but only where those losses followed the default of one or more of the QCCP’s clearing members. [#TGT:5b56ca243fc390af] Practically, the institution should determine whether the contribution was cash or assets, measure it accordingly, and then subtract any amount already applied by the QCCP for loss absorption in the specified default context before using the resulting figure in the Article 308 own funds requirement calculation. [#SRC:b21669d5cc795148]
source_text: (a) it shall calculate the own funds requirement for its pre-funded contributions to the default fund of a QCCP in accordance with the approach set out in Article 308 ;
target_text: The exposure value for an institution's pre-funded contribution to the default fund of a QCCP (DFi) shall be the amount paid in or the market value of the assets delivered by that institution reduced by any amount of that contribution that the QCCP has already used to absorb its losses following the default of one or more of its clearing members .

question: In a TWD scenario, what specific projections must a TWD firm prepare from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, and how must those projections treat capital resources impacts in relation to expected exit/operational costs, RBLs, trading book-related capital deductions, and RWAs by risk type?
gold_answer: A TWD firm must be able to produce forward-looking projections starting from the assumed reference date of the TWD option and covering the entire wind-down period, and those projections must span both cost/funding items and capital impacts. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] Specifically, the firm’s projections must cover expected exit costs, operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs over that period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] In addition, the capital resources element must be developed in a way that explicitly incorporates how the expected exit costs, operational costs and the defined RBLs affect capital resources throughout the wind-down period in the TWD scenario. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] The firm must also forecast the effect of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions as part of its capital resources impacts analysis. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] Further, the projections must address how implementing the actions, arrangements and measures that form part of the TWD option will affect capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including producing projections of RWAs for market risk, counterparty credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] Taken together, this means the firm’s wind-down projections must link the cost and RBL assumptions from the reference date to quantified capital resources and capital requirement outcomes through the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 26. This should include projections of capital resources impacts through the wind-down period in the TWD scenario, incorporating the impact of expected exit, operational costs and RBLs defined above on capital resources, as well as a forecast of the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and projections of the impact of the implementation of the actions, arrangements and measures set out as part of the TWD option on capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks.

question: When something goes wrong operationally, how should boards and senior management use impact tolerances in their decisions, and how do mapping and testing help the firm show it can still deliver important business services within those tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios?
gold_answer: Boards and senior management should use impact tolerances as a decision standard, and firms should use mapping and testing to check whether they can keep delivering important business services within those tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] Impact tolerances are intended to guide boards and senior management in prioritising investment and in setting up recovery and response arrangements. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] They can also help inform decisions during operational disruptions, but they are not the only input and should be considered together with other information needed to manage the incident effectively. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] Separately, firms are required to ensure they can deliver their important business services within impact tolerances when facing severe but plausible scenarios. [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950] Mapping and testing the delivery of those important business services equips firms to work out whether they can stay within impact tolerances and what changes may be needed to do so. [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950] Taken together, the board-level use of impact tolerances (investment and recovery/response planning) should be informed by what mapping and testing reveal about staying within tolerance in the specified scenarios. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:0f14e9411e03a950]
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 17 require firms to ensure they are able to deliver their important business services within impact tolerances in severe but plausible scenarios. Mapping and testing the delivery of important business services will equip firms to establish whether and how they can remain within impact tolerances.

question: If the meeting might be paused so scrutineers can report, what does the chairman need to be ready to do, and what details must the scrutineers’ report include for the PRA confirmation application?
gold_answer: If a society is heading toward a PRA confirmation application, the chairman should be ready to run the meeting strictly under the society’s Rules and the general law on meeting procedure, including handling a resolution to adjourn, because the meeting can be adjourned so the scrutineers can give their initial report to the society at the meeting. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] [#TGT:5624262c20121461] For the PRA’s purposes, scrutineer reporting is not just a formality: the PRA will require a report from the scrutineers to support the application for confirmation, and it must state the result of the vote while separating votes cast in person from those cast by proxy. [#TGT:5624262c20121461] That same report must also provide the total number of members eligible to vote and show what proportion of that eligible membership is represented by the votes actually cast. [#TGT:5624262c20121461] In addition, the PRA will require a confirmatory report from the scrutineers on whether the voting procedures were valid, which ties back to the need for the society to comply strictly with statutory procedural requirements and its own Rules on meetings and resolutions. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] This linkage means the chair’s procedural decisions (including any adjournment) should support producing scrutineer reports that meet the PRA’s confirmation expectations. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] [#TGT:5624262c20121461]
source_text: Experience has demonstrated the need for societies to take the greatest care to ensure that they comply strictly with the statutory procedural requirements and their own Rules on meetings and resolutions. The chairman of the meeting should ensure that he or she is well briefed and aware of the Rules and the general law relating to procedural resolutions, such as resolutions to adjourn the meeting. The PRA will require a confirmatory report from the scrutineers on the validity of the voting procedures when the society applies for confirmation (see paragraph 3.146 ).
target_text: The scrutineers initial report will be made to the society at the meeting (which may be adjourned for this purpose). question: An institution checks every month (using month-end data) that its derivative business is under the thresholds to use the Section 5 method. If it had stopped calculating exposure values under Section 4 or 5 before, what else must it do before it can start using Section 5 again?
gold_answer: Even if the institution’s monthly, month-end assessment shows its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below both thresholds for using the Section 5 method, that alone is not enough when the institution is restarting after a prior cessation. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] Where the institution has ceased to calculate exposure values under Section 4 or Section 5, it is only allowed to resume calculating exposure values under Section 4 or Section 5 once it demonstrates to the competent authority that all the conditions in Article 273a(1) or (2) have been met continuously for an uninterrupted period of one year. [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393] The two requirements operate together: the Section 5 permission is tied to a recurring monthly assessment using data as of the last day of the month to confirm the size thresholds are met, while the resumption rule adds a separate “one-year uninterrupted” proof requirement directed to the competent authority before the institution may restart calculations under Section 5. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393] In other words, the institution needs both (i) the ongoing monthly threshold-based eligibility for Section 5 and (ii) the one-year uninterrupted demonstration of the Article 273a conditions to unlock the ability to resume after it previously stopped. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]
source_text: Where an institution has ceased to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, it shall only be permitted to resume calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions as set out in Section 4 or 5 where it demonstrates to the competent authority that all the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) or (2) have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year.

question: If the FSCS needs single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours after deposits become unavailable, what should a firm do to stay ready for requests that can happen at any time, and when can the 24-hour countdown start if the trigger is a request made during the business day?
gold_answer: The firm must be capable of providing the FSCS with all single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours once the relevant deposits become unavailable deposits. [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619] In addition, the firm should be prepared to submit an SCV file and an exclusions view file whenever the PRA or the FSCS asks, because requests may be made at any time, including during a business as usual review programme. [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] For request-driven submissions, the PRA indicates that the beginning of the 24-hour period can be treated as the end of the business day on which the request was made, which affects how the firm should measure the deadline. [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] Putting these points together, the firm’s readiness should cover both triggers: (1) deposits becoming unavailable deposits (where the firm must meet the 24-hour delivery requirement to the FSCS), and (2) ad hoc or routine requests from the PRA or the FSCS (where the firm should be able to submit promptly and can calculate the 24-hour window using the end-of-business-day approach described by the PRA). [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619] [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c]
source_text: Depositor Protection 12.1 and 12.2 set out that a firm must provide an SCV file and an exclusions view file to the PRA or the FSCS within 24 hours of a deposit becoming an unavailable deposit or request by the PRA or the FSCS. The PRA considers that the beginning of the 24-hour period can be taken as the end of the business day on which the request was made. The PRA or the FSCS may request the submission of an SCV file and exclusions view file at any time, including as part of the business as usual review programme. As such, firms should be ready and able to submit SCV and exclusions view files to the PRA and FSCS upon request, and within the time period set out in the depositor protection rules.
target_text: A firm must provide to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the relevant deposits becoming unavailable deposits .

question: For a firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, how should the obligation to maintain a margin of solvency at or above the required margin be applied—does it operate as a single combined margin or as separate margins for each kind of business, and how does the “Subject to 2.3” qualifier affect the statement of that obligation?
gold_answer: A firm that carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business must treat the margin-of-solvency obligation as applying separately to each kind of business, rather than as a single combined margin across both lines. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b] In other words, when applying the rule that a firm must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency, the firm should read that requirement as two parallel requirements—one margin in respect of long-term insurance business and another margin in respect of general insurance business. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b][#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] The baseline obligation in the rule is framed as mandatory (“must maintain”) and is expressed by reference to the required margin of solvency, but it is expressly qualified by the opening condition “Subject to 2.3,” meaning the stated obligation is not absolute in all circumstances and is applied within that stated qualification. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] Separately, the rule’s scope excludes a “flat rate benefits business friendly society” from the stated obligation, so the described requirement (and its separate-margin application for dual-business firms) is directed at firms other than that excluded category. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690]
source_text: Where a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business , 2.1 has effect as if the requirement to maintain a margin of solvency were a requirement to maintain separate margins in respect of the two kinds of business.
target_text: Subject to 2.3 , a firm (other than a flat rate benefits business friendly society ) must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency .

question: For a PRA-regulated firm, when must it notify the PRA about an outsourcing arrangement that is treated as ‘material outsourcing’ because it involves services to which OCIR applies, and how should the firm handle notification timing if the arrangement was not initially assessed as material but is expected or planned to become material?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm must notify the PRA when it enters into, or significantly changes, a material outsourcing arrangement, and the PRA expects that notification to be submitted in advance of entering into the arrangement. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] Where the outsourcing is of services to which OCIR applies, the arrangement will generally be treated as “material outsourcing,” so it falls within the category that triggers the notification expectation. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] If the firm initially did not deem an outsourcing arrangement material, but it later becomes expected or planned to become material, the PRA also expects the firm to submit the notification before that change in materiality occurs. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify whether the outsourced services are within OCIR (which generally makes the outsourcing material), and (ii) plan notification so it is made before entering the arrangement or before the point at which the arrangement is expected or planned to become material. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] The PRA will take the timeliness of these notifications into account when it assesses the firm’s compliance with Fundamental Rule 7. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]
source_text: Notifications 2.3(1)(e) requires all PRA-regulated firms, including credit unions and NDFs, to notify the PRA when ‘entering, or significantly changing a material outsourcing arrangement’. The PRA expects these notifications to be made before entering into the outsourcing arrangement. The PRA also expects firms to submit these notifications before an outsourcing arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become so (see paragraph 5.5 ). The PRA will consider the timeliness of these notifications when assessing firms’ compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 .
target_text: If a firm outsources services to which OCIR applies, this arrangement will generally constitute ‘material outsourcing’. However, outsourcing and non-outsourcing third party arrangements that are not within scope of OCIR might still be ‘material outsourcing’ if they could affect the PRA’s objectives outside of an OCIR context. Examples may include outsourcing arrangements involving personal or sensitive data or carrying high reputational risk.

question: How should a firm determine the permitted asset exposure limit for an asset by reference to the range 28.2 to 28.23, and what limit applies where the asset is not covered by 28.2 to 28.22 (excluding derivatives)?
gold_answer: A firm should determine the permitted asset exposure limit by using the limits specified in the referenced set of provisions, and it must also apply a specific default outcome for certain assets that fall outside most of that range. The general rule is that permitted asset exposure limits are the ones contained in provisions 28.2 through 28.23, so the firm’s starting point is to identify whether the asset is addressed within that span and then apply the corresponding limit. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] However, there is an explicit treatment for an asset that is not covered by 28.2 through 28.22: if the asset is outside those provisions and it is not a derivative, the permitted asset exposure limit is zero (nil). [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315] Read together, this means the firm must (i) look to 28.2–28.23 for the applicable permitted limit where the asset is covered there, and (ii) apply a nil limit for any non-derivative asset that is not covered by 28.2–28.22, even though the broader set of limits is described as 28.2–28.23. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315]
source_text: The permitted asset exposure limits are those set out in 28.2 to 28.23 .
target_text: In the case of an asset which is not covered by 28.2 to 28.22 (other than a derivative ), the permitted asset exposure limit is nil.

question: When a subsidiary is checking it has the right number of SMFs for its size and updating its governance paperwork, what exactly counts as a Statement of Responsibilities (SoR), and what else must it keep up to date and aligned with the PRA Rulebook/SS28/15?
gold_answer: A Statement of Responsibilities (SoR) is the type of Statement of Responsibilities required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, so the subsidiary should treat its SoR as those section 60(2A) documents. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e] The subsidiary should also make sure it has an appropriate number of SMFs based on its size, complexity, and governance structure, following the principles in SS28/15 on strengthening individual accountability in banking. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] As part of that accountability setup, the subsidiary should keep two key governance documents current: its Management Responsibilities Maps and its SoR. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] It should then ensure responsibilities are allocated in line with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, using the up-to-date Management Responsibilities Maps and the (FSMA section 60(2A)) SoR to support that allocation. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Keeping the SoR “up to date” therefore means keeping the section 60(2A) Statements of Responsibilities current within the subsidiary’s governance and accountability arrangements. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]
source_text: A subsidiary should ensure that they have an appropriate number of SMFs according to its size, complexity, and governance structure, in line with the principles outlined in SS28/15 ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’ . 34 Firms should particularly ensure that Management Responsibilities Maps and Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) are up to date and that responsibilities are allocated in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15 . 35
target_text: 35. Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60 (2A) of FSMA: https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/8/section/60 .

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the rules listed must be used at “group level,” what does the firm need to have in its risk-management system so it can track risk for each part of the business and for the whole group, and which group-level rule areas are explicitly included?
gold_answer: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the firm must apply the specified requirements “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, so the listed rule areas are treated as group-wide requirements rather than only applying to a single entity. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] To support that group-wide application, the firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system that includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures to identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks continuously at both an individual level and an aggregated level, including the interdependencies between risks. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] In other words, the system should be capable of producing ongoing risk information for each relevant unit and also a consolidated view for the group, and it must be able to explain how risks connect across the group. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] The rule areas explicitly included for group-level application include multiple Conditions Governing Business modules (such as 2.2 to 2.6 and 2A.1 to 2A.6), Fitness and Propriety provisions (including 2.1 to 2.3, 4.1, 4.3 and 4.4), Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: When applying 11.1D, how may the participating Solvency II undertaking limit the documentation and directory of data under Conditions Governing Business 11C, and how does that limitation interact with the requirement that best estimates be net of intra-group transactions (including intra-group reinsurance contracts)?
gold_answer: In applying 11.1D, the participating Solvency II undertaking is permitted to narrow the scope of the documentation and the directory of data required under Conditions Governing Business 11C, but only to the extent that the retained materials cover the data actually used to calculate the adjustments to the best estimate described in 11.1E. [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366] At the same time, for 11.1D purposes, the best estimates of the participating Solvency II undertaking and of each related undertaking that falls within the specified categories must be determined on a basis that excludes (i.e., is net of) any intra-group transactions. [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] This means the undertaking’s decision to restrict the 11C documentation/data directory cannot omit the intra-group transaction effects that are necessary inputs to the best-estimate adjustments it is calculating under 11.1E, because those best estimates must already reflect netting of intra-group transactions. [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366] [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] In addition, where the intra-group transactions take the form of intra-group reinsurance contracts, the text indicates that a set of adjustments must be made in relation to those contracts, so the restricted documentation/data directory must still include the data used to perform those adjustments insofar as they feed into the best-estimate adjustments being calculated. [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1D , the participating Solvency II undertaking may restrict the documentation and the directory of data referred to in Conditions Governing Business 11C to the data used in the calculation of the adjustments of the best estimate referred to in 11.1E .

In relation to intra- group reinsurance contracts all of the following adjustments shall be made:

question: If a composite firm keeps separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, what does it have to write up from those accounts about eligible own funds and the notional MCR for each business?
gold_answer: Where a composite firm maintains separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business so that the results and sources for each activity are shown separately, it must also produce a statement that uses those accounts as its foundation. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] In that statement, the firm must identify the eligible own funds that cover the notional long-term insurance MCR and, separately, the eligible own funds that cover the notional general insurance MCR. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3] In practical terms, the separation of accounts across the two activities should be reflected in the statement’s structure: it should clearly distinguish the long-term insurance side from the general insurance side rather than blending them into one combined presentation. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] The minimum required elements are therefore two distinct identifications—one for eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and one for eligible own funds covering the notional general insurance MCR—each prepared on the basis of the accounts. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]
source_text: The firm must prepare a statement on the basis of the accounts referred to in 3.2 identifying the eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and the notional general insurance MCR , respectively.
target_text: A composite firm must maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business to show the sources of the results for each activity separately.

question: If a large institution’s non-performing loans and advances ratio is 5% or more, what extra templates does it have to publish each year, and when does it have to start publishing them based on the rule about two back-to-back quarters in the last four quarters before the disclosure reference date?
gold_answer: When a large institution has a non-performing loans and advances ratio that is at least 5%, it must make the additional disclosures (linked to points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR) using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5, following the Annex XV templates and Annex XVI instructions, and it must do so annually. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] The institution must begin making disclosure in line with the 5% threshold rule once it has reached or exceeded 5% in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters before the disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] For the first time it discloses, the institution must include the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if it meets the threshold on that first disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] Putting these together, the annual obligation to use the specified UK templates applies when the ratio is at or above 5%, and the start point is determined by checking whether the institution hit or exceeded 5% in two back-to-back quarters in the prior four-quarter window, while also ensuring the first disclosure reference date includes the threshold-subject templates if the ratio is at or above 5% on that date. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: When determining the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), how should a firm treat assets with credit ratings provided by credit rating agencies (CRAs) versus internally-rated assets, and how does the definition of “credit rating” and “credit rating agency” affect that distinction?
gold_answer: In determining the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), a firm is expected to group assets in an MA portfolio by credit quality step (CQS), asset class, and duration, and then apply different levels of judgement depending on whether an asset’s credit assessment is a “credit rating” from a “credit rating agency” or an internal assessment. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] The terms “credit rating” and “credit rating agency” are defined in regulation 2(1) of the IRPR regulations, so the firm should use those definitions to identify which assets fall into the CRA-rated category for this purpose. [#TGT:45aa7b23d23d130a] For assets that have CRA-provided credit ratings (as identified using those IRPR definitions), the CQS assignment process for basic FS is described as relatively prescriptive, including any adjustments to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, with the firm’s main judgement being how it categorises the asset class. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] By contrast, for internally-rated assets (i.e., assets not relying on a CRA “credit rating” as defined), the firm must exercise more judgement in determining the internal credit assessment and the CQS that should apply. [#SRC:85642c5db4f699c7] This distinction matters because the definitional boundary determines whether the firm follows the more prescriptive CRA-based assignation approach or the more judgement-based internal approach. [#TGT:45aa7b23d23d130a]
source_text: To determine the basic fundamental spread (basic FS), 2 the PRA expects that a firm will need to group the assets in an MA portfolio by credit quality step (CQS), asset class and duration. For assets with credit ratings provided by credit rating agencies 3 (CRAs) and referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement - Standard Formula 1D , the CQS and hence the assignation process for determining the basic FS, including any adjustments to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, is relatively prescriptive, with the only judgement being over the categorisation by asset class. In contrast, for internally-rated assets 4 , there is more judgement involved in determining the internal credit assessment and the CQS that should apply.
target_text: 3. Credit rating and credit rating agency are defined in regulation 2(1) of the IRPR regulations.

question: If a firm is setting up its risk-management system, what does it need to cover so it both (a) includes risks used for the SCR and risks not fully captured there, and (b) meets the requirement that calibration takes account of all quantifiable risks (including the listed minimum risk types)?
gold_answer: The firm needs a risk-management system that is broad enough to cover the risks used in the SCR calculation and also any risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, while also aligning with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks the firm faces are taken into account. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The system must be effective and properly integrated into the firm’s organisational structure and decision-making processes, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, so that the calibration and risk coverage are embedded in how the firm is run. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] To make this concrete, the calibration requirement says quantifiable risks must be captured and names at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The risk-management system must also cover at least these areas: underwriting and reserving; asset-liability management; investment risk management (especially derivatives, quasi-derivatives and similar commitments); liquidity risk and concentration risk management; operational risk management; and reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] Putting these together, the firm should ensure its listed risk-management areas are used to identify and manage the minimum risk categories and any other quantifiable risks, including those not fully reflected in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]
source_text: (2) That risk-management system must: (a) be effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions ; (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and (c) cover at least the following areas: (i) underwriting and reserving as set out in 3.1A(1) ; (ii) asset-liability management as set out in 3.1A(2) ; (iii) investment risk management, in particular derivatives , quasi-derivatives and similar commitments, as set out in 3.1A(3) ; (iv) liquidity risk and concentration risk management: as set out in 3.1A(4) and 3.1A(5) ; (v) operational risk management as set out in 3.1A(6) ; and (vi) reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques as set out in 3.1A(7) .
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: If a firm is an originator, sponsor, or original lender in a securitisation covered by the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, what does it need to be ready to show the PRA if asked, and what are the key details of the 5% risk-retention rule (when it’s measured and what value is used for off-balance-sheet items)?
gold_answer: The firm needs to be prepared to demonstrate to the PRA, on request, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms to comply with the relevant requirements in the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook (including Articles 6–9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4–6). [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614] As part of that readiness, the firm should be able to show how it meets the retention requirement that applies to the originator, sponsor or original lender: a material net economic interest of not less than 5% must be retained on an ongoing basis. [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012] The firm should also be able to explain and evidence the measurement conditions for that retained interest, because the rule specifies that the interest is measured at origination. [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012] In addition, where the retained interest relates to off-balance-sheet items, the amount is determined using notional value, so the firm’s processes should capture that basis in its compliance evidence. [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012] Overall, the PRA-facing demonstration is about having a compliance framework that can substantiate both the existence of adequate mechanisms and the specific retention measurement and maintenance features. [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]
source_text: The PRA expects firms which act as originators, original lenders, and/or sponsors in a securitisation that are subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook to be able to demonstrate to the PRA, on request, that they have in place adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms in order to comply with Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The originator , sponsor or original lender of a securitisation shall retain on an ongoing basis a material net economic interest in the securitisation of not less than 5%. That interest shall be measured at the origination and shall be determined by the notional value for off-balance-sheet items.

question: If someone is in scope because they perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA designated senior management function (with the “subject to 3.6(1)” note), can the firm give them a prescribed responsibility if they also perform an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: No. If the person performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the firm is not allowed to allocate a prescribed responsibility to them. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] The set of people you may be looking at for this decision includes those who perform a PRA senior management function and those who perform an FCA designated senior management function, and the FCA designated category is explicitly stated to operate with a “subject to 3.6(1)” qualifier. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] So the firm should (1) confirm the person is being considered in the relevant senior management function population (PRA senior management function or FCA designated senior management function, applying the qualifier), and then (2) check whether they perform an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] If they do perform that FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the prohibition applies and the prescribed responsibility must not be allocated to them, even if they also fall within the PRA or FCA designated senior management function categories. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4]
source_text: (1) performs a PRA senior management function or, subject to 3.6 (1), an FCA designated senior management function ; and
target_text: (1) A firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function .

question: If a credit union does extra activities or has over 15,000 members, can it just use the Table 1 percentages as-is to monitor the business? Also, what does the PRA mean when it says the Table 1 percentages are a “prudent practice” example for everything except loans-to-assets?
gold_answer: No—while Table 1 provides indicative ratios, the credit union is expected to monitor its relevant business using ratios with values calibrated to its own business model, not simply adopted unchanged. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The credit union should also have measures to set its tolerance for triggers and ratios that support resilience, and the board is expected to judge which ratios and values best reflect what matters most and the risks in the organisation. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] At the same time, the PRA gives an example of what it views as prudent practice: for credit unions that undertake additional activities or have more than 15,000 members, the PRA considers the indicative ratio percentages in Table 1 to be prudent for all calculations other than loans to assets. [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150] This means Table 1 can serve as a benchmark for most ratio calculations, but the credit union still needs to choose values that provide an accurate and reliable tool for the board to monitor performance against the strategic plan and regulatory obligations. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The credit union should also be able to explain and evidence its chosen ratios and the rationale for them if asked, including how it handled the loans-to-assets carve-out when considering Table 1 percentages. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150]
source_text: A credit union that is undertaking ‘additional activities’ 1 (see Table 1) or that has more than 15,000 members, and is therefore subject to the requirement in Rule 10.3(3) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, is expected to monitor its relevant business by using the ratios in paragraph 4.3 below, calibrated with values that are specifically aligned to its individual business model. Credit unions should have measures that help them define their tolerance for triggers and ratios that underpin their resilience. The ratios in table 1 below are indicative; the PRA expects boards to assess what is most important and reflects the risks in their organisation. The PRA expects the values selected by the credit union to provide an accurate and reliable business tool, by which its board may routinely and accurately monitor the credit union’s performance against its strategic plan and its regulatory obligations. The PRA also expects the credit union to be able to provide details of its chosen ratios, and evidence of the rationale underlying them, on request.
target_text: By way of example only, the PRA considers that prudent practice suggests that the indicative ratio percentages for credit unions that undertake additional activities or have more than 15,000 members for all calculations save loans to assets are those outlined in Table 1 .

question: When composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, how should a firm reconcile the general prohibition on splitting contract obligations with the ability to include a component of a with-profits annuity contract in an MA portfolio, and what evidence and policy statements does the PRA expect in that case?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the default position as not dividing the insurance or reinsurance obligations of a contract into separate parts when building the relevant portfolio, and only depart from that approach where the part being separated qualifies as an eligible element. [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379] In the specific case of a with-profits annuity contract, a component may be included in an MA portfolio only if it is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the insurance contract, can be organised and managed separately in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise satisfies the MA eligibility conditions—i.e., the firm should frame any “splitting” as the isolation of an eligible element rather than a general partitioning of obligations. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7] To support that treatment, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the liabilities included in the MA portfolio are limited to contractually guaranteed elements and do not rely on future premiums or future investment performance. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7] The PRA also expects the firm to articulate a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses will be added within the MA portfolio or handled elsewhere, so that any future changes do not undermine the basis on which the eligible element was identified. [#SRC:0bace533be32cdc7]
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: Where a merger’s terms provide for (i) compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income and (ii) bonus payments requiring members’ approval as part of the Merger Resolutions, how should the society structure member approvals, including when bonus approval must appear in the Merger Resolutions of only certain societies versus all participating societies?
gold_answer: Member approvals should be structured so that compensation for loss of office/income is approved through a distinct special resolution, while bonus payments are approved through the Merger Resolutions in the manner dictated by the prescribed-limit test. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] Specifically, if the merger terms include compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income, those proposed payments must be put to members under a separate special resolution (i.e., not merely embedded within the general merger approval). [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] In parallel, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] The placement of that bonus approval across the participating societies depends on whether the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), calculated without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the bonus approval need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, the bonus approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This approach ensures the distinct approval route for loss-of-office compensation is maintained while bonus approvals are correctly allocated across Merger Resolutions based on the prescribed-limit threshold. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]
source_text: If the terms of a merger include provision for the payment of compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or of income, then the proposed payments must be approved by a separate special resolution. A further special resolution may also be required if there is to be a distribution to members which exceeds the limits described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society.
