question: When submitting an application to the PRA for confirmation of an amalgamation or a transfer of engagements, what must be included with the application regarding the scrutineers report, and what additional commentary does the PRA indicate would be helpful in that report where invalid votes are significant?
gold_answer: For either an amalgamation (submitted as a joint application) or a transfer of engagements (submitted as separate applications), the application package must include the scrutineers report and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] In addition to enclosing the report as part of the application, the PRA indicates it would be helpful for the scrutineers report to go beyond the core reporting and also address process quality where relevant—specifically, it should note any procedural difficulties encountered and provide an analysis explaining why votes were treated as invalid when the number of invalid votes appears significant. [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586] This means the applicant(s) should treat the scrutineers report as both a required enclosure for the confirmation application and, where invalid votes are notably high, a vehicle for explaining the mechanics and causes of invalidity so the PRA can better understand the voting outcome in context. [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e] [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]
source_text: The parties in an amalgamation should make a joint application for confirmation to the PRA, while the parties to a transfer of engagements should make separate applications for confirmation of the transfer. These applications should specify the date on which the merger is intended to take effect and should be accompanied by two authenticated copies of the Instrument of Transfer, or the amalgamation agreement, and of the Merger Document or separate Schedule 16 Statement. In addition, in the case of an amalgamation, three signed copies of the Memorandum and Rules of the successor 34 to the amalgamating societies should be sent to the PRA and the FCA. The scrutineers report described in paragraphs 3.146 to 3.148 , and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved, must be enclosed with each application.
target_text: The PRA would find it helpful if the scrutineers report would also comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant (see also paragraph 3.171 ).

question: In a transfer to a specially formed successor company, how must the terms of the transfer address the society’s holding of shares by the time the society dissolves, and how does that requirement interact with the society’s ability to notify a later dissolution date in its vesting-date notice (including any limits on business activity after the vesting date)?
gold_answer: The transfer documentation must be drafted so that it ensures the society will no longer hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] In parallel, once the PRA has confirmed the transfer it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must itself notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date no later than seven days before that date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] Unless the society gives a notice that specifies a later dissolution date, the society is dissolved on the vesting date; however, if it is necessary to facilitate disposal of the society’s shares in its successor, the society may include in the vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution then occurs on that later date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] The share-disposal linkage is that the transfer terms must still secure that the society ceases to hold any shares by the (possibly later) dissolution date identified through this notice mechanism. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] If the society uses the later-dissolution option, it must stop transacting business from the notified vesting date, except business needed to dispose of its shares in its successor. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]
source_text: The terms of the transfer must include provision to secure that the society ceases to hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve (Section 100(11) of the 1986 Act). The provisions of the 1986 Act concerning the dissolution of the society and the disposal of any shares in its successor are discussed in section ‘ Notification and Dissolution ’.
target_text: When the PRA has confirmed a transfer (whether voluntary or under direction) it will notify the FCA and the society concerned. Section 97(8) of the 1986 Act requires the society to notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date, and it must do so no later than seven days before that date, and, unless a notice is given under subsection (10), subsection (9) provides that the society shall be dissolved on that date. Subsection (10) provides that, if necessary for the purpose of facilitating the disposal of its shares in its successor, the society may include, in the notice of the vesting date, notice of a later date for the dissolution of the society, and it is on this later date that the society is dissolved. A society which gives such a notice must cease to transact any business as from the notified vesting date, except such as may be necessary to dispose of its shares in its successor.

question: For a firm that is a parent entity of an international group, what does the PRA expect the firm to show in its group recovery plan regarding (i) coverage of entities in other jurisdictions and (ii) the way dependencies and mutual exclusivity between recovery options are identified and explained?
gold_answer: A firm that is a parent entity of an international group should produce a group recovery plan that both (1) evidences coverage of group entities located in other jurisdictions and (2) provides a clear, structured explanation of how recovery options depend on one another, including where options cannot be used together. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] In practice, the plan should demonstrate how different entities in other jurisdictions are addressed within the group recovery plan, rather than leaving their treatment implicit. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] Alongside that jurisdictional coverage, the PRA expects the firm to detail and explain dependencies between recovery options and to clearly flag any recovery options that are mutually exclusive. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] The dependency analysis should be framed to help the firm understand dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, so that the interaction of recovery actions is transparent in a cross-border group context. [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41] The firm should therefore link its explanation of recovery-option dependencies and mutual exclusivity to the way it has covered different entities across jurisdictions, so the plan shows how those inter-entity dependencies affect which recovery options can be executed and in what combinations. [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: When a firm maintains the required record of each key function holder’s statement of responsibilities, who must sign that record, and does the signing requirement also apply to later updates to the record?
gold_answer: A firm must maintain a current record covering the statement of responsibilities for each key function holder, and that record is not complete for compliance purposes unless it is properly executed. [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] Specifically, the record referred to in 5.4 must be signed by two parties: the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] This signing requirement is not limited to the initial version of the record; it also extends to every updated version, meaning that whenever the firm updates the record to keep it up to date, the updated version must again bear both signatures. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] In practical terms, the firm should treat “keeping an up-to-date record” as an ongoing obligation that triggers re-execution whenever the record is revised, so that the current version on file is signed by the key function holder and an appropriate firm representative. [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] This linkage ensures the firm’s up-to-date recordkeeping duty is met with a signed current record and signed updates, rather than an unsigned or partially signed document. [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: When a society establishes or reviews its corporate governance arrangements, how should it decide whether to have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code, and what specific scope limitation applies to the Combined Code referenced in the materials?
gold_answer: A society that is not publicly quoted is expected, when setting up and when reassessing its corporate governance arrangements, to take into account an appropriate governance code, choosing between the UK Corporate Governance Code and the Combined Code depending on which is suitable in the circumstances. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] Where the society looks to the Combined Code, the relevant Combined Code is the version on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council and is expressly tied to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] In practical terms, this means the society’s “have regard to” exercise for the Combined Code is anchored to that identified Combined Code and its stated accounting-period applicability, rather than an unspecified or open-ended version. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] The trigger for considering these codes is the society’s act of establishing and reviewing its corporate governance arrangements, and the society’s non-publicly-quoted status does not remove the expectation to consider the codes; it frames the context in which the society should select the appropriate one. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: For the agreement required by section 97(4)(b) of the 1986 Act between a society and its successor company, what termination and decision-making provisions are expected if flotation does not occur as planned, and what additional material does the PRA expect to review in that context?
gold_answer: The agreement required by section 97(4)(b) of the 1986 Act—i.e., the agreement between a society and its successor company on the terms of the transfer—should be drafted to manage the risk that flotation does not occur as anticipated. [#TGT:cf8d8f23b7b8b22d] In particular, the Transfer Agreement 52 is expected to contain an express mechanism allowing termination if, for any reason, flotation does not take place within a specified period after confirmation. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7] Alongside that termination right, the agreement should also provide for the board to decide not to proceed where market conditions or other developments make it unreasonable to continue, taking into account the basis on which the board obtained approval of the members. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7] These provisions together align the transfer terms agreed between the society and its successor company with the practical possibility of delay or changed circumstances affecting flotation. [#TGT:cf8d8f23b7b8b22d] In addition to the contractual provisions themselves, the PRA expects to see the society’s contingency plans, indicating that the society should be prepared to present planning materials that address how it would respond if flotation is delayed or does not occur within the specified post-confirmation period. [#SRC:f867fbae8f1ee6d7]
source_text: The Transfer Agreement 52 should include provision for its termination if, for any reason, flotation does not take place within a specified period after confirmation, and for the board to decide not to proceed if market conditions or other developments mean that it would not be reasonable to do so having regard to the basis on which it secured the approval of the members. The PRA expects to see the society’s contingency plans.
target_text: 52. The agreement required by section 97(4)(b) of the 1986 Act between a society and its successor company on the terms of the transfer.

question: If an institution wants to use the Section 4 method to work out the exposure value of its derivative positions, what size measure must it use for its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business, and how often (and using what date’s data) must it check that size against the thresholds?
gold_answer: To use the Section 4 method for calculating the exposure value of derivative positions, the institution must check whether the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business stays within the required limits, because the permission to use Section 4 depends on that size being no more than both thresholds set for the test. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2] The size figure used for this test is not left open-ended for institutions using the methods in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three: it must be the size calculated in line with Article 273a(1) or Article 273a(2), whichever applies to the institution. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] The institution must perform the threshold assessment monthly, and it must use data as of the last day of each month when doing so. [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2] Put together, this means the month-end, monthly eligibility check for Section 4 must be based on the Article 273a calculation of derivative-business size that is tied to institutions using Sections 4 to 5 methods. [#SRC:afa72c2dcedc6ca1] The institution must also recognize that the ability to use Section 4 is stated to be subject to a restriction referenced in Article 273b(2). [#TGT:a1884bd4d42120b2]
source_text: (m) for institutions using the methods set out in Sections 4 to 5 of Chapter 6 of Title II Part Three, the size of their on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business as calculated in accordance with Article 273a(1) or (2) , as applicable.
target_text: Subject to the restriction set out in Article 273b(2) , an institution may calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions in accordance with the method set out in Section 4 , provided that the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is equal to or less than both of the following thresholds on the basis of an assessment carried out on a monthly basis using the data as of the last day of the month :

question: If someone turns 18 after the notice is sent but before the meeting, or becomes a shareholding or borrowing member after the notice is sent but before the proxy deadline, do they need to get the meeting notice—and if the society misses sending a notice, when does that mistake not affect the meeting and when might it still be treated as the society’s fault?
gold_answer: Yes—your notice process should cover certain people who become eligible or become members after the notice date, and a missed notice will not always undermine the meeting, but it depends on whether the miss is truly accidental versus a society-driven error. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] You must also give notice to any person who will attain age 18 after the notice date but on or before the meeting date, and to every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member after the notice date but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, provided that in either case they would be eligible to vote if they remained a member until then. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] The Schedule 16 Statement must be included in or sent with the notices. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] On the effect of mistakes, an accidental omission to give notice does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting, and the scrutineers report may properly take account of the rule that accidental omission or non-receipt of notice does not invalidate the meeting. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] But “accidental/non-receipt” does not cover all society errors—for example, an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups, or systemic failures like leaving new members off the mailing list or excluding a class due to a computer-program fault. [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d]
source_text: In addition, notice must also be given to any person who will attain the age of 18 years after the date of the notice but on or before the date of the meeting, and to every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member of the society after the date of the notice but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, and who would, in either case, be eligible to vote at the meeting if he remained a member until then. (In practice, this may mean sending out a notice to every such person, even if they will, in fact, not be entitled to vote). The Schedule 16 Statement must be sent in or with the notices (paragraph 1(2) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, accidental omission does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new members, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management see also paragraph 3.147 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting shall not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that accidental and non-receipt would not cover all cases of error on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: When a firm’s board of directors establishes and documents a framework for the management of model risk and senior management executes and maintains it by designating roles and responsibilities to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions, how should the firm treat the assignment of those responsibilities to senior management functions in light of the PRA Rulebook’s ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ references?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the assignment of model risk management responsibilities to senior management functions as an exercise that must be aligned with the firm’s documented model risk management framework and informed by the relevant prescribed responsibilities referenced in the PRA Rulebook’s ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ sections. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33] [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3] The board of directors is expected to establish the model risk management framework and ensure it is adequately documented, while senior management is responsible for executing and maintaining that framework, including designating roles and responsibilities to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33] When those responsibilities are being allocated specifically to senior management functions, the firm should consider the relevant prescribed responsibilities in ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ 4.1 or 5.2 in the PRA Rulebook as part of that assignment process. [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3] In parallel, the board of directors and senior management are expected to challenge model outputs and understand model capabilities, limitations, and the potential impact of model uncertainty for the most material models and aggregate outputs, which should be reflected in how responsibilities are defined and owned within the framework. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33]
source_text: P2.1 Board of directors and senior management responsibility: 5 The board of directors should establish a framework for the management of model risk and this should be adequately documented. Senior management is responsible for the execution and maintenance of the framework and should designate the roles and responsibilities for the framework to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions. 6 The board of directors and senior management are expected to provide challenge to model outputs and understand model capabilities, the model limitations, and the potential impact of model uncertainty for the most material models and the aggregate outputs.
target_text: 5. When assigning the responsibilities of the management of model risk to senior management functions, firms should consider the relevant prescribed responsibilities in ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ 4.1 or 5.2 in the PRA Rulebook.

question: If a firm trades cash equities or cash bonds (which can create settlement risk even though they don’t attract counterparty credit risk), what happens if the firm doesn’t manage settlement risk well for products outside its advanced CCR model and still uses zero capital for that risk?
gold_answer: If the firm is dealing in products like cash equities or cash bonds—examples of products that can create settlement risk without attracting counterparty credit risk—the firm still needs to manage the settlement risk effectively. [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9] When that settlement risk comes from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model, and the firm’s settlement-risk management is not adequate, the PRA may question whether it is appropriate for the firm to apply a zero capital requirement to that settlement risk. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] Adequate management is illustrated by controls such as pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, and appropriate reporting; weaknesses in these kinds of measures are the type of situation in which the PRA may intervene. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] If the PRA does challenge the zero capital approach, it can require the firm to hold additional capital under Pillar 2 to address the settlement risk. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] In other words, the fact that these products’ settlement risk does not attract counterparty credit risk does not, by itself, prevent a Pillar 2 capital add-on if settlement-risk controls are not strong for exposures outside the advanced CCR model. [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9]
source_text: Where firms do not adequately manage settlement risk arising from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model 13 (eg through pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, appropriate reporting), the PRA may challenge the appropriateness of a zero capital requirement for such risk and require firms to hold additional capital under Pillar 2.
target_text: 13. This would include products (eg cash equities and cash bonds) that can result in settlement risk that does not attract counterparty credit risk.

question: When authorities request Part A information in Phase 1, how should a firm explain the purpose of that request in terms of both (i) what Part A covers and (ii) how the requested information is used for resolution planning, including the specific resolution tool and compliance monitoring context?
gold_answer: A firm should describe Part A of Phase 1 as an information request focused on foundational firm characteristics, and it should connect that scope to how authorities use the information for resolution planning and related monitoring. Part A in Phase 1 is framed as seeking information on group structure, significant legal entities, and the firm’s business model, and the stated purpose is to help authorities determine the most suitable resolution strategy for the individual firm. [#SRC:e33015cabfcd50f4] In addition, the firm should explain that the broader set of information requests is used to support development of a resolution plan specifically premised on using the bail-in tool, and that the same information is also requested to monitor the firm’s compliance with MREL and its capacity to meet those requirements going forward. [#TGT:eec6fcc945ab4321] Taken together, the firm’s explanation should link the Part A content (structure, key entities, and business model) to the authorities’ resolution-planning objective, while also situating the request within the bail-in-based resolution plan development and the ongoing MREL compliance and forward-looking capability monitoring described for the information requests. [#SRC:e33015cabfcd50f4] [#TGT:eec6fcc945ab4321]
source_text: Chapter 2 sets out the two parts of Phase 1 , A and B , and the associated information requests in more detail. Part A of Phase 1 requests information relating to group structure, significant legal entities and the firm’s business model. This will enable the authorities to identify the most appropriate resolution strategy for the individual firm.
target_text: The information outlined below will be requested from firms to facilitate the development of a resolution plan based on the use of the bail-in tool and to monitor firms’ compliance with MREL and their ability to meet requirements in the future.

question: If a TWD firm is planning its wind-down from the assumed reference date of the TWD option, what things does it need to be able to forecast, and what extra detail is required when it forecasts the capital impact (including trading book deductions and RWAs)?
gold_answer: From the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, a TWD firm needs to be able to forecast a defined set of items, and it must also build a more detailed capital-focused forecast that connects those items to capital outcomes. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] The baseline set of projections must include exit costs, operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs across the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] When forecasting capital resources impacts in the TWD scenario, the firm must incorporate how the expected exit costs, operational costs and the RBLs affect capital resources through the wind-down period. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] The capital forecast must also include a forward view of how the TWD scenario affects trading book-related capital deductions. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] Finally, the firm must project how implementing the actions, arrangements and measures that are part of the TWD option will change capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market risk, counterparty credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f] This ties the firm’s cost and RBL projections from the reference date to the required capital resources and capital requirement projections over the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] [#TGT:e9a9057a2014274f]
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 26. This should include projections of capital resources impacts through the wind-down period in the TWD scenario, incorporating the impact of expected exit, operational costs and RBLs defined above on capital resources, as well as a forecast of the impact of the TWD scenario on trading book-related capital deductions and projections of the impact of the implementation of the actions, arrangements and measures set out as part of the TWD option on capital requirements in the TWD scenario, including projections of RWAs for market, counterparty credit and operational risks.

question: If a firm does long-term insurance business, can it count its unpaid initial fund or implicit items tied to future profits and zillmerising when making sure its margin of solvency stays above the guarantee fund?
gold_answer: No. The firm must keep its margin of solvency from dropping below the guarantee fund, but for long-term insurance business it cannot use certain items to support that compliance position. [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9] In particular, the unpaid initial fund of a firm must not be taken into account, and implicit items that relate to future profits and zillmerising must also not be taken into account, when complying with the requirement identified as 4.2. [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1] Linking these points, when the firm is checking and maintaining its margin of solvency against the guarantee fund level, it should treat those excluded items as unavailable for the compliance calculation under 4.2, even though the guarantee fund threshold still has to be met. [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1] [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9] As a result, the firm needs to ensure the margin of solvency remains above the guarantee fund using other allowable elements, because the excluded items cannot be counted for that purpose in the long-term insurance business case. [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9] [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1]
source_text: In the case of long-term insurance business , the unpaid initial fund of a firm and implicit items which relate to future profits and zillmerising may not be taken into account in complying with 4.2 .
target_text: A firm must ensure that its margin of solvency does not fall below the guarantee fund .

question: When a firm is preparing its recovery plan to contemplate a range of severe macroeconomic and financial stress scenarios relevant to its specific conditions, how should it use TWD sensitivity analysis to support senior management understanding of capital and liquidity impacts, and what minimum scenario-coverage expectation must be met for G-SIIs and O-SIIs?
gold_answer: A firm should integrate TWD sensitivity analysis into its recovery planning so that, alongside contemplating a range of severe macroeconomic and financial stress scenarios relevant to the firm (including system-wide events and stress specific to individual legal persons and to groups), it can quantify how alternative key assumptions would change outcomes and communicate the plausible range of impacts to senior management. [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2] Specifically, TWD firms should be able to run sensitivity analysis that measures the impact of changing key assumptions away from those used in the TWD scenario, and use those results to set upper and lower bounds for those assumptions so senior management can understand the range of plausible effects on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after executing the TWD option. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] This capability should also be able to analyse, at a minimum, the baseline set of factors that are included in the TWD scenario (while allowing analysis of other factors as well). [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] In addition, where the firm is a global systemically important institution (G-SII) or an O-SII, SS9/17 expects the recovery plan to include analysis of at least four scenarios (described as scenarios of severe macroeconomic and financial stress relevant to the firm’s specific conditions). [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2]
source_text: TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario. TWD firms should be able to use their sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out the upper and lower bounds for TWD firms’ key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on TWD firms’ capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option. This sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors (see paragraphs 3.6 - 3.15 for more detail).
target_text: Under existing recovery planning requirements, a recovery plan must contemplate a range of scenarios of severe macroeconomic and financial stress relevant to the firm’s specific conditions including system-wide events and stress specific to individual legal persons and to groups.
