question: When a firm does not meet its combined buffer and therefore becomes subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA), how should it determine the applicable percentage factor for the MDA calculation by reference to the combined buffer quartiles, and how does that interact with the rule that the combined buffer is intended for times of stress rather than normal business planning?
gold_answer: A firm that does not meet its combined buffer must expect restrictions on distributions and must apply an MDA framework rather than treating the combined buffer as routinely usable capital in its ordinary planning. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] The MDA is calculated by multiplying a quartile-dependent percentage (60%, 40%, 20%, or 0%) by the sum of the firm’s last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in the referenced capital buffers provision), net of specified deductions. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] To select the correct percentage factor, the firm must identify which quartile of its combined buffer it is in and then apply the corresponding distribution cap: if it is in the first quartile (meeting between 75% and 100% of the combined buffer), it may distribute 60% of such profits; in the second quartile it may distribute 40%; in the third quartile 20%; and in the fourth quartile 0%. [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d] This quartile mapping operationalizes the restriction that applies when the combined buffer is not met, reinforcing that the combined buffer is meant to be drawn on in stress and not entered into as part of the firm’s base business plan. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]
source_text: Firms may use their combined buffer as required in times of stress, but should not use it in the normal course of business or propose to enter it as part of their base business plan. As set out in the PRA’s capital buffers rules, firms that do not meet their combined buffer shall face restrictions on their distributions, and be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA). The MDA must be calculated as the product of 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% (depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in) 3 and the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in Capital Buffers 4.3(5)), net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from:
target_text: 3. Where firms are in the first quartile of their combined buffer (when they meet between 75% and 100% of it), 60% of such profits can be distributed. In the second quartile, 40% can be distributed; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%.

question: If a firm is told by its supervisor that it qualifies for Simplified Obligations, does it still need to use the EBA recovery-plan scenario guidelines, and what minimum set of scenarios should it include?
gold_answer: Yes. Being notified by its supervisor that it meets the eligibility criteria means the firm is in scope of the PRA’s Simplified Obligations, under which reduced recovery planning obligations apply for scenarios and the information template. [#SRC:1714a0d1f587bfcb] However, the PRA still expects firms to follow the EBA ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’ together with the expectations in the SS, so eligibility for Simplified Obligations does not eliminate the need to align scenario selection with those guidelines. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] At a minimum, an eligible firm should include at least two scenarios drawn from the EBA guidelines that are severe enough to test the recovery plan and that best match the firm’s business model. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] In addition, consistent with the EBA guidelines and the PRA’s stated expectation for all firms (including those eligible for Simplified Obligations), the firm should include a scenario that combines system-wide and idiosyncratic events. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9] The combined-event scenario is specifically expected because it is described as the most challenging type, requiring the firm to consider trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing its recovery strategy. [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]
source_text: The PRA applies Simplified Obligations for recovery planning (Simplified Obligations) to firms that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria. For these firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template (paragraphs 2.54 – 2.55 and 2.70 ). Additional information in relation to the approach that smaller and less complex firms should take in respect of certain aspects of recovery planning is included where relevant in this SS.
target_text: The EBA has published ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’. The PRA expects firms to follow these guidelines alongside the expectations set out in this SS. Firms that are eligible for Simplified Obligations should include at least two of the scenarios set out in the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model. In accordance with the EBA guidelines, firms should include a scenario with a combination of system-wide and idiosyncratic events. The PRA therefore expects firms, including those eligible for Simplified Obligations, to include a combined system-wide and idiosyncratic event, as these scenarios are the most challenging, as firms need to consider potential trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing a recovery strategy.

question: Where 2.1(3) applies to a group, how must a relevant insurance group undertaking treat a parent undertaking that is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar (or a third country insurance or reinsurance undertaking) when calculating group solvency for the purpose of 20.1, and how does that treatment align with the fact that modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply at the level of that parent undertaking (unless an exception applies)?
gold_answer: In a group to which 2.1(3) applies, a relevant insurance group undertaking must, solely for the purpose of calculating group solvency for 20.1, treat the parent undertaking as if it were a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies, even where that parent is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or is a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] This calculation-only re-characterisation sits alongside the separate rule that, when 2.1(3) applies, modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply (with necessary changes) at the level of that same type of parent undertaking, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8] Practically, this means the group solvency computation for 20.1 is performed on the basis that the parent is treated as within the UK Solvency II firm perimeter for that computation, while the broader set of specified modules and external audit provisions are also applied at the parent level (subject to the stated “unless” carve-out). [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]
source_text: When calculating the solvency of a group falling within 2.1(3) for the purpose of 20.1 , a relevant insurance group undertaking must treat the parent undertaking (being an insurance holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar or a third country insurance undertaking or a third country reinsurance undertaking ), solely for the purposes of that calculation, as a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies.
target_text: When 2.1(3) applies, 4 to 14 , 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking unless:

question: If a firm wants to know whether it needs to follow the expectations in this SS, what firm categories does the PRA limit them to, and where is it explained that those categories are treated as “significant” in the PRA’s supervision model?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the expectations in this SS as applying only if it is a significant firm, meaning a Category 1 or Category 2 PRA-regulated firm. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] The PRA limits the SS expectations this way because it considers the cost of trying to meet them would be disproportionate for smaller insurers (many of which operate in one locality or a niche market), while larger firms with complex risk profiles are expected to seek to meet or exceed the PRA’s expectations when complying with regulatory requirements. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] To confirm what “significant” means in this context, the March 2016 document titled ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ explains that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model. [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3] Using both texts together, the SS tells you the expectations are scoped to Category 1 and 2 only, and the March 2016 supervisory approach provides the basis for treating those categories as significant for that scoping decision. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]
source_text: The PRA takes the view that for smaller insurers (the majority of which operate in one locality or niche market) to seek to meet the expectations set out in this SS would have a disproportionate cost impact on these firms. Conversely, larger firms with complex risk profiles should seek to meet (or exceed) the PRA’s expectations as set out in this SS in complying with the regulatory requirements. The PRA therefore considers it appropriate to limit the application of the expectations as set out in this SS to significant firms only (Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms). 9
target_text: 9. The ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ March 2016 explains that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model; https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/prudential-regulation/approach/insurance-approach-2016.pdf

question: If societies are merging by amalgamation and are getting ready to submit the formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, what should they have already cleared with the FCA and PRA, and what exactly must they send (and how many copies) when they apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act?
gold_answer: Before making the formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the societies should expect that PRA staff will already have reviewed and commented on drafts of the Statement, taking into account drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and the prudential information referenced as preliminary matters. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] For an amalgamation specifically, they should also have cleared the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society with both the FCA and the PRA, aligning the draft work on the Statement with the governance documents for the successor society. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] The FCA’s role is that it must be satisfied about the proposed Rules, the proposed Memorandum, and the name of the successor society, so the amalgamating societies are advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA early. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] Then, when applying to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, the societies must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to the PRA and also to the FCA. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] This ties the early clearance step to the later requirement for signed, multi-copy submissions to both regulators. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724]
source_text: In the case of an amalgamation, the FCA is required to be satisfied as regards the proposed Rules, Memorandum and name of the successor society. The amalgamating societies are, therefore, advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage (see paragraph 3.96 ). When they apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, the amalgamating societies must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to the PRA and the FCA (Section 93(2)(d)). If the FCA is satisfied on these matters it will, upon confirmation by the PRA , register the successor society and issue to it a certificate of incorporation specifying the date (the specified date) from which the incorporation takes effect, and will return to it one copy each of the Rules and Memorandum together with a certificate of registration. Copies are placed on the public file of the successor society.
target_text: A society’s formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement is likely to be the culmination of many weeks of discussion with the PRA’s staff who will have reviewed and commented upon a draft or successive drafts of the Statement, having had regard also to drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and the prudential information described in ‘Preliminary matters’ . Societies should also have cleared any proposed Rule changes or, in the case of an amalgamation, the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society, with the FCA and the PRA.

question: Where a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, what must the firm ensure about the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3), given that the firm remains fully responsible for discharging its obligations under the PRA rules and FSMA-derived requirements applicable to UK Solvency II firms?
gold_answer: When a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it must treat outsourcing as not transferring accountability and must align its outsourcing documentation accordingly. The firm remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms, even after outsourcing. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] In that context, the firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] Practically, this means the written agreement’s terms cannot be drafted in a way that conflicts with, dilutes, or reallocates the firm’s own obligations under those referenced provisions, because the firm must still discharge its obligations notwithstanding the outsourcing arrangement. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a][#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Accordingly, the compliance check is twofold: confirm the firm’s continuing responsibility for obligations despite outsourcing, and confirm the 7.5(3) written agreement’s terms and conditions are consistent with the obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245][#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: If a firm thinks it might use the Bank of England’s lending facilities (like the Discount Window Facility), what should it do when it checks whether it has enough capital, funding, and liquidity for a solvent exit, including how it values assets and runs sensitivity analysis?
gold_answer: If the firm anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility), it should factor that expectation into its overall view of whether it has adequate resources for a solvent exit. [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890] The firm’s check must still be a full assessment of financial resources—capital, funding, and liquidity—sized to absorb the complete costs of exiting solvently and to meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable). [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] That assessment needs to be grounded in realistic exit valuations of the firm’s assets and liabilities, not optimistic assumptions. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] It also needs appropriate analysis, including sensitivity analyses of factors that could affect how much resource is required, and analysis of any balance sheet items that may be hard to transfer or sell once the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] Bringing these together, the firm should evaluate whether its capital, funding, and liquidity position—taking into account any anticipated facility usage—remains sufficient under the realistic valuations and sensitivity scenarios it has run to cover exit costs and liabilities. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890]
source_text: financial resources, including capital, funding, and liquidity, 55 to absorb the full costs of the solvent exit and meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), with realistic exit valuations of assets and liabilities and appropriate analysis conducted (such as sensitivity analyses of factors that may impact the resources needed, and an analysis of any balance sheet items which may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of)
target_text: 55. This includes whether the firm anticipates the use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg Discount Window Facility). See the ‘Bank of England Market Operations Guide’ for further details.

question: If the data needed for 4.13(4) isn’t available or isn’t reliable, can a firm make up data when setting the stressed FS floor, and what limits apply so the floor still meets the PRA’s minimum expectations?
gold_answer: Yes, a firm can use constructed data when some of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is missing or unreliable, but it must do so within specific limits and still meet the PRA’s expectations for the stressed FS floor. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] The constructed data must be built on prudent assumptions and must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years, so the firm cannot construct inputs without grounding them in that historical, reliable dataset. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] At the same time, the PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (a minimum FS level at the appropriate point in the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of modelling stressed FS, and at a minimum to reapply the floor methodology and calibration described in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] If the firm changes the floor (including because it used constructed data), the firm should be able to justify those changes. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] The firm also should not allow the change to reduce the calibration below what would have been produced by reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs, so the constructed-data approach must not be used to push the floor lower than that baseline. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (ie a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point of the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of their modelling of the stressed FS. As a minimum, the PRA expects firms to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 . If any changes are made to the floor, the PRA expects these changes to be justified. They should not result in a calibration below that which would have been obtained by re-applying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs.
target_text: Where part of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is not available or where the available data is not reliable, constructed data based on prudent assumptions may be used; and the constructed data must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years.

question: If a credit union invests its surplus funds, what risks does it need to think about and write down, and for how many years after the investment date does it have to keep the written record of the 6.5 assessment?
gold_answer: When a credit union invests surplus funds, it needs to both evaluate specific categories of risk and keep written evidence of that evaluation for a set period. The credit union is required to consider and document its investment decisions and to account for counterparty risk, concentration risk, liquidity risk, and interest rate risk when making those decisions under Rules 6.5 and 6.6 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b0d16647ea0d1e00] The PRA further expects the credit union to think carefully about the risk-versus-return trade-off and to make sure the investment choice matches the credit union’s risk appetite; one way it may do this is by setting exposure limits for different counterparties based on their risk profile as part of its risk appetite statement. [#SRC:b0d16647ea0d1e00] In addition to creating that documentation, the credit union must keep a written record of the assessment in 6.5 for five years after the investment date, so the retention clock runs from the date the investment is made. [#TGT:9a674e73f8cecd3e]
source_text: Credit unions investing their surplus funds are required to consider and document their decisions and account for counterparty, concentration, liquidity, and interest rate risk under Rules 6.5 and 6.6 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. When making investment decisions, the PRA expects credit unions to carefully consider the risk return trade-off and to ensure investment decisions reflect the credit union’s risk appetite. Credit unions should consider setting exposure limits for different counterparties based on their risk profile, as part of their risk appetite statement.
target_text: A credit union must retain, for a period of five years following the date of the investment, a written record of the assessment in 6.5 .

question: Where an institution has trading book and non-trading book positions measured at fair value and applies prudent valuation standards under the PRA Rulebook, what specific breakdown must it provide for exposures adjusted under Article 34 and Article 105, and how must that breakdown be organised between the trading book and non-trading book?
gold_answer: An institution must produce a prudent valuation adjustment breakdown for exposures in both the trading book and the non-trading book when those exposures are adjusted under Article 34 and Article 105, and it must structure that disclosure so it is clearly separated by book. [#SRC:2523899445035439] This requirement sits within the broader obligation that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value are subject to the prudent valuation standards in the relevant Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook, so the breakdown is part of demonstrating compliance with those standards for fair-valued positions. [#TGT:fab620639def0122] Concretely, the institution must (i) break down the amounts of the constituent elements that make up its prudent valuation adjustment by type of risks, and (ii) provide the total of those constituent elements separately for trading book positions and for non-trading book positions. [#SRC:2523899445035439] In doing so, the institution should ensure the prudent valuation for trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty, reflecting the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value and the demands of prudential soundness, which frames why a risk-type breakdown and book-by-book totals are expected. [#TGT:fab620639def0122]
source_text: (e) for exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book that are adjusted in accordance with Article 34 and Article 105 , a breakdown of the amounts of the constituent elements of an institution's prudent valuation adjustment, by type of risks, and the total of constituent elements separately for the trading book and non-trading book positions;
target_text: Institutions shall ensure that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value.

question: For a firm that has achieved SRT for a particular transaction, how should its ongoing monitoring and stress testing address (i) the risk of a downgrade of the protection provider affecting unfunded credit protection and (ii) the possibility of securitised assets returning onto the balance sheet, and how must these considerations feed into capital planning and Pillar 2 processes?
gold_answer: A firm that has achieved SRT is expected to keep monitoring the transaction-related risks it may still face and to run regular stress testing of its securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures, with outputs feeding into capital planning and Pillar 2 consideration. [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] Within that monitoring and stress-testing, originators are expected to evaluate the risk that the protection provider is downgraded and what that would mean for both the effectiveness of the unfunded credit protection and the provider’s continued eligibility to provide it, and to incorporate those implications into capital planning. [#SRC:e7a6b6de3819019b] In parallel, the firm is expected to consider capital planning impacts if securitised assets return to its balance sheet, and to ensure stress tests assess the firm-wide impact of stressed market conditions on securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures, including knock-on implications for other risk sources (eg credit, concentration, counterparty, market, liquidity, and reputational risk). [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] The firm should also ensure its stress testing takes into account existing securitisations and pipeline transactions, and that it has procedures to assess and respond to stress-test results, with an expectation that those results are taken into account under Pillar 2. [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607] Together, these expectations mean the downgrade/eligibility analysis for unfunded credit protection should be embedded as a specific stress-testing and monitoring focus within the broader securitisation stress-testing framework and capital planning process. [#SRC:e7a6b6de3819019b] [#TGT:a1f555dbe3d2d607]
source_text: The PRA expects originators, as part of the monitoring and stress-testing mentioned in paragraph 2.11 of this SS, to assess the risk of a downgrade of the protection provider and the implications for the effectiveness of the unfunded credit protection and the eligibility of the provider to continue to provide the unfunded credit protection, and to reflect this in their capital planning.
target_text: Where a firm achieves SRT for a particular transaction, the PRA expects it to continue to monitor risks related to the transaction to which it may still be exposed. The PRA expects firms to consider the capital planning implications of securitised assets returning onto their balance sheets. The Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook requires firms to conduct regular stress testing of their securitisation activities and off balance sheet exposures. 5 The PRA expects those stress tests to consider the firm-wide impact of stressed market conditions on those activities and exposures and the implications for other sources of risk, for example, credit risk, concentration risk, counterparty risk, market risk, liquidity risk and reputational risk. The PRA expects a firm’s stress testing of securitisation activities to take into account existing securitisations and pipeline transactions. The PRA expects a firm to have in place procedures to assess and respond to the results of that stress testing and would expect them to be taken into account under Pillar 2.

question: When deriving the basic FS for senior notes using an internal credit assessment and an assigned CQS, how should a firm treat qualitative and quantitative retained risks, including interactions and combinations of risks, given that the FS assumes the eligible asset is held to maturity except for sales needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material cash-flow changes?
gold_answer: A firm should derive the basic FS by identifying and reflecting the retained risks on the assumption the eligible asset is held until maturity, while recognising the limited circumstance where sale may be necessary as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] In doing so, the firm’s internal credit assessment for the senior notes must consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also assess how those risks may interact or combine, because the PRA expects all risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations) to be captured through the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS, and therefore the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Retained risks explicitly include qualitative and quantitative risks, and qualitative risks can include matters such as the strength of terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, while quantitative risks can include economic or market stresses. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Where the firm adjusts the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, those adjustments should still be grounded in the same comprehensive internal credit assessment and assigned CQS that incorporate the full set of relevant risks and their interactions. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]
source_text: As mentioned in paragraphs 2.1 and 2.3 above, firms should consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk in their credit risk assessments. The PRA expects that all of the risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations of risks) will be considered in the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS and therefore the derivation of the basic FS (including any adjustments made to it in order to take account of differences in credit quality by rating notch).
target_text: The overarching aim of the FS is to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption that the asset is held until maturity (other than where it proves necessary to sell it, as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio, for the purpose of restoring the overall matching position where the asset and/or liability cash flows of the portfolio have materially changed). Retained risks include both qualitative and quantitative risks. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data. Quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses. Internal credit assessments must also consider how these risks may interact (as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(1) ). The examples of risks listed in this paragraph are not exhaustive.

question: When a firm plans an increase in remote trading that may relocate traders to an overseas office or entity managing risk into the UK, what governance and control outcomes must it ensure for remote bookings received in the UK, including how it should treat 100% remote booking arrangements and desks with a mix of local and remote traders?
gold_answer: A firm increasing remote trading in a way that could relocate traders overseas to manage UK risk should design its remote booking model so that UK oversight and desk design remain credible and controllable, with heightened challenge where the UK is fully remote-booked. [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf] In practice, the firm should (i) align the number and relative seniority of traders across locations with the proportion of activity managed in each location, so the operating model matches where risk is actually run; and (ii) avoid splitting a desk where the second location’s business is negligible, because that is not normally a sufficient rationale for fragmentation. [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf] For any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) that receives remote bookings, it must ensure substantive UK oversight of the remote books as a risk mitigant, with particular focus where there is no UK-based trader covering the book (i.e., “orphan books”). [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615] Where there are “shared” books or desks with both local and remote traders, the firm should clearly define them in the booking taxonomy, identify the portion of risk remote-booked into the UK, and apply remote booking controls to that identified portion. [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615] Existing arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK should receive greater scrutiny and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled, which should be demonstrated through the UK oversight and control framework described above. [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]
source_text: c) Whether the change may lead to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity with the role of remotely managing risk into the UK; where the firm plans an increase in remote trading, the allocation of the number and relative seniority of traders should normally be broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations. Where the size of business undertaken in the second location is negligible, this is unlikely to be sufficient justification to warrant the splitting of a desk. Any existing arrangements where there is 100% remote booking into the UK, irrespective of whether they result from a relocation or not, should be subjected to greater scrutiny, and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled (and see 4.25P ).
target_text: Any UK trading bank or international bank (whether a subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure that there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, and particularly in cases where there is no UK based trader covering the book (often called ‘orphan books’). ‘Shared’ books or desks, where there is a mix of local and remote traders, should be clearly defined in the booking taxonomy and the portion of the risk remote-booked into the UK is expected to be identified and subject to remote booking controls.

question: If there are lots of invalid votes in a merger vote, what extra details does the PRA want in the scrutineers report, and how does that help the PRA decide whether the Merger Resolutions votes really reflect members’ views (not just whether turnout was low)?
gold_answer: Where invalid votes appear significant, the PRA would find it helpful for the scrutineers report to do two extra things: describe any procedural difficulties encountered and explain why votes were treated as invalid. [#SRC:2c0f6dd7f7e57586] That added detail supports the PRA’s assessment of the criterion focused on whether the votes on the Merger Resolutions do not represent the views of the members, which is mainly concerned with the risk of a merger being approved by a small and unrepresentative vote. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] The PRA does not treat a very low turnout, by itself, as automatically meaning the criterion applies; instead it evaluates turnout in context and considers other factors that may have affected participation. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] In that context, the scrutineers report is one of the inputs the PRA considers on the conduct and counting of votes, including the number of and reasons for invalid proxy votes. [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97] By adding analysis of procedural problems and invalid-vote reasons, the report can help the PRA understand whether the voting process itself may have influenced the results and therefore whether the recorded votes are likely to reflect members’ views. [#SRC:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]
source_text: The PRA would find it helpful if the scrutineers report would also comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant (see also paragraph 3.171 ).
target_text: This criterion requires the PRA to consider whether the votes on the Merger Resolutions do not represent the views of the members. The main mischief to which it appears to be directed is a merger approved by a small and unrepresentative vote. However, a very low turnout, of itself, does not necessarily mean that the criterion applies. It has to be considered in the context of the other criteria, and of any other factors which may have affected the turnout: for example, whether all the members entitled to vote were fully and clearly informed of the terms of the merger proposal and its consequences; whether the members were afforded adequate facilities and opportunity to cast their votes; and the scrutineers report on the conduct and counting of votes, including the number of, and reasons for, invalid proxy votes.

question: When preparing a Merger Notification Statement for PRA approval before sending it to members within the specified time limit, what interim financial-position disclosure must the board make given that the financial information will end before approval, and how should the statement handle any director/officer compensation that requires PRA consent?
gold_answer: Before the Merger Notification Statement is sent to members, it must first be approved by the PRA and then issued within the applicable time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Because the financial information used for member-facing merger materials will necessarily cover a period that ends some time before the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, the board must explicitly state whether any material changes to the society’s financial position have occurred in the interim. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] If a material change has been identified but its impact cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so members understand it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] In addition, the Merger Notification Statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Finally, the board should treat the interim-change disclosure as important to the PRA’s later assessment, because non-disclosure of such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: When a TWD firm quantifies wind-down costs to set its capital and liquidity projections, how should it treat risk-based losses (RBLs) from market price movements during the wind-down period, and how will the PRA use Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A in reviewing the firm’s RBL estimate in that same TWD-scenario-focused modelling?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should model its wind-down cost quantification (used for capital and liquidity projections) primarily around the TWD scenario and the specific actions, arrangements, and measures it would implement under that scenario, rather than attempting to fully model a large number of scenarios given the uncertainty and proportionality concerns. [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649] Within that TWD-scenario-focused modelling, the firm should be able to reflect how market price movements over the wind-down period could affect the valuation of trading positions, i.e., the firm’s risk-based losses (RBLs). [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649] In the PRA’s review, the PRA will compare the firm’s RBL estimate against the sum of Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to gauge, in contextual terms, what proportion of capital executing the TWD option might absorb. [#TGT:31786ae603de3309] However, the firm should not treat Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A as the “right” or intended measure of RBLs, because the PRA explicitly does not view that sum as an appropriate RBL measure; it is used only as a reference metric to help interpret the firm’s RBL calculation as part of the PRA’s assessment. [#TGT:31786ae603de3309]
source_text: These projections may be subject to significant levels of uncertainty, and it would not be proportionate for TWD firms to build and maintain capabilities to fully model a large number of scenarios. TWD firms should focus the modelling of their quantification of wind-down costs, used to determine their capital and liquidity projections, on the TWD scenario, and the actions, arrangements, and measures that the TWD firm would implement under that scenario. TWD firms should be able to account for the potential impact of market price movements throughout the wind-down period on the valuations of trading positions, known as risk-based losses (RBLs, see paragraphs 4.26 and 4.38 - 4.40 ).
target_text: The PRA will compare TWD firms’ estimates of RBLs with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A in order to assess the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb. It should be understood that the PRA does not regard the sum of Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A capital as an appropriate measure of RBLs, but rather as a metric for the purpose of providing context to understand the results of a firm’s RBL calculation as part of the PRA’s assessment.

question: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets that is expected to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing to ensure sufficient liquid funds, what features must the stress testing include in terms of (i) how the credit union may meet the expectation through its own analysis and RAS, (ii) the types of scenarios and outflows to be assessed (including any retail-book elements), and (iii) the PRA’s anticipated engagement on methods and assumptions?
gold_answer: A credit union with more than £50 million in total assets is expected to perform periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually to support holding sufficient liquid funds, and that testing should be structured so it meaningfully evaluates stressed outflows. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The expectation can be met through the credit union’s own analysis, provided it is anchored in a clearly articulated RAS that specifies the duration and type of stress (or stresses) the credit union intends to withstand. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] The stress tests are expected to cover a range of severe but plausible scenarios, and this includes combined scenarios rather than only single-factor events. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] In applying the annual (or more frequent) testing cycle, the credit union should ensure the analysis explicitly considers the impact of stressed outflows, consistent with the purpose of demonstrating sufficient liquid funds. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The PRA also expects to engage with the credit union on the chosen methodology and the assumptions used, including how the credit union assesses likely run-off for different elements of the retail book, which should therefore be addressed within the stress-testing design and documentation. [#SRC:505c78059496b268]
source_text: The liquidity stress testing expectation referred to in paragraph 12.1 could be met by the credit union’s own analysis, which is based on a clearly articulated RAS (see paragraph 10.1 ) defining the duration and type of stress or stresses that the credit union aims to survive. The PRA expects the stress tests to consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios (including combined scenarios). Credit unions should expect the PRA to engage with them on the method used and assumptions made, eg their assessment of the likely run-off of different elements of the retail book.
target_text: In order to ensure a credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds under Credit Unions 9.4 , the PRA expects credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing whereby the impact of stressed outflows is considered.

question: In an RFTS application, how should the court’s timetable set at a Directions hearing be framed in relation to the applicant’s role (as transferor, transferee, or both) in submitting the application, particularly for public notification and handling written submissions from persons claiming adverse effect?
gold_answer: For an RFTS application, the court uses a Directions hearing to establish a timetable that governs what the applicant must do to (i) notify the public about the RFTS application and (ii) receive written submissions from persons who say they would be adversely affected by the scheme. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] In framing and applying that timetable, the relevant “applicant” is the party (or parties) submitting the RFTS application to the court to bring about the transfer—typically the transferor, the transferee, or both acting as applicant(s). [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] Practically, this means the timetable set at the Directions hearing should be read as binding on whichever of those entities is acting as the applicant in the particular case, because that is the actor responsible for progressing the court application. [#TGT:3c51f46b31ac10e8] The timetable’s scope specifically covers the steps and sequencing for public notification and for receiving written submissions from potentially adversely affected persons, so the applicant must be prepared to carry out those two functions in accordance with the court’s schedule. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e] The process described is triggered by the Directions hearing itself, which is the point at which the court sets out the timetable for these applicant actions. [#SRC:350ef7c8985b9d8e]
source_text: (v) A Directions hearing will take place where the court sets out a timetable for the applicant 4 to notify the public of the RFTS application and receive any written submissions from persons alleging they would be adversely affected by the scheme.
target_text: 4. The applicant is usually the transferor, transferee (or both) submitting the RFTS application to the court in order to effect the transfer

question: If a firm has big exposures to companies in its own group, what is the normal rule for how those exposures are treated, and what does the firm need to apply for if it wants a higher limit—plus which named document (with month and year) is pointed to for “Large Exposures”?
gold_answer: Normally, a firm’s exposures to entities in its own group are not treated as a special category; they are generally treated like exposures to a third party and therefore are subject to the large exposure limits. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] If the firm wants to use a higher large exposure limit for certain entities within its group, it can do so only by applying to the PRA for a non-core large exposures group permission, and the higher limit is available only where those group entities meet the relevant conditions tied to that permission. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] The text also points to a specific supervisory statement for the large exposures topic: SS16/13, called ‘Large Exposures’, dated June 2018. [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf] Putting these points together, the compliance approach is to treat intra-group exposures as if they were to an outside counterparty unless the PRA grants the non-core large exposures group permission, and to use the referenced SS16/13 ‘Large Exposures’ (June 2018) as the named supervisory statement associated with this large exposures framework. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf]
source_text: A firm’s exposures to entities in its own group are generally treated as exposures to a third party and are subject to large exposure limits. Firms can however apply to the PRA for a non-core large exposures group permission, which allows firms to apply a higher large exposure limit to certain entities within their group provided these entities meet certain conditions. 45
target_text: 45. SS16/13 ‘Large Exposures’, June 2018: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/large-exposures-ss .

question: If you are picking the rate of interest for 11.1, what is the highest it can be, given (a) the rule that uses a weighted average of reduced yields across assets and (b) the rule that says an individual long-term insurance asset’s assumed yield (before tax adjustment) must be its 11.3–11.13 yield cut by 2.5%?
gold_answer: The highest permissible rate of interest for 11.1 is the one that stays within both the overall (all-assets) cap and the per-asset cap, so you must not set it above whichever limit is tighter once both are applied. [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] The overall cap is that the 11.1 rate cannot be higher than the adjusted overall yield on assets, and that adjusted overall yield is calculated as a weighted average of the reduced yields for the individual assets (with those reduced yields being the amounts arrived at under 11.2). [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] Separately, for any asset attributed to the long-term insurance business, the assumed yield used for 11.1—measured before any adjustment for the effect of taxation—cannot be higher than the yield for that asset calculated under 11.3 to 11.13, after reducing that yield by 2.5% of itself. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] Put together, you should first ensure each relevant asset’s assumed yield respects the “11.3–11.13 yield minus 2.5%” ceiling, and then ensure the final 11.1 rate does not exceed the weighted-average adjusted overall yield built from the reduced individual-asset yields. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb]
source_text: (1) In no case must a rate of interest determined for the purposes of 11.1 exceed the adjusted overall yield on assets calculated as the weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets arrived at under 11.2 .
target_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.

question: For a credit union with more than £10 million in total assets that invests in more complex investments (eg supranational bonds, corporate bonds, bank bonds, or money market funds), what combined PRA expectations apply regarding (i) governance documentation and (ii) adherence to concentration limits, including any stated exception?
gold_answer: A credit union that is above the £10 million asset threshold and is investing in more complex investments is expected to meet both a governance expectation and an investment concentration expectation, and it should treat these as cumulative. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] Specifically, where the credit union is undertaking the relevant additional activities, it is expected to have and maintain an investment policy that has been approved by its board. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] In parallel, because it has more than £10 million in total assets, the PRA expects it to follow the concentration limits described for that category of credit union. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] The concentration-limits expectation also extends to any credit union that holds investments falling under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, so a credit union investing in the more complex instruments referenced should assess whether its holdings fall into that rules-based category as well. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] When applying the concentration limits, the PRA indicates an exception for the investments listed in paragraph 11.2. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] The additional expectations for credit unions above £10 million and for those investing in more complex investments are stated as being set out in Chapters 11 and 14, respectively. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c]
source_text: Additional expectations relating to investments for credit unions with more than £10 million in assets and credit unions that invest in more complex investments (supranational bonds, corporate bonds, bank bonds, and money market funds) are set out in Chapters 11 and 14 , respectively. Credit unions undertaking additional activities 4 are also expected to maintain a board-approved investment policy (see paragraph 14.2 in Chapter 14 ).
