question: Before a society sends the transfer notification statement to members, what PRA approval steps and supporting materials are expected, and how is that approval evidenced back to the society (including any copy-handling and public-file actions involving the Transfer Statement/Transfer Document)?
gold_answer: A society should treat PRA approval as a prerequisite to issuing the transfer notification statement to members, and should be prepared both to submit an approval application with supporting materials and to receive formal confirmation of approval from the PRA. [#SRC:fd3cb3782a25a1b2] In general, the application for approval should follow the procedure described in paragraphs 4.97 to 4.103, and the final draft of the transfer notification statement should be submitted with the relevant documents listed in paragraph 4.102, adapted as appropriate to the case and to the less extensive information the statement must contain. [#SRC:fd3cb3782a25a1b2] The PRA then provides its statement of approval of the Transfer Statement in the manner set out in Appendix 1, and confirms approval by returning to the society one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement bearing the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be] Once available, the society will be asked to provide the PRA with 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and any Transfer Summary. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be] Although there is no statutory requirement to place copies of the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary on the society’s public file, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and Transfer Statement (if printed separately) to be placed on the public file because they are public documents. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be]
source_text: The transfer notification statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraphs 4.97 to 4.103 , and the final draft of the statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 4.102 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain.
target_text: The PRA’s statement of approval of the Transfer Statement will be given as is set out in Appendix 1 . The PRA’s approval of the Transfer Statement will be confirmed by returning to the society one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement with the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA. The society will be asked to give 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and Transfer Summary, if any, to the PRA when they are available. There is no statutory requirement for copies of the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary to be placed on the public file of a society but, because they are both public documents, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and Transfer Statement, if printed separately, to be placed on the public file.

question: Where an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, serves as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, how should it align (i) the calculation of own funds requirements for CCP-related transactions with that client and (ii) its internal assessment of whether own funds held against CCP exposures are adequate, including exposures arising from contractual arrangements referred to in Article 304?
gold_answer: An institution acting as a clearing member and, in that capacity, as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP must calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client using the specified framework (Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter, Section 4 of Chapter 4 of the Title, and Title VI, as applicable). [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] In parallel, it must assess—using appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing—whether the level of own funds it holds against its exposures to a CCP adequately reflects the inherent risks of those exposures. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] This adequacy assessment must cover not only general CCP exposures and potential future or contingent credit exposures, but also exposures arising from default fund contributions. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] Additionally, because the institution is a clearing member, the assessment must also include exposures that result from contractual arrangements as laid down in Article 304, ensuring those contractual-arrangement exposures are captured in the stress/scenario-based evaluation of own-funds sufficiency. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] Practically, the institution should ensure that the own-funds amounts produced by the required calculation approach for the client-facing CCP-related transactions are then tested for risk-adequacy against the full set of CCP exposure types identified for clearing members, including the Article 304 contractual-arrangement exposures. [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0]
source_text: Institutions shall assess, through appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing, whether the level of own funds held against exposures to a CCP, including potential future or contingent credit exposures, exposures from default fund contributions and, where the institution is acting as a clearing member , exposures resulting from contractual arrangements as laid down in Article 304 , adequately relates to the inherent risks of those exposures.
target_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, acts as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP shall calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter, with Section 4 of Chapter 4 of this Title and with Title VI, as applicable.

question: If a society plans to dissolve after a transfer to a specially formed successor company, what must the transfer terms achieve about the society’s shares by the dissolution date, and what notices and timing rules apply for telling the PRA and the FCA the vesting date (including when dissolution happens and what the society can do after the vesting date if it sets a later dissolution date)?
gold_answer: The transfer terms must include a mechanism that makes sure the society will stop holding any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date the society is due to dissolve. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] After the PRA confirms the transfer, it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must also notify both the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date at least seven days before that date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] If the society does not give a notice specifying a later dissolution date, dissolution happens on the vesting date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] If disposing of the society’s shares in its successor requires more time, the society may include in its vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution then occurs on that later date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] This matters for the transfer terms because the “no shares held” outcome must be achieved by whatever dissolution date applies (whether the vesting date or a later date notified to facilitate share disposal). [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] When a later dissolution date is notified, the society must stop doing business from the vesting date except what is needed to dispose of its shares in its successor. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]
source_text: The terms of the transfer must include provision to secure that the society ceases to hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve (Section 100(11) of the 1986 Act). The provisions of the 1986 Act concerning the dissolution of the society and the disposal of any shares in its successor are discussed in section ‘ Notification and Dissolution ’.
target_text: When the PRA has confirmed a transfer (whether voluntary or under direction) it will notify the FCA and the society concerned. Section 97(8) of the 1986 Act requires the society to notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date, and it must do so no later than seven days before that date, and, unless a notice is given under subsection (10), subsection (9) provides that the society shall be dissolved on that date. Subsection (10) provides that, if necessary for the purpose of facilitating the disposal of its shares in its successor, the society may include, in the notice of the vesting date, notice of a later date for the dissolution of the society, and it is on this later date that the society is dissolved. A society which gives such a notice must cease to transact any business as from the notified vesting date, except such as may be necessary to dispose of its shares in its successor.

question: How should a TWD firm document and operationalise its TWD option so that it can be executed in real-life stress, including how the wind-down period is defined and what must be quantified in the recovery plan, and how this documentation links to the firm’s TWD capabilities used for its recovery plan and BRP?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should both (i) set out the TWD option in its recovery plan in a way that supports straightforward execution under stress and (ii) maintain capabilities that allow it to develop and execute that option across real-life circumstances, using those capabilities to support both the recovery plan and the BRP. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8] The recovery plan should explain the TWD option, and where relevant include the playbook, so the option can be implemented readily in a stress scenario. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] In addition, the recovery plan should quantify wind-down costs and describe impacts on projected capital and liquidity resources over the full wind-down period, measured from execution of the TWD option until trading activities are wound down. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] The wind-down period should be broken into an active wind-down period (from execution until the firm has exited all positions it can exit without undue costs) and a passive wind-down period (the remainder, during which exposures of remaining rump positions are hedged where possible until expiry). [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] To make that plan executable beyond paper design, the firm should have TWD capabilities that enable development and execution of the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities when developing and executing its recovery plan and BRP. [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8]
source_text: The TWD option should be explained in the TWD firm’s recovery plan, including the playbook where relevant, such that the TWD option would be easily implemented in a stress. The quantification of the costs of the wind-down, set out in more detail in Chapter 4 , and any impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources throughout the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm’s trading activities have been wound down (hereinafter referred to as the ‘wind-down period’), should also be set out in the TWD firm’s recovery plan. 14 The wind-down period can be split into the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm has exited all the positions it can exit without incurring undue costs (hereinafter referred to as the ‘active wind-down period’); and the rest of the wind-down period, during which the firm hedges the exposures of the remaining ‘rump’ positions (insofar as this is possible) until they expire (hereinafter referred to as the ‘passive wind-down period’).
target_text: TWD firms should have TWD capabilities that will enable them to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances. TWD firms should use their TWD capabilities to help them to develop and execute their recovery plan and BRP.

question: If a firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3), what does it need to have in place at group level to check whether important group business services can stay within impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption, and when would 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 not apply because of where the parent undertaking’s head office is?
gold_answer: For a firm in a group covered by 2.1(3), the firm must make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems let the firm assess whether important group business services could remain within the impact tolerance if there is a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] In the same 2.1(3) setting, the firm also needs to identify whether a specific disapplication condition is met: 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] This means the firm’s operational resilience assessment capability at group level (focused on impact tolerance for important group business services under severe but plausible disruption) is a required capability for the firm as a group member, while the applicability of 22.2–22.4 depends on the parent undertaking’s head-office jurisdiction and the stated IRPR regulation conditions. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at the level of the group could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.

question: If a firm gets a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, how quickly does it have to send the FSCS the single customer views and exclusions views, and after the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 what must the FSCS tell the PRA and by when (including how this links to paying compensation within the 9.2 time limits)?
gold_answer: After a firm receives a Part 4A permission to accept deposits, it must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views within three months of receiving that permission. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] After the FSCS receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, the FSCS then has a separate deadline: it must, within six months of receiving that required information, advise the PRA about whether the information coming from the firm’s SCV system can be submitted to the FSCS and whether it will work with (i.e., be compatible with) the FSCS’s systems. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] This FSCS advice is not just a general data-quality check; it is specifically framed around whether the FSCS’s systems can use the SCV information so that the FSCS can pay compensation within the time limits referred to in 9.2. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] Put together, the firm’s obligation is a three-month delivery requirement triggered by the permission event, while the FSCS’s obligation is a six-month assessment-and-notification requirement triggered by receipt of the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 and directed to the PRA. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74]
source_text: The FSCS must, within six months of receiving the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 , advise the PRA whether the information provided by a firm’s SCV system is capable of being submitted to the FSCS and whether it is compatible with the FSCS’s systems to enable it to pay compensation within the time limits contained in 9.2 .
target_text: A firm must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views within three months of receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits .

question: If a society picks dates for its transfer scheme, what does it need to do about the Qualifying Day (compared with other reference dates), and who exactly gets the section 100(2)(b) and (4) cash bonus based on that Qualifying Day?
gold_answer: The society needs to treat the Qualifying Day as a single, specific date that drives who must be given the right to the Statutory Cash Bonus under section 100, and it must keep that Qualifying Day clearly distinct from any other “reference dates” it may choose for other parts of the transfer scheme. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Once that one Qualifying Day is set, the cash bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) must be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and who was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution. [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc] This means you cannot decide bonus eligibility by switching between different dates used elsewhere in the scheme, because the Commission’s view is that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these bonus-related purposes. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] The same Qualifying Day may also matter for identifying which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or shares in the successor company, but the bonus payment class is still defined by shareholding on the Qualifying Day plus ineligibility to vote on the requisite resolution. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc]
source_text: The choice of Qualifying Day 53 is important because it is a determining factor in deciding which members must have conferred upon them a right to the Statutory Cash Bonus 54 provided by Section 100 of the 1986 Act. It may also be relevant in deciding which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or of shares in the successor company. The Commission’s view was that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these purposes, which must be clearly distinguished from any other ‘reference dates’ which may be chosen by a society for the purposes of its transfer scheme.
target_text: 54. The bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) of the 1986 Act to be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution.

question: If you’re writing a short internal note on Pillar 2B, what should you say about where the PRA buffer sits compared with the TCR and the combined buffer, and how Section II links Pillar 2B to weak governance/risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: Your note should combine (1) the capital-stack placement and function of the PRA buffer and (2) the Section II topics that explain how Pillar 2B is determined and used in supervision. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995] On placement and function, state that the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an additional capital amount firms should maintain on top of their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and that it is intended to absorb losses that could arise in a severe stress scenario without duplicating what the combined buffers are meant to cover. [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Also state that the PRA buffer, the combined buffer, and the TCR together form the PRA’s capital framework (shown as a capital stack). [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] Then link this to Section II by noting that Section II explains the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined, and how it relates to the CRD buffers, and it provides the PRA’s approach to dealing with weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B as well as group risk, including RFB group risk. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]
source_text: Section II: Pillar 2B provides information on the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined and how it relates to the CRD buffers. Section II also provides details on the PRA’s approach to tackling weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B and group risk, including RFB group risk.
target_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.

question: When a firm outsources a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider that is in the same group, how must the firm reflect its control or influence over the service provider in the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3), given the requirement that the agreement’s terms and conditions align with the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A?
gold_answer: The firm must structure the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) so that its terms and conditions remain aligned with the firm’s obligations under 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, and it must do so in a way that reflects the group relationship when the service provider is in the same group. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] In practice, where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group and the firm is outsourcing a critical or important operational function or activity, the firm must explicitly consider how much it controls the service provider or can influence the service provider’s actions, and ensure the agreement is consistent with that assessment. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] This means the agreement should not be drafted in isolation from the firm’s actual ability to direct or shape the service provider’s conduct within the group, because the firm is required to take that control/influence into account for this type of outsourcing. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] At the same time, the agreement’s terms and conditions must remain consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, so the firm should check that any provisions addressing the intra-group control or influence do not conflict with those obligations. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: Where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group , the firm must, when outsourcing any critical or important operational functions or activities, take into account the extent to which the firm controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.

question: If a disruption has already happened, what should impact tolerances be used for by boards and senior management, and what should regular testing in severe but plausible scenarios focus on (and not focus on) to match that use?
gold_answer: Impact tolerances should be used as a standard for boards and senior management to help decide where to prioritise investment and how to set up recovery and response arrangements, and they can also help guide decisions during an operational disruption alongside other incident information. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] Regular testing should then be designed to show the firm can remain within those impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios, reflecting that the tolerance framework assumes a disruption has occurred. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] As a result, the testing should not be aimed at proving the firm can stop incidents from happening; instead it should concentrate on whether the firm’s recovery and response arrangements are effective enough to keep performance within the tolerance once disruption is underway. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] This creates a direct link between how impact tolerances drive investment and planning decisions and what the tests are meant to validate: the firm is checking that its planned recovery and response actions are sufficient to manage disruption within the tolerance standard that leadership uses for prioritisation. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] The PRA’s expectation to focus on recovery and response arrangements supports keeping both planning and testing centred on managing incidents effectively after they occur. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 22 require firms to test regularly their ability to remain within impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios. Impact tolerances assume a disruption has occurred, and so testing the ability to remain within impact tolerances should not focus on preventing incidents from occurring. The PRA expects firms to focus on recovery and response arrangements.

question: If a firm has death risk cover and also takes on investment risk, what calculations does it need to run, and what does it do with the death-risk result (including any parts it must ignore)?
gold_answer: When a firm has both types of exposure, it needs to follow one rule for death risk and another rule for investment risk, and then combine the death-risk output into the solvency margin. For death risk cover, the firm must work out a sum using the calculation in 2.3, but it must not use 2.3(4) or 2.3(5) for that particular sum, and it must add the resulting amount to the required margin of solvency calculated under any of 3.2 and 3.3 (even if that required margin is zero). [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] For investment risk, the firm must apply the calculation in 2.2 only where, and only to the extent that, it bears an investment risk, so the calculation is limited to the part of the firm’s business that actually carries that risk. [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe] Putting these together, the firm runs 2.2 for the investment-risk-bearing portion, and separately runs the adjusted 2.3 for death risk and adds that 2.3-based sum onto the required margin of solvency produced under 3.2/3.3. [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe]
source_text: Where a firm covers a death risk, a sum arrived at by applying the calculation in 2.3 (but excluding for these purposes 2.3 (4) and (5)) must be added to the required margin of solvency , including a required margin of solvency of zero, arrived at under any of 3.2 and 3.3 .
target_text: If and in so far as a firm bears an investment risk, the calculation in 2.2 must be applied.

question: If a firm makes a material change to the systems it uses to meet 11.1 and 11.2, who does it have to tell, by when, and what signed statement has to go with the notification in 15.3?
gold_answer: If there is a material change in the firm’s systems that are used to comply with 11.1 and 11.2, the firm must notify both the PRA and the FSCS, and the deadline is within 3 months of the change. [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b] Separately, the notification described in 15.3 must include an additional document: a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body. [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f] The signed statement is not generic; it must confirm that the firm’s systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 and also that they satisfy the requirements in 11.8. [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f] Putting these together for practical compliance, when the firm is dealing with a material change to the relevant systems and making the required notifications to the PRA and FSCS within the 3‑month period, it should ensure the 15.3 notification is accompanied by the governing-body-signed confirmation covering 11.1, 11.2, and 11.8. [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b] [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f]
source_text: The notification in 15.3 must be accompanied by a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body confirming that the firm’s systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 and satisfy the requirements in 11.8 .
target_text: A firm must notify the PRA and FSCS of a material change in the firm’s systems to comply with 11.1 and 11.2 within 3 months of the change.

question: When calculating the add-on of a hedging set under Articles 280a to 280f, what is the meaning of the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient ‘ε’, and how is εj for a specific hedging set j determined?
gold_answer: For purposes of calculating the add-on of a hedging set under Articles 280a to 280f, the term “hedging set supervisory factor coefficient” refers to the coefficient denoted by ε that is used in that add-on calculation. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] Where the coefficient is indexed by hedging set, εj means the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient for hedging set j, and it is not chosen ad hoc; instead, εj must be determined in accordance with Article 280. [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c] In practical terms, this links the add-on calculation context (Articles 280a to 280f) to the method for fixing the coefficient value for each hedging set (Article 280): the add-on calculation uses ε as its supervisory factor coefficient, and for any particular hedging set j the applicable coefficient is εj as determined under Article 280. [#TGT:ce763c4d8b7f8eb2] [#SRC:b96f4cdc656c880c]
source_text: ε j = the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient of hedging set j determined in accordance with Article 280 ;
target_text: For the purpose of calculating the add-on of a hedging set as referred to in Articles 280a to 280f , the hedging set supervisory factor coefficient ‘ ε ’ shall be the following:

question: If a firm is working out its expense provision at the valuation date, what does it need to do with its real expenses from the last 12 months and inflation assumptions, while also making sure the provision is big enough for the scenario where it stops taking new business 12 months after the valuation date (net of tax)?
gold_answer: The firm needs to build an expense provision that is anchored in its recent actual costs and prudent inflation expectations, but that also meets a minimum sufficiency test tied to a specific “stop new business” scenario. [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] First, the provision for expenses (whether implicit or explicit) must not fall below the amount that, on prudent assumptions, would be needed to cover the total net cost of fulfilling contracts, after taking taxation effects into account, if the firm were to cease transacting new business twelve months after the valuation date. [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] Second, when setting that provision, the firm must look back at what it actually spent in the twelve months before the valuation date, and it must also consider how inflation will affect future expenses. [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] The inflation element must be based on prudent assumptions about future increases in prices and earnings, so the provision reflects expected growth in expenses rather than only past spending. [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] Putting these together, the firm should ensure the provision is informed by the last year’s actual expenses and prudent inflation projections, while still being at least large enough to cover the net-of-tax contract-fulfilment costs under the twelve-month cessation scenario. [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc]
source_text: In accordance with 13.2 , a firm’s provision for expenses, whether implicit or explicit, must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of the effect of taxation) that would be likely to be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date .
target_text: The provision mentioned in 13.1 must have regard to the firm's actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and the effects of inflation on future expenses on prudent assumptions as to the future rates of increase in prices and earnings.

question: If a credit union is about to make a subordinated loan, what does it need to do before the loan is provided, and how long must it keep the paperwork after the loan date?
gold_answer: Before a credit union provides a subordinated loan, it must carry out an assessment focused on the financial implications of making that loan. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] This assessment is a pre-loan step: it needs to be done prior to provision, so the credit union should not wait until after the loan is made to complete it. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] After the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must keep a written record of the assessment (the assessment referred to in 3.14) for a set retention period. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] The retention period is five years, and it is measured from the date of the subordinated loan, meaning the clock starts on the loan date and runs for five years after that date. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] Put together, the credit union needs to (1) do the financial-implications assessment before providing the subordinated loan and (2) ensure there is a written record of that assessment that can be retained for five years following the loan date. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]
source_text: A credit union must retain, for a period of five years following the date of a subordinated loan, a written record of the assessment in 3.14 .
target_text: Prior to the provision of a subordinated loan, a credit union must carry out an assessment of the financial implications of making the loan.

question: If a firm is listing risks for its SCR work, what should it write down about risks that are not (or not fully) in the SCR calculation, and how does that fit with the rule that calibration must take in all quantifiable risks (including the named underwriting, market, credit, and operational risks)?
gold_answer: The firm should document two things side by side: the risks that are part of the SCR calculation and the risks that are missing from it or only partly captured, and it should do this in a way that supports a calibration designed to include all quantifiable risks the firm is exposed to. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] Specifically, the firm’s write-up must cover the risks that are included in the SCR calculation and also call out the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] Separately, the calibration requirement sets the expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, and it gives a minimum set that must be included: non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] Putting these together, the firm should not assume the SCR calculation list is complete; instead, it should use the “not, or not fully, included” section to identify any quantifiable exposures that still need to be considered to meet the calibration expectation, even if they are not fully reflected in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]
source_text: (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: If a firm has assets where the cash-flow timing is uncertain but still bounded (like callable bond final redemption payments), what are the two ways the firm can try to include them in the MA portfolio, and what is the cap on how much HP cash flows can contribute to the MA benefit?
gold_answer: For assets whose cash-flow timing is uncertain but limited within contractual bounds (including examples like callable bond final redemption payments or bonds where the start of repayments can vary within a bounded period), the firm has two routes to present for MA portfolio inclusion. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] First, the firm can apply to treat the assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement, recognising that the PRA will assess that request on a case-by-case basis. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] Second, the firm can assess whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows (as referenced in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D) and, if they do, include them in the MA portfolio within the limited proportion allowed for such assets. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] Under the SS terminology, assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A are called assets with HP cash flows, and firms can demonstrate these do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (as discussed in Chapter 4). [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1] If the firm uses the HP cash flow route, the aggregate limit is that HP cash flows may create only 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and the PRA may also apply additional safeguards to address the extra risks they introduce. [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: If a UK subsidiary is part of a group based outside the UK, what should it do to make its recovery plan easy for the board and business teams to use, and what should it do if the PRA asks for more detailed UK playbook work?
gold_answer: The recovery plan should be set up so it is easy to use in practice by both the board and the specific business areas that would need to use it, because the board will be making key decisions in a stress and needs to be able to find and understand what it needs quickly. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] For a UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK, this usability focus should be combined with considering the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii), since that guidance is specifically flagged as relevant for such UK subsidiaries. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] If the PRA explicitly asks the firm to do more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of its UK recovery planning work, the firm should treat that as an expected enhancement to its recovery planning materials and contact its supervisor to discuss whether the request applies to it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] In practical terms, the firm should ensure the plan’s structure supports quick board navigation and understanding while also being usable by the business areas, and it should be ready to expand UK playbook detail when the PRA requests it. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If an insurance contract lets the premium be paid as one upfront amount and then smaller instalments, can a firm split the contract into parts to put some of it in an MA portfolio? What extra checks does Matching Adjustment 2.3 require for a with-profits annuity “component,” including how it must be managed under regulation 4(6)?
gold_answer: A firm generally should not use an upfront-plus-instalments premium pattern as a reason to split one insurance contract into separate parts for Matching Adjustment purposes, except in the limited cases referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] Matching Adjustment 2.3 instead permits inclusion only of a “component” of a with-profits annuity contract where that component is legally established and clearly identifiable as guaranteed within the contract and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] So, even if the premium is paid over time, the firm must avoid a notional split that would undermine separate management of the MA portfolio from the rest of the business, which the PRA links to regulation 4(6)(b). [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] To support inclusion, the PRA expects the firm to provide a detailed assessment demonstrating that the liabilities included are limited to contractually guaranteed elements and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] The firm is also expected to set out a clear policy on whether future attaching bonuses will be added within the MA portfolio or outside it, which helps define what is (and is not) part of the guaranteed component being managed separately. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7]
source_text: Some contracts of insurance include an option for the premium to be paid as an initial sum followed by a series of further (smaller) instalments. Except in the limited cases set out in paragraphs 3.5A , 3.5B and 3.5C above, the PRA does not view any approach that notionally splits a contract into parts as being compatible with Matching Adjustment 2.3 . The PRA’s view is that such a treatment would also undermine the ability of the insurer to manage its MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, as required by regulation 4(6)(b) of the IRPR regulations.
target_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.

question: Where a firm plans to issue a notified instrument that includes new or complex features (including instruments marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’), what engagement with the PRA is expected and who within the firm is expected to be accountable for the quality of the notification (including where signing/submission is delegated)?
gold_answer: The firm should plan for earlier and potentially longer PRA engagement when the notified instrument has new or complex features, including where the instrument is marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’, because the PRA is likely to need more time to review such cases. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] In that context, the PRA expects the firm to contact its usual supervisory contact as early as possible—such as once the relevant terms and conditions (including any side agreements) have been drafted—and to provide a clear explanation of how the proposed features meet the letter and objective of PRA rules and supervisory expectations. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] Separately, the PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to take responsibility for the overall quality of the firm’s capital structure, including being accountable for the quality of notifications to the PRA under Definition of Capital Part Rule 7A to 7D, even if the act of signing and submitting a notification form is delegated. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] Taken together, this means the firm should combine early supervisory engagement on the substance of new/complex features with clear internal accountability at SMF level for the quality of the notification package that supports that engagement. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868]
source_text: The PRA is likely to need more time to review a notified instrument with complex feature(s) (as set out in paragraphs 2.3 to 2.5 above), or issuances with new features, for example, instruments marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’. The PRA expects the firm to engage with its usual supervisory contact as early as possible (for example, once the relevant terms and conditions including any side agreements are drafted) with a clear explanation of how the proposed features comply with the letter and objective of the PRA rules and supervisory expectations. Notwithstanding that Tier 2 instruments are subject to post-notification, where a firm is proposing to include new or complex features that could affect eligibility, the PRA expects to discuss these in advance.
target_text: The PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to take responsibility for ensuring the quality of the capital structure overall. This includes being accountable for the quality of notifications to the PRA under Definition of Capital Part Rule 7A to 7D , acknowledging that the act of signing and submitting any notification form may be delegated. In a relatively rare case where it may be necessary for a firm to include complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, the PRA expects the relevant SMF to inform the firm’s board in advance of the issuance, evidencing why the instrument cannot be issued without the proposed complex feature(s) and that, notwithstanding the proposed complexity, they consider the instrument compliant with the objective of the Own Funds (CRR) Part . question: For a firm that has created a record in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015, what retention period and PRA access obligation applies to each version of that record when the firm is complying with 5.8, and how is the start of the retention period determined?
gold_answer: Where a firm has a record that was created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015, the firm is required to apply the 5.8 compliance framework to that record. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] In practical terms, this means the firm must retain each version of the relevant record for ten years, with the ten-year period running from the date that particular version is replaced by a more current version. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] The same retention approach also applies to each version of the management responsibilities map, and the firm must be able to supply both the map and the record to the PRA if the PRA asks for them. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] Accordingly, for the specific population of records captured by the “as at 31 December 2015” condition, the firm should treat version control and supersession dates as the trigger for calculating the ten-year retention window, and ensure the retained versions are retrievable for PRA requests. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]
source_text: A firm must comply with 5.8 in relation to any record created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015.
target_text: Each version of both the management responsibilities map and the record in 5.4 must be retained for a period of ten years from the date on which it was superseded by a more up-to-date record, and must be provided to the PRA on request.

question: If a firm says it can rebuild its capital and liquidity after a stress, what should it do to check that its recovery options still work when other firms are likely doing similar things (like trying to issue equity), and how does scenario testing help show the plan works and its parts fit together in different stresses?
gold_answer: The firm should evaluate its recovery options not just in isolation, but in the context of how a stress would affect the market and what peers are likely to do at the same time, and then use scenario testing to demonstrate the recovery plan remains workable across different stress types and that its components interact as intended. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] Concretely, the firm is expected to have enough credible options to restore capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress, and when it assesses how much each option can deliver it should factor in likely peer actions. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] For example, it should consider that in a market-wide stress its ability to issue equity may be reduced, which would lower the practical capacity of that option. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] Scenario testing then provides the mechanism to show the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress and to test how different elements of the plan—such as indicators, governance and options—would interact in those stresses. [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] To link the two, the firm should ensure its scenario tests incorporate the peer-action assumptions (including diminished equity issuance capacity in market-wide stress) so the interaction testing reflects the same constraints used in the option capacity assessment. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure they have sufficient credible options to restore their capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress. In assessing the capacity of these options, firms should take into account the likely actions of peers in a stress. For example, firms should assess whether their ability to issue equity will be diminished in a market wide stress. See also ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below.
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.

question: When calculating the leverage ratio for quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024 on the basis that Article 473a of the CRR is disregarded for the capital measure under Article 429(3) of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part, what specific form of capital must be used as the capital measure for the relevant paragraph 2 purpose?
gold_answer: For quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024, the leverage ratio must be calculated using a capital measure determined on the basis that Article 473a of the CRR is treated as not applying for the purposes of the capital measure under Article 429(3) in Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part. [#SRC:05bd855cd46919eb] In that same calculation context, where the rule refers to “paragraph 2” and requires a defined “capital measure” for those purposes, the capital measure is specified as tier 1 capital (leverage). [#TGT:1d76390248a589f0] Accordingly, the compliant approach is to (i) identify that the relevant reporting window is limited to quarterly periods ending on or before 31 December 2024, (ii) apply the leverage ratio calculation framework under Article 429(3) while explicitly disregarding Article 473a only for the capital-measure component, and (iii) populate that capital-measure component with tier 1 capital (leverage) as the required definition for paragraph 2. [#SRC:05bd855cd46919eb] [#TGT:1d76390248a589f0] This links the time-bounded “disregard Article 473a” instruction to the specific capital definition that must be used for the paragraph 2 purpose. [#SRC:05bd855cd46919eb] [#TGT:1d76390248a589f0]
source_text: (g) in relation to the quarterly periods up to 31 December 2024, the leverage ratio calculated as if Article 473a of the CRR did not apply for purposes of the capital measure under Article 429(3) of Chapter 3 of the Leverage Ratio (CRR) Part .
target_text: For the purposes of paragraph 2 , the capital measure shall be tier 1 capital (leverage) .

question: For a UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK, how should the recovery plan describe (i) the UK governance framework for monitoring indicators and taking action, including when decisions are escalated to group level, and (ii) the SMR accountability arrangements for recovery planning, including the named executive’s responsibilities for the recovery plan and resolution pack and engagement with the PRA?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK should set out a UK-specific governance framework that explains how indicators are monitored and how actions are triggered, and it should also specify the point at which decisions are escalated to group level. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2] In parallel, because recovery planning is treated as a prescribed responsibility under the SMR, the firm should identify a named executive who is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and who oversees the internal governance processes supporting them. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The accountable executive director should be clearly identified as responsible for the recovery plan and for serving as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on recovery plan matters. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The PRA’s expectations for this accountable person include being answerable for the quality of the recovery plan, ensuring it is structured to be usable by senior executives and board members in a stress, driving improvements (including in response to PRA feedback), and managing the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning issues. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] For UK subsidiaries of non-UK groups, the plan should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that the subsidiary meets relevant SMR-related requirements referenced for such firms, aligning the UK governance framework and escalation arrangements with clearly assigned responsibilities under the SMR. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2]
source_text: (vi) The plan should include a UK governance framework for monitoring the indicators and taking action where appropriate. For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, in meeting expectations set out in Chapter 2 (viii) , the PRA expects firms to set out when decisions would be escalated to group level. In addition, the PRA expects UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK to meet requirements set out in Chapter 2 (xiii) (c) in relation to responsibilities under the SMR.
target_text: Firms are reminded that recovery planning is a prescribed responsibility under the SMR which means that there should be a named executive at each firm that is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and for overseeing the internal processes regarding their governance. 18 Firms should identify the accountable executive director responsible for the firm’s recovery plan and for acting as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on its recovery plan. The PRA has observed that this is typically the CEO, CFO or CRO. The PRA will hold this person accountable for the quality of the recovery plan, for the plan being structured so as to be usable by senior executives and board members in a stress, for making improvements to the recovery plan (including in response to the PRA’s feedback) and for the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning issues.

question: For a firm that meets the definition of a ‘UK trading bank’ and is therefore within scope of the PRA’s booking expectations in the specified chapters and annex, what does the PRA expect regarding allocation of oversight for booking arrangements to an SMF, how should that be documented, and when might approval as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7) be appropriate for individuals in the parent or group entities?
gold_answer: A firm that is a ‘UK trading bank’—ie, a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm headquartered in the UK or in a UK-based group, with investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas—falls within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations identified in the supervisory statement, including the listed paragraphs and the Annex on Context and definitions. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] Where those booking-arrangements expectations apply, the PRA expects the firm to assign responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to document that allocation in the relevant individual’s Statement of Responsibilities. [#TGT:a696590f07b39032] In addition, if individuals located in the parent or other group entities have significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), reflecting their group-level influence over UK regulated activity that can include aspects connected to booking arrangements. [#TGT:a696590f07b39032] The supervisory statement also indicates that it distinguishes where expectations apply to international banks alone versus both international banks and UK trading banks, and points to a summary of terminology for the scope of application. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. We make clear in the relevant sections where the expectations apply to international banks alone, and where they apply to international banks and UK trading banks. See paragraph 4.24B for a summary of the terminology used to describe the scope of application for the booking expectations.
target_text: Where applicable, the PRA expects firms to allocate the responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF, and record this appropriately in their Statement of Responsibilities. Where individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, it may be appropriate for them to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7). question: For a firm that has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year, how should it determine the valuation basis for periodic fees when it is in its second fee year and received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity between 1 January in its first fee year and 1 April in its second fee year, and how does that approach relate to the first-fee-year periodic fee basis for the first twelve months of new business?
gold_answer: A firm that has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year should use projected valuations in the specified second-fee-year scenario, and this aligns conceptually with the first-fee-year approach of paying periodic fees using a projected valuation for the first twelve months of new business. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] Specifically, if the firm is in its second fee year and it received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity during the window from 1 January in its first fee year to 1 April in its second fee year, it should apply projected valuations in the manner referenced (as set out in 3.7). [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] This second-fee-year instruction is particularly relevant because the firm has not yet completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year, so a projected valuation is used rather than a completed-year measure. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] In parallel, the first-fee-year rule states that a firm in its first fee year pays periodic fees based on its projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] Taken together, the passages indicate that projected valuation is the valuation basis both for first-fee-year periodic fees (covering the first twelve months of new business) and, for firms meeting the stated timing and permission conditions, for periodic fees in the second fee year as well. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666]

question: In stress conditions, how should a firm approach the Matching Adjustment (MA) and fundamental spread (FS) used for technical provisions (TPs), and in what circumstances may it increase the fundamental spread beyond the amount calculated under rules 4.10 to 4.16 (including any additions referenced in 4.16 and 4.17)?
gold_answer: For TP purposes, the firm should treat the MA and FS as being calculated under Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook, and the PRA’s expectation is that the MA calculation method itself should not be altered merely because conditions are stressed. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] However, stress conditions require the firm to reassess whether the assumptions used in calculating the MA and FS for the TP calculation remain appropriate, including any additions to the FS (whether additions linked to assets with HP cash flows under Matching Adjustment 4.16 or additions made for other reasons under Matching Adjustment 4.17). [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] In addition, the firm has discretion to increase the fundamental spread beyond the amount calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 when that increase is necessary so that the fundamental spread covers all risks that the firm retains. [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1] Read together, this means the firm should keep the MA calculation method stable while using stress-driven review of assumptions (including FS add-ons) and, where needed, applying an increase to the fundamental spread to ensure comprehensive coverage of retained risks within the 4.10–4.16 framework. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1]
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook (restating as rules the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations) sets out how the MA and FS should be calculated for the purpose of determining TPs. While the PRA considers that the MA calculation method should not change in stress conditions, firms should consider if the assumptions used to calculate the MA and FS for the TP calculation, including any additions to the FS (either for assets with HP cash flows as per Matching Adjustment 4.16 or for other reasons as per Matching Adjustment 4.17 ), remain appropriate in stress conditions.
target_text: A firm may increase the fundamental spread calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 where necessary to ensure it covers all risks retained by the firm .

question: If a firm is about to give an attestation under 9.1 and it uses the matching adjustment, what does it need to analyse first and what must it do with any risks that analysis turns up?
gold_answer: Before giving any attestation under 9.1, the firm must analyse and justify two points: that the fundamental spread it uses reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] If the firm applies the matching adjustment, it also has an obligation to manage any risks that are identified in the analysis carried out in accordance with Matching Adjustment 10.1. [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc] Read together, this means the firm’s retained-risk assessment (embedded in the fundamental spread justification) and its portfolio-based confidence assessment are not just documentation for the attestation; they are also a mechanism for surfacing risks that must then be managed when the matching adjustment is applied. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc] The key sequencing is that the analysis and justification must occur before the attestation, and any risks identified through the relevant analysis must be managed as part of applying the matching adjustment. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc]
source_text: (4) Where a firm applies the matching adjustment , the firm must manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken in accordance with Matching Adjustment 10.1 .
target_text: Before providing any attestation in accordance with 9.1 , a firm must analyse and justify that the fundamental spread used by the firm reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets .

question: When documenting the purpose and use of a model, what must be described about the model’s operating boundaries and how should the firm treat use of the model outside those boundaries, including in stressed macroeconomic conditions?
gold_answer: A firm’s documentation of a model’s purpose and use should include a clear statement of the model operating boundaries under which the model’s performance is expected to be acceptable, alongside the relevant product or portfolio and a comparison of intended versus actual use. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] In this context, “operating boundaries” should be expressed as the sample data range used to assess model performance, and in multivariate settings this range includes the empirical variance-covariance relationships reflected in the sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] The documentation should also make explicit that applying the model by extrapolating beyond those operating boundaries is assumed to increase model risk, and this linkage should be highlighted where the extrapolation involves conditions such as macroeconomic indices during shock or stressed economic environments. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] Practically, the firm should connect the boundary description to the intended-versus-actual use comparison by identifying whether actual use stays within the sample data range (and associated multivariate relationships) that underpins the performance assessment, or whether it extends beyond it. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] Where actual use extends beyond the defined operating boundaries, the firm should treat that use as involving increased model risk and reflect that in the model’s documented use case and boundary conditions. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]
source_text: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable;

Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model.
