question: When the PRA assesses an internal model application or a firm’s continued compliance with calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 for internal model permissions, how should the firm incorporate the PRA’s requested EVT-in-stress test into its regular cycle of internal model validation (including sensitivity testing and performance monitoring) so as to support assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated?
gold_answer: A firm should embed the PRA-requested EVT-in-stress test within its regular internal model validation cycle so it functions as a recurring validation tool that supports the firm’s ability to demonstrate appropriate capital requirements and provides assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] In practice, the EVT-in-stress exercise should be treated as part of the firm’s ongoing validation toolkit, because the PRA indicates it will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress when assessing internal model applications and continued compliance with the relevant calibration standards and internal model requirements for permissions. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] To integrate it into the required validation cycle, the firm should align the EVT-in-stress test with the cycle elements that already must exist: monitoring internal model performance and reviewing whether the model specification remains appropriate; testing model results against experience; operating an effective statistical validation process that enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that capital requirements are appropriate; and testing sensitivity of results to changes in key underlying assumptions (which can be informed by stressed comparisons of economic value and Effective Value). [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] The firm should also ensure the data used for the EVT-in-stress work is assessed for accuracy, completeness, and appropriateness as part of the same validation cycle. [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]
source_text: The PRA considers reassessment of the EVT in stress, in particular the comparison of stressed economic value and Effective Value in (iv) above, to be a helpful validation exercise that could contribute to firms meeting the internal model requirements (see Chapter 14 of the Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models Part of the PRA Rulebook). When assessing internal model applications and firms’ continued compliance with the calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 relevant for granting internal model permissions, the PRA will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress, to assist in providing assurance that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated. Firms may wish to consider adding an EVT in stress to their regular suite of validation tools.
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place a regular cycle of internal model validation which includes: (a) monitoring the performance of the internal model , reviewing the ongoing appropriateness of its specification and testing its results against experience; (b) an effective statistical process for validating the internal model which enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) an analysis of the stability of the internal model and, in particular, the testing of the sensitivity of the results of the internal model to changes in key underlying assumptions; and (d) an assessment of the accuracy, completeness and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model .

question: If a firm is not using monthly reporting under 3.1 and it learns it has started or stopped having close links with someone, what form does it have to use, what information has to be included, and how quickly does it need to send the notification (including the latest deadline)?
gold_answer: If the firm has not elected monthly reporting under 3.1, it must make a notification (or arrange for another firm in its group to make it) when it becomes aware it has begun to have, or ceased to have, close links with any person. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] That notification must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form, and it must be sent as soon as reasonably practicable, with an absolute deadline of no later than one month after the firm becomes aware of the start or end of the close links. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] Using the correct form is not enough on its own: the submission must also include all the relevant information that the Close Links Notification Form specifies, so the firm should ensure the form is completed with the required details rather than leaving required items blank. [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5] Taken together, the firm should (i) identify the awareness date as the trigger, (ii) complete the Close Links Notification Form with the relevant information required by that form, and (iii) submit it promptly and in any case within one month, whether the firm submits directly or via another group firm. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5]
source_text: The notification submitted under 2.4 must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form and must include all the relevant information specified therein.
target_text: Where a firm has not elected to report changes in close links on a monthly basis under 3.1 , it must make (or procure that another firm in its group makes) a notification by completing the Close Links Notification Form as soon as reasonably practicable and no later than one month after it becomes aware that it has begun to have or ceased to have close links with any person.

question: If a firm uses an internal model, what does it have to send to the PRA each year about the “analysis of change,” and what extra narrative material is required (and can the firm pick the format for that narrative)?
gold_answer: Each year, a firm using an internal model must submit template AoC.01 to the PRA, and that template must cover the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] The AoC.01 submission is not just numbers: it must include quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, and it must be prepared following the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] Alongside that annual AoC.01 submission, the firm must also provide supporting narrative documentation required under Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] For this supporting narrative documentation, the firm can choose the format it uses, so long as it submits the narratives as required. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] In short, the annual package combines the AoC.01 template (completed per Chapter 10 instructions) plus the additional supporting narratives linked to the Reporting Part requirements, with flexibility on narrative format. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3]
source_text: Firms are also required to submit the supporting narrative documentation, in accordance with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, in a format they choose.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: How should a firm align its risk-management system’s scope of covered risks with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks are taken into account, and which minimum risk categories must be reflected across both the SCR-related coverage and the system’s specified areas?
gold_answer: A firm should design its risk-management system so that it both (i) covers the risks relevant to the SCR calculation (and those not, or not fully, captured by that calculation) and (ii) is aligned with the expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account through calibration. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The system must be effective and embedded in the firm’s organisational structure and decision-making, with proper consideration of persons who have key functions, so that the calibration and risk coverage are operationally implemented rather than treated as a standalone exercise. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] In practical terms, the firm should ensure that the risk coverage includes the risks to be included in the SCR calculation and also addresses risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, while still ensuring that all quantifiable risks are taken into account. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] At a minimum, the calibration expectation explicitly includes non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk, and the risk-management system must cover specified areas including underwriting and reserving, asset-liability management, investment risk management (notably derivatives, quasi-derivatives and similar commitments), liquidity and concentration risk management, operational risk management, and reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]
source_text: (2) That risk-management system must: (a) be effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions ; (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and (c) cover at least the following areas: (i) underwriting and reserving as set out in 3.1A(1) ; (ii) asset-liability management as set out in 3.1A(2) ; (iii) investment risk management, in particular derivatives , quasi-derivatives and similar commitments, as set out in 3.1A(3) ; (iv) liquidity risk and concentration risk management: as set out in 3.1A(4) and 3.1A(5) ; (v) operational risk management as set out in 3.1A(6) ; and (vi) reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques as set out in 3.1A(7) .
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: When a scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, how should the parties determine whether the PRA’s stated s166 commissioning approach is triggered if they disagree on the valuation of the technical provisions being transferred, and at what point relative to the independent expert nomination would the assessment be commissioned?
gold_answer: To determine whether the PRA’s described approach to commissioning an assessment under s166 of FSMA applies, the parties should apply the threshold tests using the higher of any differing valuations of the technical provisions being transferred, and then align the timing of any resulting assessment with the PRA’s stated sequencing. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] Specifically, where the scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off and the gross technical provisions exceed £100 million, and the scheme would increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%, the PRA indicates it intends in most cases to use its s166 powers to assess the transferee’s operational readiness to accept the scheme. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] In applying those quantitative conditions when valuations differ, the higher valuation is the one used to decide whether the relevant threshold is met. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] If the thresholds are met on that basis, the PRA’s stated process is that the operational-readiness assessment would be commissioned before the independent expert is nominated. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] The PRA also describes an exception: it may refrain from commissioning a new s166 assessment where it can satisfy itself by other means, such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8]
source_text: Where a scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, with gross technical provisions of more than £100 million, 10 and where the scheme will increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%, the PRA intends to exercise its powers under s166 of FSMA in order to assess the operational readiness of the transferee to accept the scheme in most cases, except where it is able to satisfy itself by other means such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. This assessment would be commissioned prior to the nomination of the independent expert.
target_text: 10. If the parties have differing valuations of the technical provisions being transferred, the higher valuation will be used in determining whether the threshold is triggered.

question: Where a firm holds accounts on behalf of beneficiaries (including client accounts and trust accounts) that contain or may contain eligible deposits, what must the firm do to ensure immediate identification, and what additional capability and timeframe applies if the PRA or the FSCS requests information about eligibility status?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that beneficiary-held accounts—including client accounts and trust accounts—that contain or may contain eligible deposits are marked so they can be identified immediately. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] In addition to applying that marking approach, the PRA expects the firm to be able to provide the PRA or the FSCS with account details that distinguish eligible accounts from ineligible accounts, so that the eligibility status is separately identifiable in what is provided. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] The information must be made available in a format that aligns with the relevant rule and the PRA’s statement, and it must be deliverable quickly enough to support immediate identification in practice when a request is made. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Specifically, the firm must be able to produce and provide those separately identified details within twelve hours starting from the time the PRA or the FSCS makes the request. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Taken together, this means the marking obligation applies to the relevant beneficiary-held accounts, and the firm must also have operational readiness to extract and supply eligibility-separated account data to the PRA or FSCS on request within the stated twelve-hour window. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: When you’re working out how much capital a firm should hold in the PRA’s capital stack, what is the PRA buffer meant to do and what exact items make up the combined buffer (including any extra item that applies only to ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies)?
gold_answer: In the PRA’s capital stack, the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an extra amount of capital the firm should maintain on top of its total capital requirement (TCR) and on top of the combined buffer. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] Its purpose is to absorb losses that could occur under a severe stress scenario, and it is designed to avoid overlapping with (ie duplicating) the combined buffers. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] The combined buffer that sits alongside the PRA buffer and the TCR is made up of specific named components: the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), and the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] There is also an additional component that applies only for certain firms: for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies, the combined buffer includes the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer). [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7] Putting these together, the firm identifies the combined buffer from those components and then adds the PRA buffer above it, alongside meeting the TCR, to reflect the PRA’s overall capital framework. [#SRC:37bcd95fb7b21224] [#TGT:9c1fa36fe39c19a7]
source_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.
target_text: 33. The combined buffer comprises the Capital Conservation Buffer (CCoB), the Countercyclical Buffer (CCyB), the buffer for global systemically important institutions (G-SIIs) and (for ring-fenced banks and the largest building societies) the other systemically important institutions buffer (O-SII buffer).

question: When preparing the Statement for a merger under paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act, how should a society address any proposed member bonus in the Statement and in the Merger Resolutions, including how the required scope of member approval changes depending on whether the total gross cost of the bonus(es) is within or exceeds the prescribed limit?
gold_answer: A society should treat any proposed member bonus as a matter that must be both disclosed in the merger Statement and put to members for approval through the Merger Resolutions, with the breadth of the resolutions depending on the prescribed-limit test. The Statement must state the bonus (if any) that is to be paid to members as consideration for the merger, so the document needs an explicit specification of that payment. [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] In parallel, member approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions, and the PRA’s view on what may constitute a bonus is referenced for that purpose. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] For structuring the approvals, the relevant cost measure is the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), assessed without adjusting for any prospective corporation tax recovery. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If that gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval only needs to be included in each Merger Resolution of the society whose funds are to be distributed; if it exceeds the limit, it must be included in each Merger Resolution of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This approach aligns the Statement’s required disclosure of the bonus with the resolutions-based approval mechanism for paying it. [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]
source_text: Paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act requires the Statement to specify the bonus, if any, to be paid to members in consideration of the merger. The PRA’s views on what may, or may not, be regarded as bonus are given in paragraphs 3.41 to 3.42 , and the statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission, what does it need to do about uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from assets with highly predictable cash-flows, and how should that feed into its SCR stress calculation for changes to the FS and MA?
gold_answer: The firm must first identify every source of uncertainty about the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets whose cash-flows are highly predictable. [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35] Those identified uncertainties should then be treated as part of the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed when the firm builds its SCR, because the SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks the firm faces. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] The SCR calculation should be constructed so it can reflect how a stress event could change the FS and MA, meaning the firm should assess how the cash-flow uncertainties could affect the FS and MA and ensure that effect is captured in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] When modelling stress conditions, the firm should include changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including additions made through the attestation process. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] In addition, for assets with highly predictable cash flows, the SCR should explicitly allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern and for changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment, so the uncertainty identification is linked to the stress impacts reflected in the SCR. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]
source_text: A firm’s SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks 6 to which it is exposed. The calculation of the SCR should therefore allow for any changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. In doing this, firms should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed, how these risks could affect the FS and MA and assess how this impact is captured within the SCR calculation. Changes to the FS in stress conditions should include any changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including those made as part of the attestation process. For assets with HP cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets as well as any changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment 8 .
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty regarding the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable .

question: At the point of initial investment, if a firm cannot develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS due to data scarcity, how should it reconcile proposing a simpler (standard) methodology with the expectation to model a term structure, and what demonstration is needed to justify using a uniform allowance instead?
gold_answer: A firm that cannot build a robust methodology for the addition to the FS at the point of initial investment (for example because of data scarcity) may propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, but it should still treat term-structure modelling as the default expectation unless it can justify a uniform allowance. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] In practice, the firm can start with a standard approach (and include safeguards aimed at protecting the quality of matching), while assessing whether it can meet the conditions for not modelling a term structure. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] To rely on a uniform allowance rather than modelling a term structure for the addition to the FS, the firm needs to be able to demonstrate two points: (1) that using a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and (2) that it would not materially affect either the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests. [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] Where the firm proceeds with a standard methodology due to initial-investment constraints, the PRA indicates it does not necessarily expect the firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as referenced in the earlier paragraph, but the firm must still align its approach with the term-structure expectation or the uniform-allowance demonstration. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c]
source_text: The PRA understands that, at the point of initial investment, in many cases it may not be possible to develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS, for example due to data scarcity. Firms may therefore propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, together with any safeguards that could mitigate the risks to the quality of matching. The PRA does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as set out in paragraph 5.21 above.
target_text: Firms should model a term structure for the addition to the FS unless it can be demonstrated that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for the risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests.

question: If a firm has some health insurance based on actuarial principles and some other general insurance business, what does it do first under 8.2 to 8.6, and then what amount does it multiply by the percentage used for 7.10?
gold_answer: It must split the calculation by business type first, and only then apply the 7.10 percentage to the relevant sum(s). When 8.6 applies to a firm whose general insurance business is partly health insurance based on actuarial principles and partly other business, the steps in 8.2 to 8.6 have to be run separately for each part of the business. [#TGT:da680341ca9e8782] Doing that separate run is meant to produce a sum under 8.6 for the health insurance part and a sum under 8.5 for the other business part. [#TGT:da680341ca9e8782] After the firm has the sum arrived at under 8.6 (and, if applicable, any sum arrived at under 8.7), it must multiply the relevant amount by the same percentage that applies for the purposes of 7.10. [#SRC:c8340ee9a644c3f3] The multiplication rule covers either a single sum (under 8.6 or 8.7) or the aggregate of the sums under 8.6 and 8.7, depending on what has been calculated. [#SRC:c8340ee9a644c3f3] In other words, the split-business requirement determines how the 8.6 figure is produced for health insurance, and the multiplication requirement determines how that 8.6 (and any 8.7) figure is then scaled using the 7.10 percentage. [#TGT:da680341ca9e8782][#SRC:c8340ee9a644c3f3]
source_text: A firm must multiply the sum arrived at under 8.6 or 8.7 , or the aggregate of the sums arrived at under 8.6 and 8.7 , by the same percentage as is applicable for the purposes of 7.10 .
target_text: Where 8.6 applies to a firm whose general insurance business consists partly of health insurance based on actuarial principles and partly of other business, 8.2 to 8.6 must operate separately for each part of the general insurance business , so as to produce a sum under 8.6 for the health insurance and a sum under 8.5 for the other business.

question: When a G-SII uses the derogation that permits Article 441 information to be disclosed separately from the standalone document referenced in Article 434(1), how does that interact with the general requirement that Titles II and III disclosures be provided in electronic format and in a single medium or location, and what form must that single medium or location take?
gold_answer: A G-SII that relies on the derogation may place the information required under Article 441 in a different medium or location than the standalone document referenced in Article 434(1), even though institutions generally must publish required disclosures in one place. [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] The baseline rule is that institutions must disclose all information required under Titles II and III electronically and in a single medium or location. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] That single medium or location must be either (i) a standalone document that serves as a readily accessible source of prudential information for users, or (ii) a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports that contains the required disclosures and is easily identifiable to those users. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] In applying the derogation, the institution can therefore keep the Titles II and III disclosures organized in the required single electronic medium or location meeting the specified form, while allowing the Article 441 information to be disclosed separately from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1). [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]
source_text: By way of derogation from Article 434(1) , where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1 , it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.

question: For a firm carrying on long-term insurance business, how must it treat the unpaid initial fund and implicit items related to future profits and zillmerising when ensuring its margin of solvency does not fall below the guarantee fund?
gold_answer: A firm carrying on long-term insurance business must ensure that its margin of solvency remains at or above the guarantee fund, and it must do so without relying on certain items that are disallowed for compliance purposes. [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9] Specifically, in the long-term insurance business context, the unpaid initial fund of a firm cannot be counted, and implicit items connected with future profits and zillmerising also cannot be counted, when complying with the relevant requirement referenced as 4.2. [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1] Read together, this means that when the firm assesses and maintains its margin of solvency against the guarantee fund threshold, it should not include the unpaid initial fund or those implicit future-profit/zillmerising items as part of what it uses to meet the compliance calculation under 4.2. [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1] The practical compliance outcome is that the firm must maintain sufficient solvency margin above the guarantee fund based on other permissible components, because the excluded items cannot be taken into account for that compliance purpose. [#TGT:0515d4099ee613d9] [#SRC:7c720b1aa8fe3fa1]
source_text: In the case of long-term insurance business , the unpaid initial fund of a firm and implicit items which relate to future profits and zillmerising may not be taken into account in complying with 4.2 .
target_text: A firm must ensure that its margin of solvency does not fall below the guarantee fund .

question: If a derivative has several important risk drivers and at least one of them puts it in the commodity risk category, when do you map it to more than one risk category, and how do you then pick the risk driver to place it into a commodity hedging set (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3))?
gold_answer: You must handle the mapping step first, and then use the commodity-specific rule to place the transaction into a hedging set once it is in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] If the derivative has more than one material risk driver, you generally map it to more than one risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] However, if all of its material risk drivers are within the same risk category, you only map it once to that single category, and you base that mapping on the most material of those risk drivers. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If its material risk drivers sit in different risk categories, you map it once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and for each category you use the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for the mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), you must assign it to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or (for those Article 277(3) transactions) the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When drafting outsourcing terms for a material outsourced function, how should a firm address (i) the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider, and (ii) the PRA’s expectation that service providers are made aware of the Bank and PRA’s statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers (including the effect of any failure to provide that awareness)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the contractual inspection and audit rights for a material outsourced function as a distinct requirement, while also ensuring the service provider is informed about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers that may apply directly to the provider. The outsourcing arrangement should include the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function. [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa] In parallel, and explicitly independent of later chapter expectations on access, audit, and information rights, the firm should make the service provider aware that the Bank and PRA have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply to outsourced service providers as well as firms. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The PRA expects firms to communicate the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 (noting those tables are not exhaustive), so the provider understands the potential direct reach of those powers beyond the contract’s audit/inspection clauses. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] Importantly, even if the firm does not make the provider aware of these powers and requirements, that failure does not change whether the powers apply. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]
source_text: the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function (see Chapter 8 );
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: If a firm is planning a solvent exit, what does it need to do about paying back or transferring deposits and making sure it has enough time and resources, and what extra thing should it consider if it is a building society (given that a solvent exit might not end in liquidation)?
gold_answer: In a solvent exit, the firm is expected to stop its PRA-regulated activities while staying solvent, and it should plan to transfer and/or repay all deposits as part of that exit. [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] The planning should include enough time and resources to allow the firm to meet its liabilities when they fall due while it carries out the deposit transfers and/or repayments, and the firm should anticipate that the solvent exit ends when deposit-taking is removed from its Part 4A permission or when its Part 4A permission is cancelled (removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] Separately, the firm should recognize that a solvent exit does not automatically mean the firm will be liquidated, because that outcome depends on the circumstances. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654] If the firm is a building society, it should connect its deposit transfer/repayment plan to the fact that completing that step will mean it no longer meets the principal purpose test, and it should also consider what steps are needed for dissolution under the Building Societies Act 1986. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]
source_text: A solvent exit means the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent. 2 The firm should transfer 3 or repay (or both) all deposits as part of its solvent exit. 4 In the firm’s solvent exit planning, it should build in sufficient time and resources to support the firm in meeting liabilities when they fall due and in transferring and/or repaying all deposits. At a point after this, a solvent exit will end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission, or with the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (hereinafter referred to as the removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). 5
target_text: 4. A solvent exit does not necessarily result in the liquidation of the firm, as it depends on the circumstances. If the firm is a building society, the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits will mean it ceases to meet the principal purpose test. Therefore, a building society should also take into account steps which are necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986.

question: When a credit union is considering a transaction that is a loan provided on subordinated terms, how should it determine whether the Chapter 11 investment expectations apply, given the expectation for credit unions investing in more complex investments under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: A loan provided by a credit union on subordinated terms is treated as not being an investment for the purposes of the Chapter that contains that definition, so it would not fall within “investment” categorisation in that Chapter on that basis alone. [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1] Separately, where a credit union does invest in more complex investments under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, it is expected to follow the investment expectations in Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1–11.6). [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4] Putting these together, the credit union should first classify the proposed subordinated loan under the Chapter’s definition (i.e., confirm it is a loan on subordinated terms and therefore not an investment for that Chapter), and then apply Chapter 11 expectations only to activities that are “investing in more complex investments” under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8), rather than to the subordinated loan merely because it involves deploying funds. [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1] [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4] This linkage matters because the Chapter 11 expectations are framed as applying to credit unions’ more complex investments under those specific rules, while the subordinated-loan provision narrows what counts as an investment within the Chapter’s scope. [#SRC:424fed32b68149c4] [#TGT:3e9e53999c7170f1]
source_text: Credit unions that invest in more complex investments under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook are expected to adhere to the investment expectations set out in Chapter 11 (paragraphs 11.1-11.6 ).
target_text: For the purposes of this Chapter, a loan is not an investment if it is provided by a credit union on subordinated terms.

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the proportional share held by the participating undertaking be applied to data from related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, and how does this interact with the instruction that this inclusion applies notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A and must follow points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A?
gold_answer: In calculating the solvency of a group, the calculation must reflect the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings, and that proportional-share approach is also the basis for including data from related undertakings that are linked by a common management relationship. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] Practically, this means that where the group’s solvency calculation needs to take account of related undertakings, the participating undertaking’s proportional share is the measure used to determine the extent to which those related undertakings are reflected in the group calculation. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] For related undertakings linked by a common management relationship, their data must be included using that proportional-share basis, and the inclusion is to be carried out in line with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A rather than being excluded or altered due to point (4) of 11.1A. [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] The linkage is that the group solvency calculation’s requirement to take account of proportional share is implemented, for common-management related undertakings, through the specific instruction to include their data proportionally and to do so under the specified points of 11.1A even where point (4) of 11.1A might otherwise be relevant. [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc] [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]
source_text: Notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship shall be included in accordance with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A on the basis of the proportional share as referred to in Chapter 8 .
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: If a firm has an option, when does it count as having acquired or disposed of assets for valuation purposes, and what does it then do to the values it has worked out under 18 to 19 for that type of asset?
gold_answer: The firm only treats itself as having acquired or disposed of assets because of an option when, at the relevant date, it is a party to the option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, and the option is one that fits the rule’s description for 20.1. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] Once that deemed acquisition or disposal applies, the firm must adjust the value it has ascribed under 18 to 19 for each asset description by incorporating the value of the assets of that same description that are deemed acquired or disposed of under the option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] Concretely, the firm should (i) determine whether the relevant-date conditions for being deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option are met, and (ii) if they are, increase or decrease the 18 to 19 value for that asset description by the value of the assets deemed acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] The adjustment is made at the level of “assets of each description,” so the deemed option effect is applied to the matching category rather than being treated as a general, undifferentiated change. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]
source_text: For the purposes of 20.1 , the firm must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option if, at the relevant date , it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised and the option is one which:
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .

question: What does the text say non-executive directors must do (including what “independence of mind” looks like in board decisions), and where is the related EU law reference shown (Article 91(8) of the Capital Requirements Directive 2013/36/EU)?
gold_answer: The text says that all non-executive directors who are members of the management body—whether independent or not—have a binding obligation to act with honesty, integrity, and independence of mind. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] It also clarifies that “independence of mind” is not just a label but a pattern of behaviour that shows up especially during board discussions and decision-making, where each board member should be able to reach sound, objective, and independent decisions and judgements. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] Alongside that, the same passage ties these expectations to specified internal conduct requirements by stating that non-executive directors are required under Rules 2.1–2.3 and 3.4 in the Conduct Rules Part of the Rulebook to act with integrity, due skill, care and diligence, and to be open and co-operative with regulators. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] The related EU law reference is shown separately as a citation to “Article 91(8) Capital Requirements Directive (2013/36/EU),” including a link to the legislation source, which is the explicit place where the EU provision is identified in the provided materials. [#TGT:f668b599884eb746]
source_text: As members of the management body, all non-executive directors, whether independent or not, have a binding obligation to act with honesty, integrity and independence of mind 53 and are required under Rules 2.1 - 2.3 and 3.4 in the Conduct Rules Part of the Rulebook to act with integrity, due skill, care and diligence and to be open and co-operative with regulators 54 . Independence of mind is a pattern of behaviour, shown in particular during discussions and decision making at the board. All members of the board should be able to make their own sound, objective and independent decisions and judgements. 55 Banks should consider the appropriate number of non-executive directors who are significant shareholders or who are appointed or nominated by a significant shareholder.
target_text: 53. Article 91(8) Capital Requirements Directive (2013/36/EU): https://www.legislation.gov.uk/eudr/2013/36/article/91 .

question: When a firm is determining its basic own funds and has a participation in a financial and credit institution that triggers a full-value reduction because it exceeds the 10% threshold, how should the firm proceed if a straightforward application of Own Funds 3K.5 is not possible, including how it should identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment applies?
gold_answer: The firm must reduce its basic own funds by the full value of any participation in a financial and credit institution that exceeds 10% of the specified items included in 3A.1(1)(a), 3A.1(1)(b), 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f), for the purpose of determining its basic own funds. [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] In applying that reduction, the firm should observe Guidelines 4 and 5 because they support the calculations required by Own Funds 3K, which frames how the relevant amounts are worked out. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] If the reduction is a deduction from own-funds and the firm cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a straightforward way, it should follow Guideline 6 to determine which tier of own-funds the adjustment should be applied to. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] This means the firm first identifies whether the participation exceeds the 10% threshold against the referenced 3A.1(1) items and then executes the required full-value reduction in basic own funds, while using the guideline support for the calculation and, where needed, using Guideline 6 to allocate the deduction to the appropriate own-funds tier. [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]
source_text: Firms should observe Guidelines 4 and 5 which support the carrying out of the calculations required by Own Funds 3K . Where a deduction from own-funds is necessary, and where a straightforward application of Own Funds 3K.5 is not possible, firms should follow Guideline 6 to identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment should apply.
target_text: A firm must, for the purpose of determining its basic own funds , reduce its basic own funds by the full value of participations , as referred to in 3K.6 , in a financial and credit institution that exceeds 10% of items included in 3A.1(1)(a) , 3A.1(1)(b) , 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f) .

question: If a firm is new and hasn’t finished a full financial year yet, what valuation should it use to pay periodic fees in its first fee year, and what should it use in its second fee year if it got its new or extended permission between 1 January (in its first fee year) and 1 April (in its second fee year)?
gold_answer: The firm should use projected valuation in both situations described, but the trigger conditions differ between the first and second fee years. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] In the first fee year, the periodic fees are paid based on the firm’s projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] For the second fee year, the projected-valuation approach applies only where the firm has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year and it is in its second fee year, and it received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity during the period from 1 January in its first fee year to 1 April in its second fee year. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] When those second-fee-year conditions are met, the firm should apply projected valuations in the way referenced (as set out in 3.7). [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] Linking the two passages, the first-fee-year rule establishes projected valuation as the basis for periodic fees for the first twelve months of new business, and the second-fee-year rule extends the use of projected valuations into the second fee year for firms that are still without a completed full financial year and that obtained the relevant permission within the stated date window. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6]

question: Where a firm has established a specific, independent and autonomous internal channel for disclosure of reportable concerns, what must the firm do to ensure that workers in a third country firm’s UK establishment can use that channel, and what information must be provided to the third country firm in the UK?
gold_answer: The firm must both (i) have an internal disclosure channel that meets the required characteristics and (ii) ensure that this channel is operationally extended to the relevant UK establishment of the third country firm, with appropriate information provided to enable use. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] Specifically, the firm is required to establish, implement and maintain arrangements that allow a person (including a firm’s employee) to disclose reportable concerns internally via a channel that is specific, independent and autonomous. [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6] In addition, the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK about the channel identified in 2A.2, and it must make that channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] Taken together, this means the firm cannot treat the internal channel as limited to its own direct employees: it must ensure the channel is available for use by workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment and must communicate the necessary channel information to the third country firm in the UK so that disclosures of reportable concerns can be made through that internal channel. [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e] [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6]
source_text: the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK on the channel in 2A.2 and make the channel available to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment.
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement and maintain appropriate and effective arrangements for the disclosure of reportable concerns by a person , including a firm’s employee , internally through a specific, independent and autonomous channel.

question: When the PRA assesses a firm’s ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP (and, for major UK firms, alongside the Bank’s annual stress test (AST)), what specific aspects of the firm’s projected stress results and scenario impacts does the assessment focus on?
gold_answer: In the SREP, the PRA’s assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing is directed at judging whether the firm’s stress-testing outputs and supporting rationale are credible, and for major UK firms this SREP work is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). [#SRC:7a56cad9ade1c41e] Within that assessment, the PRA evaluates the credibility and reasonableness of the firm’s projected stress results and the assumptions used to build those projections. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] The assessment then concentrates on how the stress scenario adversely affects the firm’s capital position, specifically where it reduces capital resources and increases capital requirements. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] It also examines the nature and severity of the scenario that underpins the stress results, as part of determining whether the projected outcomes are reasonable. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] Finally, the assessment considers the reasonableness of any mitigating actions the firm proposes to mitigate the impact of the stress, linking the projected capital impacts to the firm’s planned responses. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]
source_text: The PRA carries out an assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP. 40 For the major UK firms this is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). 41
target_text: The assessment considers the credibility and reasonableness of firms’ projected stress results and the underlying assumptions on which the stress projections are build. The assessment focusses on the areas where the stress scenario adversely impacts firms’ capital positions (ie reducing capital resources and increasing capital requirements), the nature and severity of the scenario on which the stress results are based and the reasonableness of mitigating actions firms propose to mitigate the impact of the stress.

question: If you are checking what a firm or FMI needs to follow, what do you do if a guideline isn’t in Appendices 1–3, and how do you treat ESMA guideline updates that came out after the end of the transition period (even if ESMA is the source of the linked materials)?
gold_answer: You should not treat Appendices 1 to 3 as a complete checklist: even if a predecessor committee’s Guidelines and Recommendations are missing from those lists, firms and FMIs should still comply with them where relevant, unless they have been revoked or replaced by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] Separately, when working within the scope of this SoP, you should use the ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations that were in place at the end of the transition period (the SoP provides links to those), and you should disregard changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and any new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period because they are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024] Put together, your review should (i) allow for relevant predecessor materials even if unlisted, subject to revocation/supersession, and (ii) freeze the ESMA set at the end-of-transition point for SoP relevance, even though the Bank and PRA acknowledge ESMA as the source of the linked materials. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024]
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.

Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. question: If the voting date is after the society’s AGM that year, what date should be used as the qualifying shareholding date for a shareholding members resolution, and can someone use an overdrawn share account to count as holding shares or being a member on that date?
gold_answer: If the voting date happens after the society’s AGM in that financial year, the qualifying shareholding date is not the prior year-end; it is the first day of the period that begins 56 days before the meeting date. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] Once that date (and any related period-based test) is identified, the person must meet any “hold shares on a given date” or “hold shares during a given period” condition through genuine shareholding, because an overdrawn share account cannot be used to satisfy a shareholding requirement for a specific date or period. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] The same restriction applies to any requirement to be a member on a given date (such as the kind of membership-on-a-date condition referenced at paragraph 3.111(a)): holding an overdrawn share account does not count as meeting that membership condition. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] Put together, for a shareholding members resolution where the voting date is later than the AGM and the society’s Rules include the shareholding/continuity provisions described in paragraph 3.110, the society should (i) set the qualifying shareholding date using the 56-day lookback rule and (ii) reject overdrawn share accounts as a basis for meeting either shareholding or membership-on-a-date tests tied to that qualifying date. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407]
source_text: There is no requirement for continuity of shareholding between paragraphs 3.111(a) and (b) (In contrast, in the case of an ordinary or special resolution, membership at paragraph 3.111(a) may be satisfied by either borrowing or shareholding membership provided the shareholding member satisfies the other conditions of paragraph 3.111(b) to (d) in order to vote in his or her capacity as a shareholder). Note also that a person cannot meet a requirement for holding shares on a given date, or during a given period, by relying on his holding of a share account with an overdrawn balance; and a person cannot meet a requirement for being a member on a given date (for example, at paragraph 3.111(a) ) by relying on his holding of such a share account.

question: If a derivative has more than one material risk driver, when do institutions map it once versus mapping it to multiple risk categories, and how does that fit with the idea that mapping is based on the primary risk driver (the only material risk driver)?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply the special mapping approach for derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver, while also recognizing that mapping is otherwise performed using the primary risk driver, which is defined as the only material risk driver of the transaction. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1] When the transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions map it to more than one risk category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The “map once” outcome happens when all of the transaction’s material risk drivers sit in the same risk category: in that case, the institution maps the transaction only a single time to that category, using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The “map multiple times” outcome happens when the material risk drivers belong to different risk categories: then the institution maps the transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, and in each category the mapping is based on the most material risk driver within that category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Separately, where mapping is conducted on the basis of the primary risk driver, the mapping is anchored to that primary risk driver and treats it as the only material risk driver. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.
target_text: Institutions shall conduct the mapping referred to in paragraph 1 on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction. The primary risk driver shall be the only material risk driver of a derivative transaction.

question: If a merger plan includes a bonus to help balance reserves because the transferor society has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society, and the plan might also pay a bonus to the transferee society’s members, which societies’ Merger Resolutions need to ask members to approve the bonus—especially when the total gross cost is above or below the prescribed limit?
gold_answer: You need member approval for the bonus payments through the Merger Resolutions, and which societies must put that approval to members depends on (1) whose funds will be paid out and (2) whether the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] The fact that the bonus is being used to equalise reserves—such as paying members of a transferor society that has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society—does not remove the need to follow the Merger Resolution approval approach, and any decision to also pay a bonus to members of the transferee society must only proceed where it is prudent to equalise the combined society’s reserves at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6] Apply the prescribed-limit test using the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery). [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If that gross cost is within the prescribed limit, only the society whose funds are being distributed needs to include the bonus approval in each of its Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then every participating society must include the bonus approval in each of its Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] In parallel, the reserve-equalisation design (including whether both sets of members receive a bonus) should be framed around the prudence condition described for setting the combined society’s reserve level. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]
source_text: A bonus may, for example, be paid to the members of a transferor society with a higher capital ratio than the transferee society so as to equalise the reserves which both bring to the combined society. If it is thought desirable also to pay a bonus to the members of the transferee society, then the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the capital ratio of the transferee society, but only if it is prudent to do so. The statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: When a CRR firm writes its self-assessment, what group-related risks does it need to look for, and what specific kind of test must the CRR consolidation entity run for each important group business service (including who is covered and what disruption is assumed)?
gold_answer: In its self-assessment, a CRR firm needs to look for any extra risks coming from elsewhere in its group that could affect its ability to keep delivering important business services within the set impact tolerances. [#SRC:525172756112897c] For a CRR firm, that self-assessment must also draw on the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services, which includes checking whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group that provides each important group business service would still be able to stay within the impact tolerance set for that service. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] The test the CRR consolidation entity must apply is framed around a “severe but plausible disruption” to the provider’s operations, and the assessment is done service-by-service for the important group business services. [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] Putting these together, the CRR firm’s self-assessment should combine (1) identification of group-originating risks to meeting impact tolerances and (2) the consolidation entity’s disruption-based assessment across the consolidation group members that provide the relevant important group business services. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]
source_text: identify any additional risks to their ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances arising from elsewhere in their group. In the case of a CRR firm, the self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken to comply with the requirements under Rules 8.6 , 8.7 and 8.8 , regarding important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance.
target_text: A CRR consolidation entity must assess whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group providing each important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that important group business service in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.

question: When a firm is determining whether an outsourcing or third party arrangement is a “material outsourcing” for PRA purposes, how should it reconcile the PRA’s use of “material outsourcing” (including its relationship to “critical or important outsourcing”) with the expectation to apply the Table 5 criteria, particularly where the arrangement involves an ICT product or service such as cloud?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the PRA’s term “material outsourcing” as the operative classification for its assessment, recognising that the PRA views it as covering what other frameworks describe as “critical or important outsourcing.” [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] In practical terms, that means the firm’s materiality assessment should be performed by having regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5, considering those criteria both individually and together, for any outsourcing or third party arrangement that is not already addressed by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] The firm should also understand that the PRA’s approach is intended to align, in substance, with the criteria used to identify “critical or important outsourcing arrangements” under the EBA Outsourcing GL, while allowing for some justified exceptions (including exceptions that reference the PRA’s operational resilience requirements). [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] When the arrangement involves ICT products or services (for example, cloud), the firm should not treat the mere presence of ICT as determinative; instead, it must still apply the Table 5 criteria to decide whether the arrangement is material. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] Overall, the firm’s conclusion on materiality should come from applying the Table 5 criteria within the PRA’s “material outsourcing” framing, rather than assuming ICT involvement or alternative terminology automatically sets the outcome. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1]
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms to have regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5 below, both individually and in conjunction, when assessing the materiality of an outsourcing or third party arrangement not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9 . Although in practice many material outsourcing and third party arrangements involve ICT products or services (eg cloud), the presence of a given ICT product or service does not, in itself, automatically render an outsourcing arrangement material.

question: When making an application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, how should the board’s declaration address other merger or takeover proposals, and how does that interact with the requirement to notify members of prescribed particulars when a proposal has been received (including the timing relative to AGM and special meeting notices for Merger Resolutions)?
gold_answer: In applying to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the application must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also explicitly state whether any other merger or takeover proposals exist (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information provided about those proposals is correct. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] Where a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must also ensure members receive a notification containing the prescribed particulars, sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] This notification may be delivered as a standalone communication or bundled with each notice of the society’s annual general meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] In addition, if the prescribed-particulars notification has not already been provided, it must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Practically, the board’s declaration about other proposals supports completeness and accuracy in the PRA submission, while the member-notification duty governs how and when prescribed particulars about received proposals must be communicated around AGM and special-meeting notices. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] [#TGT:e13932686034a534]
source_text: Schedule 16 Statements must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports. An application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board, that the Statement is complete and includes all material information of which, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware. That declaration should say whether or not there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise see paragraph 3.89 – 3.90 ) and confirm that the information about them is correct. The application should be accompanied by the following documents:
target_text: If a proposal of either kind has been received, then notification of the prescribed particulars must be sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting, either separately or together with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting, and (where such notification has not already been given) must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved.

question: For purposes of applying the MRM expectations in the supervisory statement, which UK-incorporated regulated firms are in scope because they have internal model approval, and how does that scope align with the specific types of internally developed models used to calculate regulatory capital requirements?
gold_answer: Firms in scope for the MRM expectations are regulated United Kingdom (UK)-incorporated banks, building societies, and PRA-designated investment firms that have internal model approval to calculate regulatory capital requirements. [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5] The relevant internal model approval is described as approval to use internally developed models for calculating regulatory capital requirements for credit risk under Internal Ratings Based approaches, for market risk under the Internal Model Approach, or for counterparty credit risk under the Internal Model Method. [#TGT:73ca40c7f7a5494b] In practical terms, a firm should treat itself as within scope when it meets both elements: (i) it is one of the UK-incorporated regulated firm types identified (bank, building society, or PRA-designated investment firm), and (ii) its internal model approval relates to one or more of the specified internally developed model categories used for regulatory capital calculations (credit risk IRB, market risk IMA, or counterparty credit risk IMM). [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5] [#TGT:73ca40c7f7a5494b] Conversely, the supervisory statement’s expectations are stated not to apply to firms without permission to use internal models to calculate regulatory capital, and also not to third-country firms operating in the UK through a branch; this exclusion would apply even if such firms use models, because the scope hinges on the UK-incorporated regulated firm set and the relevant permission/approval. [#SRC:2eaafa63a784aad5]
source_text: This SS is relevant to all regulated United Kingdom (UK)-incorporated banks, building societies and PRA-designated investment firms with internal model approval to calculate regulatory capital requirements. 2 The expectations in this SS do not apply to firms which do not have permission to use internal models to calculate regulatory capital and third-country firms operating in the UK through a branch. However, the PRA considers that those firms may find the proposed principles useful, and are welcome to consider them to manage model risk within their firm. Credit unions, insurers, and reinsurers are not in scope of the MRM expectations in this supervisory statement.
target_text: 2. These are firms with approval to use internally developed models to calculate regulatory capital requirements for credit risk (Internal Ratings Based approaches), market risk (Internal Model Approach) or counterparty credit risk (Internal Model Method).

question: If a bank wants to follow the EBA Outsourcing GL in the UK, what does this SS say it adds (name the chapters it expands on), and where on the PRA website can the bank find the EBA Outsourcing GL (give the exact link)?
gold_answer: For UK use of the EBA Outsourcing GL, the SS says it serves to clarify how the PRA expects banks to approach the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ in light of the PRA’s own requirements and expectations. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] The SS also states that it expands on the expectations in the EBA Outsourcing GL in certain parts, and it gives concrete examples by naming Chapter 7 (data security) and Chapter 10 (business continuity and exit plans). [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] Separately, the PRA explains that its website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period, and it indicates that the EBA Outsourcing GL are available there. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] The PRA provides the specific web address where the EBA Outsourcing GL can be accessed: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] In practice, a bank would use the PRA-hosted EBA Outsourcing GL as the base document and then use the SS to understand the PRA’s clarifications and the additional detail it provides for Chapters 7 and 10. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9][#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0]
source_text: European Banking Authority (EBA) ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ (EBA Outsourcing GL). 2 This SS clarifies how the PRA expects banks to approach the EBA Outsourcing GL in the context of its requirements and expectations. In addition, certain chapters in this SS expand on the expectations in the EBA Outsourcing GL, for instance Chapters 7 (Data security) and 10 (Business continuity and exit plans); and 3
target_text: 2. The PRA website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period. The EBA Outsourcing GL are available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf .
