question: For a firm’s solvent exit preparations, how should it design and evidence “adequate assurance activities” around the solvent exit analysis, including who may perform the assurance and how governance challenge and approval should be handled, and how does this interact with the requirement to review and update the analysis at least every three years or after a material change?
gold_answer: A firm should put in place assurance activities that are sufficient to provide confidence in its solvent exit preparations, and it may choose to conduct those activities either internally or externally. [#SRC:ea9ddbd597480228] In practice, examples of such assurance include having internal audit or external specialists review the solvent exit analysis, and ensuring the firm’s governance body provides robust challenge (including challenge from non-executive directors). [#TGT:0b2dcaf71653c0b9] The assurance approach should be applied to the solvent exit analysis as it is maintained over time, meaning the firm should revisit the analysis whenever a material change occurs that could affect solvent exit preparations and, in any event, at least once every three years. [#SRC:ea9ddbd597480228] The accountable executive has specific governance responsibilities: they should ensure the solvent exit analysis is approved in line with the firm’s governance arrangements, and they should confirm that the firm meets the expectations in the supervisory statement. [#SRC:ea9ddbd597480228] The firm should also be able to provide the PRA, upon request, with the current version of its solvent exit analysis, which reinforces the need for assurance and governance challenge to be demonstrable on the up-to-date document. [#SRC:ea9ddbd597480228]
source_text: A firm should undertake adequate assurance activities for its solvent exit preparations as described in this Chapter. These assurance activities can be performed internally, or externally as the firm considers appropriate. 37 The firm should review and update the solvent exit analysis whenever a material change has taken place that may affect its preparations for a solvent exit, and at least once every three years. 38 The accountable executive should ensure that the solvent exit analysis is approved in accordance with the firm’s governance arrangements. 39 The accountable executive should also confirm that the firm meets the expectations in this SS. The firm should be able to provide to the PRA on request the current version of its solvent exit analysis. 40
target_text: 37. Examples of assurance activities include a review by parties such as internal audit or external specialists; and obtaining sufficient challenge from the firm’s governance body (including non-executive directors) on the solvent exit analysis.

question: When directors of a society are contemplating a transfer and the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, how should the directors align their internal readiness work (including consultation with external auditors or other advisers) with the society’s obligation to apply to the PRA for confirmation in the manner the PRA may direct, and what PRA decision points are implicated at approval of the Transfer Statement and at confirmation?
gold_answer: The directors should treat systems readiness as a prerequisite that supports the society’s ability to make a proper application for PRA confirmation once the Transfer Resolutions have been passed, and they should plan for PRA scrutiny both at Transfer Statement approval and at the later confirmation stage. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] Before the society applies, the directors must satisfy themselves—working with external auditors or other advisers—that the society’s systems can produce the relevant information, because the PRA will require an assurance on that capability when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] After the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the manner the PRA may direct, and the transfer cannot take effect until the PRA has confirmed it. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] In preparing for confirmation, the directors should also anticipate that one criterion the PRA considers at confirmation is whether a relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled, which makes early assurance work and procedural compliance directly relevant to the confirmation outcome. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]
source_text: The directors of a society contemplating a transfer must satisfy themselves, in consultation with their external auditors, or other advisers, that the society’s systems are capable of delivering the information described above. The PRA will require an assurance on this point when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. One of the criteria which the PRA has to consider at the confirmation stage is whether some relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled (see section ‘ Confirmation ’).
target_text: No transfer can take effect until it has been confirmed by the PRA. This section first describes the form of application and public notice required. It then explains the PRA view of how the statutory Confirmation Criteria should be interpreted. Finally, it gives guidance on the procedure customarily followed by the PRA when considering confirmation applications and hearing representations. Sections 97(4)(d) and 98(2) of, together with Part II of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, provide that when the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in such manner as the PRA may direct.

question: When a society sends a Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary with the meeting notice, how should it assess whether an omission in sending those materials (or a failure of receipt) can be treated as an “accidental omission” that does not invalidate the meeting, and what types of management or system issues should be treated as outside that protection for purposes of the scrutineers’ report?
gold_answer: The society should treat the Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary as part of the notice package that must be provided to every person entitled to receive it, and then evaluate any gap in sending or receipt against the limited “accidental omission/non-receipt” protection referenced for meeting validity and scrutineer review. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] In practice, the scrutineers’ report may take into account that an accidental omission to give notice, or non-receipt of notice, by an entitled person does not of itself invalidate the meeting proceedings. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] However, the society should not assume that every internal mistake qualifies as “accidental,” because the protection does not extend to all cases of “error” by the society/management. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] Specifically, “accidental omission” excludes systemic failures to send notices, such as failures affecting new shareholders or borrowers, or omission of a group/class due to a faulty computer programme or mailing list issue. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] Likewise, an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups should be treated as outside the “accidental/non-receipt” category when assessing validity and reporting. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] Accordingly, the society should distinguish isolated, genuinely accidental lapses from systemic or deliberate/erroneous management choices when documenting notice compliance and supporting the scrutineers’ conclusions. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0]
source_text: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the notice to every person entitled to receive it (paragraphs 2 and 4 of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, ‘accidental omission’ does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new shareholders or borrowers, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management – see also paragraph 4.153 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers’ report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that ‘accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting does not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting’. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that ‘accidental’ and ‘non-receipt’ would not cover all cases of ‘error’ on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: When setting a firm’s provision for expenses for valuation purposes, how must the firm combine (i) the minimum amount needed on prudent assumptions to cover the total net cost (after taxation) of fulfilling contracts if it stopped writing new business 12 months after the valuation date, with (ii) the requirement to reflect actual expenses in the 12 months before the valuation date and prudent inflation assumptions for future expenses?
gold_answer: A firm must set its provision for expenses at a level that is not below a prudently assessed minimum, while also calibrating that provision using both recent actual expense experience and prudent inflation expectations. [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] Specifically, the provision (whether implicit or explicit) must be at least the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost—after allowing for taxation effects—that would likely arise from fulfilling contracts if the firm were to stop transacting new business twelve months after the valuation date. [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] In determining that provision, the firm must also have regard to its actual expenses incurred in the twelve months immediately preceding the valuation date. [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] In addition, the firm must factor in the effects of inflation on future expenses, using prudent assumptions about future rates of increase in prices and earnings, so that the provision reflects expected expense growth rather than only past levels. [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc] The resulting provision therefore needs to be both (i) sufficient for the post-valuation run-off scenario described and (ii) informed by the firm’s recent expense base and prudent inflation-driven projections. [#SRC:76b4e3f63e49250f] [#TGT:d5f33a809f90d2bc]
source_text: In accordance with 13.2 , a firm’s provision for expenses, whether implicit or explicit, must not be less than the amount required, on prudent assumptions, to meet the total net cost (after taking account of the effect of taxation) that would be likely to be incurred in fulfilling contracts if the firm were to cease to transact new business twelve months after the valuation date .
target_text: The provision mentioned in 13.1 must have regard to the firm's actual expenses in the last twelve months before the valuation date and the effects of inflation on future expenses on prudent assumptions as to the future rates of increase in prices and earnings.

question: For a credit union that undertakes ‘additional activities’ or has more than 15,000 members (and is therefore within the monitoring expectation tied to Rule 10.3(3)), how should it set and use ratio values for monitoring, and how does the PRA’s example of “prudent practice” for the indicative ratio percentages (including the stated exception for loans-to-assets calculations) affect that approach?
gold_answer: A credit union that undertakes ‘additional activities’ or has more than 15,000 members is expected to monitor its relevant business using ratios, but it should calibrate the values to align specifically to its individual business model rather than treating any indicative percentages as automatically determinative. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] In doing so, the credit union should establish measures that help define its tolerance for triggers and ratios that support resilience, and its board is expected to decide which ratios and values best reflect what is most important and the risks in the organisation. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The PRA’s example of prudent practice provides a benchmark: for credit unions in this scope, the PRA considers the indicative ratio percentages in Table 1 to be prudent for all calculations except loans to assets. [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150] Practically, this means the board can use the Table 1 indicative percentages as a reference point for most ratio calculations while still selecting values that function as an accurate and reliable tool for routine monitoring against the strategic plan and regulatory obligations. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] The credit union should also be able to provide details of its chosen ratios and evidence of the rationale for them on request, including how it treated the loans-to-assets exception when considering Table 1 percentages. [#SRC:5983e59e8a0d7466] [#TGT:76fa69d28babf150]
source_text: A credit union that is undertaking ‘additional activities’ 1 (see Table 1) or that has more than 15,000 members, and is therefore subject to the requirement in Rule 10.3(3) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, is expected to monitor its relevant business by using the ratios in paragraph 4.3 below, calibrated with values that are specifically aligned to its individual business model. Credit unions should have measures that help them define their tolerance for triggers and ratios that underpin their resilience. The ratios in table 1 below are indicative; the PRA expects boards to assess what is most important and reflects the risks in their organisation. The PRA expects the values selected by the credit union to provide an accurate and reliable business tool, by which its board may routinely and accurately monitor the credit union’s performance against its strategic plan and its regulatory obligations. The PRA also expects the credit union to be able to provide details of its chosen ratios, and evidence of the rationale underlying them, on request.
target_text: By way of example only, the PRA considers that prudent practice suggests that the indicative ratio percentages for credit unions that undertake additional activities or have more than 15,000 members for all calculations save loans to assets are those outlined in Table 1 .

question: When assessing recovery capacity, how should a firm treat the combined impact of recovery options under different types of stress, and how does this differ from scenario testing in terms of option selection and dependencies?
gold_answer: A firm should treat recovery capacity as an assessment of the total financial benefits it could credibly realise across a range of stresses, and it should do so by evaluating the combined impact of all options that could credibly be realised together under different types of stress. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b] This combined-impact assessment must explicitly take account of dependencies between options, because the analysis is about what can be realised together rather than viewing each option in isolation. [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e] In practice, this means the firm’s recovery capacity work should (i) identify the set of options that could credibly be realised together, (ii) assess their total benefits under different stress types, and (iii) reflect how dependencies between options affect the combined outcome. [#SRC:a1a9ded92f4a8c2e] The firm should also distinguish this recovery capacity assessment from scenario testing: scenario testing is framed around specific scenario conditions and focuses on which options would likely be selected in response to those particular conditions, rather than calculating the total benefits of all options that could be realised together. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b] Accordingly, recovery capacity is a total-capacity measure under a range of stresses with option interdependencies considered, while scenario testing is a selection exercise tied to individual scenario conditions. [#TGT:a2d9491b1c29bb6b]
source_text: the assessment of the combined impact of all options that could currently credibly be realised together under different types of stress, considering the dependencies between options (covered in ‘ (ii) Recovery capacity ’ below); and
target_text: It is important that firms understand the total financial benefits they could credibly realise in a range of stresses if they need to do so (ie their ‘recovery capacity’). The total recovery capacity should include the benefits of all options that could be realised together under different types of stress. This is different from scenario testing, where firms consider which options would likely be selected in response to the specific conditions in the different scenarios.

question: Where the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that a home resolution authority’s regime will achieve outcomes aligned with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives, how does that affect the PRA’s willingness to host a branch from that jurisdiction, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances fit into the resulting supervisory or structural expectations for an existing branch?
gold_answer: If the PRA cannot obtain adequate assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver outcomes consistent with the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA’s stated position is that it is likely not prepared to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] For an international bank already operating through an existing branch, the PRA indicates that the firm may be required to establish a UK subsidiary where such assurance is lacking. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] In that same insufficient-assurance scenario, the PRA further signals that supervision may need to move toward a more standalone basis, aligned with an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This supervisory emphasis on standalone outcomes links to the Bank’s stated capability: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the ability to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] Taken together, the PRA’s reluctance to host (or its push toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch) is framed around ensuring resolvability aligned with UK objectives, while the Bank’s branch resolution powers provide a mechanism that can operate on a standalone basis where circumstances warrant. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]
source_text: The PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver the appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority. In the absence of adequate levels of assurance, the PRA will likely not be prepared to host such a branch from that jurisdiction. 53 In the case of an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary. If there is insufficient assurance over the home state resolution arrangements, this may in turn mean that it would be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with a MPE approach to resolution.
target_text: 53. The Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances.

question: What does a critical third party need to be able to show regulators, and how do the playbook checks and exercises (including the 12-month and biennial timing) help prove that?
gold_answer: A critical third party must be able to demonstrate to the regulators that it can comply with this Part, and one way to do that is to point to how it meets the incident management playbook obligations described in the Part. [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] Specifically, it has to assess the effectiveness of its incident management playbook on a regular basis, and that regular assessment includes running an appropriate playbook exercise with a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] The timing of that exercise is also part of what should be demonstrated: the first exercise must be completed within 12 months of the critical third party being designated by the Treasury, and then the exercise must occur at least every two years after that. [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d] To make the demonstration meaningful to regulators, the critical third party should be able to present evidence that these assessments and exercises were carried out in line with the required scope (representative sample) and schedule (12 months, then biennially). [#TGT:2d682f43e1f6ff70] [#SRC:6fb580eef1e5447d]
source_text: As part of its obligation under 5.1 , a critical third party must assess the effectiveness of its incident management playbook regularly, including undertaking an appropriate incident management playbook exercise with a representative sample of the firms to which it provides systemic third party services within 12 months of the critical third party being designated by the Treasury and at least biennially thereafter.
target_text: A critical third party must be able to demonstrate to the regulators its ability to comply with this Part.

question: For a firm acting as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation that is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, what must it be able to demonstrate to the PRA on request regarding its compliance arrangements, and how does the rule on what underlying exposures may include (specifically, the prohibition on securitisation positions) fit within that demonstration?
gold_answer: A firm acting as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a securitisation that is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook is expected to be able to show the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms designed to achieve compliance with the specified parts of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook (Articles 6, 7, 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4–6). [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614] As part of what those arrangements must be capable of supporting in practice, the firm’s compliance framework should ensure that the pool of underlying exposures used in the securitisation does not contain securitisation positions, because the underlying exposures are not permitted to include such positions. [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb] In other words, when the PRA requests evidence, the firm should be able to demonstrate that its internal processes and mechanisms are adequate not only in general terms for the referenced Articles and Chapters, but also in how they prevent the inclusion of prohibited exposure types within the securitisation’s underlying exposures. [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614] [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]
source_text: The PRA expects firms which act as originators, original lenders, and/or sponsors in a securitisation that are subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook to be able to demonstrate to the PRA, on request, that they have in place adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms in order to comply with Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The underlying exposures used in a securitisation shall not include securitisation positions .

question: If an institution is working out its risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs (for Article 92(3)), what steps does it follow, and which sections/chapters tell it how to calculate the exposure values before it applies the risk weight?
gold_answer: To calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs for Article 92(3), an institution must start by calculating the exposure values for its CCP trade exposures, then add those exposure values together, and then multiply the total by the relevant risk weight. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The exposure values used in that total must be calculated using the specified framework: Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter and, where applicable, Section 4 of Chapter 4. [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6] The source text also makes clear that, for this risk-weighted exposure amount calculation, the exposure values are those calculated under the paragraph-based method referenced for exposure values (paragraphs 2 and 3), and the risk weight applied is the one determined under the referenced paragraph 1. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] Putting these together, the institution should not skip directly to applying a risk weight; it must first compute exposure values under the required Sections/Chapter approach (and the referenced paragraph method), sum them across its CCP trade exposures, and only then apply the risk weight to that sum to arrive at the risk-weighted exposure amounts. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: An institution shall calculate exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter and with Section 4 of Chapter 4, as applicable.

question: If you work at a third-country branch undertaking in the UK, where do you look for (1) the PRA rules that apply to you and (2) the extra PRA expectations you’re expected to refer to, and how does this connect to the PRA’s focus on ‘supervisability’?
gold_answer: You should use two complementary sources: the PRA Rulebook for the applicable rules, and the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index for the additional rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, and you should organise your compliance work so it supports the PRA’s assessment of ‘supervisability’ and regulatory equivalence. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] First, because third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules that are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, you should identify and track those requirements in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501] Second, for further details of PRA rules and expectations the PRA expects third country branches to refer to, you should consult the listed sections of the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index, specifically the pages covering third-country branches of international insurers, Cross-cutting policies, Run Off and Undertakings in Difficulty, and Policyholder Protection. [#TGT:3b54c4e703c83d05] Linking these sources matters because the PRA’s authorisation and supervision approach for third-country branches is anchored in its statutory objectives and is underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and its ability to effectively supervise a branch insurer (its ‘supervisability’). [#SRC:b3cd6bbde42a8501]
source_text: The PRA’s approach to the authorisation and supervision of third-country branches is anchored in its statutory objectives. The principles of this approach are set out in further detail in Section 2 and are underpinned by the PRA’s assessment of regulatory equivalence and ‘supervisability’, which is the PRA’s ability to effectively supervise an insurer that seeks to operate in the UK through a branch. Third-country branch undertakings operating in the UK are subject to the PRA’s rules which are relevant to third-country branches and third-country branch undertakings, as set out in the PRA Rulebook. Additional background is set out in the approach document and SS44/15 – Solvency II: third-country insurance and pure reinsurance branches . 3
target_text: 3. For further details of PRA rules and expectations to which the PRA expects third country branches to refer, please see the following sections of the Prudential and Resolution Policy Index: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/prudential-and-resolution-policy-index/insurance/third-country-branches-of-international-insurers , Cross-cutting policies: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/prudential-and-resolution-policy-index/insurance/cross-cutting-policies , Run Off and Undertakings in Difficulty: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/prudential-and-resolution-policy-index/insurance/run-off-and-undertakings-in-difficulty , and Policyholder Protection: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/prudential-and-resolution-policy-index/insurance/policyholder-protection .

question: Given that the PRA’s expectations in the SS primarily address risks for corporate bond assets but are intended to be considered more widely unless stated otherwise, what modelling approach does the PRA expect a firm to take for the FS where the firm has material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments) within its MA portfolio, and how should the firm justify its approach if it does not distinguish between asset classes?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the SS expectations as a starting point beyond corporate bonds, but develop a distinct FS modelling approach for less liquid assets when its MA portfolio has material exposure to them, rather than assuming the corporate bond approach automatically fits. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] Specifically, for less liquid assets (including illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for those assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] The firm may be able to use an approach similar to the corporate bond methodology, but the extent of any changes from the core corporate bond method and calibration should be driven by how similar the less liquid assets are to corporate bonds; where similarity is low, a more bespoke methodology may be needed. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] This aligns with the PRA’s framing that, although the SS primarily targets corporate bond risks, many expectations are intended to apply more broadly across assets in MA portfolios unless the SS says otherwise, including specific expectations for less liquid assets in identified parts of the SS. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] If the firm does not distinguish between asset classes in its modelling, it should clearly justify why the model remains appropriate for each asset class, including the less liquid assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]
source_text: The PRA recognises that many firms hold a relatively wide range of assets in their MA portfolios. These assets will differ in terms of liquidity and complexity; many of them may not be traded assets. The PRA’s expectations set out in this statement primarily apply to the risks arising in respect of corporate bond assets within firms’ MA portfolios. However, many of the expectations apply irrespective of the assets held and the PRA would therefore expect firms to consider the expectations set out in the SS to be more widely applicable unless specifically stated otherwise. In a number of places (eg paragraphs 4.10 , 4.15 , 4.20 , 4.22 , 5.17 and 5.18 ) the SS sets out specific expectations in relation to less liquid assets. In future, the PRA may issue further, more bespoke, expectations for the SCR treatment of other assets within an MA portfolio, such as illiquid assets.
target_text: In the case of firms that have material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments) within the MA portfolio, the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for these assets. While an approach similar to that used for corporate bonds may be possible, the level of adaptation from the core corporate bond methodology and calibration should depend on the similarity of the assets in question to corporate bonds. In some cases a more bespoke methodology may be necessary. Where firms do not distinguish between asset classes in their modelling, then the appropriateness of the model for each asset class should be clearly justified.

question: If an insurer’s risk tolerances or market conditions change, what does it need to do about its limits, and how should that be reflected in the insurer’s written policies and procedures for risk management and related areas?
gold_answer: When an insurer’s risk tolerances change or broader market conditions change, it is expected to review its limits and adjust them as appropriate, rather than leaving limits static. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] That expectation should be operationalized through the insurer’s written policies and adequate procedures, because the firm must establish, implement, and maintain documented policies and procedures covering at least risk management as well as internal control, internal audit, and (where relevant) outsourcing. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] In practice, the insurer should ensure its written risk management policy describes how limits are monitored, how reviews are initiated (including change-driven reviews), and how decisions to adjust limits are made and recorded. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] For an insurer other than a small non-Directive insurer, the limits review should occur at least annually and be carried out as part of the broader review of its risk management policies, so the annual cycle should be built into the documented procedures and governance calendar. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] Aligning the limits-review steps with the maintained written-policy framework helps demonstrate that the insurer is not only reviewing limits, but doing so through established and ongoing procedures across the relevant governance functions. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72]
source_text: An insurer is expected to regularly review its limits and make appropriate adjustments when its risk tolerances or broader market conditions change. An insurer, other than a small non-Directive insurer, 14 should review these at least annually as part of the broader review of its risk management policies as required under Conditions Governing Business 2.4(4) and Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance 3.4(4) .
target_text: (1) establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures in relation to at least risk management, internal control, internal audit and, where relevant, outsourcing ;

question: If a firm gets a notice from the Bank of England saying it is (or is likely to be) subject to external or internal MREL above regulatory capital requirements, what MREL details does the PRA expect it to give, and how can the PRA change or update what it asks for in Phase 2?
gold_answer: If the Bank of England has notified a firm that it is, or is likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements, the PRA expects the firm to provide specific MREL information. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] That expected package covers MREL resources, projected resources, and individual instrument characteristics. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] This information is provided in the context of the PRA’s Phase 2 information-gathering, which is shaped after the PRA reviews Phase 1 submissions and, working with the Bank of England, determines a preferred resolution strategy that defines what should be requested in Phase 2. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA applies supervisory judgement to decide how broad and detailed the Phase 2 request will be and may integrate the request with other scheduled supervisory initiatives to avoid duplicating effort. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA also notes that it may require information beyond what is otherwise outlined, and it will notify firms when Phase 2 information needs to be updated, including potentially asking for refreshed data as the firm moves closer to resolution. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9]
source_text: The PRA will review Phase 1 submissions and, in conjunction with the Bank of England, will determine a preferred resolution strategy for the firm. This will define the information that should be requested in Phase 2 . Supervisory judgement will inform the breadth and depth of the information firms will be requested to provide in Phase 2 and, where possible, this will be integrated with other scheduled supervisory initiatives (eg business model analysis reviews, liquidity reviews, operational risk reviews) in order to avoid duplication of effort. The PRA expects firms that are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources as specified in Chapter 2 section A4 of this statement. Given the diversity of legal, financial and operational structures across firms, firms may be required to provide information beyond that which is outlined in this supervisory statement. The PRA will notify firms where updates are required to Phase 2 information. As firms move closer to resolution the PRA may ask for data to be updated.
target_text: The PRA expects firms that have been notified by the Bank of England that they are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources, projected resources, and individual instrument characteristics.

question: When a TWD firm writes its recovery plan, what does it need to say about the TWD option (including the active and passive wind-down periods and the cost/capital/liquidity impacts), and how do the firm’s TWD capabilities fit in for carrying out the recovery plan and BRP in real-life situations?
gold_answer: In its recovery plan, a TWD firm should describe the TWD option in a way that makes it easy to carry out in a stress, and it should back that plan with TWD capabilities that let it develop and execute the option in real-life circumstances, including for the BRP. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8] The plan should explain the TWD option and, where relevant, include the playbook so implementation in stress is straightforward. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] The plan should also quantify the costs of the wind-down and set out the impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources across the wind-down period, which runs from the moment the TWD option is executed until the firm’s trading activities have been wound down. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] For clarity and execution, the wind-down period should be split into: (1) an active wind-down period, ending when the firm has exited all positions it can exit without undue costs; and (2) a passive wind-down period, when the firm hedges exposures of remaining rump positions where possible until they expire. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] Separately, the firm should maintain TWD capabilities that enable it to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities to help develop and execute both its recovery plan and its BRP. [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8]
source_text: The TWD option should be explained in the TWD firm’s recovery plan, including the playbook where relevant, such that the TWD option would be easily implemented in a stress. The quantification of the costs of the wind-down, set out in more detail in Chapter 4 , and any impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources throughout the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm’s trading activities have been wound down (hereinafter referred to as the ‘wind-down period’), should also be set out in the TWD firm’s recovery plan. 14 The wind-down period can be split into the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm has exited all the positions it can exit without incurring undue costs (hereinafter referred to as the ‘active wind-down period’); and the rest of the wind-down period, during which the firm hedges the exposures of the remaining ‘rump’ positions (insofar as this is possible) until they expire (hereinafter referred to as the ‘passive wind-down period’).
target_text: TWD firms should have TWD capabilities that will enable them to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances. TWD firms should use their TWD capabilities to help them to develop and execute their recovery plan and BRP.

question: If a firm is trying to set a long-run PD for a grade or pool, what does it mean to use a data series of “appropriate length,” and why can’t the firm just take its own historic average and update it every year?
gold_answer: Using a data series of “appropriate length” means the firm should select enough data to support a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, not merely the shortest or most convenient history. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] For long-run PDs that are meant to be averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the firm is expected to estimate expected default rates over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply averaging the default rates it actually experienced over some past years. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] Put together, this implies the length and composition of the data series should help the firm reflect different economic conditions so the estimate is a reasonable long-run measure. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] The firm should change the long-run estimate when there is reason to think the current long-run estimate is no longer accurate. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] But it should not automatically update the estimate just because another year of defaults has occurred, since those extra years may not be representative of the long-run average even though they extend the data series. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] This keeps the estimate focused on long-run representativeness and reasonableness, not year-by-year drift. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]
source_text: Principle 3: a firm should use a data series of appropriate length in order to provide a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate referred to in paragraph 10.13 ; and
target_text: In order to estimate PDs that are long-run averages of one year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects firms to estimate expected default rates for the grade/pool over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply taking the historic average of default rates actually incurred by the firm over a period of years. The PRA expects that a long-run estimate would be changed when there is reason to believe that the existing long-run estimate is no longer accurate, but that it would not be automatically updated to incorporate the experience of additional years, as these may not be representative of the long-run average.

question: When a firm includes assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, how should it determine and evidence any required FS additions, including how it should treat sources of cash flow variability versus uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount?
gold_answer: A firm should treat assets with HP cash flows as a trigger for additional risk assessment within its MA portfolio and, where those additional risks arise, it must increase the FS for those assets to provision for them, consistent with the requirement that such assets are likely to introduce additional risks and therefore require FS increases. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] In determining the size and scope of those FS additions, the firm should consider additional risks arising from sources of cash flow variability and ensure those risks are sufficiently captured by the required FS additions using the guidance in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of the chapter. [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6] The firm must also identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for them, so the FS additions should reflect both variability-driven risks and timing/amount uncertainty. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] To evidence compliance, the PRA expects the firm to document the details of the identified sources of uncertainty and explain how it has allowed for them, which should align with the firm’s application of the paragraph 5.17 to 5.29 guidance when demonstrating that FS additions sufficiently capture the relevant risks. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: Assets with HP cash flows are likely to introduce additional risks into firms’ MA portfolios and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required (in accordance with Matching Adjustment 4.16 ) to provision for these additional risks. As required by Chapter 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part , firms must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for these. The PRA expects firms to document details of these sources of uncertainty and how they have allowed for them.

question: If a firm already has a management information framework and indicators from the PRA’s recovery planning work, can it reuse those instead of building a brand-new set, and what exactly does it need to watch (levels, projections, trends) so the indicators help with solvent-exit decisions?
gold_answer: Yes. A firm can draw on and adapt its existing management information framework and the indicator framework it developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, and it is not required to create and monitor a separate new set of indicators just for this. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] But the firm still needs to monitor the indicators in a way that supports decision-making on a solvent exit: it should track the projected levels and the actual levels, and it should also monitor the trend of those indicators over time. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] The indicators are intended to be used alongside other relevant information so that decisions about a solvent exit can be made clearly and without delay. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] Putting the two points together, the firm should (i) reuse and tailor its existing indicator set where appropriate, (ii) set up monitoring that compares forecasts to what is actually happening, and (iii) keep an eye on whether each indicator is improving, deteriorating, or stable, so the information can drive timely solvent-exit decisions. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] [#TGT:30201d932e512926]
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should monitor the projected and actual levels of these indicators, as well as their trend. These indicators, alongside other relevant information, 23 should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit.

question: When a firm uses its own independent booking taxonomy (rather than common industry definitions), what minimum elements must it still document to ensure bookings—particularly remote and branch bookings—are consistently classified and attributable to a single responsible individual?
gold_answer: Even where a firm relies on its own independent booking taxonomy, it should still document enough detail to ensure consistent classification of booking practices and clear accountability for each booking’s correctness. The PRA recognises firms may already have independent taxonomies and is not currently seeking to impose common definitions, but it expects firms to identify and classify the types of booking they employ and to develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy that defines terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, shared desks, and the classification of branch bookings. [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87] Alongside that taxonomy, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should set out any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The documentation should explicitly cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, so those scenarios are both classified (taxonomy) and governed (permissions and definitions). [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] For accountability, the PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual—usually the trader—so the firm’s records should support that traceability for each taxonomy category, including remote and branch bookings. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]
source_text: Booking responsibilities: A firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking including whether the trader is solely responsible. This should articulate the distinction, if any, between traders, sales and sales traders. This should also cover those individuals booking into legal entities and branches including traders based overseas booking into UK branches. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traced to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual, which will usually be the trader. Trade entry is different from the independent checking of the trade and should be performed in line with the firm’s segregation of duties controls. 37
target_text: Booking taxonomy: A firm should identify and classify the types of booking they employ and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy to assist with this. This should clearly define the use of terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, and shared desks. The classification of branch bookings should also be covered. The PRA recognises that firms have already developed their own independent taxonomies to describe booking practices and is not seeking to impose common definitions for booking taxonomies at the current time. However, a set of illustrative examples have been provided in the Annex that the PRA considers to be an approximation of current industry practice and represent how the PRA has used certain terms throughout this statement.

question: If a firm wants to put income protection claims in payment into an MA portfolio, what does it need to know about recovery time risk, and what changes when the piece of liability is an eligible element under 1.2 eligible element (1)(b) so that the condition in 2.2(1) doesn’t apply?
gold_answer: For income protection claims in payment included in an MA portfolio, recovery time risk can be treated as a permitted underwriting risk linked to that portfolio, and there is no stated cap or restriction on how much recovery time risk exposure the firm may have in its MA portfolio. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] Separately, if the relevant part of the liability is an eligible element specified in 1.2 eligible element (1)(b), the firm should apply the rule that the condition in 2.2(1) does not apply to that eligible element, meaning the firm should not treat meeting 2.2(1) as a prerequisite for that element’s treatment. [#TGT:a8298c1acbe7503a] To support inclusion of the in-payment elements, the firm should ensure those elements are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and the PRA indicates this can allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted where the claims are not subject to future premiums. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] The firm should also avoid expanding the MA portfolio beyond this context, because the PRA does not expect recovery time risk to justify including other types of liabilities besides income protection claims in payment. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: The condition set out in 2.2(1) does not apply in respect of an eligible element specified in 1.2 eligible element (1)(b).

question: Where the PRA has deferred (in whole or in part) a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy because payment would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, when must the deferred amount be paid, and what is the maximum duration of any single deferral (including whether it can be renewed)?
gold_answer: A deferred contribution must be paid once making the payment no longer threatens the firm’s liquidity and solvency, and any PRA-granted deferral of a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy cannot run for more than six months at a time, though it may be renewed if the firm asks. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The trigger for payment is the point at which paying the deferred amount ceases to jeopardise the liquidity and solvency of the firm, meaning the deferral is not a permanent waiver but a timing adjustment tied to the firm’s financial condition. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA’s ability to defer applies where it considers that the contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and it may defer the obligation in whole or in part for a class A2 member in relation to a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Even if the liquidity/solvency concern persists, the PRA cannot grant a single deferral for longer than six months; however, the firm can request renewal, allowing the deferral to be extended through successive periods if renewed. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Accordingly, compliance planning should align both the condition-based payment point and the six-month cap with potential renewal requests. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: If two or more people share a joint account, how do you work out each person’s amount for the £120,000 maximum compensation limit, and what do you do if the account terms don’t say how to split it?
gold_answer: You apply the £120,000 maximum compensation limit at the level of each depositor, so you must first work out each person’s share of the joint account and then treat that share as part of that person’s aggregate eligible deposits. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] For joint accounts, each depositor’s share is handled separately when calculating the relevant limits, rather than treating the joint account as one single pot for compensation purposes. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] If there is no contrary provision telling you a different split, the default is to divide the joint account equally between the depositors and round each person’s share to the nearest penny. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] After you have allocated the joint account in that way, the maximum compensation sum payable for each depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits is £120,000. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] The text also signals that the £120,000 maximum is not the only possible outcome in all situations, because it allows for additional compensation in cases where 4.3 or 4.4 apply. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] So, the practical approach is: split the joint account into depositor shares (equal split to the nearest penny unless stated otherwise), add each share to that depositor’s other eligible deposits, and then apply the £120,000 cap subject to any additional-compensation cases referenced. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]
source_text: The share of each depositor of a joint account shall be considered separately in calculating the limits provided for in 4.2 and 4.3 , except where 5.5 applies. In the absence of contrary provision, the joint account shall be divided equally among the depositors to the nearest penny.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: If a firm is dealing with capital instruments that count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds, when does it have to tell the PRA for CET1/AT1 compared with Tier 2, and how does that fit with the Rulebook’s idea of “pre-issuance notification” and “post-notification” in Rules 7A to 7D?
gold_answer: The timing depends on the type of capital instrument, and the difference lines up with the Rulebook’s split between pre-issuance notification and post-notification. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] For CET1 and AT1 capital instruments that will count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds (at solo, sub-consolidated, group consolidated level, or any combination), the firm is generally required to notify the PRA at least one month before the planned issuance date or before the planned amendment/variation to the terms. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05] This matches the statement that Rules 7A to 7D require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] For Tier 2 capital instruments that will count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds at those same levels, the firm is generally required to notify the PRA immediately after the instrument is issued or immediately after the terms are amended/varied. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05] That “after the fact” timing aligns with the Rulebook’s description of post-notification for Tier 2 issuances under Rules 7A to 7D. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] So, the practical takeaway is: CET1/AT1 notice is sent in advance, while Tier 2 notice is sent right after the event. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]
source_text: Firms are generally required 6 to notify the PRA at least one month before the intended date of issuance or amendment or variation to the terms of each CET1 or AT1 capital instrument, and immediately after issuing or amending or varying the terms of each Tier 2 capital instrument, that will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds, either at solo, sub-consolidated or group consolidated level or any combination of these.
target_text: 6. Rules 7A to 7D of Definition of Capital Part of the PRA Rulebook require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances, and post-notification for Tier 2 issuances.

question: If a firm has to finish the investigation for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017, how does that fit with the rule that an appropriate actuary must investigate the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business every third financial year?
gold_answer: The firm has two linked duties: it must complete the investigation referred to in 2.1 for the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017, and it must also make sure an appropriate actuary carries out an investigation into the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business every third financial year. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] The first duty sets a specific initial deadline tied to a particular year-end, so the firm must not let the “every third financial year” pattern push that first completion past the first qualifying financial year-end. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] After meeting that initial completion requirement, the firm should continue to ensure that, on the recurring schedule, an investigation is made every third financial year and that it is performed by the appropriate actuary and focuses on the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business. [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] If the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 also happens to be one of the “every third financial year” points, the firm can align the work so that the investigation completed for that year is also the actuary-led investigation into the firm’s financial condition for its insurance business. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the investigation referred to in 2.1 is completed in respect of the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017.
target_text: A firm must ensure that an investigation is made by the appropriate actuary into the financial condition of the firm in respect of its insurance business every third financial year .

question: The TARGET points to “Paragraph 4.6, The Bank’s SoP on FiR.” If a Firm follows that reference, how quickly should it be able to provide its liquidity analysis, and what does it need to have in place so the analysis can be updated and adjusted during stress?
gold_answer: For the reference to “Paragraph 4.6, The Bank’s SoP on FiR,” a Firm is expected to be able to produce liquidity analysis quickly and keep it reliable and usable even when conditions deteriorate. [#TGT:6a4f41448caac1c1] On timing, the Firm should be able to make the liquidity analysis available on a T+1 basis, and it should be capable of providing it even faster when that is both necessary and appropriate. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] On maintaining the analysis, the Firm should be able to refresh the relevant liquidity analysis as necessary, and it should do so at the level of material entities (not only at a consolidated level). [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] To make these outputs dependable, the Firm’s mechanism for collecting and compiling the information should be robust and should comply with the relevant data quality processes within the firm. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6] The analysis also needs to be adaptable so it can be readily adjusted to reflect the circumstances of a stress, supporting decision-making when the stress scenario changes. [#SRC:29dd29593feaede6]
source_text: Firms should be able to refresh the relevant liquidity analysis as necessary, at the level of material entities, and deliver this information in a timely manner. Firms should be able to make the liquidity analysis available on a T+1 basis, or more rapidly if both necessary and appropriate. The mechanism for collecting and compiling information should be robust and compliant with the relevant data quality processes within the firm. The liquidity analysis should be sufficiently adaptable that it can be readily adjusted to reflect the circumstances of a stress. 75
target_text: 75. Paragraph 4.6, The Bank’s SoP on FiR.

question: In a takeover where the PRA confirms a transfer of a society’s business to an existing company, how should the Statutory Cash Bonus be determined and timed—specifically, how does the PRA’s ability to require no bonus or a reduced bonus interact with the calculation method based on the latest balance sheet and the member’s shares on the Qualifying Day, including the case where a Transfer Statement is issued around the financial year-end?
gold_answer: In a takeover (i.e., where the PRA confirms a transfer of a society’s business to an existing company), the starting point is that any Statutory Cash Bonus is computed using the reserves-to-total-liability ratio from the society’s latest balance sheet and applying that proportion to the value of the shares the member holds on the Qualifying Day. [#TGT:6e6626d8e0f6b007] However, even where that calculation would otherwise yield a payable amount, the PRA may direct that no Statutory Cash Bonus is paid, or that a lesser amount is paid, based on what it considers equitable between the members. [#SRC:fc03d66ef75da373] Where the Transfer Statement is approved and sent to members just before or shortly after the end of the society’s financial year, the timing matters because the Annual Report and Accounts for that year will have been published by the vesting date, which is when qualifying membership must be established and when the bonus is due to be paid. [#TGT:6e6626d8e0f6b007] In that scenario, the “latest balance sheet” used for the calculation is the one in the most recent Annual Accounts (and similar considerations can apply if half-yearly results are published). [#TGT:6e6626d8e0f6b007] Any PRA direction to reduce or eliminate the bonus would therefore operate against this calculated baseline and timing framework. [#SRC:fc03d66ef75da373]
source_text: The PRA may direct, however, where it confirms a transfer of a society’s business to an existing company (ie only in a takeover), that no Statutory Cash Bonus is paid or that a lesser amount is paid than that referred to in paragraph 4.50 , having regard to what is equitable between the members.
target_text: The bonus is to be calculated as that proportion which the society’s reserves bear to its total liability to its members in respect of shares, as shown in the latest balance sheet of the society, applied to the value of the shares held by the member on the Qualifying Day. If a Transfer Statement is approved and sent to the members just before, or shortly after, the end of the financial year of the society, it will be important to note that the Annual Report and Accounts for the year will have been published by the vesting date, when qualifying membership has to be established and the bonus is due to be paid. In those circumstances, ‘the latest balance sheet of the society’ will be that published in the most recent Annual Accounts. The same considerations may apply when a society publishes half-yearly results.

question: If a model gives extra weight to some parts of a dataset (or the model design makes some elements show up more than others), what should you check about bias, and how does that fit into the overall model complexity assessment?
gold_answer: You should check whether the heavier weighting or representation of certain dataset elements (or the way the model is designed) could skew results in a way that creates ethical and/or social implications, and treat that as a sign of potential designer or data bias relevant to complexity. [#TGT:330cb726532ca174] That bias check is not separate from complexity; it should be folded into the model’s complexity assessment, which looks at risk factors affecting inherent risk across the modelling process, such as input data nature/quality, methodology and assumptions, implementation integrity requirements, and the frequency and/or extensiveness of model use. [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] If the situation involves newly advanced approaches or technologies, you should be ready to broaden the complexity assessment to include additional bias-related risk factors (including the potential for designer or data bias) and related considerations like interpretability, explainability, and transparency, where necessary. [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] The practical outcome should be a documented view of how the weighting/representation imbalance could affect outputs and why that increases (or does not increase) the model’s complexity and inherent risk profile. [#TGT:330cb726532ca174]
source_text: c) The assessment of a model's complexity should consider the risk factors that impact a model’s inherent risk 8 within each component of the modelling process, eg the nature and quality of the input data, the choice of methodology (including assumptions), the requirements and integrity of implementation, and the frequency and/or extensiveness of use of the model. Where necessary (in particular with the use of newly advanced approaches or technologies), the complexity assessment may also consider risk factors related to: (i) the use of alternative and unstructured data, 9 and (ii) measures of a model's interpretability, 10 explainability, 11 transparency, and the potential for designer or data bias 12 to be present.
target_text: 12. When elements of a dataset (or as a result of model design) are more heavily weighted and/or represented than others, producing results that could have ethical and/ or social implications.

question: If your firm is under the Senior Managers and Certification Regime, what does the PRA expect the SMF to do when the securitisation documents say some originator balance-sheet assets meet eligibility criteria and you want to treat them as comparable to assets going to the SSPE—especially about when the check must be made and when to raise issues?
gold_answer: The PRA expects a firm that is subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime to identify a relevant individual performing a Senior Management Function (SMF) who will exercise effective oversight of securitisation issuance. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c] When the firm is applying Article 6(2) to treat assets held on the originator’s balance sheet as comparable to assets that will be transferred to the SSPE, the SMF’s oversight should ensure the firm is using the securitisation documentation to confirm those assets meet the eligibility criteria and is applying the Article 6(2) test at the correct point in time. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] Specifically, the comparability deeming applies only where, at the time of selecting the assets, the stated conditions are met, so the SMF should make sure the firm’s process evaluates the conditions during selection rather than after selection or at closing. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] If the SMF identifies issues in how the firm is overseeing securitisation issuance (including this Article 6(2) comparability assessment), the PRA expects the SMF to escalate those issues to the board or a relevant sub-committee where appropriate. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c]
source_text: The PRA expects firms subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime to identify a relevant individual performing a Senior Management Function (SMF) to exercise effective oversight of securitisation issuance, including with regard to the requirements in Article 6(2) of Chapter 2 and Article 18 of Chapter 4 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook on adverse selection. Where appropriate, the PRA expects SMFs to escalate issues related to oversight of securitisation issuance to the board or a relevant sub-committee.
