question: For the purposes of calculating the TPs, when a firm with a matching adjustment permission has an assigned asset mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), how should it address variation in credit quality by rating notch in the adjustment to the fundamental spread, and what additional consideration applies to that adjustment?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must adjust the fundamental spread that is derived from the credit quality step attributed to an assigned asset so that the adjustment reflects the corresponding rating notch, where the asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive). [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This notch-reflective adjustment is part of the approach used for calculating the TPs, and the firm must also consider the materiality of the impact of the adjustment to the fundamental spread when allowing for variation in credit quality by rating notch for those TP calculations. [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8] In practice, this means the firm should not treat the credit quality step alone as sufficient for the fundamental spread outcome when a corresponding rating notch exists; instead, it must modify the fundamental spread derived from that step to align with the notch. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] At the same time, because the framework explicitly highlights the materiality of the impact of the adjustment to the fundamental spread for notch-based variation, the firm should evaluate how significant the notch-driven change is in the context of the TP calculation. [#SRC:b45bca76519236b8]
source_text: the materiality of the impact of the adjustment to the FS to allow for variation in credit quality by rating notch for the purposes of calculating the TPs ( Matching Adjustment 6 );
target_text: Where an assigned asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard (within the meaning of 7.1(1) ) mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), a firm with a matching adjustment permission must make an adjustment to the fundamental spread derived from the credit quality step attributed to that asset in order to reflect the corresponding rating notch , in accordance with 6.3 and 6.4 .

question: If a firm is below its combined buffer and needs to work out how much it can pay out, what percentage of its last four quarters’ profits can it distribute in each combined buffer quartile, and why shouldn’t it plan to use the combined buffer in normal business?
gold_answer: If a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it faces limits on distributions and becomes subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA), so it cannot simply pay out profits without applying that cap. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] The MDA uses a percentage that depends on which quartile of the combined buffer the firm is in, multiplied by the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in the referenced capital buffers provision), net of certain deductions. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] The quartile percentages set the maximum share of such profits that can be distributed: in the first quartile (where the firm meets between 75% and 100% of its combined buffer), 60% can be distributed; in the second quartile, 40%; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%. [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d] Separately, the combined buffer is described as something firms may use in times of stress, and firms are told not to use it in the normal course of business or build a plan that assumes they will enter into it. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b] Putting these together, the quartile-based MDA limits are a practical consequence of being below the combined buffer, consistent with the expectation that the buffer is not a routine funding source for distributions. [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]
source_text: Firms may use their combined buffer as required in times of stress, but should not use it in the normal course of business or propose to enter it as part of their base business plan. As set out in the PRA’s capital buffers rules, firms that do not meet their combined buffer shall face restrictions on their distributions, and be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA). The MDA must be calculated as the product of 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% (depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in) 3 and the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in Capital Buffers 4.3(5)), net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from:
target_text: 3. Where firms are in the first quartile of their combined buffer (when they meet between 75% and 100% of it), 60% of such profits can be distributed. In the second quartile, 40% can be distributed; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%.

question: If a firm uses historical data to set internal model parameters, what does it need to do so the data is still “accurate, complete and appropriate,” and when is it not safe to assume historical data covers all quantifiable risks?
gold_answer: Using historical data can be part of meeting the internal model data standard, but the firm must ensure the data used for the internal model is accurate, complete and appropriate in light of what the model is meant to capture. [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0] The key risk is assuming that “historical-only” parameter setting automatically reflects all quantifiable risks; the firm is cautioned not to make that assumption unless it can show the unadjusted historical distribution captures the full range of possible future events. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] To make the historical dataset “complete and appropriate” for parameterisation, the firm should evaluate whether the historical distribution is broad enough to represent future outcomes, not just past observations. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] A concrete way to demonstrate this is by using stress and scenario testing to evidence that the unadjusted distribution covers the full range of possible future events relevant to the firm’s quantifiable risks. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] If the firm cannot make that demonstration, then—even if the historical data is accurate—it should not treat historical-only parameterisation as satisfying the “complete and appropriate” requirement for internal model data. [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0] [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645]
source_text: The concept of ENID also applies to the data used to set the parameters for the internal model, in line with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11.4 . Firms should not assume that parameterising the internal model using only historical data will take into account all quantifiable risks, unless an unadjusted distribution has been shown to capture the full range of possible future events, for example by way of stress and scenario testing.
target_text: (1) Data used for the internal model must be accurate, complete and appropriate.

question: How should a firm determine the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business when it has annual contribution income data for at least one preceding financial year, and how does the approach change if the firm has not existed long enough to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: A firm must set its minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business by first determining whether it has a “preceding financial year” from which annual contribution income can be assessed, because the calculation method depends on that threshold. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] Where the firm has existed long enough to have at least one preceding financial year, it must identify its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business in any preceding financial year and then use that figure to select the corresponding minimum guarantee fund amount from the referenced table (column 1 for the income band and column 2 for the minimum guarantee fund). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] In contrast, if the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, it does not use the table-based approach tied to highest annual contribution income; instead, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is a fixed amount of £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] Accordingly, the firm’s first compliance step is to confirm whether it has a preceding financial year, since that determines whether the minimum guarantee fund is derived from the table based on highest historical annual contribution income or set at the £90,000 default for newer firms. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]
source_text: Subject to 6.2 , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is the amount in column 2 of the following table, which corresponds to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in respect of that business in any preceding financial year , as shown in column 1 of the table:
target_text: If a firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000.

question: When applying the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ in the UK context, how does this SS describe the PRA’s approach to those Guidelines, and where does the PRA indicate the EBA Outsourcing GL can be accessed on its website (including the specific link)?
gold_answer: The SS explains that it is intended to clarify how the PRA expects banks to apply the EBA ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ (EBA Outsourcing GL) within the context of the PRA’s own requirements and expectations. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] It also indicates that the SS goes beyond mere clarification in some areas by expanding on expectations found in the EBA Outsourcing GL, specifically pointing to Chapter 7 on data security and Chapter 10 on business continuity and exit plans as examples of where additional PRA expectations are set out. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9] In terms of access, the PRA states that its website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period, and it identifies that the EBA Outsourcing GL are available there. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] The PRA provides a direct URL for the EBA Outsourcing GL: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf. [#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0] Taken together, this means banks should use the SS to understand the PRA’s expectations (including the SS’s expansions on Chapters 7 and 10) while obtaining the underlying EBA Outsourcing GL from the PRA-hosted link referenced above. [#SRC:b10a9b3b65eeb7a9][#TGT:fdde1620bcc52ae0]
source_text: European Banking Authority (EBA) ‘Guidelines on outsourcing arrangements’ (EBA Outsourcing GL). 2 This SS clarifies how the PRA expects banks to approach the EBA Outsourcing GL in the context of its requirements and expectations. In addition, certain chapters in this SS expand on the expectations in the EBA Outsourcing GL, for instance Chapters 7 (Data security) and 10 (Business continuity and exit plans); and 3
target_text: 2. The PRA website hosts the Guidelines and Recommendations that were complied with in the UK before the end of the transition period. The EBA Outsourcing GL are available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/paper/2020/december/gl-outsourcing-arrangements.pdf .

question: When assessing whether a credit institution’s arrangements, strategies, processes and mechanisms, together with its own funds and liquidity, ensure sound management and coverage of its risks under the PRA’s review and evaluation in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013, how does the PRA’s stated approach for STS ABCP sponsor status affect the likelihood of a positive determination, and what specific sponsor status condition is highlighted (including how non-STS programmes are treated)?
gold_answer: A positive PRA determination under the Regulation 34A(2) review and evaluation is framed as a finding that the credit institution’s arrangements, strategies, processes and mechanisms, together with the own funds and liquidity it holds, provide for sound management and coverage of its risks. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] However, for the specific purpose of being an STS ABCP sponsor, the PRA indicates it is unlikely to reach that positive determination unless an additional condition about the firm’s current sponsorship position is met. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] In practice, this means: - The baseline determination concerns whether the institution’s implemented risk arrangements and its own funds and liquidity are sufficient to manage and cover risks, as assessed via the Regulation 34A(2) review and evaluation. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] - For STS ABCP sponsor purposes, the PRA is unlikely to make that determination unless the firm is currently a sponsor for at least one ABCP programme. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] - The PRA’s stated condition can be satisfied by an existing non-STS ABCP programme where the firm wishes to seek STS status for that programme. [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a] Accordingly, even where the Regulation 34A(2) assessment focuses on risk arrangements and financial resources, the PRA’s STS ABCP sponsor approach adds a current-sponsorship threshold that affects the likelihood of a favourable determination. [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219] [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a]
source_text: (ii) the PRA has determined on the basis of the review and evaluation referred to in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013 that the arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms implemented by that credit institution and the own funds and liquidity it holds ensure the sound management and coverage of its risks ( SECN 2.3.25R(2) of the FCA Handbook ).
target_text: For the purposes of being an STS ABCP sponsor , the PRA is unlikely to determine on the basis of the review and evaluation referred to in Regulation 34A(2) of the Capital Requirements Regulations 2013 that the arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms implemented by that credit institution and the own funds and liquidity it holds ensure the sound management and coverage of its risks, unless the firm is currently a sponsor for at least one ABCP programme. This may include any existing non-STS ABCP programme for which the firm wishes to seek STS status.

question: If a firm is deciding whether to keep its liquidity contingency plan and recovery plan together or separate, what does the PRA expect, and what does the firm still need to do because Rule 12 sets requirements for the liquidity contingency plan?
gold_answer: The PRA’s general expectation is that a firm will combine its liquidity contingency plan (contingency funding plan) and its recovery plan into one integrated document, because doing so is intended to help the firm be alerted to liquidity stress and respond to it through a coherent process, and to support a coherent risk management framework. [#SRC:d6da2dce246d82de] Even if the firm follows that integrated approach, it must still ensure that the liquidity contingency plan component meets the requirements that apply to it under Rule 12 in the Internal Liquidity Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:856519b5145b9260] The PRA accepts that there may be cases where separate documents are necessary, such as where local regulators’ requirements make separation needed, but it expects this to be the exception rather than the norm. [#SRC:d6da2dce246d82de] Where the firm does keep separate documents, it should make sure the separate liquidity contingency plan and recovery plan remain consistent with each other, while treating the liquidity contingency plan as the document that must satisfy the Rule 12 requirements. [#SRC:d6da2dce246d82de] [#TGT:856519b5145b9260]
source_text: Firms are strongly encouraged to combine their liquidity contingency plan 16 (also known as a contingency funding plan) and their recovery plan into one integrated document. This would ensure that the firm has a coherent process for being alerted to and addressing a liquidity stress and helps to ensure a coherent risk management framework. The PRA recognises that there may be some instances when it is necessary to maintain separate documents (eg due to requirements of local regulators), but expects this to be the exception and that any separate documents should be consistent with each other.
target_text: 16. Rule 12 of the Internal Liquidity Adequacy Assessment Part of the PRA Rulebook sets out the requirements a firm needs to meet in relation to its liquidity contingency plan.

question: If a firm wants permission to use an MA, what does it need to confirm about Matching Adjustment 13.3, and what can’t it also apply to the same insurance or reinsurance obligations once it uses the matching adjustment?
gold_answer: The firm must confirm that it will meet the requirements of Matching Adjustment 13.3 if permission to apply an MA is granted. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] Separately, if the firm applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, it must not also apply a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or a volatility adjustment for those obligations. [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5] Read together, the confirmation about meeting Matching Adjustment 13.3 should be made with an understanding that the matching adjustment is not permitted to be used alongside those other measures for the same obligations in the relevant portfolio. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5] In practice, the firm should align its permission request and its implementation plan so that: (i) it is prepared to comply with Matching Adjustment 13.3 once permission is granted, and (ii) it does not apply either the risk-free interest rate transitional measure or the volatility adjustment to the obligations to which it applies the matching adjustment. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5]
source_text: iv. confirmation that the firm will meet the requirements of Matching Adjustment 13.3 if permission to apply an MA is granted;
target_text: A firm that applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations must not apply a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment in respect of those obligations.

question: When a society chooses to send a Transfer Summary rather than the full Transfer Statement to members, how must that summary be distributed in relation to the notice of the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered, and what continuing role does the PRA have during the transfer process in connection with the Transfer Statement?
gold_answer: If a society opts to use a Transfer Summary in place of the full Transfer Statement, it must treat the summary as a substitute document that is sent to members, rather than sending the Transfer Statement itself. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] In that case, the summary must be sent to every member who is entitled to receive the meeting notice, and it must be provided in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] Alongside this member-communication choice, the PRA’s role remains tied to the Transfer Statement and the transfer process: the chapter describes the PRA as approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members and participating in the confirmation procedure. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The same chapter also describes the PRA as continuing its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process, meaning the PRA’s involvement is not limited to a single approval step even where a Transfer Summary is used for member distribution. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The practical compliance outcome is that the society must align the timing and recipient scope of the Transfer Summary with the meeting notice for the Transfer Resolutions, while recognizing that the PRA’s approval and confirmation-procedure role is framed around the Transfer Statement and is accompanied by ongoing prudential supervision throughout the transfer process. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]
source_text: The chapter also describes the role of the PRA in approving the Transfer Statement which must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure, together with its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process. The Transfer Summary, 44 which a society may send to its members instead of the Transfer Statement, is also discussed.
target_text: 44. The summary of the Transfer Statement which may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent, instead of the Transfer Statement, in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered, to every member entitled to receive that notice.

question: If an institution is adding up exposure values for its trade exposures with CCPs and then multiplying by a risk weight for Article 92(3), what happens when some of the collateral posted to a CCP or clearing member is bankruptcy remote if the CCP, clearing member, or other clients become insolvent—can those exposures be counted as zero in the total?
gold_answer: Yes—if the specific bankruptcy-remote condition is met, the institution may treat certain exposures as having a zero exposure value, and that affects the total that is later risk-weighted. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] The general calculation for risk-weighted exposure amounts for trade exposures with CCPs is to take the sum of the exposure values of the institution’s trade exposures with CCPs (as calculated under the relevant paragraphs) and multiply that sum by the risk weight determined under the relevant paragraph, for Article 92(3) purposes. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The zero exposure value option applies only to counterparty credit risk exposures for assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member, and only where those assets are bankruptcy remote if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent. [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4] If the institution applies this derogation, the exposure value for those specified collateral-related exposures is set to zero, meaning they do not add to the summed exposure values that are then multiplied by the applicable risk weight in the CCP trade exposure calculation. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The institution should therefore apply the zeroing at the exposure-value stage before completing the sum-and-multiply step. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 1 , where assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member are bankruptcy remote in the event that the CCP, the clearing member or one or more of the other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, an institution may attribute an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for those assets.

question: If a firm is reapplying the floor methodology and calibration referenced in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 for stressed FS, but some of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is missing or unreliable, how may the firm proceed while still meeting the PRA’s expectations on justification and minimum calibration outcomes?
gold_answer: A firm may address missing or unreliable inputs for the data referred to in 4.13(4) by using constructed data, but it must do so in a way that preserves the PRA’s minimum expectations for the floor used in stressed FS modelling. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] Specifically, the PRA expects the firm to maintain a floor (a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point in the calculation) based on long-term average spreads and, at a minimum, to reapply the methodology and calibration for that floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] Where the 4.13(4) data is not available or not reliable, the firm may use constructed data based on prudent assumptions, but that constructed data must be anchored in available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years. [#TGT:5f5585242ebb290e] If the firm makes any changes to the floor (including changes driven by the use of constructed data), the PRA expects those changes to be justified. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d] In addition, the firm should ensure that any such changes do not produce a calibration below what would have resulted from reapplying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs, so the constructed-data approach should be designed and evidenced to avoid lowering the floor beneath that minimum outcome. [#SRC:c25a4960dc77cc1d]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to maintain a floor (ie a minimum level of FS at the appropriate point of the calculation) based on long-term average spreads as part of their modelling of the stressed FS. As a minimum, the PRA expects firms to reapply the methodology and calibration of the floor as set out in Matching Adjustment 4.11 to 4.15 . If any changes are made to the floor, the PRA expects these changes to be justified. They should not result in a calibration below that which would have been obtained by re-applying the methodology and calibration used to calculate the TPs.
target_text: Where part of the data referred to in 4.13(4) is not available or where the available data is not reliable, constructed data based on prudent assumptions may be used; and the constructed data must be based on available and reliable data relating to the previous 30 years.

question: If the PRA or FSCS asks for the SCV and exclusions file, what does the bank have to do within 24 hours, and what kinds of deposits (not in the SCV) should be listed in the exclusions file?
gold_answer: If the PRA or FSCS requests it, the bank must provide its single customer view (SCV) and exclusions file within 24 hours, and it must maintain these files to support orderly resolution. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] To make that possible, the bank’s systems must automatically work out the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and must also identify any part of an eligible deposit that is above the specified coverage level. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] Alongside those automated identifications, the exclusions file should include data on deposits that are not in the SCV, so that the information provided is not limited only to what appears in the SCV. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] The text gives examples of deposits that are not in the SCV and therefore should appear in the exclusions file, including deposits held in client accounts and deposits held in deposit aggregators. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] In practice, when responding to the PRA or FSCS request within the 24-hour window, the bank should ensure both that its systems produce the depositor-level covered amounts and over-coverage indicators and that the exclusions file contains the specified non-SCV deposit categories. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6]
source_text: In order to support orderly resolution, banks must maintain a single customer view and exclusions file, 67 and are required to provide this to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request. 68 Banks’ systems must automatically identify the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and identify any portion of an eligible deposit that is over the specified coverage level. 69
target_text: 67. The exclusions file that firms are required to provide should include data on deposits which are not in the SCV including for example deposits held in client accounts and deposit aggregators.

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how do you determine whether the firm must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, or whether 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 are disapplied due to the group parent’s head office being in a designated overseas jurisdiction under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations (and regulation 14(3) applying)?
gold_answer: For a firm in a group covered by 2.1(3), you must first assess whether the group-level operational resilience obligation applies, and then check whether the specific disapplication condition for 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 is met. The firm is generally required to ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of its group comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (noting the stated exception for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3), and that 2.1(3) is referenced as being subject to 22.5). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] Separately, where the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] In practice, this means you must confirm both the group coverage status (2.1(3)) and the overseas-jurisdiction/regulation-14(3) condition to conclude whether 22.2–22.4 are switched off, while still addressing the group-level compliance duty described for groups within scope of 2.1(3) (as framed in the operational resilience provision). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , with the exception of Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3) , the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations set out in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 .

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) means certain rules have to be applied at the group level, what happens to a firm’s responsibility when it outsources a function or insurance/reinsurance activity—does outsourcing change who is accountable for meeting the group-level Conditions Governing Business, Fitness and Propriety, Allocation of Responsibilities, and Key Function Holder – Notifications requirements?
gold_answer: Outsourcing does not change who is accountable: the firm remains responsible for meeting its obligations, even when the relevant requirements are being applied at the level of the group. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the specified requirements must be applied at group level with any necessary adjustments, and this includes a defined set of Conditions Governing Business modules, certain Fitness and Propriety provisions, Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (applied in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] If the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it still remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other applicable provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Practically, this means the firm must structure and oversee outsourcing so that it can continue to comply with those group-level requirements (for example, the relevant Conditions Governing Business and the notification-related requirements), because responsibility for compliance stays with the firm rather than moving to the outsource provider. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: If a firm is significant (as defined) or has AMA permission, which operational risk forms does it need to fill in, and does it still need to send them with the ICAAP if the same information was already sent through STDF or another way?
gold_answer: If the firm is a significant firm or has permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach, it is expected to complete the operational risk data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075, but it does not need to re-provide information that the PRA already received through other means. [#TGT:749a0bb00a1a5a55] The PRA already collects operational risk historical loss information from firms in the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme, and the operational risk Pillar 2 data items are required unless they have already been submitted via STDF. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] The timing is linked to the ICAAP: firms must submit the required data together with their ICAAP submissions. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] Put together, the firm should prepare FSA072–FSA075 for operational risk, check whether any of the required content has already been provided via STDF or another reporting channel, and then include whatever remains outstanding in the ICAAP submission package rather than duplicating what the PRA already holds. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] [#TGT:749a0bb00a1a5a55]
source_text: The PRA already collects information on operational risk historical losses from firms participating in the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme. All significant firms and firms with AMA permission must report the data contained in the operational risk Pillar 2 data items in accordance with Reporting Pillar 2, 2.3 , unless those data have already been submitted as part of the STDF programme. Firms are required to submit the data with their ICAAP submissions. ‘Significant firm’ means a deposit-taker or PRA-designated investment firm whose size, interconnectedness, complexity and business type give it the capacity to cause significant disruption to the UK financial system (and through that to economic activity more widely) by failing or carrying on its business in an unsafe manner. The PRA may also request some firms that are not significant to report the same data and will notify the firms accordingly in advance of their submitting an ICAAP document.
target_text: A significant firm and any firm that is not significant but that has permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach must complete the data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075 for operational risk, unless the data required in that data item has already been reported to the PRA by other means.

question: If an institution is a clearing member and sits between a client and a CCP, what does it need to do both to (1) work out the own funds requirements for the client’s CCP-related transactions and (2) check, using stress tests, that the own funds it holds for CCP exposures (including default fund and Article 304 contractual arrangement exposures) are enough?
gold_answer: When an institution acts as a clearing member and, in that role, is a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it must calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client by following the specified set of rule sections (Sections 1 to 8 of the Chapter, Section 4 of Chapter 4 of the Title, and Title VI, as applicable). [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] Separately, it must run appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing to judge whether the own funds it holds against exposures to a CCP are at a level that matches the inherent risks of those exposures. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] That stress/scenario check must include potential future or contingent credit exposures and exposures from default fund contributions. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] And because the institution is acting as a clearing member, it must also include exposures that come from contractual arrangements as laid down in Article 304 in the same adequacy assessment. [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0] In other words, the institution should both compute the client-transaction own funds requirement using the required calculation framework and then validate, via stress/scenario work, that the own funds held across all the listed CCP exposure types (including the clearing-member contractual arrangement exposures) remain risk-appropriate. [#TGT:44da4c43fe9df94e] [#SRC:a3a91a063d2c4fd0]
source_text: Institutions shall assess, through appropriate scenario analysis and stress testing, whether the level of own funds held against exposures to a CCP, including potential future or contingent credit exposures, exposures from default fund contributions and, where the institution is acting as a clearing member , exposures resulting from contractual arrangements as laid down in Article 304 , adequately relates to the inherent risks of those exposures.
target_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member and, in that capacity, acts as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP shall calculate the own funds requirements for its CCP-related transactions with that client in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter, with Section 4 of Chapter 4 of this Title and with Title VI, as applicable.

question: If someone has normal eligible deposits and also a temporary high balance, what are the maximum amounts that can be paid, and when is there no limit for the temporary high balance?
gold_answer: You need to treat the person’s ordinary eligible deposits and any temporary high balance as separate categories with different maximums. For the person’s aggregate eligible deposits, the maximum compensation sum payable is £120,000, although the text notes that extra compensation may be payable in cases that fall under 4.3 or 4.4. [#SRC:336f75f8cdcde56e] For a temporary high balance, the maximum compensation sum is £1,400,000, and that maximum is stated to apply subject to 4.4. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] There is also a specific situation where the temporary high balance has no cap at all: if the temporary high balance comes from a payment connected with personal injury or incapacity, then no limit applies to the compensation payable for that temporary high balance. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] Putting these together, a person could be limited to £120,000 for their aggregate eligible deposits while still being able to claim temporary high balance compensation up to £1,400,000 (or without limit in the personal injury or incapacity payment case), with both the aggregate-deposit and temporary-high-balance rules referencing 4.4 as a relevant condition. [#SRC:336f75f8cdcde56e] [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]
source_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: If a firm wants to stop quarterly reporting because its submission period is under a year, what is the relief actually called (even if the document uses a different word), and which PRA categories can apply normally versus only in special cases?
gold_answer: For a firm trying to limit quarterly supervisory reporting because the predefined submission period is less than one year, the relief should be understood as being granted through a modification by consent, even though the document uses the word “waiver” throughout. [#TGT:0eac4043346185e2] Under the PRA’s stated eligibility approach, firms designated as Category 3 or 4 under the potential impact framework can apply for this exemption from quarterly reporting, whether they are solo firms or part of a group. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] Category 1 and 2 firms are treated differently: the PRA may consider limitations for them only on an exceptional basis rather than as a standard eligibility route. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] The text indicates that one type of exceptional case could involve small firms that sit within groups where the group is designated as Category 1 or 2 by the PRA. [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c] So, the firm should use the modification-by-consent framing (despite the “waiver” label) and then assess whether it fits the normal Category 3/4 eligibility or needs to justify an exceptional Category 1/2 case. [#TGT:0eac4043346185e2] [#SRC:5d517e892ad5235c]
source_text: The PRA considers that some firms may be eligible to apply for a modification by consent to limit regular supervisory reporting where the predefined submission period is less than one year. The PRA considers that firms designated as Category 3 or 4 by the PRA under the potential impact framework, whether solo or part of a group, are eligible to apply for this exemption from quarterly reporting. The PRA will grant this limitation via a rule modification under s138A FSMA 4 . The PRA may consider limitations for Category 1 and 2 firms on an exceptional basis. These cases could include small firms that are part of groups, where the group is designated as category 1 or 2 by the PRA.
target_text: 4. While the term ‘waiver’ is used throughout this document, the exemption would be granted by a modification by consent.

question: In calibrating the PRA buffer for a new bank, when does the PRA’s time-limited approach cease to apply and what supervisory-judgement basis allows the PRA to move earlier to an established-bank stress-testing calibration, including the type of circumstances that could justify diverging from the stated approach?
gold_answer: The PRA’s time-limited approach for setting the PRA buffer for new banks ends once either of the relevant conditions referenced in the prior material (paragraph 4.8) no longer applies; at that point, the bank’s PRA buffer is calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments in the same manner as for established banks. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] Separately, the PRA may bring forward that transition: the text indicates that an earlier move to the established-bank, stress-testing-based calibration can be introduced where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] In addition, when exercising supervisory judgement, the PRA may—only in exceptional circumstances—diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, including where the stated approach would fail to avoid a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] That divergence power explicitly includes cases where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives that justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer approach used for established banks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] Accordingly, the default trigger for ending the time-limited approach is the cessation of the referenced conditions, but supervisory judgement can justify an earlier shift (or other divergence) in exceptional circumstances, including heightened-risks scenarios and outcomes that would otherwise be disproportionate to financial stability risks. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]
source_text: The PRA’s approach for setting the PRA buffer is designed to support new banks in their early years of operation, and as such is time-limited. Once either of the conditions set out above (paragraph 4.8 ) no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer will be calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks. However, as stated in paragraph 4.12 , such an approach could be introduced earlier where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives.
target_text: When exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA may, in exceptional circumstances, diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, for instance where the stated approach does not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. Such divergence could also include instances where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives which justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks.

question: In a firm subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime, how should the identified Senior Management Function (SMF) oversee compliance with Article 6(2) in relation to treating on-balance-sheet originator assets as comparable to assets to be transferred to the SSPE, including what timing point must be considered and when escalation is expected?
gold_answer: A firm subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime is expected to designate a relevant individual performing a Senior Management Function (SMF) to provide effective oversight of securitisation issuance, and that oversight should explicitly cover how the firm applies Article 6(2) when assessing whether certain originator assets can be treated as comparable to assets intended for transfer to the SSPE. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c] For Article 6(2) purposes, the SMF’s oversight should focus on the firm’s determination that assets held on the originator’s balance sheet, which the securitisation documentation indicates meet the eligibility criteria, are only deemed comparable where the required conditions are satisfied at the time the assets are selected. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] In practice, this means the SMF should ensure the firm has a process to check (i) that the documentation of the securitisation supports that the on-balance-sheet assets meet the eligibility criteria, and (ii) that the Article 6(2) conditions are evaluated at the selection point rather than later in the transaction lifecycle. [#TGT:de53496f24c9e07b] Where appropriate, the SMF is expected to escalate issues identified in this oversight of securitisation issuance to the board or a relevant sub-committee. [#SRC:ecf215575f4bdc6c]
source_text: The PRA expects firms subject to the Senior Managers and Certification Regime to identify a relevant individual performing a Senior Management Function (SMF) to exercise effective oversight of securitisation issuance, including with regard to the requirements in Article 6(2) of Chapter 2 and Article 18 of Chapter 4 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook on adverse selection. Where appropriate, the PRA expects SMFs to escalate issues related to oversight of securitisation issuance to the board or a relevant sub-committee.

question: For a firm using an internal model, what quarterly submission to the PRA is required for internal model changes, and what additional materials and rulebook references must be followed when preparing that submission?
gold_answer: A firm that uses an internal model must make a quarterly submission to the PRA using template QMC.01, and that submission must cover model changes together with supporting qualitative/narrative material prepared in line with the relevant rulebook instructions and reporting provisions. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] Specifically, the firm must submit quarterly template QMC.01 and include information on model changes plus supporting qualitative information, following the instructions in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 (for the template referenced in Chapter 9). [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] In addition, the quarterly reporting obligation described for internal model change governance requires the firm to provide a quarterly summary of both minor and major model changes to the PRA using the QMC.01 template, accompanied by supporting narrative documentation, and to do so in line with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d] Taken together, this means the quarterly QMC.01 filing is not limited to a bare template: it must be completed with the specified model-change information and the required qualitative/narrative support, and it must be prepared consistently with both the template instructions (Chapter 10 section QMC.01) and the reporting provision that frames the quarterly summary requirement (Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part). [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] [#SRC:2de692b032a74b5d]
source_text: It is important that the internal model change policy is of a good standard. Firms should consider all the relevant PRA Rulebook requirements and the EIOPA Guidelines when developing and maintaining their internal model change policy. Firms are required to report a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA using the QMC.01 template and supporting narrative documentation, in accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part in the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies so that specified requirements must be applied at the level of the group, how should a firm treat its responsibility for compliance if it outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity—particularly in relation to the group-level application of the listed Conditions Governing Business, Fitness and Propriety, Allocation of Responsibilities, and Key Function Holder – Notifications requirements?
gold_answer: A firm should treat outsourcing as not reducing or transferring its compliance responsibility, even where the relevant requirements are being applied at the level of the group because 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] In that situation, the firm must ensure that the specified requirements continue to be met at group level “with any necessary changes,” including the identified Conditions Governing Business modules (such as 1A, 2.2–2.6, 2A.1–2A.6, 3, 3A, 4, 4A, 5, 6, 7, and 11A–11F), the listed Fitness and Propriety provisions, Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (as applied in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] If the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it nevertheless remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other applicable legal and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Accordingly, outsourcing arrangements must be managed so that the firm can still demonstrate compliance with those group-applied requirements, because the accountability for meeting the obligations stays with the firm rather than the outsource provider. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245]
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: If an institution wants to (re)start calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions using the Section 5 method because its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is within the relevant monthly thresholds, what additional condition must it satisfy if it had previously ceased calculating exposure values under Section 4 or 5, and how does that condition relate to the monthly assessment basis?
gold_answer: An institution that previously stopped calculating the exposure values of its derivative positions under Section 4 or Section 5 cannot simply resume the Section 5 method based only on meeting the size thresholds; it must first show the competent authority that the relevant conditions have been satisfied continuously for a full year. [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393] In contrast, eligibility to use the Section 5 method is framed around an ongoing size test: the institution may use Section 5 provided its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below both thresholds, determined through a monthly assessment using data as of the last day of each month. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] Read together, the monthly, month-end data assessment supports determining whether the institution meets the Section 5 size thresholds at each point in time, but where the institution is resuming after having ceased calculations, it must additionally demonstrate to the competent authority that the applicable conditions in Article 273a(1) or (2) were met without interruption for one year before resumption is permitted. [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393] The practical linkage is that the institution’s month-end, monthly assessment process for its derivative business size can be part of the evidence base for ongoing Section 5 eligibility, while the resumption gate requires a separate, uninterrupted one-year demonstration of the Article 273a conditions to the competent authority. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] [#SRC:c5ef344684d38393]
source_text: Where an institution has ceased to calculate the exposure values of its derivative positions in accordance with Section 4 or 5 , as applicable, it shall only be permitted to resume calculating the exposure value of its derivative positions as set out in Section 4 or 5 where it demonstrates to the competent authority that all the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) or (2) have been met for an uninterrupted period of one year.

question: If a derivative has several important (material) risk drivers, when do institutions map it to one risk category versus several, and how do they tell if the position is long or short for the most material risk driver they use for that mapping?
gold_answer: Institutions should handle a derivative with more than one material risk driver by (1) mapping it correctly across risk categories based on where its material risk drivers sit, and (2) classifying the position as long or short by looking at how the transaction’s market value moves when the relevant risk driver increases. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If every material risk driver for the transaction is in the same risk category, the institution maps the transaction only once to that single category, using the most material risk driver as the basis for that mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the transaction’s material risk drivers are spread across different risk categories, the institution maps the transaction once to each risk category where it has at least one material risk driver, and in each category it uses the most material risk driver in that category as the basis. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] After identifying the most material risk driver used for a given mapping, the institution determines direction: it is a long position if the transaction’s market value rises when that risk driver’s value rises, and it is a short position if the market value falls when that risk driver’s value rises. [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301] This ties the mapping decision to a consistent long/short test for the specific risk driver that anchors each mapped risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When an entity falls within the scope of “large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies” (or a large subsidiary of a parent undertaking established in a third country), how should it determine whether it must make an individual or sub-consolidated disclosure specifically about remuneration policy and practices for staff whose activities materially affect the institution’s risk profile, and what is the minimum content anchor for that remuneration disclosure?
gold_answer: A large subsidiary that is within the scope described (i.e., a large subsidiary of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or a large subsidiary of a parent undertaking established in a third country) must make the required disclosures either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis, and that basis choice governs how it presents any remuneration-related disclosure that is required within the specified disclosure set. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] In parallel, where the disclosure set includes remuneration information, the institution’s remuneration disclosure must address its remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile, meaning the content must be framed around those staff categories and their risk relevance. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] Practically, this means the entity should (i) confirm it is a “large subsidiary” in one of the listed parent-structure situations and therefore is subject to the specified-Articles disclosure obligation, and (ii) ensure that, whichever reporting basis it uses (individual or sub-consolidated), the remuneration section is organized to cover the relevant staff categories defined by material impact on risk profile. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] The minimum content anchor for the remuneration portion is that it must be “regarding” remuneration policy and practices and must be scoped to those risk-material staff categories, rather than to all staff generally. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]
source_text: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country shall disclose the information specified in Articles 437 , 438 , 440 , 442 , 450 , 451 , 451a and 453 on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis.

question: How should a firm’s obligation to maintain an effective system of governance for sound and prudent management be implemented when the firm is part of a group subject to group supervision under 2.2(1) and 2.2(2), particularly regarding consistency across undertakings and group-level control?
gold_answer: A firm must maintain an effective system of governance that supports sound and prudent management of its business, and where the firm sits within a group subject to group supervision under 2.2(1) and 2.2(2), that governance framework must be implemented in a way that is consistent across all undertakings within the group-supervision scope so it can be controlled at the group level. [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6] [#SRC:81456a787f326c75] In practice, this means the firm should not treat governance as a purely standalone, entity-by-entity arrangement when it is included in the group supervision perimeter; instead, the governance and reporting procedures need to be rolled out consistently across the relevant undertakings so that the group can exercise control over them. [#SRC:81456a787f326c75] The baseline requirement remains that the system of governance must be effective and designed to ensure sound and prudent management of the firm’s business. [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6] Accordingly, the firm should align its governance and reporting procedures with the group-wide implementation approach required for undertakings in scope, so that group-level control is achievable while still meeting the firm-level standard of effective governance for prudent management. [#SRC:81456a787f326c75] [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]
source_text: (2) Without prejudice to (1), the effective system of governance and reporting procedures must be implemented consistently in all the undertakings included in the scope of group supervision under 2.2(1) and 2.2(2) so that the effective system of governance and reporting procedures can be controlled at the level of the group .
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place an effective system of governance which provides for sound and prudent management of its business.

question: Where a third country branch outsources activities to a service provider that is in the same group, how should the branch approach (i) assessing group-based control or influence over the service provider for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and (ii) responding to a PRA (or other relevant competent authority) request for information needed to supervise compliance of the outsourced activities with the regulatory system?
gold_answer: A third country branch that outsources activities to a service provider in the same group may factor its degree of control over, or ability to influence, that service provider when applying the requirements referenced in 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, but it must still be able to provide supervisory authorities with the information they need about the outsourced activities. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Specifically, the branch’s group relationship is relevant only to the extent it demonstrates how the branch controls the service provider or can influence the provider’s actions for those identified purposes. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Separately, when the PRA or any other relevant competent authority asks, the branch should make available all information necessary for those authorities to supervise whether the outsourced activities are being performed in compliance with the requirements of the regulatory system. [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1] In practice, this means the branch should be prepared to explain both (i) how its control/influence within the group affects the service provider’s conduct in relation to 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and (ii) to furnish the underlying information about the outsourced activities that enables supervisory review of compliance performance. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]
source_text: If a third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch may, for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11 , take into account the extent to which the branch controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.
target_text: A third country branch should make available on request to the PRA and any other relevant competent authority, all information necessary to enable the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise the compliance of the performance of the outsourced activities with the requirements of the regulatory system.

question: If an institution checks its derivatives business size every month using month-end data and it is under the thresholds, can it use the Section 5 method for exposure value—and what happens if it does not meet the Article 273a(2) conditions?
gold_answer: Being under the thresholds based on the required monthly check is necessary but not sufficient for using the Section 5 method; the institution must also meet the Article 273a(2) conditions. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] The rule allows an institution to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method in Section 5 only when, subject to the restriction in Article 273b(2), it has assessed the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business on a monthly basis using data as of the last day of the month and found that size to be no more than both thresholds referenced. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] However, there is a separate prohibition: if the institution does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(2), it must not use the method in Section 5. [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598] This means that even if the monthly, month-end-data assessment shows the business is within the thresholds, the institution still cannot use Section 5 if it fails Article 273a(2). [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598] In practice, the institution should treat the monthly threshold assessment and the Article 273a(2) conditions as cumulative gates, with the Article 273b(2) restriction also applying where relevant. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d]
source_text: An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) shall not use the method set out in Section 4 . An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(2) shall not use the method set out in Section 5 .

question: If you are working out MCR (l,gi), what does it represent, and how do you both (a) choose the calculation approach and (b) limit which technical provisions or premiums written you include?
gold_answer: MCR (l,gi) represents the linear formula component for long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations that relate to general insurance business, and it is calculated in line with 4A.5. [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd] To choose the calculation approach, you must calculate MCR (l,gi) in the same way as the linear MCR measure referenced in Minimum Capital Requirement 3C (i.e., the approach used for MCR (linear,l)), consistent with the rule that also aligns MCR (gi,gi) with the method for MCR (linear,gi) in Minimum Capital Requirement 3B. [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478] At the same time, you must limit the inputs used in that calculation: the technical provisions or premiums written you use must only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations. [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478] Putting those points together, you apply the required linear calculation method while keeping the data set restricted to general insurance and reinsurance obligations, which matches the fact that MCR (l,gi) is specifically a component tied to long-term obligations relating to general insurance business. [#SRC:bcc921ae0bcf10dd] [#TGT:696a8ad3ed7cf478]
source_text: (2) MCR(l,gi) denotes the linear formula component for long-term insurance and reinsurance obligations relating to general insurance business calculated in accordance with 4A.5 .
target_text: MCR (gi,gi) and MCR (l,gi) must be calculated in the same way as MCR (linear,gi) and MCR (linear,l) referred to in Minimum Capital Requirement 3B and 3C respectively, but the technical provisions or premiums written used in the calculation must only relate to the firm’s general insurance and reinsurance obligations .

question: For a TWD firm, how should the firm align its capability to refresh the material components of the TWD option that require judgement with the requirement to run sensitivity analyses of key market factors, including the expected timeframe for doing so and the minimum scope of sensitivities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to use its data refresh and full plan refresh capabilities to update the material, judgement-driven components of its TWD option within a timeframe ranging from a matter of days to a matter of weeks, with the exact speed depending on the nature and extent of the stress. [#SRC:58ebd6a4c26d1aaa] In doing so, the firm’s refresh process should incorporate sensitivity analyses focused on the key market factors in the TWD scenario, as well as the assumptions and judgments that could materially affect capital and liquidity projections and RBLs. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4] Practically, this means the refresh capability is not only about updating inputs, but also about testing how changes in those key factors and related assumptions/judgments would move the firm’s projected capital and liquidity outcomes and its RBLs. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4] The sensitivity work should be included as part of the refresh of the material components that require judgement, and it should cover updates to the factors referenced for sensitivity analysis in the relevant paragraphs identified in the expectation. [#SRC:58ebd6a4c26d1aaa] The minimum expectation is that sensitivities of capital and liquidity to the specified factors are included, rather than being optional or ad hoc. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4]
source_text: The PRA expects that TWD firms’ data refresh and full plan refresh capabilities can be utilised such that TWD firms are able to perform a refresh of the material components of the TWD option that require judgement, between a matter of days and a matter of weeks (depending on the nature and extent of the stress). 29 This should include sensitivity analyses of updates to the factors set out in paragraphs 4.49 - 4.51 .

question: When a firm is classifying an outsourcing or third party arrangement, how should it reconcile the PRA’s use of the term “material outsourcing” with the “critical or important outsourcing” terminology in retained EU legislation/PRA rules, and what performance-failure test should it apply to decide whether the arrangement is material?
gold_answer: A firm should treat “material outsourcing” as the PRA’s preferred label for the same practical category as “critical or important outsourcing” in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules, and then apply the PRA/EBA-aligned criteria to decide whether the arrangement is material. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] In particular, the PRA explains it uses “material outsourcing” to reduce confusion with other partially overlapping regulatory terms (eg “critical function” or “critical service” in an OCIR context), while still intending “material outsourcing” to encompass “critical or important outsourcing” for all practical purposes. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] Consistently with that framing, the firm should generally classify an outsourcing or third party arrangement as material where a defect or failure in the arrangement’s performance could materially impair the firm (ie the firm’s ability to meet the relevant impairment threshold described in the PRA Rulebook definition and, where applicable, the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria). [#TGT:52624254f79512d2] The criteria the firm uses for identifying “material outsourcing” should be substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria for “critical or important outsourcing,” but the firm should also recognise that the PRA notes there are some justified exceptions, including exceptions that reference the PRA’s operational resilience requirements. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] This means the firm’s decision should be anchored in the failure/defect material-impairment test while using the aligned criteria set, adjusted only where the PRA’s stated exceptions apply. [#TGT:52624254f79512d2]
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
