question: For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, how should the firm integrate the guidance on fire drills and playbooks into its UK recovery planning, including when a fire drill must be performed relative to recovery plan submissions and what to do if the PRA requests more detailed UK playbook work?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK should treat fire drills and playbooks as connected elements of its UK recovery planning: it should consider the relevant guidance on fire drills and playbooks, and be prepared to do additional UK playbook work if the PRA asks for it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] In parallel, the firm must plan fire drill exercises around its recovery plan submission cycle, because the PRA expects at least one ‘live’ simulation exercise on the recovery plan before each submission, while also ensuring there is at least one such exercise every three years. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] If the PRA explicitly requests more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of the firm’s UK recovery planning, the firm should contact its supervisor to discuss whether that request applies to it and how to proceed. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] The firm should also recognize that the submission frequency for the recovery plan is set by the PRA on a firm-by-firm basis (with larger firms often on an annual cycle), which in turn drives how often the pre-submission fire drill expectation will arise. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: Fire drill exercises are ‘live’ simulation type exercises where firms act out key parts of a response to a designed scenario. This is a useful way to test the effectiveness of the recovery plan in a ‘live’ situation. The PRA expects each firm to carry out at least one fire drill exercise on its recovery plan prior to each submission of the recovery plan to the PRA, subject to a minimum of one fire drill taking place every three years. The PRA determines the frequency with which firms should submit their recovery plan on a firm-by-firm basis, with larger firms tending to submit their plans on an annual cycle.

question: If a firm is discounting future payments and wants to use an asset’s yield from its long-term insurance business, what is the highest yield it can assume (including the 2.5% reduction and the “before tax adjustment” point), and how does that fit with the rule that discount rates must come from a prudent look at yields on existing assets and, when relevant, future investments?
gold_answer: The firm’s discount rates for present value calculations must be set so they are not higher than rates that come from a prudent assessment of yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business and, where appropriate, the yields expected on sums that will be invested in the future. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] When the firm uses an assumed yield for a specific asset attributed to that long-term insurance business (for the purposes of 11.1), there is an extra cap: before making any adjustment for taxation, the assumed yield must not be above the asset’s yield as calculated under 11.3 to 11.13, after reducing that calculated yield by 2.5% of itself. [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8] Put together, the prudent-assessment requirement tells the firm what the overall ceiling is for the interest rates used to discount future payments, while the assumed-yield rule imposes a concrete, asset-level maximum that is a discounted version of the calculated yield and is applied on a pre-tax-adjustment basis. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8] In practice, the firm should base its discount rates on prudent yield expectations, but also check that any assumed yield for an attributed asset does not exceed the “calculated yield minus 2.5%” limit before considering taxation effects. [#TGT:0ebf68bbb636c221] [#SRC:82f678b5a7efdda8]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.
target_text: The rates of interest to be used in calculating the present value of future payments by or to a firm must be no greater than the rates of interest determined from a prudent assessment of the yields on existing assets attributed to the long-term insurance business and, to the extent appropriate, the yields which it is expected will be obtained on sums to be invested in the future.

question: When assessing the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, how should the PRA treat any excess of a buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom over that entity’s share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk, and in what circumstance would that difference not be reflected in the consolidated group PRA buffer?
gold_answer: In assessing the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, the PRA’s assessment is informed by the extent to which any buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom is higher than that entity’s share of the buffer applied at consolidated group level for the same risk. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] This means the PRA looks at the size of the “difference” between (i) the outside‑UK entity’s own applicable buffer and (ii) the portion of the consolidated group buffer allocated to that entity for the same risk, and uses that difference as an input to its consolidated group buffer assessment. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] However, the PRA would not carry that difference through into (ie, would not reflect it in) the consolidated group PRA buffer where the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8] Accordingly, the excess can inform the assessment in general, but it is not reflected in the consolidated group PRA buffer when consolidated group requirements already mitigate the relevant underlying risk. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8]
source_text: The PRA’s assessment of the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk will be informed by the amount by which any buffer applicable on an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applicable at the consolidated group level to cover the same risk. 50 51
target_text: 51. The PRA would not reflect such a difference in the consolidated group PRA buffer where the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements.

question: When setting parameters for an internal model, how should a firm reconcile the requirement that internal model data be accurate, complete and appropriate with the caution against relying only on historical data unless the unadjusted distribution is demonstrated to capture the full range of possible future events (e.g., via stress and scenario testing)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the data-quality requirement for the internal model as applying not only to the raw dataset but also to whether the dataset and any resulting parameterisation are suitable to represent the full range of quantifiable risks the model is intended to capture. [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0] In practice, this means the firm should not regard “accurate” historical data, by itself, as necessarily “complete and appropriate” for parameter-setting if it fails to reflect all quantifiable risks and plausible future outcomes. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] To align both expectations, the firm should (i) assess whether using only historical data could omit relevant future-event variability, and (ii) only rely on an unadjusted historical distribution where it has been demonstrated to capture the full range of possible future events. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] One way to evidence that the historical distribution is sufficiently comprehensive for parameterisation is to use stress and scenario testing to show that the distribution covers the range of potential future events the firm could face. [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645] If that demonstration is not available, the firm should avoid assuming that historical-only parameterisation satisfies the “complete and appropriate” standard for internal model data, even if the historical dataset is otherwise accurate. [#TGT:3644b834dbb543a0] [#SRC:68b5b0672bda8645]
source_text: The concept of ENID also applies to the data used to set the parameters for the internal model, in line with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11.4 . Firms should not assume that parameterising the internal model using only historical data will take into account all quantifiable risks, unless an unadjusted distribution has been shown to capture the full range of possible future events, for example by way of stress and scenario testing.
target_text: (1) Data used for the internal model must be accurate, complete and appropriate.

question: When a firm experiences a material change in the firm’s systems to comply with 11.1 and 11.2, what notifications must it make and what signed confirmation must accompany the notification in 15.3, including the relevant timing?
gold_answer: A firm that has a material change in the firm’s systems used to comply with 11.1 and 11.2 must provide a notification to both the PRA and the FSCS, and it must do so within 3 months of the change. [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b] In addition, the notification referred to in 15.3 is not standalone: it must be accompanied by a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body. [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f] That signed statement must confirm two things: first, that the firm’s systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2; and second, that those systems satisfy the requirements in 11.8. [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f] Read together, this means that when the firm is notifying the PRA and FSCS about a material change to the relevant compliance systems within the 3‑month window, the firm must also ensure the 15.3 notification package includes the governing-body-signed confirmation covering compliance with 11.1 and 11.2 and satisfaction of 11.8. [#TGT:933dedc51e46fe4b] [#SRC:5b1ab5485cfeeb3f]
source_text: The notification in 15.3 must be accompanied by a statement signed on behalf of the firm’s governing body confirming that the firm’s systems comply with 11.1 and 11.2 and satisfy the requirements in 11.8 .
target_text: A firm must notify the PRA and FSCS of a material change in the firm’s systems to comply with 11.1 and 11.2 within 3 months of the change.

question: If a firm is sending the application notice for an insurance business transfer scheme, who must get the notice, what should the notice tell people about making representations to the court, and what extra documents must be available on request (including whether they can be provided online) if the firm also includes a statement and summary of the scheme report?
gold_answer: For an insurance business transfer scheme application, the notice must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose reinsurance contracts are proposed to be transferred, unless the court directs otherwise. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] The notice (and other communications and advertising by or on behalf of the firm(s)) should also give practical information on how and when affected parties should make representations so that the court can take them into account. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] When the firm includes a statement with the notice, it would normally be appropriate for that statement to set out the scheme’s terms and include a summary of the scheme report designed so recipients can understand, in broad terms, how the scheme is likely to affect them; the summary should be clear and concise but still detailed enough for that purpose, and it should not be overly long or difficult to understand. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201] Separately, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone who asks for them, and providing them via the internet is acceptable where it is suitable for the person making the request. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]
source_text: It would normally be appropriate to include with the notice referred to in 2.49 above a statement setting out the terms of the scheme and containing a summary of the scheme report. Ideally every recipient should understand in broad terms from the summary how the scheme is likely to affect them. This objective will be most nearly achieved if the summary is clear and concise while containing sufficient detail for the purpose. A lengthy summary or one that was hard to understand would not be appropriate. The Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them. The internet can be used for this purpose if it is suitable for the person making the request.
target_text: Under the Business Transfers Regulations, unless the court directs otherwise, notice of the application must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) any of whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme. It may also be appropriate to give notice to others affected, for example, to anyone with an interest in the policies being transferred who has notified the transferor of their interest. This notice, along with other communications and advertising by or and on behalf of the firm(s), should provide details of how and when any representations by affected parties should be made in order to be considered by the court.

question: If I’m checking the SoP links to EIOPA materials, do I need to look at EIOPA updates made after the transition period, and what should I do about older Guidelines and Recommendations from predecessor committees that aren’t in the appendices?
gold_answer: For SoP purposes, you should rely on the EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations that were in place at the end of the transition period, using the SoP links, and you should not treat later EIOPA changes or new EIOPA materials issued after that point as relevant to the SoP. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] However, you also need to recognize that the appendices are not a complete inventory, so the fact that something is missing from the lists does not mean it can be ignored. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] Specifically, Guidelines and Recommendations made by predecessor committees to the ESAs may be absent from the appendices, yet firms and FMIs are expected to continue complying with them where relevant. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] The key limiter is that this continuation expectation does not apply if those predecessor materials have been revoked or replaced—either by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] Putting both points together: use the SoP links as the Bank and PRA’s acknowledged EIOPA source for end-of-transition materials, but separately assess any relevant predecessor-committee materials that may not appear in the appendices, unless they have been revoked or superseded. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of these materials.

question: When a representer submits a written representation to the PRA, what procedural information must the PRA provide to that representer, and how does that relate to the stated purpose of the appendix for those making written representations and/or participating in oral confirmation hearings?
gold_answer: A representer who submits a written representation to the PRA should expect two linked procedural outcomes: (1) the PRA will confirm it has received the submission, and (2) the PRA will provide procedural guidance by sending the representer a copy of Appendix 5 on merger confirmation procedures. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e] This aligns with the stated function of the appendix as a document intended for people making written representations to the PRA and/or those involved in oral confirmation hearings, because it is meant to describe the procedures the PRA plans to follow. [#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6] In practical terms, the appendix operates as the PRA’s procedural roadmap for representers (and hearing participants), and the PRA’s act of sending it to each representer ensures that those engaging through written representations have access to that roadmap at the point their representation is received and acknowledged. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e][#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6] Separately, the PRA will also circulate written representations to the societies concerned and give those societies a chance to comment, which is part of the overall procedure the appendix is intended to set out. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e][#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6]
source_text: The PRA will acknowledge the receipt of each representation or notice and will send a copy of Appendix 5 , on merger confirmation procedures, to each representer. It will send copies of all written representations to the societies concerned and will afford them an opportunity to comment on them.
target_text: This appendix is for the use of those making written representations to the PRA and/or those participating in oral confirmation hearings. It sets out the procedures which the PRA intends to follow.

question: If a firm needs to mark eligible deposits so they can be spotted right away, can it do this by marking the depositor’s account instead of each deposit, and should the marker stay on the account even if the balance is zero or negative?
gold_answer: Yes—so long as the firm’s method makes eligible deposits immediately identifiable, marking can be implemented in a way that achieves that outcome by using an account marker for eligible depositors. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] The PRA explains that, for meeting Depositor Protection 11.1, marking eligible deposits may be done by marking accounts of eligible depositors that contain eligible deposits, which indicates that an account-level marker can be an acceptable way to implement the marking requirement. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] If an account that has the eligible deposit marker later has a nil balance, or its balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect the firm to remove the marker. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] Accordingly, the firm should design its marking process so the marker supports immediate identification of eligible deposits while remaining in place on the relevant account even through zero or negative balances. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5]
source_text: For the purposes of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1 , the PRA considers the marking of eligible deposits may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors which contain eligible deposits. For the avoidance of doubt, where such an account has a nil balance, or the balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect firms to remove the eligible deposit marker.
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: When a firm applies the matching adjustment and is preparing to provide an attestation in accordance with 9.1, how must it connect its analysis of the fundamental spread and the ability to earn the matching adjustment from the relevant portfolio of assets to its ongoing risk management duties?
gold_answer: A firm that applies the matching adjustment must treat its pre-attestation analysis as an input into its risk management, and then actively manage the risks that analysis identifies. [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc] Before it provides any attestation in accordance with 9.1, the firm must perform an analysis and justification showing (i) the fundamental spread it uses reflects compensation for all retained risks and (ii) the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] Where that analysis (including the assessment of retained risks and the confidence in earning the matching adjustment from the portfolio) identifies risks, the firm must manage those identified risks as required when applying the matching adjustment. [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc] In practice, this means the firm should ensure the risks it retains—captured through its fundamental spread justification—are not only identified but also subject to management actions, and that the portfolio-based confidence assessment is supported by risk management that addresses any vulnerabilities revealed by the analysis. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] This linkage is required because the attestation is preceded by analysis and justification, while the application of the matching adjustment carries an explicit duty to manage risks identified in the relevant analysis. [#TGT:4d06c3de64a9c9ce] [#SRC:afd68bad9897c2bc]
source_text: (4) Where a firm applies the matching adjustment , the firm must manage any risks that are identified in the analysis undertaken in accordance with Matching Adjustment 10.1 .
target_text: Before providing any attestation in accordance with 9.1 , a firm must analyse and justify that the fundamental spread used by the firm reflects compensation for all retained risks, and that the matching adjustment can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets .

question: How should a firm reconcile the requirement to complete the investigation referred to in 2.1 for the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 with the separate requirement that an investigation into the firm’s financial condition (in respect of its insurance business) be made every third financial year by the appropriate actuary?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017 as a mandatory completion point for the investigation referred to in 2.1, and it must also ensure that investigations into its financial condition for its insurance business occur on a recurring every-third-financial-year cycle and are carried out by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] In practice, this means the firm cannot defer the 2.1 investigation beyond that first qualifying year-end, even if its “every third financial year” cadence would otherwise place the next investigation later. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] The firm should therefore (i) identify the first financial year that ends on or after 1 January 2017 and ensure the 2.1 investigation is completed for that year, and (ii) separately track the ongoing third-financial-year schedule for investigations into the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business, ensuring each such investigation is made by the appropriate actuary. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf] Where the first qualifying year-end also happens to fall on a third-financial-year point, the firm can satisfy both requirements in that same year provided the investigation made by the appropriate actuary covers the firm’s financial condition in respect of its insurance business and is completed for that financial year. [#SRC:fbe9526d072301c2] [#TGT:3caa12ffd3bf3daf]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the investigation referred to in 2.1 is completed in respect of the first financial year ending on or after 1 January 2017.
target_text: A firm must ensure that an investigation is made by the appropriate actuary into the financial condition of the firm in respect of its insurance business every third financial year .

question: If the firm is outsourcing a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider in the same group, what does the firm need to think about regarding control or influence, and how should that show up in the written agreement mentioned in 7.5(3) so it matches the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A?
gold_answer: When the firm outsources a critical or important operational function or activity to a service provider that is in the same group, the firm must consider how much it controls the service provider or how much it can influence the service provider’s actions. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] That consideration should then be reflected in how the firm prepares the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3), because the firm must ensure the agreement’s terms and conditions are consistent with the firm’s obligations under 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] Put simply, the firm cannot treat the agreement as a generic outsourcing contract: for intra-group outsourcing of critical or important functions, the firm must build the agreement in a way that aligns with (i) the firm’s required assessment of its control or influence over the service provider and (ii) the firm’s obligations in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A. [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5] [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] The compliance check is therefore twofold: confirm the agreement is consistent with the obligations referenced in 7.1, 7.2 and 7.2A, and confirm that, because the provider is in the same group, the firm has taken its control/influence into account when setting the agreement’s terms. [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a] [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5]
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: Where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group , the firm must, when outsourcing any critical or important operational functions or activities, take into account the extent to which the firm controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.

question: For a TWD firm projecting exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, how should it determine what qualifies as an “exit cost” for positions that will be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the TWD scenario’s actions, arrangements and measures?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should treat “exit costs” as a specific, quantifiable component of the broader set of items it is expected to project from the assumed reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] In determining what qualifies as an exit cost, the firm should calculate, for each position that is intended to be novated, terminated, or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures of the TWD scenario, the difference between (i) the expected exit value under that TWD scenario and (ii) the accounting book value of that position. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] This definition links the firm’s projection obligation to a concrete measurement method: the firm’s exit-cost projection should be built by identifying the relevant positions covered by the TWD scenario’s planned actions and then measuring the “gap” between expected exit value and book value for those positions. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] The resulting exit-cost figures should be capable of being projected from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period alongside the firm’s other projected elements (operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs). [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 24. An exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and accounting book value for positions to be novated, terminated or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario.

question: If a firm is working out its with-profits policy liabilities using the retrospective aggregate method (and the plus/minus rule for items that increase or reduce future liability to policyholders), what does it mean for earlier additions to those liabilities to be “permanent enhancements” for surplus funds, and what should the firm do if its view of what is permanent changes later?
gold_answer: For surplus funds purposes, “permanent enhancements” are amounts that were previously added to with-profits policy liabilities and that the firm expects, at the time it calculates surplus funds, to stay in place except in the most extreme adverse circumstances. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] If the firm later changes which additions it considers permanent, it should reflect that change in later surplus funds calculations rather than leaving the earlier view unchanged. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] Separately, unless the circumstances in 3.2 apply, the firm must calculate the value of its with-profits policy liabilities (other than future policy-related liabilities) by adding up, for each with-profits policy, the retrospective value of the relevant items. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] In doing that retrospective calculation, the firm must treat items that increase the future liability to policyholders as positive numbers and items that reduce the future liability to policyholders as negative numbers. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] Put together, the firm should (i) decide which prior additions are expected to be permanent for the surplus funds calculation date, and (ii) compute the underlying with-profits policy liabilities using the retrospective, per-policy aggregation approach with the required positive/negative treatment. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79]
source_text: The reference to ‘permanent enhancements’ within Surplus Funds 3.3(3) is intended to capture amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities which a firm expects to be permanent at the time of the surplus funds calculation (ie to apply in all but the most extreme adverse circumstances). Any change in the additions that are considered permanent over time should be reflected in subsequent calculations of surplus funds.

question: If a firm is working out its Class A tariff base, what SCV information does it have to use (and to what standard at the valuation date), and what kinds of account balances must it still include even if the account holder is not absolutely entitled—plus what can it leave out?
gold_answer: For the Class A tariff base, the firm must calculate using covered deposits taken from the SCV file, and it must use information that matches what the firm would have to include in its single customer view. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] The information used for the calculation must also meet the extent and standard that would apply if the firm were preparing the single customer view in line with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base. [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] Alongside that SCV-based method, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account holding funds where the account holder is not absolutely entitled, and it must also include safeguarded funds under the rules when building the tariff base figure. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] Even with those inclusions, the firm is allowed to exclude any funds that it has confirmed are not covered deposits, meaning the SCV-based covered-deposit population can be reduced only where the firm has made that confirmation. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]
source_text: Depositor Protection 43 sets out the PRA’s rule for calculating the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base). Depositor Protection 43.2 requires firms to do this calculation on the basis of covered deposits from the SCV file. Depositor Protection 43.1 requires firms to include the total balance of deposits in any account which holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, under the rules. Any funds which the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits may be excluded.
target_text: The class A tariff base calculation must be made on the basis of the information that the firm would have to include in its single customer views . The information must be of the extent and standard required if the firm was preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base.

question: If an insurer is building its risk monitoring metrics and deciding what liquidity buffer(s) to hold, what does the text say the buffer is for and what kinds of things should be monitored, including how this applies to both UK Solvency II firms (and related entities) and non-Directive insurers?
gold_answer: When the insurer sets up its risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, the buffer should be treated as liquid assets held to help the insurer meet liabilities as they fall due, and the metrics should support monitoring that buffer. [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352] For a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents, the described requirement is to invest in assets that keep the investment portfolio liquid and to assess whether the assets are appropriate for paying obligations when they are due. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] The guideline expectations described also point to specific monitoring topics that can be built into the metrics: the insurer should look at total liquidity needs (including an appropriate liquidity buffer), track the level and monitoring of liquid assets, and consider possible haircuts that might apply if assets have to be sold. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] For a non-Directive insurer, the stated expectation is to maintain adequate liquidity so there is no significant risk of being unable to meet liabilities as they fall due, which reinforces the buffer’s purpose. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] The buffer is also expected to be sufficient in both benign and stressed conditions, so monitoring should be able to reflect performance in those conditions. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: If the firm is a UK ISPV, whose signatures are needed on the 5.4 record every time it is updated?
gold_answer: If the firm is a UK ISPV, the 5.4 signing rule still applies, but the role named in that rule is adjusted: any mention of a key function holder is read as meaning a PRA senior management function holder. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] With that adjustment, the 5.4 record and each updated version must carry two signatures: one from the PRA senior management function holder (in place of the key function holder) and one from an appropriate representative of the firm. [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] Practically, this requires the firm to obtain both signatures not only when the record is first prepared but also whenever the record is revised, because the requirement explicitly covers “each updated version.” [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] The UK ISPV-specific reading is what determines which individual satisfies the “key function holder” signatory slot, so the firm should route the record to the relevant PRA senior management function holder for signature rather than treating the key function holder as a separate category for UK ISPV purposes. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c]
source_text: The requirements in 5.4 and 5.6 apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV as if any reference to a key function holder were a reference to a PRA senior management function holder .
target_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .

question: For a firm with a TMTP permission that decides to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, what must it disclose and how should it determine the “maximum amount,” including how that maximum is derived under the TMTP method or a legacy approach in its permission?
gold_answer: Where a firm with a TMTP permission chooses to apply less than the maximum transitional deduction, it should treat the “maximum amount” as the upper bound of the permitted range (with the applied amount falling between zero and that maximum) and then disclose both figures. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The “maximum amount” for this purpose is the maximum number produced either by the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or by the legacy approach described in the firm’s relevant permission, so the firm must identify which of those two bases applies to it when determining the maximum. [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33] In terms of transparency and supervisory engagement, when applying less than the maximum, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and to share the same information with its supervision team. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The firm should also maintain a transparent, consistently applied approach to determining the TMTP benefit it applies, and the PRA expects that approach to be followed across all Solvency II reporting (including QRTs) and reflected in the firm’s ORSA and risk management framework. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]
source_text: For all firms with a TMTP permission there is a requirement that the amount of the transitional deduction to be applied by a firm is to be between zero and a maximum amount. 6 If a decision is taken by such a firm to apply less than the maximum amount, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures, and to share this information with its supervision team. The firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the amount of TMTP benefit it is applying. The PRA expects this approach to be followed consistently by firms within all Solvency II reporting including for Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs). This approach should also be reflected within a firm’s ORSA and risk management framework.
target_text: 6. The amount is the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or the legacy approach outlined in the relevant firm’s permission.

question: If a credit union has more than £10 million in total assets and also does additional activities that involve more complex investments (like supranational bonds or money market funds), what does it need to do about its investment policy, and what does the PRA expect about concentration limits (including any exception mentioned)?
gold_answer: In this situation, the credit union is expected to address both internal governance and portfolio concentration, because the passages describe expectations that apply to (a) credit unions over £10 million in assets and (b) credit unions investing in more complex investments or undertaking additional activities. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] On governance, credit unions undertaking additional activities are expected to keep an investment policy that has been approved by the board. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c] On concentration, the PRA expects credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets to comply with the concentration limits it sets out for that group, and it also applies that expectation to any credit union holding investments that fall under Rules 6.4(7) and 6.4(8) of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] When applying those concentration limits, the PRA notes an exception for the investments listed in paragraph 11.2. [#TGT:6cdd849d0a0503ce] The additional expectations tied to the £10 million threshold and to more complex investments are indicated as being located in Chapters 11 and 14, respectively, which frames where the credit union should look for the detailed expectations. [#SRC:183eb2475d6b7e0c]
source_text: Additional expectations relating to investments for credit unions with more than £10 million in assets and credit unions that invest in more complex investments (supranational bonds, corporate bonds, bank bonds, and money market funds) are set out in Chapters 11 and 14 , respectively. Credit unions undertaking additional activities 4 are also expected to maintain a board-approved investment policy (see paragraph 14.2 in Chapter 14 ).

question: Where a CRR firm is a member of a group, how does the Part’s general scope interact with the special treatment of an Article 109 undertaking, and what specific compliance obligation is imposed on an Article 109 undertaking in relation to the types of groups it belongs to?
gold_answer: For a CRR firm that is a member of a group, the Part generally applies, but it does so with an express carve-out that preserves the application of provision 2.3 specifically for an Article 109 undertaking. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] In other words, the scope statement both brings group-member CRR firms within the Part and simultaneously signals that Article 109 undertakings are treated differently by identifying 2.3 as the relevant hook for them. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] Separately and more concretely, an Article 109 undertaking has a defined compliance duty: it must comply with 2.1(2) not only for its own group, but also for any UK consolidation group or non-UK sub-group of which it is a member. [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8] This means that, when the entity is an Article 109 undertaking, the compliance analysis must connect the Part’s scope carve-out for Article 109 undertakings with the specific requirement to apply 2.1(2) across each relevant group context (UK consolidation group, non-UK sub-group, and its group). [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8]
source_text: This Part applies to a CRR firm that is a member of a group save that 2.3 applies to an Article 109 undertaking .
target_text: An Article 109 undertaking must comply with 2.1 (2) in relation to any UK consolidation group or non- UK sub-group of which it is a member, as well as in relation to its group .

question: If the Merger Notification Statement has to be approved by the PRA before it goes to members, what does the board need to say about any financial changes since the financial period ended, and what compensation details must be included for directors or other officers of the transferor society?
gold_answer: The Merger Notification Statement cannot be sent to members until it has been approved by the PRA, and it must then be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Because the financial information used will cover a period ending before the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, the board must tell members whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the period between the financial information’s end date and the approval date. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] Where a material change has been identified but cannot be measured in numbers, the board must still explain the change in words so members know it has been identified and is relevant to their decision on the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] Separately, the Merger Notification Statement must set out particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The board should also be aware that not disclosing interim material changes will matter to the PRA when it later considers the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: How should a firm operationalise its record-keeping for outsourcing arrangements so that it can meet the PRA’s expectation to provide information the PRA would reasonably expect notice of, and how does Fundamental Rule 7 shape what must be disclosed to the PRA?
gold_answer: A firm should maintain records of its outsourcing arrangements at a level that supports timely, appropriate disclosure to the PRA of matters the PRA would reasonably expect to be told about, because the PRA expects both robust record-keeping and proactive availability of relevant information. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] Fundamental Rule 7 frames the disclosure standard by requiring the firm to deal with regulators openly and cooperatively and to disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice. [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] In practice, the firm should (i) keep appropriate records of outsourcing arrangements, including records of material outsourcing arrangements that it would likely already hold when complying with 2.3(1)(e) of the Notifications Part of the PRA Rulebook; and (ii) ensure those records are sufficient to enable the firm to fulfil the PRA’s expectations concerning concentration risk referenced in 5.24. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] The firm should then make information on its outsourcing and third party arrangements available to the PRA where the PRA would reasonably expect notice, aligning the content and timing of what is provided with the Fundamental Rule 7 obligation to disclose appropriately and cooperate. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d] [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd] Separately, the firm should be prepared that the PRA may request data on outsourcing arrangements under section 165 of FSMA where appropriate and justified, which reinforces the need for well-organised records. [#SRC:ff27a2b6ca15a12d]
source_text: The PRA expects all firms to keep appropriate records of their outsourcing arrangements. The PRA considers that a firm, in complying with 2.3(1)(e) of the Notifications Part of the PRA Rulebook, would likely already have records of its material outsourcing arrangements for this purpose. The records should also be sufficient to enable the firm to fulfil the expectations concerning concentration risk set out in 5.24 . Firms should also make any information on their outsourcing and third party arrangements of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice available to it in accordance with Fundamental Rule 7 . The PRA may, if appropriate and justified, also request data on firms’ outsourcing arrangements under section 165 of FSMA. 34
target_text: Fundamental Rule 7: A firm must deal with its regulators in an open and cooperative way and must disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice.

question: For a TWD firm preparing information under this SS, how should Template A (Appendix 1) be used alongside the PRA’s broader expectation for templates and instructions, and what specific analytical capability must the firm be able to evidence through the data it can produce?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should treat Template A (Appendix 1) as one of the templates that guides the level of detail the PRA expects the firm to be able to produce under this SS, and use it to evidence a specific analytical capability rather than as a generic data request. [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c] In particular, Template A is described as a guide to the breadth and granularity of data the firm should be able to provide to demonstrate that it can analyse exit costs and liquidity flows. [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8] The firm’s output should therefore be structured to show analysis “through the segmentation of the balance sheet,” and that segmentation must be done by both the method of exit and the price of exit. [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8] This linkage matters because the PRA’s expectation is framed at the level of producing data under the SS using the templates and accompanying instructions, while Template A specifies the concrete analytical demonstration the data must support (exit costs and liquidity flows via balance-sheet segmentation by method and price). [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c] [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8]
source_text: Template A (Appendix 1) provides a guide to the breadth and granularity of data that TWD firms should be able to provide to demonstrate an ability to analyse exit costs and liquidity flows through the segmentation of the balance sheet by method and price of exit.
target_text: The following templates and accompanying instructions provide a guide to the breadth and granularity of data that the PRA would expect TWD firms to be able to produce under this SS. They are available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2021/october/trading-activity-wind-down .

question: If an outsourcing or third party arrangement uses an ICT service (like cloud), does that automatically make it “material outsourcing,” and what steps should the firm follow to decide—especially given the PRA says “material outsourcing” covers what some rules call “critical or important outsourcing”?
gold_answer: No—using an ICT product or service (such as cloud) does not automatically make an outsourcing arrangement material. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] The firm should still decide materiality by looking at all applicable criteria in Table 5, considering each criterion on its own and also how the criteria work together, for arrangements that are not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] In doing so, the firm should apply the PRA’s terminology: the PRA uses “material outsourcing” for clarity and indicates that, for practical purposes, a “material outsourcing” arrangement includes what retained EU legislation or PRA rules describe as a “critical or important outsourcing” arrangement. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The firm can also take comfort that the criteria it uses to identify “material outsourcing” are described as substantively aligned with the criteria for identifying “critical or important outsourcing arrangements” under the EBA Outsourcing GL, while noting there are some justified exceptions, including ones tied to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The decision should therefore come from applying the Table 5 criteria within this PRA framing, not from ICT presence alone. [#TGT:1899b72a48748aa1] [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b]
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms to have regard to all applicable criteria in Table 5 below, both individually and in conjunction, when assessing the materiality of an outsourcing or third party arrangement not otherwise covered by paragraphs 5.8 and 5.9 . Although in practice many material outsourcing and third party arrangements involve ICT products or services (eg cloud), the presence of a given ICT product or service does not, in itself, automatically render an outsourcing arrangement material.

question: When calculating the FSCS Class A tariff base, how must a firm determine the information basis and quality standard for the covered-deposits calculation, and how does that interact with the requirement to include balances in accounts holding funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled or which are safeguarded funds (including any permitted exclusions)?
gold_answer: A firm calculating the FSCS Class A tariff base must base the calculation on covered deposits using the SCV file, and it must do so using the same information set and quality standard that would be required for its single customer view as at the valuation date for the tariff base. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] In practice, this means the firm should treat the SCV-derived covered-deposit data as the core input, but ensure that the data included is as complete and prepared to the same extent and standard as if the firm were preparing the single customer view in line with the SCV requirements at that valuation date. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf] Within that SCV-based approach, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account that holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, as well as any safeguarded funds, when applying the rules for the tariff base. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] However, the firm may exclude funds that it has confirmed are not covered deposits, even though the calculation is otherwise grounded in SCV information prepared to the required valuation-date standard. [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]
source_text: Depositor Protection 43 sets out the PRA’s rule for calculating the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base). Depositor Protection 43.2 requires firms to do this calculation on the basis of covered deposits from the SCV file. Depositor Protection 43.1 requires firms to include the total balance of deposits in any account which holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, under the rules. Any funds which the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits may be excluded.
target_text: The class A tariff base calculation must be made on the basis of the information that the firm would have to include in its single customer views . The information must be of the extent and standard required if the firm was preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base.

question: If a CRR firm is in a group, does this Part apply, and what extra rule applies when the firm is an Article 109 undertaking—especially about which groups it has to follow 2.1(2) for?
gold_answer: If a CRR firm is a member of a group, this Part applies to it as the default position. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] However, the scope text also makes clear there is a specific exception-style treatment for an Article 109 undertaking, because it states that 2.3 applies to an Article 109 undertaking even within that general scope framework. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] For an Article 109 undertaking, the concrete compliance requirement described is that it must comply with 2.1(2) in relation to multiple group settings: any UK consolidation group of which it is a member, any non-UK sub-group of which it is a member, and also its group. [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8] Putting these together, when the entity is an Article 109 undertaking you should not stop at the general statement that the Part applies to group-member CRR firms; you must also recognize the special reference to 2.3 and ensure 2.1(2) is applied across each of the specified group categories tied to the undertaking’s memberships. [#SRC:dc14bff9877a00fe] [#TGT:2e47547ee682f3f8]
source_text: This Part applies to a CRR firm that is a member of a group save that 2.3 applies to an Article 109 undertaking .
target_text: An Article 109 undertaking must comply with 2.1 (2) in relation to any UK consolidation group or non- UK sub-group of which it is a member, as well as in relation to its group .

question: If you’re checking an asset’s permitted exposure limit, where do you look for the limits, and what happens if the asset isn’t covered by 28.2 to 28.22 and it’s not a derivative?
gold_answer: You determine the permitted asset exposure limit by referring to the limits set out in the specified rule range, and you also need to apply a special “default” limit for certain assets that are not covered by most of that range. Specifically, the permitted asset exposure limits are the ones contained in 28.2 through 28.23, so you should check those provisions to see whether the asset is covered and what limit is stated there. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] If the asset is not covered by 28.2 through 28.22 and it is not a derivative, then the permitted asset exposure limit is nil, meaning the exposure limit is zero for that asset. [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315] Putting these together, your process is: first, look within 28.2–28.23 for an applicable limit; second, if you cannot find coverage for the asset in 28.2–28.22 and the asset is not a derivative, you must treat the permitted limit as nil rather than trying to infer a limit from elsewhere in the 28.2–28.23 range. [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:15448cfaa68fe315]
source_text: The permitted asset exposure limits are those set out in 28.2 to 28.23 .
target_text: In the case of an asset which is not covered by 28.2 to 28.22 (other than a derivative ), the permitted asset exposure limit is nil.

question: When may an institution calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions using the method in Section 5, given the monthly assessment and threshold condition, and what prohibition applies if the institution does not meet the relevant Article 273a conditions?
gold_answer: An institution may use the Section 5 method to calculate the exposure value of its derivative positions only if it satisfies the eligibility framework that combines (i) the monthly size assessment and threshold test and (ii) the separate condition-based prohibition tied to Article 273a. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] Specifically, the institution is permitted to calculate exposure value under Section 5 (and only “subject to the restriction set out in Article 273b(2)”) provided it assesses, on a monthly basis using data as of the last day of each month, whether the size of its on- and off-balance-sheet derivative business is at or below both thresholds referenced in the rule. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] In addition to meeting that monthly threshold-based gate, the institution must also meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(2); if it does not meet those Article 273a(2) conditions, it is not allowed to use the method in Section 5 at all, regardless of the monthly assessment outcome. [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598] Therefore, compliance requires both: passing the monthly, month-end-data threshold assessment (and respecting the Article 273b(2) restriction) and satisfying Article 273a(2), because failure on the Article 273a(2) conditions triggers an outright prohibition on Section 5 usage. [#TGT:76ff5419b175628d] [#SRC:9eb9559cd3b01598]
source_text: An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(1) shall not use the method set out in Section 4 . An institution which does not meet the conditions set out in Article 273a(2) shall not use the method set out in Section 5 .

question: When an institution that acts as a clearing member is calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5, and it also applies the Section 5 method to determine the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor may it apply in that client-exposure calculation, and how does that fit within the overall CVA own-funds computation?
gold_answer: An institution that acts as a clearing member may integrate two specific calculation features when determining its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI: it may base the CVA calculation on a reduced exposure at default derived from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5, and—when separately calculating the own funds requirement for exposures to a client using the Section 5 method—it may apply a maturity factor of 0.21 within that Section 5 calculation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This combination is available only where the institution is acting as a clearing member, because both the reduced exposure-at-default permission and the maturity-factor permission are framed for an institution in that role. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] Operationally, the institution can (i) use the reduced exposure at default produced by the specified paragraph 3–5 calculations for purposes of its Title VI CVA own-funds requirement, and (ii) in the distinct context of applying the Section 5 method to compute the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client, use the 0.21 maturity factor as part of that computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The maturity factor of 0.21 is expressly permitted as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]
source_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default resulting from the calculations set out in paragraphs 3 , 4 and 5 for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Title VI.
target_text: By way of derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) , where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client , that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation.

question: If a firm is a ‘UK trading bank’ (as defined in the text) and the PRA’s booking expectations apply to it, who should be put in charge of overseeing booking arrangements, what paperwork should show that, and when could someone in the parent or another group company need SMF7 approval?
gold_answer: If the firm is a ‘UK trading bank’—meaning it is a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is UK-headquartered or part of a UK-based group and it carries on investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas—then it is within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations identified in the supervisory statement (including the specified paragraphs and the Annex on Context and definitions). [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] Where those expectations apply, the PRA expects the firm to give an SMF responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements. [#TGT:a696590f07b39032] The firm should also record that responsibility in the relevant person’s Statement of Responsibilities so the oversight role is formally documented. [#TGT:a696590f07b39032] Separately, if people in the parent or other group entities have significant influence over how one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities are managed or conducted, it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7). [#TGT:a696590f07b39032] The supervisory statement also signals that it clarifies where booking expectations apply to international banks only versus both international banks and UK trading banks, and it points to a terminology summary for scope. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. We make clear in the relevant sections where the expectations apply to international banks alone, and where they apply to international banks and UK trading banks. See paragraph 4.24B for a summary of the terminology used to describe the scope of application for the booking expectations.
target_text: Where applicable, the PRA expects firms to allocate the responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF, and record this appropriately in their Statement of Responsibilities. Where individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, it may be appropriate for them to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7).
