target_text: If an undertaking proposes to establish or amend a debt securities programme for the issue of an item which the firm intends to include within the basic own funds forming the own funds eligible for the group SCR , the firm must:

question: If a firm is allowed to use a partial or full internal model, what does it have to send the PRA every quarter about model changes, and which template and instructions tell it what to include (including qualitative support)?
gold_answer: If a firm has permission to use a partial or full internal model, it has to send the PRA a quarterly update about changes to that model. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] The quarterly update must be a summary that covers both minor and major model changes, and it is required under Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook together with the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] To provide the information in the required reporting format, firms using an internal model must submit quarterly template QMC.01 in Chapter 9. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] That template is used to specify information on model changes and to include supporting qualitative information, so the quarterly summary is not just a list of changes but also includes qualitative support. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The firm must also follow the instructions in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10, which sets out how to complete the template and what information to provide. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] In practice, the firm meets the quarterly summary requirement by completing and submitting QMC.01 with the required model-change details and qualitative support to the PRA each quarter. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When the PRA applies its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state requirements, what does the PRA expect regarding (i) meeting MREL alongside CET1 held for risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers, and (ii) avoiding any double counting of CET1 across those expectations?
gold_answer: Where the PRA is applying its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) in relation to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, firms are expected to satisfy MREL while also maintaining CET1 at a level that reflects their risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe] [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] In doing so, the PRA’s expectation is that firms should not count the same CET1 twice—once toward meeting MREL and again toward the CET1 amount that reflects the risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] Although CET1 can be used to meet MREL, firms are not required to meet MREL using CET1, which reinforces the expectation that CET1 held to reflect buffers should not be automatically treated as simultaneously fulfilling MREL. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The scope of these expectations is framed by the PRA’s application of the Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 policies to the Bank-set MREL across both interim and end-state requirements, meaning the same non-double-counting approach should be observed in that policy context. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]
source_text: The PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy ( Chapter 2 ) and Threshold Conditions policy ( Chapter 3 ) in respect of MREL set by the Bank with respect to both interim and end-state MREL requirements.
target_text: The PRA expects firms to meet both MREL and maintain an amount of CET1 that reflects their risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. The PRA expects firms not to double count CET1 towards both MREL and the amount reflecting the risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. While firms can meet MREL with CET1, they do not have to meet it with CET1. See ‘The Bank of England’s approach to setting MREL’ 5 for details.

question: For a CRR firm preparing its self-assessment of its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances, how must it incorporate (i) additional risks arising from elsewhere in its group and (ii) the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services, including the disruption scenario and the scope of entities to be assessed?
gold_answer: A CRR firm’s self-assessment must go beyond its own operations by identifying extra risks to staying within impact tolerances that come from elsewhere in its group, and it must also be informed by the CRR consolidation entity’s work on important group business services. [#SRC:525172756112897c] In practice, the CRR consolidation entity’s work that informs the self-assessment includes an assessment of whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group that provides an important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that service when facing a severe but plausible disruption to its operations. [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] The linkage is that the self-assessment’s group-risk identification is complemented by (and should take account of) the consolidation-group-wide testing of resilience against a defined disruption scenario for each important group business service. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb] Accordingly, the CRR firm should ensure its self-assessment reflects both (i) group-derived risks affecting its ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances and (ii) the consolidation entity’s conclusions about whether each relevant consolidation group member can remain within the applicable impact tolerance under severe-but-plausible disruption conditions. [#SRC:525172756112897c] [#TGT:4e1aaf4d13ad6adb]
source_text: identify any additional risks to their ability to deliver important business services within impact tolerances arising from elsewhere in their group. In the case of a CRR firm, the self-assessment should also be informed by any work the CRR consolidation entity has undertaken to comply with the requirements under Rules 8.6 , 8.7 and 8.8 , regarding important group business services and whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group could remain within impact tolerance.
target_text: A CRR consolidation entity must assess whether each member of the CRR consolidation entity’s consolidation group providing each important group business service could remain within the impact tolerance set for that important group business service in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.

question: If a counterparty is under liquidity stress and might “recall sleeper collateral,” what does “sleeper collateral” mean here, and why could that recall be a problem for the insurer?
gold_answer: Here, “sleeper collateral” means collateral value that an insurer is already contractually required to post to a counterparty, but has not posted yet because the counterparty has not called for it. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] A recall of sleeper collateral is flagged as one of the ways stressed counterparties or other market participants can create liquidity pressure that could adversely affect the insurer. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] Putting those two points together, the recall matters because it can turn an unposted, call-dependent obligation into an immediate liquidity need for the insurer, even though nothing had been posted before the call. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] The same stress scenario also includes other potentially harmful actions—like selling similar assets that the insurer may rely on for liquidity (which can move market prices), not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes—so a sleeper-collateral recall should be viewed as part of a broader set of stress-driven behaviors that can worsen the insurer’s liquidity situation. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] In short, the insurer should treat sleeper collateral as a contingent obligation that can be activated by a counterparty’s recall during liquidity stress. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]
source_text: actions of counterparties, and other market participants experiencing liquidity stresses that could adversely affect the insurer, for instance by selling similar assets to those that the insurer may rely on for liquidity and affecting market prices, recalling sleeper collateral, 17 not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes.
target_text: 17. Sleeper collateral refers to the value of collateral that an insurer is contractually obliged to post to a counterparty, but has not yet posted as it has not yet been called by the counterparty.

question: If a firm is trying to meet the Chapter’s expectations and wants to plan for situations where it might need a solvent exit, what kind of scenarios should it think about, and which two named recovery-planning references can it use to build or adapt those scenarios?
gold_answer: To meet the Chapter’s expectations, the firm should think through plausible situations that could realistically lead to the firm needing to execute a solvent exit, using those circumstances as the basis for its planning. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The firm is allowed to use scenario work it already has from recovery planning, and it may adapt those recovery-planning scenarios so they help the firm understand when a solvent exit might become necessary. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The recovery-planning sources specifically pointed to for those recovery planning expectations are (1) Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and (2) the ‘(a) Design’ component under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ in SS9/17. [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a] Practically, that means the firm’s solvent-exit scenario thinking should be built around plausible solvent-exit-triggering circumstances, while being informed by the scenario design and scenario testing material referenced in those two recovery-planning documents. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]
source_text: In meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm should take account of plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit (see Box A for illustrative examples). A firm may draw on and adapt scenarios developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations 19 to inform it of such circumstances.
target_text: 19. Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook; and ‘(a) Design’ under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17.

question: If a credit union wants to sell shares inside an ISA tax-free wrapper and also wants to start offering fixed-rate shares or deposits, can it rely on HMRC approval to skip other legal requirements, and what does the PRA expect it to do before it starts the fixed-rate products?
gold_answer: No. Even if the credit union gets approval from HMRC in connection with offering shares in an ISA tax-free wrapper, that approval does not give it any exemption from complying with the statutory requirements referenced in the source passage. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] Separately, for the fixed-rate side, the PRA’s expectation is that any credit union intending to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be met before it begins that activity. [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] Read together, the key point is that HMRC approval relates to the ISA wrapper context and does not remove statutory compliance duties, while the PRA frames statutory compliance for fixed-rate issuance as a condition that must be satisfied in advance of starting. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b] So the credit union should both refer to the relevant HMRC regulations for the ISA offering and ensure it has met the statutory mandatory requirements before launching fixed-rate shares or deposits, without treating HMRC approval as a substitute for those statutory obligations. [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d] [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]
source_text: Credit unions that wish to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper are expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC). Credit unions should be aware that approval from HMRC does not provide any degree of exemption from compliance with the statutory requirements referred to above in paragraph 5.2 .
target_text: The PRA expects that any credit union that intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits complies with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning such activity. 2

question: When a firm seeks to include an asset with cash flows that are not fixed in its relevant portfolio of assets under regulation 4(9) of the IRPR regulations, what specific evidential showing must it make about predictability and materiality, and how does the interpretive limitation in the related guidance constrain when such assets can be treated as not creating material risks to the quality of matching?
gold_answer: To include an asset with cash flows that are not fixed in a firm’s relevant portfolio of assets under the regulation 4(9) condition, the firm must be able to demonstrate two linked points: (1) that the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable, and (2) that the risks to the quality of matching are not material. [#SRC:1865ea7a3f01fff9] The interpretive limitation clarifies how these points fit together for regulation 4(9): such assets are only capable of being included without giving rise to material risks to the quality of matching if the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable. [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf] In practice, this means the firm’s evidence on predictability is not merely supportive but is the gating criterion for treating the asset as not creating material matching risk under regulation 4(9). [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf] Accordingly, the evidential package should explicitly address the predictability of the non-fixed cash flows and separately confirm that, on that basis, any residual risks to matching quality are not material. [#SRC:1865ea7a3f01fff9] If the firm cannot substantiate that the non-fixed cash flows are highly predictable, the interpretive limitation indicates the asset cannot be treated as includable on the basis that it does not give rise to material risks to the quality of matching. [#TGT:d2e8a1f59f1408cf]
source_text: ii. evidence that, in relation to any asset with cash flows that are not fixed, the asset cash flows are highly predictable (regulations 4(9)(a) and 4(10) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 5 ) and that the risks to the quality of matching are not material;
target_text: For the purpose, and without limiting the generality, of the condition in regulation 4(9) of the IRPR regulations , assets with cash-flows that are not fixed are only capable of being included in a firm’s relevant portfolio of assets without giving rise to material risks to the quality of matching if the cash-flows that are not fixed are highly predictable .

question: When explaining Pillar 2B to a firm, how should the PRA describe (i) what the PRA buffer is intended to do within the capital stack relative to the TCR and combined buffer, and (ii) how Section II frames the PRA’s use of Pillar 2B in relation to weak governance and risk management and group risk (including RFB group risk)?
gold_answer: A compliant explanation should present Pillar 2B as both a defined capital layer in the PRA’s capital framework and as a supervisory tool whose determination and application are discussed in Section II, including its linkage to governance and group-risk considerations. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995] Specifically, the PRA buffer (Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms are expected to hold on top of their total capital requirement (TCR) and the combined buffer, and it is designed to absorb losses that could occur under a severe stress scenario while avoiding overlap with the combined buffers. [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] In describing how it fits in the capital stack, the explanation should make clear that the PRA buffer, the combined buffer, and the TCR together constitute the PRA’s capital framework (as depicted by the capital stack). [#TGT:37bcd95fb7b21224] To connect this capital-stack description to Section II’s supervisory framing, the explanation should also note that Section II sets out the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined, and how it relates to the CRD buffers, and it further describes the PRA’s approach to addressing weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B as well as group risk, including RFB group risk. [#SRC:1399703aeb306995]
source_text: Section II: Pillar 2B provides information on the purpose of the PRA buffer, how it is determined and how it relates to the CRD buffers. Section II also provides details on the PRA’s approach to tackling weak governance and risk management under Pillar 2B and group risk, including RFB group risk.
target_text: The PRA buffer (also referred to as Pillar 2B) is an amount of capital firms should maintain in addition to their total capital requirement 32 (TCR) and the combined buffer. The PRA buffer absorbs losses that may arise under a severe stress scenario, while avoiding duplication with the combined buffers. Together the PRA buffer, the combined buffer 33 and the TCR make up the PRA’s capital framework as illustrated by the capital stack in Figure 2.

question: If someone is claiming compensation for a temporary high balance, when should the FSCS pay, and what happens if the depositor’s written application or evidence has a material mistake or leaves something important out (including when the FSCS thinks it was wholly unintentional)?
gold_answer: For a temporary high balance claim, the FSCS is required to pay compensation within three months of the compensation date, unless an exception in 10.9 to 10.11 applies. [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] However, that payment outcome depends on the claim not being rejected based on what the depositor submitted. [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] If the depositor’s written application or evidence contains a material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS is allowed to reject the claim for compensation, which would mean no payment is made (including within the three-month period). [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] There is an important carve-out: even where there is a material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may still accept the claim if it considers the problem to be wholly unintentional. [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c] So, the practical sequence is: first, the FSCS assesses whether the depositor’s written application/evidence has a material error or missing information and whether any such issue is wholly unintentional; then, if the claim is not rejected on that basis, the FSCS must pay the temporary high balance compensation within three months of the compensation date (subject to the 10.9 to 10.11 exceptions). [#SRC:620668f3ab20c44f] [#TGT:044561de7cc92e8c]
source_text: The FSCS must pay compensation in respect of a temporary high balance within three months of the compensation date , unless one or more of 10.9 to 10.11 applies.
target_text: If the written application or evidence provided by the depositor under 10.3 contains any material inaccuracy or omission, the FSCS may reject the claim for compensation unless this is considered by the FSCS to be wholly unintentional.

question: Where the Bank has concerns about a subsidiary or its resolution group’s arrangements to deliver orderly resolution by reference to broadly comparable resolution outcomes to those in the Bank’s RAF SoP, how should those concerns be framed when the entity in question is a UK branch of an overseas banking group, given the RAF SoP’s stated scope and the Bank’s engagement approach?
gold_answer: If the Bank is assessing whether a subsidiary or its resolution group has arrangements capable of delivering orderly resolution, it does so by considering whether the resolution outcomes are broadly comparable to those described in the Bank’s RAF SoP. [#SRC:b2f88e21854e1ef3] However, when the entity is a UK branch of an overseas banking group, the RAF SoP is not directly applicable to that branch, so the Bank’s use of the SoP must be framed as informing engagement rather than as applying the SoP to the branch itself. [#TGT:d78ab983ef2f3205] In that branch context, the Bank engages with international counterparts on the branch’s resolvability, and the resolvability outcomes in the SoP inform that engagement and are therefore relevant to overseas banking groups. [#TGT:d78ab983ef2f3205] The SoP also supplies context for the Bank’s engagement, acting as UK resolution authority, with the PRA regarding authorisation and supervision of UK branches of overseas banking groups. [#TGT:d78ab983ef2f3205] Accordingly, any concerns about orderly-resolution arrangements should be articulated by linking them to the SoP’s outcomes as a benchmark for “broadly comparable” outcomes, while recognising that for UK branches the SoP functions as an input to engagement with international counterparts and with the PRA rather than a directly applicable standard. [#SRC:b2f88e21854e1ef3] [#TGT:d78ab983ef2f3205]
source_text: it has concerns about the arrangements for the subsidiary or its resolution group to deliver orderly resolution, taking into account the resolution outcomes that are broadly comparable outcomes as those set out in the Bank’s RAF SoP. 48
target_text: 48. Paragraph 2.7 of the RAF SoP sets out that: ‘This SoP does not apply to the UK branches of overseas banking groups. The Bank engages with international counterparts regarding the resolvability of these branches. The resolvability outcomes in this SoP will therefore inform this engagement and so will be of interest to overseas banking groups in this context. The SoP also provides relevant context for the Bank’s engagement (in its capacity as UK resolution authority) with the PRA in respect of the authorisation and supervision of the UK branches of overseas banking groups’. May 2021: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/paper/2020/updates-to-the-boes-approach-to-assessing-resolvability .

question: If you are a managing agent, what does “SCR” mean in the rules that are applied to you (3.1(2)(b), 3.8(2)(c), and 6.1(1)(i)), and what do you have to calculate for each syndicate you manage because of that?
gold_answer: For a managing agent, in the context of 3.1(2)(b), 3.8(2)(c) and 6.1(1)(i) as they apply to managing agents, “SCR” is not read in a generic way; it is interpreted as the notional syndicate SCR that managing agents must calculate under Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2. [#SRC:44175f318dae3378] That interpretation matters because it ties the meaning of “SCR” in those applied provisions directly to a specific calculated figure (the notional syndicate SCR), rather than any other SCR measure. [#SRC:44175f318dae3378] As a result, you must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which you manage, so that each syndicate has its own notional SCR available to be used wherever those applied provisions refer to “SCR.” [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad] Put simply, the calculation is required at the level of each individual syndicate you manage, and that per-syndicate notional SCR is what the applied provisions mean when they say “SCR.” [#TGT:aabb18c60cd5c8ad] [#SRC:44175f318dae3378]
source_text: (1) 3.1 (2)(b), 3.8 (2)(c) and 6.1 (1)(i), as applied to managing agents , the reference to “ SCR ” is to be interpreted as a reference to the notional syndicate SCR calculated by managing agents as required by Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2 .
target_text: A managing agent must calculate a notional SCR for each syndicate which it manages.

question: When an undertaking proposes to establish or amend a debt securities programme for issuing an item the firm intends to include within the basic own funds forming the own funds eligible for the group SCR, what programme-level conditions must be met regarding (i) changes in law or regulation since the last notification under 6.4 and (ii) the status of instruments issued under the programme?
gold_answer: Where an undertaking proposes to establish or amend a debt securities programme for issuing an item the firm intends to include within the basic own funds forming the own funds eligible for the group SCR, the programme must be structured so that it supports that intended basic own funds treatment. [#TGT:d43cd8def623245e] In particular, the programme must comply with the relevant requirements, and the information previously notified to the PRA under 6.4 about the programme must remain unaffected by any changes in law or regulation (or changes in how those are interpreted or applied) that have taken effect since the last notification made under 6.4. [#SRC:a0002fe3a6bea784] In addition, the programme’s terms must ensure that any instrument issued under the programme constitutes basic own funds. [#SRC:a0002fe3a6bea784] These conditions operate at the programme level and are directly tied to the firm’s intention to include the issued item within basic own funds for group SCR eligibility, so they must be satisfied when the undertaking is proposing to establish or amend the programme for that purpose. [#TGT:d43cd8def623245e]

question: When determining the amount by which a firm must increase its exposure to assets under 23.1 to reflect any exposure of the firm’s dependants, how must the exposure of each dependant be calculated, and how does that calculation connect to the firm’s own exposure amount determined under 18 to 22?
gold_answer: In applying 23.1, the firm must add to its own exposure amount an increment that reflects any exposure of the firm’s dependants to assets of the relevant description, but that increment depends on a specific method for computing each dependant’s exposure. [#SRC:250709f3ef53e2f6] Specifically, for the purposes of 23.1, each dependant’s exposure is not determined by a bespoke dependant-only rule; instead, it must be computed by taking the same provisions used for the firm’s exposure—18 to 22—and applying them to the dependant as though the dependant were itself a firm to which 18 to 22 apply, regardless of whether the dependant is actually such a firm. [#TGT:d0975ff530ed6e30] The linkage is that the firm’s base exposure is first “determined in accordance with 18 to 22,” and then the firm increases that amount by an additional amount representing the dependant exposure to assets of that description, where the dependant exposure is itself calculated by the 18-to-22 methodology applied on a hypothetical “as if it were a firm” basis. [#SRC:250709f3ef53e2f6] [#TGT:d0975ff530ed6e30] This ensures the firm’s increase under 23.1 is grounded in a consistent calculation framework for both the firm and each dependant. [#SRC:250709f3ef53e2f6] [#TGT:d0975ff530ed6e30]
source_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.
target_text: For the purposes of 23.1 , the exposure of each dependant must be calculated by applying 18 to 22 to that dependant as if it were a firm to which those provisions apply (whether it is or not).

question: In the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, what ongoing monitoring is a UK domestic firm expected to perform regarding the controller or proposed controller, and what immediate notification to the PRA is required if the firm identifies potential issues with the information provided in the notice?
gold_answer: A UK domestic firm must both (i) actively monitor relevant developments about the controller or proposed controller connected to the notification and (ii) promptly alert the PRA if it discovers a potential integrity problem in what was submitted. Specifically, during the period referred to in 3.6, the firm is required to take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller to which the notification related. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] In addition, for the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control, the firm must notify the PRA immediately if it becomes aware, or has information reasonably suggesting, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided information to the PRA that was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete, or inaccurate, or that the information has or may have changed in a material particular. [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e] Read together, the “reasonable steps” monitoring obligation supports timely detection of changes or defects in the submitted information, while the separate duty sets the trigger and timing for escalation: once awareness or reasonable suggestion exists within that interim window, notification must be immediate. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]
source_text: During the period referred to in 3.6 , a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or the proposed controller to which the notification related.
target_text: (1) A UK domestic firm must notify the PRA immediately if, in the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control , the firm becomes aware, or has information which reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information which was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular.

question: When structuring a society’s transfer scheme, how should the society identify the Qualifying Day for purposes of determining entitlement to the Statutory Cash Bonus, and which specific class of shareholders must receive the section 100(2)(b) and (4) bonus based on that Qualifying Day?
gold_answer: For a transfer scheme, the society should designate a single Qualifying Day as the controlling date for determining who must be given the right to the Statutory Cash Bonus under section 100, and it should ensure that this Qualifying Day is clearly separated from any other “reference dates” the society may use for other transfer-scheme purposes. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Using that one Qualifying Day, the society must pay the bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) to every shareholder of the society who (i) held shares on the Qualifying Day and (ii) was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution. [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc] In practical terms, the Qualifying Day selection is not merely administrative: it is a determining factor for identifying which members must have the bonus right conferred, and it may also affect which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or shares in the successor company. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] Accordingly, the society should avoid treating multiple dates as “Qualifying Days,” because the Commission’s view is that only one Qualifying Day can apply for these purposes, and that single date then anchors the shareholder class described above for payment of the section 100(2)(b) and (4) bonus. [#SRC:1efdcc3c346d1b8a] [#TGT:ede0da8a1461e0fc]
source_text: The choice of Qualifying Day 53 is important because it is a determining factor in deciding which members must have conferred upon them a right to the Statutory Cash Bonus 54 provided by Section 100 of the 1986 Act. It may also be relevant in deciding which members may receive certain rights under a proposed distribution of funds or of shares in the successor company. The Commission’s view was that there can be only one Qualifying Day for these purposes, which must be clearly distinguished from any other ‘reference dates’ which may be chosen by a society for the purposes of its transfer scheme.
target_text: 54. The bonus required by section 100(2)(b) and (4) of the 1986 Act to be paid to every shareholder of the society who held shares on the Qualifying Day and was not eligible to vote on the requisite shareholding members’ resolution.

question: If you are using the PRA supervisory statement on algorithmic trading, what does it tell you to read alongside it, and what does that other document cover (in plain terms), including when it applies?
gold_answer: You should use the PRA supervisory statement as the document that sets the PRA’s expectations for a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, and you should read it together with Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 where that Regulation is relevant to your firm. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] The Regulation you are asked to read alongside it is about organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, and it also deals with defined terms for the purposes of the Directive it supplements. [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] Put together, this means the supervisory statement provides the PRA’s algorithmic-trading governance and risk-management expectations, while the Regulation provides a broader organisational and operating framework for investment firms that can help you interpret and structure those expectations. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] The key practical step is to confirm whether the Regulation is applicable in your situation (as indicated by the supervisory statement), and then use its organisational and operating-conditions focus as part of the context when applying the PRA’s expectations to algorithmic trading. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]
source_text: This supervisory statement (SS) sets out the PRA’s expectations of a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading and should be read alongside: Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 on organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms 1 (if applicable); the General Organisational Requirements Part and Risk Control Part of the PRA Rulebook; European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) Guidelines on systems and controls in automated trading environment trading platforms; 2 Joint ESMA and European Banking Authority (EBA) Guidelines on the assessment of suitability of members of the management body and key function holders; 3 and EBA Guidelines on internal governance. 4
target_text: 1. Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 of 25 April 2016 supplementing Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms and defined terms for the purposes of that Directive.

question: If a relevant third-country firm is sending the PRA liquidity info using what it already reports to its home state supervisor (HSS), what LCR items does it need to include and in what currency format, and how does the fact that the HSS’s LCR rules come from the Basel Committee’s 2013 Liquidity Coverage Requirement affect how the firm should describe what “LCR” means here?
gold_answer: The firm should provide the PRA with whole-firm liquidity information that is based on the data it reports to its home state supervisor (HSS), and it should explain the LCR reference in a way that matches the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s 2013 introduction of the Liquidity Coverage Requirement. [#TGT:b05def7c40876dda] The PRA expects the data to be delivered in one consolidated currency, and if the firm provides this to the HSS, it should also provide it on a significant currency basis. [#SRC:432f97ed6f63cee5] For the LCR portion, the firm should include the HSS-reported information that relates to the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR), including the completed LCR template, plus any other additional liquidity reports that the firm submits to the HSS. [#SRC:432f97ed6f63cee5] Put together, the firm’s PRA submission should (i) mirror the LCR materials and related liquidity reports it already sends to the HSS, (ii) follow the consolidated-currency presentation and add significant-currency views when that is part of what is provided to the HSS, and (iii) describe the LCR context as the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee’s 2013 Liquidity Coverage Requirement. [#SRC:432f97ed6f63cee5] [#TGT:b05def7c40876dda]
source_text: The PRA expects relevant third-country firms to submit liquidity information at the whole-firm level, based upon data which is reported to the firm’s home state supervisor (‘HSS’). Data should be provided in a single, consolidated currency and where this is provided to the HSS, also on a significant currency basis. In particular, this should include data reported to the firm’s HSS that relates to the liquidity coverage ratio (LCR) 2 and in particular the completed LCR template and any other additional liquidity reports submitted to the HSS. 3
target_text: 2. Based on the HSS’s implementation of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s introduction of Liquidity Coverage Requirement (LCR) in 2013.

question: When determining the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description, how must the firm treat assets it is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option, given that exposure is calculated by adjusting values in accordance with 19 to 23 and that asset values must be ascribed under this Part (or, if no valuation provision exists, by reference to a reasonable immediate transfer price)?
gold_answer: In determining the firm’s exposure to assets of each description, the firm must start from a value ascribed to those assets and then apply the required adjustments, including the specific option-related adjustment. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] The starting point is that a value must be ascribed to assets of each description as an amount determined under this Part; if the rules contain no valuation provision for a particular description, the value is instead the amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description is then determined by adjusting that ascribed value in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] Within those adjustments, the value ascribed (under 18 to 19) for assets of each description must be increased or decreased to reflect the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] Practically, this means the firm cannot calculate exposure solely on the unadjusted ascribed value: it must incorporate the option-deemed acquisitions or disposals by increasing or decreasing the relevant asset-description value before (or as part of) completing the exposure determination under the 19 to 23 adjustment framework. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: If an institution has fair value positions in both the trading book and the non-trading book, what does it need to show about its prudent valuation adjustment for exposures adjusted under Article 34 and Article 105, and how should it split the information between the two books?
gold_answer: It needs to present a clear breakdown of its prudent valuation adjustment for the relevant exposures, and it must present that information separately for the trading book and the non-trading book. [#SRC:2523899445035439] This is required in the context that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value must be subject to the prudent valuation standards in the applicable Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook, so the breakdown supports showing that those fair-valued positions are being treated under the prudent valuation framework. [#TGT:fab620639def0122] The breakdown itself must include the amounts of the constituent elements that make up the institution’s prudent valuation adjustment, grouped by type of risks. [#SRC:2523899445035439] It must also include the total of those constituent elements, and those totals must be shown separately for trading book positions and for non-trading book positions (rather than only one combined total). [#SRC:2523899445035439] When preparing this, the institution should ensure the prudent valuation of trading book positions reaches an appropriate degree of certainty, taking into account the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value and the demands of prudential soundness, which explains the need for structured, book-specific reporting. [#TGT:fab620639def0122]
source_text: (e) for exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book that are adjusted in accordance with Article 34 and Article 105 , a breakdown of the amounts of the constituent elements of an institution's prudent valuation adjustment, by type of risks, and the total of constituent elements separately for the trading book and non-trading book positions;
target_text: Institutions shall ensure that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value.

question: When a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction that is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, how should the firm’s internal audit assurance work address the prohibition on including securitisation positions in the underlying exposures, and which specific Articles/Chapters must that assurance cover?
gold_answer: A firm that is an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction within scope of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook should ensure its internal audit function provides assurance that the firm’s securitisation involvement complies with the specified PRA Rulebook provisions, and that this assurance explicitly encompasses the rule that the underlying exposures must not include securitisation positions. [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb] In practice, the internal audit assurance should be framed around the firm’s “involvement in the securitisation” and test compliance against the required set of provisions, namely Articles 6, 7, 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4–6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] Within that assurance scope, audit work should include checking that the pool of underlying exposures used in the securitisation does not contain any securitisation positions, because such inclusion is prohibited for underlying exposures used in a securitisation. [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb] Accordingly, the audit plan should connect the compliance assurance expectation for the firm’s role (originator/original lender/sponsor) with a concrete verification step on exposure composition, so that the prohibition is covered as part of the overall compliance assurance against the identified Articles and Chapters. [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]
source_text: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation is compliant with the requirements in Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The underlying exposures used in a securitisation shall not include securitisation positions .

question: For a Solvency II firm applying the prudent person principle and the RFF requirements in Own Funds 3L in the PRA Rulebook, how must it adjust the excess of assets over liabilities when calculating the reconciliation reserve where restricted own funds items sit within a ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio and exceed the notional SCR?
gold_answer: A Solvency II firm should treat the reconciliation reserve calculation as requiring a specific downward adjustment to the excess of assets over liabilities, and it should do so in a way that aligns with the firm’s application of the RFF requirements in Own Funds 3L in the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:d1e7889ee3f4eddd] Specifically, for the purposes of calculating the reconciliation reserve, the firm must start from the excess of assets over liabilities referred to in 3C and then reduce that excess by the amount of restricted own funds items that are within a ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio to the extent those items exceed the notional SCR of that ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio. [#TGT:66a2a8ea2096b536] This adjustment is framed as mandatory (“must reduce”) and is applied only to the portion of restricted own funds items that is above the notional SCR, rather than to all restricted own funds items in the relevant fund or portfolio. [#TGT:66a2a8ea2096b536] In operational terms, the firm should identify the restricted own funds items within each ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio, determine the notional SCR for that fund or portfolio, and then reduce the 3C excess by any resulting “in excess” amount as part of the reconciliation reserve computation, while remaining within the Own Funds 3L RFF requirements framework applicable to Solvency II firms. [#SRC:d1e7889ee3f4eddd] The calculation is also stated to be subject to 3L.2. [#TGT:66a2a8ea2096b536]
source_text: (a) for Solvency II firms, the prudent person principle set out in Investments 2 to 5 in the PRA Rulebook and RFF requirements in Own Funds 3L in the PRA Rulebook, and for non-Directive firms any PRA-designated rules in prudential sourcebooks;
target_text: Subject to 3L.2 , for the purposes of calculating the reconciliation reserve, a firm must reduce the excess of assets over liabilities referred to in 3C by the amount of restricted own funds items within a ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio in excess of the notional SCR of the ring-fenced fund or matching adjustment portfolio .

question: When the Prudential Regulator is considering whether to confirm a merger under the criteria prescribed by section 95(4) of the 1986 Act (the Three Criteria), how does section 95(6) operate if defects mean the PRA would otherwise be precluded from confirming, and what are the possible outcomes depending on whether the defects are substantially remedied?
gold_answer: When deciding whether to confirm a merger, the Prudential Regulator must consider the criteria prescribed by section 95(4) of the 1986 Act (the Three Criteria). [#TGT:f876d164651d21b2] If the PRA would be unable to confirm because of defects that fall within those Three Criteria, section 95(6) allows the PRA to direct a society to remedy the defects rather than immediately refusing confirmation. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] A direction under section 95(6) can require procedural steps such as calling a further meeting, including to hold a new vote after issuing a revised Schedule 16 Statement that includes material information previously omitted, or after fixing defects in the systems used to send meeting notices and Statements and to validate votes. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] After the society has acted, the PRA assesses whether the defects have been substantially remedied, based on evidence furnished by the society. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] If the PRA is satisfied on that evidence that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger (i.e., the Three Criteria no longer preclude confirmation). [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee] If the PRA is not satisfied, confirmation must be refused. [#SRC:8ba3cc430698d0ee]
source_text: Where the PRA would be precluded from confirming a merger by reason of any of the defects specified in the Three Criteria, 37 Section 95(6) provides that it may direct a society to remedy the defects. A direction under that subsection may require a society to call a further meeting; for example, to vote again in the light of a revised Schedule 16 Statement containing material information previously omitted, or after correction of defects in the systems for sending notices of meeting and Statements and validation of votes. If the PRA is then satisfied, having considered evidence furnished by the society, that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger. If not, then confirmation must be refused.
target_text: 37. The criteria prescribed by section 95(4) of the 1986 Act which the Prudential Regulator has to consider when deciding whether to confirm a merger. Note: the Three Criteria are varied in certain circumstances (see paragraph 3.194).

question: When testing governance arrangements for recovery planning, how should a firm design and use the recovery plan so that the board can take strategic decisions in a stress, and what specific aspect of the plan’s structure is being tested in that exercise?
gold_answer: In a governance test of recovery planning, the firm should treat the exercise as a practical check that the recovery plan is usable for real decision-making by the board under stress, including whether the board can rapidly find and understand what it needs to decide. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] The test should therefore be designed to confirm that the plan’s structure supports quick navigation and comprehension by the board (as the key decision-maker in a stress) and is also readily usable by the specific business areas that would need to apply it. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] Concretely, the governance test may involve assembling the right people at short notice and assessing whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions, which directly probes whether the plan works as an operational “playbook” rather than a static document. [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc] In that sense, the specific aspect being tested is the usefulness of the plan’s “playbook” element—i.e., whether it enables the relevant participants to act quickly and make strategic choices when convened on short notice—aligned with the PRA’s expectation that the board can quickly navigate and understand the plan in a stress. [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc] [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d]
source_text: testing the governance arrangements. This might include assembling the right people at short notice and understanding whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions. This would test the usefulness of the ‘playbook’ (see ‘ (vii) Playbooks and structure of recovery plans ’ below);
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If the PRA asks a firm to run a test based on EVT in stress to check that the MA in stress is not overstated, what parts of the firm’s regular internal model validation cycle should that test be tied to (like monitoring, statistical validation, sensitivity testing, and data checks)?
gold_answer: The EVT-in-stress test should be built into the firm’s regular internal model validation cycle as a repeatable check that helps the firm give the PRA assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] This linkage matters because the PRA states it will ask firms, when assessing internal model applications and ongoing compliance for internal model permissions, to apply a test based on EVT in stress to support that assurance. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] To fit the test into the required validation cycle, the firm should connect it to the cycle components it must already maintain: (a) ongoing monitoring of internal model performance, review of whether the model specification remains appropriate, and testing results against experience; (b) an effective statistical validation process that allows the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) stability analysis, especially sensitivity testing of results to changes in key underlying assumptions (which can be informed by the stressed comparison work described for EVT in stress); and (d) checks on the accuracy, completeness, and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model. [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] Using the EVT-in-stress test as part of this cycle also aligns with the PRA’s view that reassessing EVT in stress can be a helpful validation exercise for meeting internal model requirements. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4]
source_text: The PRA considers reassessment of the EVT in stress, in particular the comparison of stressed economic value and Effective Value in (iv) above, to be a helpful validation exercise that could contribute to firms meeting the internal model requirements (see Chapter 14 of the Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models Part of the PRA Rulebook). When assessing internal model applications and firms’ continued compliance with the calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 relevant for granting internal model permissions, the PRA will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress, to assist in providing assurance that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated. Firms may wish to consider adding an EVT in stress to their regular suite of validation tools.
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place a regular cycle of internal model validation which includes: (a) monitoring the performance of the internal model , reviewing the ongoing appropriateness of its specification and testing its results against experience; (b) an effective statistical process for validating the internal model which enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) an analysis of the stability of the internal model and, in particular, the testing of the sensitivity of the results of the internal model to changes in key underlying assumptions; and (d) an assessment of the accuracy, completeness and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model .

question: If a controller or proposed controller is an investment manager buying or selling listed shares as part of fund management and is following directions 2.1 and 2.3, what form can they use, and what does the section 178 notice need to include and be sent with?
gold_answer: For an investment manager in this listed-shares fund management situation, the PRA allows use of a specific Controller’s form, and the section 178 notice must be completed to match the information and document requirements of the relevant Controller’s Form. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] The PRA’s direction for this context is that where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with acquiring or disposing of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity, it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] Separately, the PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by the documents required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Putting these together, the permitted form in the investment-manager listed-shares case is the Controller’s form at 6.5, and the notice should include the information and supporting documents that the applicable Controller’s Form requires. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]
source_text: Where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with the acquiring or disposal of listed shares in the course its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5 .
target_text: The PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by such documents as are required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application.

question: When calculating surplus funds, how should a firm treat amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities that it expects to be permanent, and how does that treatment interact with the requirement to calculate with-profits policy liabilities on a retrospective aggregate basis (including the sign convention for items that increase or reduce future liability to policyholders)?
gold_answer: In calculating surplus funds, the firm should treat “permanent enhancements” as those amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities that the firm expects, at the time it performs the surplus funds calculation, to remain in place in all but the most extreme adverse circumstances. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] This assessment is not static: if what the firm considers to be permanent additions changes over time, the firm must carry that change through into later surplus funds calculations. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] In parallel, unless the circumstances in 3.2 apply, the firm must calculate the value of its with-profits policy liabilities (excluding future policy-related liabilities) by aggregating, for each with-profits policy, the retrospective value of the specified components. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] When performing that retrospective aggregation, the firm must apply the stated sign convention: treat items that increase the future liability to policyholders as positive and items that reduce that future liability as negative. [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79] Practically, this means the firm’s view of which prior additions are “permanent enhancements” informs what it expects to remain embedded in the with-profits policy liabilities at the surplus funds calculation date, while the liabilities themselves are computed using the retrospective, per-policy aggregation method and sign treatment described. [#SRC:5c6323cce75978ab] [#TGT:2f00d7e807d9bf79]
source_text: The reference to ‘permanent enhancements’ within Surplus Funds 3.3(3) is intended to capture amounts previously added to with-profits policy liabilities which a firm expects to be permanent at the time of the surplus funds calculation (ie to apply in all but the most extreme adverse circumstances). Any change in the additions that are considered permanent over time should be reflected in subsequent calculations of surplus funds.

question: When applying the PRA’s expectations on a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading, how should a firm treat Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 in terms of its subject-matter scope and its relationship to the supervisory statement, including any applicability qualifier?
gold_answer: A firm should treat Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 as an external instrument that the PRA expects the supervisory statement on algorithmic trading risk management and governance to be read alongside, but only where it is relevant to the firm. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] In doing so, the firm should understand that the Regulation’s subject-matter is organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms, and that it also addresses defined terms for the purposes of the Directive it supplements. [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] The practical linkage is that the supervisory statement frames PRA expectations specifically for algorithmic trading risk management and governance, while the Regulation provides a broader organisational and operating-conditions context for investment firms that may inform how those expectations are interpreted and implemented. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3] Accordingly, a firm should (i) identify whether the Regulation is applicable to it (as indicated by the supervisory statement’s qualifier), and then (ii) align its algorithmic trading governance and risk management approach with the organisational and operating-conditions concepts addressed in the Regulation when reading the documents together. [#SRC:c69125ba4b5fdbc2] [#TGT:e332b1004b0a62b3]
source_text: This supervisory statement (SS) sets out the PRA’s expectations of a firm’s risk management and governance of algorithmic trading and should be read alongside: Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 on organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms 1 (if applicable); the General Organisational Requirements Part and Risk Control Part of the PRA Rulebook; European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) Guidelines on systems and controls in automated trading environment trading platforms; 2 Joint ESMA and European Banking Authority (EBA) Guidelines on the assessment of suitability of members of the management body and key function holders; 3 and EBA Guidelines on internal governance. 4
target_text: 1. Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2017/565 of 25 April 2016 supplementing Directive 2014/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards organisational requirements and operating conditions for investment firms and defined terms for the purposes of that Directive.

question: If an asset has both economic risk and event risk, what approach should the firm follow, and how can the firm explain that its event-risk treatment is still conservative using the PRA’s idea of fatter-tailed distributions and the “one quarter of the difference” provision tied to an 85th percentile?
gold_answer: When an asset has both economic and event risk exposures, the firm should apply the approach that corresponds to the dominant risks for that asset. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] If the firm needs to explain why its handling of the event-risk component remains appropriately prudent under that dominant-risk approach, it can anchor the explanation in the PRA’s view that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be represented by fatter-tailed distributions. [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c] In particular, where more complete credible data is available to support more sophisticated modelling, the firm can describe how setting a provision equal to one quarter of the difference in MA benefit between median and worst cash flows is treated by the PRA as broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution. [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c] Using that benchmark, the firm can show that—even though it is following the dominant-risk approach for the combined exposure—it would likely be demonstrating adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks that arise from event-driven outcomes. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: The PRA considers that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be best represented by fatter-tailed distributions. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA considers that a provision of one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution and that this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks.

question: When an asset in an MA portfolio is upgraded and the issuer changes the asset’s cash flows, how should a firm apply its ‘sufficient compensation’ criteria to decide whether it can keep the asset in the MA portfolio and, if so, to what extent it may continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows (including any conditions tied to matching relevant MA eligible liabilities and partial recognition)?
gold_answer: A firm may be able to keep an upgraded asset in the MA portfolio without removing it, but only where its own ‘sufficient compensation’ criteria are designed to deal with foreseeable events like an upgrade and are effective in assessing whether compensation remains sufficient. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] Those criteria can be devised by reference to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows and the firm’s ability, if the issuer changes those cash flows, to purchase a replacement asset of at least as good quality as the original so that matching continues. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3] In applying the criteria, the firm may continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows only up to the level of the contractual compensation payable, so that compensation is sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match the relevant MA eligible liabilities. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] The PRA also expects the firm to be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in its earlier assessment referenced in the TARGET passage. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3] Where the firm uses this approach, recognition of only part of the asset’s cash flows up to the compensation level is contemplated, but it is framed as being subject to the considerations on partial recognition referenced in the TARGET passage. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to consider how their own criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ cater for foreseeable events such as an asset being upgraded. The PRA considers that in such upgrade events, a firm would not necessarily need to remove the asset from the MA portfolio, if its own criteria provide for this (and to the extent that those criteria were effective in assessing whether compensation would be sufficient, taking into account paragraph 2.37 above). For example, where sufficiency of compensation criteria follow the approach described in paragraph 2.41 above, the firm might continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows up to the level of the compensation payable, ie so that the asset’s compensation would remain sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match relevant MA eligible liabilities.
target_text: The PRA’s view is that it may be possible for firms’ criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ to be devised by reference to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows, together with the ability to purchase an asset of at least as good quality as the original to replace these cash flows in the event they are changed by the issuer, ie to ensure that this matching continues. The PRA expects a firm to be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in its assessment in paragraph 2.39 above. This may, in practice, mean that the firm would recognise part of the asset’s cash flows up to the level of contractual compensation payable, subject to the considerations relating to partial recognition set out in paragraphs 2.15 to 2.16A above.

question: For a firm that is a party to a transfer event and is making the updates described under 6.1(1) and (2), how should it ensure adherence to Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 (including any waiver/modification position), while also meeting the constraint on the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed after those updates?
gold_answer: A firm that is a party to a transfer event and is carrying out the updates under 6.1(1) and (2) must manage those updates so they do not increase the aggregate amount of TMTP claimed by the firms involved in the transfer event. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] At the same time, the firm must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is followed unless the firm has been granted a waiver or modification under 3.3 of the SoP titled ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] In practice, the PRA indicates it expects compliance with 6.2 can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’, which provides a mechanism the firm can use when implementing the 6.1(1) and (2) updates while keeping the aggregate TMTP from increasing across the parties to the transfer event. [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7] The firm should therefore (i) confirm whether it is operating under the default requirement to adhere to 6.2 or under an applicable waiver/modification, and (ii) apply an adjustment to ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’ in a way that supports adherence to 6.2 while ensuring the 6.1(1) and (2) updates do not cause any increase in the aggregate TMTP claimed by the transfer-event parties. [#TGT:1e44705117d023b6] [#SRC:b34bb4d4e11aa3c7]
source_text: Firms must ensure that Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6.2 is adhered to, unless they have been granted a waiver or modification as set out in 3.3 of the SoP ‘Permissions for transitional measures on technical provisions and risk-free interest rates’. The PRA expects this can be achieved by adjusting the value for ‘Z B ’ or ‘C 0 ’.
