question: If an institution has two OTC derivative contracts that perfectly match and sit in the same netting agreement, what can it do in the exposure calculation under Sections 3, 4 and 5, and when is it allowed to use one exposure number for the whole contractual netting agreement versus having to calculate one per transaction?
gold_answer: For exposure calculations done using the methods in Sections 3, 4 and 5, an institution is allowed to handle two OTC derivative contracts that are perfectly matching and included in the same netting agreement by treating them like a single contract whose notional principal is zero. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] Separately, whether the institution can produce one exposure value covering all transactions in a contractual netting agreement depends on meeting all the conditions in Article 274(1): if those conditions are met, it may calculate a single exposure value for the agreement; if not, it must calculate exposure values transaction-by-transaction, and each transaction is treated as its own netting set. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Putting these together, the “single zero-notional contract” approach is a permitted way to treat a specific pair of perfectly matching OTC derivatives within the Section 3–5 calculation methods, while the decision to aggregate exposure across the entire contractual netting agreement (or instead split it into separate netting sets per transaction) is governed by whether the Article 274(1) conditions are satisfied. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: In calculating the exposure value in accordance with the methods set out in Sections 3 , 4 and 5 , institutions may treat two OTC derivative contracts included in the same netting agreement that are perfectly matching as if they were a single contract with a notional principal equal to zero.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If the C17.01/C17.02 reporting instructions tell you to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website, what UK document should you use instead, and where do you find it online?
gold_answer: You should treat the instruction to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website as meaning you must use the corresponding disclosure produced by the PRA for those COREP templates. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] The online location for that PRA disclosure is the “Regulatory reporting – banking sector” page in the prudential regulation section of the Bank of England website, using the specific web address provided. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954] This linkage matters because the COREP instructions for C17.01 and C17.02 explicitly redirect certain non-UK references (including the EBA supervisory disclosure reference) to UK equivalents, so your reporting should be based on the PRA-produced disclosure rather than the EBA publication. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] In other words, when you see the EBA supervisory disclosure reference in those instructions, you should navigate to the Bank of England prudential regulation area and retrieve the PRA disclosure from the Regulatory reporting – banking sector page, ensuring your template completion uses the UK-referenced source. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954]
source_text: Example occurrences: The CRR COREP instructions for C17.01 and C17.02 (Annexes I and II of PRA Rulebook, Reporting (CRR) Part, Templates and Instructions) contain references to supervisory disclosures published on the EBA website, and the gross domestic product at market prices data published by Eurostat. These references should be read as a reference to the corresponding disclosure produced by the PRA, 4 and the corresponding data published by the Office for National Statistics. The instructions for Solvency II templates S06.02, S08.01, S30.02, S30.04, S31.01, S31.02 and S37.01 include a list of credit rating agencies as registered or certified by the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). This should be read as a reference to the list of credit rating agencies as registered or certified within the UK.
target_text: 4. This can be found on the Regulatory reporting – banking sector page in the prudential regulation section of the Bank of England website: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/regulatory-reporting/regulatory-reporting-banking-sector .

question: When a credit union reschedules a delinquent loan or capitalises arrears, what is the expected governance action by directors regarding the provisioning amount, and for how long must the relevant provision be kept in place in order to demonstrate accurate compliance with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: Directors are expected to take active, ongoing steps to assure themselves that their credit union is accurately complying with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, including in situations where loan terms are changed. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] In the specific case where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears are capitalised, accurate compliance requires that the provision level that applied immediately before the rescheduling or recapitalisation is not reduced simply because of that restructuring event. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] Instead, the credit union must keep that pre-change provision in place until the loan has demonstrated sustained performance for a defined period. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] The required duration is six months of performance following the rescheduling or recapitalisation, after which the credit union may reassess provisioning consistent with the applicable rules. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] Accordingly, directors should regularly satisfy themselves that the credit union maintains the immediately pre-rescheduling (or pre-recapitalisation) provision throughout that six-month performance window as part of their oversight of accurate compliance with Rules 3.11 and 3.12. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff]
source_text: The PRA expects that all directors regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union accurately complies with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears capitalised, the provision a credit union is required to make immediately prior to the rescheduling or recapitalisation must be maintained until the loan has performed for six months.

question: When a firm lacks the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6 and therefore must appoint an external actuary, what due diligence must the firm perform before making that appointment, and how must that assessment be calibrated to the firm’s business and applicable regulatory standards?
gold_answer: Where a firm does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6, it is required to appoint an external actuary. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab] Before making that appointment, the firm must carry out reasonable due diligence to satisfy itself that the actuary it selects has the skill and experience needed to perform the actuary’s functions under the regulatory system. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] That pre-appointment assessment is not generic: the firm must calibrate its evaluation of the actuary’s competence to (i) the nature, scale, and complexity of the firm’s business and (ii) the specific requirements and standards under the regulatory system that apply to the firm. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71] In practice, this means the firm should treat the external appointment triggered by the Conditions Governing Business 6 capability gap as the point at which it must verify the actuary’s suitability, rather than assuming that “external” status alone is sufficient. [#TGT:bb5e586ce2dcc1ab] The firm’s obligation is therefore twofold: ensure an external actuary is appointed when internal/group capability is lacking, and ensure—before appointment—that the chosen actuary’s qualifications match the firm’s regulatory functions and business profile. [#SRC:dcc349f7a298ef71]
source_text: Before a firm appoints an actuary under 2.1 or 2.2 , it must take reasonable steps to ensure that the actuary has the required skill and experience to perform his functions under the regulatory system commensurate with the nature, scale and complexity of the firm’s business and the requirements and standards under the regulatory system to which it is subject.
target_text: A firm must appoint an external actuary if it does not have the capability within the firm or the firm’s group to comply with Conditions Governing Business 6 .

question: If you see “critical or important outsourcing” in older EU/PRA wording but the PRA text you’re using talks about “material outsourcing,” what does that mean in practice, and how do you decide if a specific outsourcing or third party arrangement counts as material?
gold_answer: In practice, you should read “material outsourcing” as the PRA’s clearer term for what would otherwise be treated as “critical or important outsourcing” under relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules, because the PRA says the former is intended to cover the latter for all practical purposes. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] The PRA also explains it chose this wording to avoid confusion with other similar-sounding concepts used elsewhere in financial regulation (for example, “critical function” or “critical service” in an OCIR context). [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] To decide whether a particular outsourcing or third party arrangement is material, you should generally apply the performance-failure test: treat the arrangement as material where a defect or failure in how it is performed could materially impair the firm (as described in the PRA Rulebook definition and, where applicable, the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria). [#TGT:52624254f79512d2] When applying criteria to identify material arrangements, you should use an approach that is substantively aligned to the EBA Outsourcing GL criteria for identifying “critical or important outsourcing arrangements,” while recognising the PRA notes there are a few justified exceptions, including ones tied to the PRA’s operational resilience requirements. [#SRC:c6da983dfd07933b] Put together, you map the terminology across, then use the defect/failure material-impairment test with the aligned criteria set (adjusted only for the PRA’s stated exceptions). [#TGT:52624254f79512d2]
source_text: This SS uses ‘material outsourcing’ instead of ‘critical or important’ for clarity and to help firms avoid confusion with different but partly overlapping terms that exist in financial regulation, such as ‘critical function’ or ‘critical service’ in an OCIR context. For all intents and purposes, the PRA considers that a ‘material outsourcing’ arrangement encompasses a ‘critical or important outsourcing’ arrangement in relevant retained EU legislation or PRA rules. Moreover, the criteria that firms should take into account when identifying ‘material outsourcing’ arrangements is substantively aligned to the criteria for identifying ‘critical or important outsourcing arrangements’ under the EBA Outsourcing GL with a few justified exceptions, such as those that reference the PRA’s requirements on operational resilience (see paragraphs 5.11 – 5.13 below).

question: For a firm within scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations, how should the bank reflect its chosen booking model in contingency planning for winding down trading books, and how does the PRA’s proportional application of those expectations interact with the potential resolution impediments described for a global booking model under an MPE strategy?
gold_answer: A bank that is within the scope of the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations should ensure that its contingency plans for winding down trading books in a solvent and orderly manner explicitly incorporate the implications of the booking model it has adopted, because the PRA expects the booking model to be fully taken into account in those plans. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] This planning focus sits alongside the PRA’s statement that it will apply the booking-arrangements expectations proportionately to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity the firm undertakes, meaning the depth and intensity of the bank’s implementation should be calibrated to that activity profile. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236] In practice, where the bank uses a global booking model, it should treat the model’s group inter-connectivity as a factor that can complicate post-resolution restructuring and, under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy, can become an impediment to resolution that the bank should address through its planning. [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d] The proportionality principle does not remove the need to address those model-driven risks; rather, it frames how extensively the bank evidences and operationalises the integration of booking-model considerations into wind-down and resolution-related contingency plans, in line with its investment banking or sales and trading footprint. [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]
source_text: The expectations of a firm’s booking arrangements set out in this section are applicable to all international banks and UK trading banks. Paragraphs 4.24A - 4.25Z and 4.25AE are applicable to both types of bank, paragraphs 4.25AA - 4.25AD are applicable only to international banks [see para 1.1 ]. The PRA will apply these expectations in a manner that is proportionate to the level of investment banking or sales and trading activity that the firm undertakes.
target_text: While a global booking model may not be considered a direct impediment under a single point of entry resolution strategy, it could add complexity to the restructuring of the group post resolution. Under a multiple-point-of-entry (MPE) strategy, the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the group associated to a global booking could be an impediment to resolution that the bank should address. 40 Similarly, where contingency plans to be able to wind down trading books in a solvent and orderly fashion are important to any orderly exit, recovery, or resolution strategy, the PRA expects that the particular booking model adopted by a bank will have been fully taken into account in those plans.

question: How should a PRA-regulated firm determine whether an outsourcing or other third-party arrangement that is not within scope of OCIR can still trigger the PRA notification expectation for ‘material outsourcing,’ and what timing does the PRA expect for that notification?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm should treat the notification obligation as potentially applying even where an arrangement is not within scope of OCIR, because non-OCIR outsourcing and even non-outsourcing third-party arrangements may still be “material outsourcing” if they could affect the PRA’s objectives outside an OCIR context. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] The TARGET text indicates that examples of arrangements that may be material on this basis include those involving personal or sensitive data or those carrying high reputational risk, which are concrete indicators the firm can use when assessing materiality beyond OCIR scope. [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20] Once the firm concludes the arrangement is material outsourcing (whether due to OCIR applicability or due to potential impact on the PRA’s objectives), the SOURCE text requires notification to the PRA when entering into, or significantly changing, that material outsourcing arrangement. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] The PRA expects the firm to submit the notification before entering into the outsourcing arrangement, and also before an arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become material. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71] The PRA will consider how timely the firm’s notifications are when assessing compliance with Fundamental Rule 7. [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]
source_text: Notifications 2.3(1)(e) requires all PRA-regulated firms, including credit unions and NDFs, to notify the PRA when ‘entering, or significantly changing a material outsourcing arrangement’. The PRA expects these notifications to be made before entering into the outsourcing arrangement. The PRA also expects firms to submit these notifications before an outsourcing arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become so (see paragraph 5.5 ). The PRA will consider the timeliness of these notifications when assessing firms’ compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 .
target_text: If a firm outsources services to which OCIR applies, this arrangement will generally constitute ‘material outsourcing’. However, outsourcing and non-outsourcing third party arrangements that are not within scope of OCIR might still be ‘material outsourcing’ if they could affect the PRA’s objectives outside of an OCIR context. Examples may include outsourcing arrangements involving personal or sensitive data or carrying high reputational risk.

question: If a society sends a Transfer Summary instead of the full Transfer Statement, who must get it and when must it be sent, and what does the text say the PRA is doing during the transfer process?
gold_answer: When a society uses a Transfer Summary as a replacement for the Transfer Statement, the summary is the document the society may send to its members instead of sending the full Transfer Statement. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The summary must go to every member who is entitled to receive the notice of the meeting, and it must be sent in or with that meeting notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] Separately from how the society communicates with members, the PRA is described as having a role in approving the Transfer Statement that must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] The PRA is also described as continuing its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process, so its involvement runs through the transfer process rather than being limited to a single point in time. [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] Putting these points together, the society’s choice to send a summary affects what is included with the meeting notice and who receives it, while the PRA’s described responsibilities still focus on approval of the Transfer Statement and participation in confirmation, alongside ongoing supervision during the transfer process. [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f] [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]
source_text: The chapter also describes the role of the PRA in approving the Transfer Statement which must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure, together with its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process. The Transfer Summary, 44 which a society may send to its members instead of the Transfer Statement, is also discussed.
target_text: 44. The summary of the Transfer Statement which may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent, instead of the Transfer Statement, in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered, to every member entitled to receive that notice.

question: If a firm has to send a report regularly under Chapter 3 and also publish a regular summary under Chapter 4, where does it look for what the report should include and look like, and who tells it the expected dates?
gold_answer: The firm should use the chapter that explains the PRA’s expectations for the content and format of the report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3 to shape what the Chapter 3 report includes and how it is presented. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] At the same time, the firm must remember that the overall process is periodic and has two linked outputs: (1) submitting the report periodically under Chapter 3 and (2) publishing a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] For timing, the PRA will communicate the expected dates for both the firm’s submission and its disclosure in advance, so the firm should plan its internal timetable around those PRA-provided dates rather than guessing them. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] Putting these together, the firm should draft the Chapter 3 report to meet the PRA’s stated content/format expectations, then use the PRA’s advance communication of expected dates to schedule both the Chapter 3 submission and the Chapter 4 summary publication as part of the same periodic compliance cycle. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8]
source_text: Firms are required to submit reports periodically under Chapter 3 of the rules and publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4 of the rules. The PRA will communicate the expected dates for firms’ submission and disclosure in advance.
target_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3.

question: When preparing the notice of a society meeting and the related scrutineers report, how should the society treat (i) people who turn 18 after the notice date but on/before the meeting date and (ii) people who become shareholding or borrowing members after the notice date but before the final proxy-form receipt date, and how should the “accidental omission/non-receipt does not invalidate” principle be applied where management errors affect notice distribution?
gold_answer: The society should plan its notice process on the basis that certain individuals who join or become eligible after the notice date may still need to be sent notice, and the scrutineers report may take account of the statutory protection for genuinely accidental omission or non-receipt, while recognizing that some management-driven failures fall outside that protection. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] Operationally, notice must also be given to (a) any person who will reach age 18 after the notice date but on or before the meeting date, and (b) every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member after the notice date but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, where in either case the person would be eligible to vote at the meeting if they remained a member until then. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] The Schedule 16 Statement must be sent in or with the notices. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] For validity and reporting, accidental omission to give notice (and, in the scrutineers report context, non-receipt of notice) does not invalidate the meeting proceedings. [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d] [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] However, the scrutineers report should not treat as “accidental/non-receipt” cases where the society’s error reflects an erroneous management decision not to send notices to particular persons or groups, or a systemic failure such as omitting new members or excluding a class of members due to a computer-program fault. [#TGT:f23025bd819d81c5] [#SRC:89ce33483e37159d]
source_text: In addition, notice must also be given to any person who will attain the age of 18 years after the date of the notice but on or before the date of the meeting, and to every person who becomes a shareholding or borrowing member of the society after the date of the notice but before the final date for receipt of proxy voting forms, and who would, in either case, be eligible to vote at the meeting if he remained a member until then. (In practice, this may mean sending out a notice to every such person, even if they will, in fact, not be entitled to vote). The Schedule 16 Statement must be sent in or with the notices (paragraph 1(2) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, accidental omission does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new members, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management see also paragraph 3.147 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting shall not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that accidental and non-receipt would not cover all cases of error on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: If an Institution has a contractual netting agreement, when can it use one exposure value for all the transactions, and what does it need to tell the competent authorities if it starts or stops using the method it uses to calculate exposure values for its derivative positions?
gold_answer: An Institution can use one combined exposure value for all transactions inside a contractual netting agreement only if all the conditions in Article 274(1) are met. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] If those conditions are not met, the Institution must calculate an exposure value for each transaction separately, and each transaction is treated as its own netting set. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Separately from choosing between a combined or separate calculation outcome, the Institution has a notification duty tied to the calculation methods it uses for exposure values of derivative positions: it must notify the competent authorities of the methods in Section 4 or 5 that it uses, or that it ceases to use, as applicable. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] Putting these together, if the Institution changes how it calculates exposure values for derivative positions—such as moving from separate transaction exposure values to a single exposure value under a contractual netting agreement (or the reverse)—it should ensure that the competent authorities are notified about the relevant Section 4 or 5 method being adopted or discontinued, while the permissibility of a single exposure value depends on meeting all Article 274(1) conditions. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: Institutions shall notify the competent authorities of the methods set out in Section 4 or 5 that they use, or cease to use, as applicable, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If a firm is a UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK, what should its recovery plan say about who makes decisions in the UK and when issues go up to the group level, and who (by name/role) is accountable under the SMR for the recovery plan and resolution pack and for dealing with the PRA?
gold_answer: For a UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK, the recovery plan should describe a UK governance framework that covers how the firm monitors its indicators and how it will take action when needed, and it should also state when decisions would be escalated to group level. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2] Separately, the firm should treat recovery planning as an SMR prescribed responsibility by ensuring there is a named executive who is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and who oversees the internal governance processes around them. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The firm should identify the accountable executive director responsible for the recovery plan and for acting as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on the recovery plan. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The PRA indicates this accountable person is often the CEO, CFO or CRO, and it will hold that person responsible for the plan’s quality, for making the plan usable for senior executives and board members in a stress, for improving the plan (including after PRA feedback), and for the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] For this type of UK subsidiary, the plan should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that the firm meets SMR-related requirements referenced for such subsidiaries, so the UK governance and escalation approach is matched to clear SMR responsibilities. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2]
source_text: (vi) The plan should include a UK governance framework for monitoring the indicators and taking action where appropriate. For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, in meeting expectations set out in Chapter 2 (viii) , the PRA expects firms to set out when decisions would be escalated to group level. In addition, the PRA expects UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK to meet requirements set out in Chapter 2 (xiii) (c) in relation to responsibilities under the SMR.
target_text: Firms are reminded that recovery planning is a prescribed responsibility under the SMR which means that there should be a named executive at each firm that is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and for overseeing the internal processes regarding their governance. 18 Firms should identify the accountable executive director responsible for the firm’s recovery plan and for acting as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on its recovery plan. The PRA has observed that this is typically the CEO, CFO or CRO. The PRA will hold this person accountable for the quality of the recovery plan, for the plan being structured so as to be usable by senior executives and board members in a stress, for making improvements to the recovery plan (including in response to the PRA’s feedback) and for the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning issues.

question: If a TWD firm is working out wind-down costs for its capital and liquidity projections, what does it need to include about market price moves and trading positions (RBLs), and what does the PRA do with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A when it checks the firm’s RBL number?
gold_answer: In building capital and liquidity projections from wind-down cost quantification, a TWD firm should concentrate its modelling on the TWD scenario and on the actions, arrangements, and measures it would actually use in that scenario, because fully modelling many scenarios is not proportionate given the uncertainty. [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649] As part of that same wind-down-period analysis, the firm should be able to capture how market price movements during the wind-down period could change the valuation of its trading positions, which is the source of risk-based losses (RBLs). [#SRC:adaf36e17eb8c649] When the PRA reviews the firm’s RBL estimate, it will compare that estimate with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to understand, in context, how much capital executing the TWD option might absorb. [#TGT:31786ae603de3309] The comparison is not meant to redefine RBLs: the PRA does not consider Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A to be an appropriate measure of RBLs, and uses it only as a contextual metric to interpret the firm’s RBL calculation in its assessment. [#TGT:31786ae603de3309]
source_text: These projections may be subject to significant levels of uncertainty, and it would not be proportionate for TWD firms to build and maintain capabilities to fully model a large number of scenarios. TWD firms should focus the modelling of their quantification of wind-down costs, used to determine their capital and liquidity projections, on the TWD scenario, and the actions, arrangements, and measures that the TWD firm would implement under that scenario. TWD firms should be able to account for the potential impact of market price movements throughout the wind-down period on the valuations of trading positions, known as risk-based losses (RBLs, see paragraphs 4.26 and 4.38 - 4.40 ).
target_text: The PRA will compare TWD firms’ estimates of RBLs with Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A in order to assess the proportion of capital that executing the TWD option might absorb. It should be understood that the PRA does not regard the sum of Pillar 1 plus Pillar 2A capital as an appropriate measure of RBLs, but rather as a metric for the purpose of providing context to understand the results of a firm’s RBL calculation as part of the PRA’s assessment.

question: When the PRA’s external audit rules apply to an undertaking’s SFCR, how should the auditor treat the scale of the matching adjustment in scope terms, and how does the SFCR “relevant elements” concept—illustrated by the example of quantifying the impact of setting the MA to zero—support that conclusion, including the linkage to Life Technical Provisions?
gold_answer: Where the PRA’s external audit rules apply, the scale of the matching adjustment (MA)—meaning how much the MA affects technical provisions—falls within the scope of audit. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] This scope conclusion is supported because the MA’s impact is treated as part of the SFCR “relevant elements” on which the external auditor must form a view. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] The SFCR “relevant elements” framing is illustrated by the specified example that the undertaking should quantify how its financial position would change if the MA were reduced to zero, and that quantification is identified as a relevant element of the SFCR. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] In addition, the MA is described as having a direct effect on Life Technical Provisions, and those Life Technical Provisions are stated to be within the scope of the External Audit rule, reinforcing why the MA’s scale (as it impacts technical provisions) is audit-scoped. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] Accordingly, an auditor assessing SFCR relevant elements should treat both (i) the magnitude of MA impact on technical provisions and (ii) the quantified “MA to zero” impact on financial position as within the audit’s remit, because together they evidence the MA’s audit-relevant effect on reported positions and technical provisions. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf]
source_text: The scale of the matching adjustment (ie the extent to which the MA impacts on technical provisions) is within scope of audit where the PRA’s external audit rules apply. 6 This reflects the fact that the impact of the MA falls within the ‘relevant elements’ that external auditors of the SFCR are required to form a view on. 7
target_text: 7. For example, the quantification of the impact of a change to zero of the MA on that undertaking’s financial position is specified as a relevant element of the SFCR (External Audit 2.2(1) and Rules 3.4(1)(a) and (b) in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. In addition, the MA has a direct effect on Life Technical Provisions which are within scope of the External Audit rule.

question: When the PRA assesses, for a given risk type, whether minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceed that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements, how should the entity’s share be calculated and what categories of requirements or risks would the PRA generally exclude from that assessment (including where consolidation nets exposures)?
gold_answer: In assessing, for a given risk type, whether minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom (on an individual or sub-consolidated basis) exceed that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk, the entity’s share should be computed using the consolidated group capital requirement scaled by the entity’s proportion of the group’s Pillar 1 RWAs. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] Specifically, the entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement is determined by multiplying the consolidated group capital requirement by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs attributable to that entity. [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] The RWAs attributable to the entity are calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs (on the same basis as group RWAs) minus the entity’s risk-weighted exposures to other group entities, which operationalizes the consolidation netting concept. [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] When making the exceedance assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements attributable to risks that are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] The PRA would also not generally take into account requirements attributable to risks that net off in consolidation, with intragroup risks and offsetting positions given as examples, aligning with the subtraction of exposures to other group entities in the RWA attribution calculation. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]
source_text: the extent to which, for any given risk type, the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom, on an individual or sub-consolidated basis, exceed the entity’s share 19 of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk. When making this assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements that are attributable to risks that: (i) are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework 20 or by other means; 21 or (ii) net off in consolidation (for example, intragroup risks and offsetting positions); and
target_text: 19. An entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement can be determined by multiplying that consolidated group capital requirement by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs that are attributable to that entity. The consolidated group’s RWAs that are attributable to an entity is calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs, calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs, minus the risk-weighted exposures of the entity to other group entities.

question: For a firm that has permission to use a partial or full internal model, what quarterly submission to the PRA is required for model changes, and what specific template and instruction source must be used to provide both change details and qualitative support?
gold_answer: A firm with permission to use a partial or full internal model must provide the PRA with a quarterly submission covering model changes, and it must do so using the specified PRA template and instructions. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] The quarterly content must be a summary of both minor and major model changes provided to the PRA, reflecting the requirement tied to Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] To meet the quarterly reporting format and information expectations, firms using an internal model must submit quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9, which requires information on model changes together with supporting qualitative information. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The submission must be prepared in line with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10, which governs how the template is to be completed and what supporting qualitative detail is to accompany the model-change information. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] Taken together, this means the firm’s quarterly summary of minor and major changes is operationalized through template QMC.01 and its Chapter 10 instructions, and the deliverable is submitted to the PRA each quarter. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When a TWD firm runs sensitivity analysis on its TWD scenario assumptions, what does it need to show senior management about capital and liquidity impacts, and how should that work fit with the idea that TWD capabilities are based on fully winding down trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to run sensitivity analysis that measures how changing key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) would affect outcomes, and it should use that analysis to help senior management see the plausible range of impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] Concretely, the firm’s sensitivity analysis capability should be able to set upper and lower bounds for the firm’s key assumptions, so management can understand not only a central view but also the range of plausible results. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The capability should also include the ability to analyse at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are part of the TWD scenario (and potentially other factors), so the sensitivity work covers the scenario’s core elements. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] This sensitivity analysis should be developed and applied within the broader expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities, meaning the ranges and bounds should be assessed in a full trading wind-down setting. [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]
source_text: TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario. TWD firms should be able to use their sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out the upper and lower bounds for TWD firms’ key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on TWD firms’ capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option. This sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors (see paragraphs 3.6 - 3.15 for more detail).
target_text: This does not impact the expectation (set out in more detail in Chapter 4 ) that a TWD firm’s TWD capabilities should be built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities.

question: When a bank is required to provide a single customer view and exclusions file to the PRA or FSCS, what must the bank’s systems be able to identify about covered and eligible deposits, and what specific types of deposits should the exclusions file include that are not in the SCV?
gold_answer: A bank must be able to deliver a single customer view (SCV) and an exclusions file to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours after the PRA or FSCS requests it, and the bank’s systems must support that delivery by automatically calculating key depositor-level amounts. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] Specifically, the systems must automatically identify the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and must also flag any part of an eligible deposit that exceeds the specified coverage level. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] In addition, the exclusions file that the firm provides should contain data on deposits that are not included in the SCV, and the text gives examples of such excluded deposits. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] Those examples include deposits held in client accounts and deposits held via deposit aggregators, which should be captured in the exclusions file even though they are not in the SCV. [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6] Taken together, this means the bank must both (i) meet the 24-hour provision requirement to the PRA or FSCS and (ii) ensure the exclusions file is populated with the specified categories of non-SCV deposits while its systems automatically compute covered amounts and identify over-coverage portions for eligible deposits. [#SRC:85d027c5ae493740] [#TGT:a5f45339915181b6]
source_text: In order to support orderly resolution, banks must maintain a single customer view and exclusions file, 67 and are required to provide this to the PRA or FSCS within 24 hours of a request. 68 Banks’ systems must automatically identify the amount of covered deposits payable to each depositor and identify any portion of an eligible deposit that is over the specified coverage level. 69
target_text: 67. The exclusions file that firms are required to provide should include data on deposits which are not in the SCV including for example deposits held in client accounts and deposit aggregators.

question: If a firm is working out the basic FS for senior notes, what risks does it need to look at in its internal credit assessment, and how does that connect to the FS idea that the asset is held to maturity (except when selling is needed to rebalance the MA portfolio after big cash-flow changes)?
gold_answer: To work out the basic FS for senior notes, the firm should treat the FS as a measure of how much of the spread on an eligible asset reflects the risks the firm keeps, using an assumption that the asset is held until maturity, except where selling is needed for MA portfolio rebalancing to restore the overall matching position after material changes in asset and/or liability cash flows. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Within that framework, the internal credit assessment must cover both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk, and it must also consider how those risks can interact or combine, because retained risks include both types and the interaction point is explicitly called out. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] The PRA expects that all risks to which the senior notes are exposed—including combinations of risks—feed through the internal credit assessment into the assigned CQS and therefore into the derivation of the basic FS. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e] Examples of qualitative risks include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, and examples of quantitative risks include economic or market stresses; these examples are not exhaustive. [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2] Any adjustments to the basic FS to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch should still be based on that same comprehensive assessment and CQS linkage. [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]
source_text: As mentioned in paragraphs 2.1 and 2.3 above, firms should consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk in their credit risk assessments. The PRA expects that all of the risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations of risks) will be considered in the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS and therefore the derivation of the basic FS (including any adjustments made to it in order to take account of differences in credit quality by rating notch).
target_text: The overarching aim of the FS is to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption that the asset is held until maturity (other than where it proves necessary to sell it, as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio, for the purpose of restoring the overall matching position where the asset and/or liability cash flows of the portfolio have materially changed). Retained risks include both qualitative and quantitative risks. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data. Quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses. Internal credit assessments must also consider how these risks may interact (as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(1) ). The examples of risks listed in this paragraph are not exhaustive.

question: For a firm that both covers a death risk and bears an investment risk, how should it combine the required margin of solvency adjustment with the applicable calculation steps, including any stated exclusions and the scope of when each calculation applies?
gold_answer: A firm that covers a death risk and also bears an investment risk must apply two distinct calculation directions, each triggered by a different risk condition, and then incorporate the death-risk result into the required margin of solvency. Specifically, when the firm covers a death risk, it must compute a sum using the calculation in 2.3, but it must leave out elements 2.3(4) and 2.3(5) for this purpose, and then add that computed sum to the required margin of solvency determined under any of 3.2 and 3.3 (including where that required margin is zero). [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] Separately, the firm must apply the calculation in 2.2 only to the extent that, and only when, it bears an investment risk (i.e., the obligation is conditional and limited to the portion of business where investment risk is borne). [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe] In practice, this means the firm performs the 2.2 calculation for the investment-risk-bearing part, while also performing the modified 2.3 calculation for death risk and adding that 2.3-derived sum onto the required margin of solvency produced under 3.2/3.3. [#SRC:d279a616f589ab73] [#TGT:8218e6bc18fdaefe]
source_text: Where a firm covers a death risk, a sum arrived at by applying the calculation in 2.3 (but excluding for these purposes 2.3 (4) and (5)) must be added to the required margin of solvency , including a required margin of solvency of zero, arrived at under any of 3.2 and 3.3 .
target_text: If and in so far as a firm bears an investment risk, the calculation in 2.2 must be applied.

question: For a derivative transaction with more than one material risk driver, how should institutions determine (i) whether the transaction is mapped once or multiple times across risk categories and (ii) for each mapped risk category, whether the institution holds a long or short position in the most material risk driver used for that mapping?
gold_answer: Institutions must first decide the mapping count and scope for a derivative transaction with more than one material risk driver by checking whether those drivers fall within one risk category or span multiple risk categories, and then determine long/short direction by how the transaction’s market value responds to increases in the relevant risk driver. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, and the mapping is based on the most material risk driver within that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers belong to different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and for each such category the mapping is based on the most material risk driver in that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] For the risk driver used as the basis of mapping (i.e., the most material risk driver in the relevant category), a long position means the transaction’s market value increases when the value of that risk driver increases, while a short position means the market value decreases when the value of that risk driver increases. [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301] Applying these steps together ensures that the transaction is mapped to the correct set of risk categories and that the position direction is assessed consistently for the specific risk driver that anchors each mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When the PRA is deciding whether a firm should hold a larger buffer or otherwise strengthen its capital position, how should the PRA’s assessment of capital under IFRS 9 transitional arrangements (including the time limit for that assessment) be understood in light of when IFRS 9 became effective and what it replaced?
gold_answer: In deciding whether a firm should hold a larger buffer or strengthen its capital position, the PRA’s assessment can include both general capital/risk factors and, for a limited period, an additional lens tied to IFRS 9 transitional arrangements. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] Specifically, the PRA expects firms to increase buffers or strengthen capital where needed based on factors such as the firm’s leverage ratio, Tier 1 and total capital ratios, risks from double leverage, and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not fully captured in the stress test. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] Alongside those factors, until the end of 2023 the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for IFRS 9 where firms are using those arrangements. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] This transitional-assessment element relates to IFRS 9 as the accounting framework for financial instruments: IFRS 9 introduced new accounting rules for financial instruments and replaced the prior rules in IAS 39, and it became effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018 (following EU endorsement). [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1] Taken together, the PRA’s capital-buffer expectations may be informed by both the firm’s prudential metrics and risk capture, and—where applicable—by how the firm’s capital position is assessed under the IFRS 9 transitional arrangements through end-2023, in the context of IFRS 9’s post-2018 effective regime replacing IAS 39. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary based on other factors. These include, but are not limited to: the firm’s leverage ratio; Tier 1 and total capital ratios; risks associated with double leverage; and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not captured fully as part of the stress test. Until the end of 2023, the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9, 53 where firms are using these arrangements.
target_text: 53. IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and sets out new rules for accounting for financial instruments, replacing the rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39. Following endorsement for use in the EU, IFRS 9 is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. The PRA’s communications to firms on IFRS 9 are available on the Bank’s website at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/letter/2017/transition-disclosures-for-ifrs9-financial-instruments .

question: If a firm has a TMTP permission and uses less than the maximum TMTP amount, what numbers does it need to show and share, and how do you work out what counts as the “maximum amount” (TMTP method vs the legacy approach in the permission)?
gold_answer: If a firm with a TMTP permission applies less than the maximum transitional deduction, it should treat the applied TMTP amount as a figure that must sit between zero and a defined maximum, and it should be able to explain how it chose that applied amount. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The “maximum amount” it is comparing against is not an arbitrary cap: it is the maximum number calculated either using the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or using the legacy approach set out in the firm’s relevant permission, so the firm must determine which calculation basis applies to it. [#TGT:f321e44c98b40d33] When it applies less than that maximum, the PRA expects the firm to (1) include both the maximum amount and the actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures and (2) share those same two numbers with its supervision team. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c] The firm should also keep its method for determining the TMTP benefit transparent and apply it consistently across Solvency II reporting (including QRTs), and ensure the same approach is reflected in its ORSA and risk management framework. [#SRC:e6ce08835f92cf1c]
source_text: For all firms with a TMTP permission there is a requirement that the amount of the transitional deduction to be applied by a firm is to be between zero and a maximum amount. 6 If a decision is taken by such a firm to apply less than the maximum amount, the PRA expects the firm to include both the maximum amount and actual TMTP amount in the notes to market disclosures, and to share this information with its supervision team. The firm should maintain a transparent approach to determining the amount of TMTP benefit it is applying. The PRA expects this approach to be followed consistently by firms within all Solvency II reporting including for Quarterly Reporting Templates (QRTs). This approach should also be reflected within a firm’s ORSA and risk management framework.
target_text: 6. The amount is the maximum number derived from the TMTP method in Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 5 or the legacy approach outlined in the relevant firm’s permission.

question: If you need to work out whether an entity established outside the United Kingdom is facing minimum requirements that are higher than its share of the group requirement for the same risk type, how do you calculate the entity’s share using Pillar 1 RWAs, and which kinds of risks does the PRA usually leave out because they are already mitigated or net out in consolidation?
gold_answer: To judge whether minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom (on an individual or sub-consolidated basis) are higher than that entity’s share of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk type, you first calculate the entity’s share of the relevant consolidated group capital requirement using Pillar 1 RWAs. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] The share is found by multiplying the consolidated group capital requirement by the proportion of the group’s Pillar 1 RWAs that are attributable to the entity. [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] To get the group RWAs attributable to the entity, take the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs (calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs) and subtract the entity’s risk-weighted exposures to other group entities, which reflects that certain intragroup exposures are removed through consolidation. [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604] When the PRA makes the comparison, it would not generally count requirements that relate to risks already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] It would also not generally count requirements tied to risks that net off in consolidation, including intragroup risks and offsetting positions, which is consistent with excluding exposures to other group entities in the RWA attribution step. [#SRC:ef9de1e6e4142317] [#TGT:0b98872ee0444604]
source_text: the extent to which, for any given risk type, the minimum requirements applied to an entity established outside the United Kingdom, on an individual or sub-consolidated basis, exceed the entity’s share 19 of the consolidated group requirements for the same risk. When making this assessment, the PRA would not generally take into account requirements that are attributable to risks that: (i) are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework 20 or by other means; 21 or (ii) net off in consolidation (for example, intragroup risks and offsetting positions); and
target_text: 19. An entity’s share of a particular consolidated group capital requirement can be determined by multiplying that consolidated group capital requirement by the proportion of the consolidated group’s Pillar 1 RWAs that are attributable to that entity. The consolidated group’s RWAs that are attributable to an entity is calculated as the entity’s Pillar 1 RWAs, calculated on the same basis as the group RWAs, minus the risk-weighted exposures of the entity to other group entities.

question: If a new bank is under the PRA’s time-limited buffer approach, what happens when the earlier conditions stop applying, and when could the PRA still change course sooner—especially if the usual method would lead to too much capital compared with financial stability risks?
gold_answer: When the time-limited approach for new banks no longer applies—because either of the earlier conditions referenced in the prior material (paragraph 4.8) has ceased—the PRA buffer is then set using the bank’s stress testing assessments, consistent with how established banks are treated. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] The same source also indicates that the PRA can introduce this established-bank, stress-testing-based approach earlier if it identifies heightened risks to its objectives. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] Beyond that, the PRA may use supervisory judgement to depart from the stated approach in exceptional circumstances, including where following the stated approach would not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] This exceptional-circumstances divergence can also cover situations where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives and considers that those risks justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer approach used for established banks. [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a] In practice, that means there is a normal “end point” tied to the earlier conditions, but there is also an explicit ability to move earlier (or otherwise diverge) when exceptional circumstances or heightened risks make the standard approach inappropriate. [#SRC:786185f23d84f194] [#TGT:7cb7aa7ed1a3d55a]
source_text: The PRA’s approach for setting the PRA buffer is designed to support new banks in their early years of operation, and as such is time-limited. Once either of the conditions set out above (paragraph 4.8 ) no longer apply, the bank’s PRA buffer will be calibrated using the bank’s stress testing assessments, in line with established banks. However, as stated in paragraph 4.12 , such an approach could be introduced earlier where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives.
target_text: When exercising its supervisory judgement, the PRA may, in exceptional circumstances, diverge from the stated approach to calculating the PRA buffer for new and growing banks, for instance where the stated approach does not achieve the intended outcome of avoiding a disproportionate level of capital relative to financial stability risks. Such divergence could also include instances where the PRA identifies heightened risks to its objectives which justify an earlier transition to the PRA buffer in line with established banks.

question: If a credit union has more than £50 million in total assets and needs to do liquidity stress testing at least once a year, what should it build into the test (like the RAS, the kinds of scenarios, and what outflows/run-off to look at), and what does the PRA expect to discuss with the credit union about the test?
gold_answer: For a credit union with more than £50 million in total assets, the PRA expects periodic liquidity stress testing at least annually so the credit union can demonstrate it is holding sufficient liquid funds by considering the impact of stressed outflows. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The credit union can meet this expectation through its own analysis, but that analysis should be based on a clearly articulated RAS that sets out the duration and type of stress (or stresses) the credit union aims to survive. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] The test should not be limited to mild or narrow events; it should examine a range of severe but plausible scenarios, and it should also include combined scenarios. [#SRC:505c78059496b268] Because the annual testing is meant to evaluate stressed outflows, the credit union should design the scenarios and calculations so outflows under stress are explicitly assessed as part of the liquidity impact. [#TGT:73d0793fc2f7a1d0] The PRA expects to engage with the credit union on the method used and the assumptions made, including the credit union’s view of likely run-off for different parts of the retail book, so those assumptions should be identified and supportable within the stress-testing approach. [#SRC:505c78059496b268]
source_text: The liquidity stress testing expectation referred to in paragraph 12.1 could be met by the credit union’s own analysis, which is based on a clearly articulated RAS (see paragraph 10.1 ) defining the duration and type of stress or stresses that the credit union aims to survive. The PRA expects the stress tests to consider the impact of a range of severe, but plausible scenarios (including combined scenarios). Credit unions should expect the PRA to engage with them on the method used and assumptions made, eg their assessment of the likely run-off of different elements of the retail book.
target_text: In order to ensure a credit union is holding sufficient liquid funds under Credit Unions 9.4 , the PRA expects credit unions with more than £50 million in total assets to carry out periodic (at least annual) liquidity stress testing whereby the impact of stressed outflows is considered.

question: If a firm is planning for continuity under Operational Continuity 3.1(2), what does it need to be able to do during restructuring for recovery or resolution, and what Bank of England document can it draw on to help with that planning?
gold_answer: For Operational Continuity 3.1(2), the firm needs to be able to keep critical services running even if restructuring for recovery or resolution causes changes in how services are provided, and it can draw on its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ to support that planning. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] The capability expectation is not limited to one anticipated event: the firm should be able to ensure continuity regardless of the restructuring scenarios it may encounter, and it should factor different scenarios into its continuity planning. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] Using the ‘Restructuring Planning’ Statement of Policy as an input can help the firm structure or inform its approach to preparing for those restructuring-driven changes to service provision while still meeting the continuity objective for critical services. [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] The overall result should be a continuity plan and capability that remains effective across multiple possible restructuring situations, rather than being tailored to a single assumed path. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]
source_text: In implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2), firms should have the capability to ensure continuity of critical services during possible changes to service provision resulting from restructuring related to recovery or resolution. 16 Firms should have the capability to ensure continuity irrespective of the scenarios that they may encounter during such a restructuring and should take different scenarios into account in planning for continuity.
target_text: 16. Firms may be able to draw on their implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’, available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/financial-stability/resolution/resolvability-assessment-framework/resolvability-assessment-framework-policy-documents .

question: If you are putting together the Merger Document (with the Schedule 16 Statement) for a merger, what does the Schedule 16 Statement need to say about possible conflicts with contracts, and whose contracts must be covered (including connected undertakings), given the Merger Document is provided unless a board-resolution consent route is being sought for the transferee society?
gold_answer: You must ensure the Merger Document includes the Schedule 16 Statement as part of the submission package, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] Within that Schedule 16 Statement, the PRA expects a clear statement on contractual conflicts: it must say whether the merger will conflict, or will not conflict, with contractual obligations. [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca] The scope of that conflict check is broad: it must cover contractual obligations of either society, and it must also cover the contractual obligations of their connected undertakings. [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca] The contractual obligations to be considered are not limited to a narrow category; the statement must explicitly include agency agreements as an example of the types of contractual obligations that need to be assessed for conflict. [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca] Alongside including the Schedule 16 Statement in the Merger Document, the submission is also accompanied by the specified explanations referenced for the Merger Document package. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1]
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: The PRA will require the Schedule 16 Statement to include a statement as to whether or not the merger will conflict with any contractual obligations, including agency agreements, of either society or their connected undertakings.

question: If a credit union changes a delinquent loan by rescheduling it or adding the arrears to the balance, what should directors be checking about provisioning, and how long does the credit union have to keep the same provision that applied right before the change?
gold_answer: Directors are expected to regularly check and reassure themselves that their credit union is accurately meeting the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, including when delinquent loans are being handled through restructuring. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] When a delinquent loan is rescheduled or when arrears are capitalised, the credit union must not treat the restructuring itself as a reason to lower the provision that was required just before the rescheduling or recapitalisation. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] The provision that applied immediately prior to the change must be kept at that level until the loan has shown it is performing again for a set period. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] That period is six months of performance, and only after that six-month performance period can the credit union move away from maintaining the pre-change provision, consistent with accurate compliance oversight by directors. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] Directors should therefore focus their regular checks on whether the credit union is maintaining the required pre-change provision for the full six months, as part of satisfying themselves about accurate compliance with Rules 3.11 and 3.12. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff]
source_text: The PRA expects that all directors regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union accurately complies with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears capitalised, the provision a credit union is required to make immediately prior to the rescheduling or recapitalisation must be maintained until the loan has performed for six months.

question: How must institutions map a derivative transaction that has more than one material risk driver when the primary (or most material, within a given risk category) risk driver is a climatic conditions variable, and the other material risk driver(s) fall into different risk categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must treat the climatic conditions variable as requiring mapping to the commodity risk category, while also applying the multi-risk-driver mapping approach for derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In practice, this means the transaction is not mapped to a single category only; instead, it is mapped across all relevant risk categories that contain at least one material risk driver, including commodity where the climatic conditions variable is the primary or most material driver in a given risk category. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] For the commodity mapping specifically, the climatic conditions variable is the basis for mapping the transaction to the commodity risk category. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] For the other risk categories implicated by the remaining material risk drivers, the institution must map the transaction once to each such risk category, using the most material risk driver within each category as the basis for that category’s mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If, however, all material risk drivers happen to fall within the same risk category, the institution maps the transaction only once to that category based on the most material driver—while still recognizing that a climatic conditions variable, when it is the primary or most material driver, points to commodity as the relevant category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]
source_text: (b) where the primary risk driver of a transaction, or the most material risk driver in a given risk category for transactions referred to in paragraph 3 , is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When a firm seeks to include assets with contractually bounded but uncertain cash-flow timing (eg callable bond final redemptions or bonds where the start of repayments can vary within a bounded period) in an MA portfolio, how should it frame the application between the fixed cash flow requirement and the alternative treatment as assets with HP cash flows, and what portfolio-level limit applies to that HP treatment?
gold_answer: A firm should treat assets with bounded but uncertain cash-flow timing as requiring a tailored justification, because the PRA will decide whether they satisfy the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis when assessing the firm’s application to include them. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] In framing the application, the firm can also evaluate whether those same assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows (by reference to the criteria in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D) and, if they do, propose including them in the MA portfolio under the limited allowance for such assets rather than relying solely on fixed cash flow treatment. [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4] For that alternative route, the SS defines assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A as “assets with HP cash flows,” and indicates firms can demonstrate these do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (as discussed in Chapter 4). [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1] The firm must also respect the aggregate portfolio constraint: HP cash flows are limited to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and the PRA may apply additional safeguards to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio. [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: When a firm is required to deliver single customer view and exclusions view information within 24 hours, how is the start of that 24-hour period treated when the trigger is a request rather than deposits becoming unavailable, and who may make such a request (including in business-as-usual activity)?
gold_answer: A firm must be able to deliver single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours, and this obligation applies both when relevant deposits become unavailable deposits and when the PRA or the FSCS requests the files. [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619] Where the 24-hour clock is driven by a request, the PRA’s view is that the start of the 24-hour period may be treated as the end of the business day on which the request was made, rather than the moment the request is received. [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] The PRA or the FSCS can request submission at any time, and the SOURCE explicitly notes that this can include requests made as part of a business as usual review programme. [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] In practice, this means the firm should maintain operational readiness to generate and submit the SCV file and the exclusions view file promptly upon request, while still meeting the 24-hour deadline that also applies when deposits become unavailable deposits.
