[#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619] The firm’s compliance approach should therefore align its timing controls to the trigger: use the “end of business day” convention for request-triggered submissions (per the PRA’s stated interpretation), and ensure the same 24-hour turnaround is met for submissions to the FSCS when the trigger is the deposits becoming unavailable deposits. [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c] [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619]
source_text: Depositor Protection 12.1 and 12.2 set out that a firm must provide an SCV file and an exclusions view file to the PRA or the FSCS within 24 hours of a deposit becoming an unavailable deposit or request by the PRA or the FSCS. The PRA considers that the beginning of the 24-hour period can be taken as the end of the business day on which the request was made. The PRA or the FSCS may request the submission of an SCV file and exclusions view file at any time, including as part of the business as usual review programme. As such, firms should be ready and able to submit SCV and exclusions view files to the PRA and FSCS upon request, and within the time period set out in the depositor protection rules.
target_text: A firm must provide to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the relevant deposits becoming unavailable deposits .

question: Given that the PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC, how should a TWD firm explain the compliance value of implementing those SoPs in relation to Fundamental Rule 8’s requirement to prepare for resolution and minimise disruption of critical services?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should treat implementation of the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC as a practical means of supporting its ability to meet Fundamental Rule 8, even though the PRA does not directly supervise against those SoPs. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52] Fundamental Rule 8 requires a firm to be prepared for resolution so that, if needed, it can be resolved in an orderly way while keeping disruption to critical services to a minimum. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] In explaining the compliance value, the firm can link (i) the Bank’s approach—developed with PRA consultation—to promoting the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8, with (ii) the operational outcome that implementing the SoPs helps TWD firms develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52] That linkage matters because the Rule 8 standard is about readiness for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption, and the SoPs are described as enabling the firm to build and carry out a specific post-resolution restructuring option (the TWD option), which is part of being prepared in practice. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] Accordingly, the firm’s rationale should emphasize that the SoPs are not framed as a separate supervisory checklist, but as implementation tools that help deliver the resolution preparedness outcome required by Rule 8. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]
source_text: The PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC. However, the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies. The Bank’s approach acts to promote the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8 in the Fundamental Rules Part of the PRA Rulebook. Implementing these Bank’s SoPs will help TWD firms to develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: When a firm identifies an “exception” involving a material model, what must its formally approved policies and procedures cover, and what specific controls and governance steps are expected for (i) exceptions for model use and (ii) exceptions for model performance, given the definition of “exceptions” in the referenced text?
gold_answer: A firm should treat an “exception” for a material model as a defined category of non-standard model usage or outcomes and should have formally approved policies and procedures that specify what exceptions it will allow and how they are escalated and managed. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] In this context, an exception includes situations such as using a model without approval by the appropriate oversight entity or without validation for use, using a model outside its intended purpose, continuing to use a model despite persistent breaches of performance metrics, or where back testing indicates model results do not align with actual outcomes. [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818] For exceptions for model use, the firm’s approach should ensure the exception is temporary, is subject to post-model adjustments (PMAs), and is reported to and supported by stakeholders and senior management. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] For model performance exceptions, the firm should set clear guidelines to determine a maximum tolerance for deviations from expectation, and apply appropriate risk controls and mitigants once defined triggers and thresholds are breached. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] Those controls and mitigants can include alternative models, heightened review and challenge, more frequent monitoring post-model adjustments, and recalibration or redevelopment of the existing methodology. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933]
source_text: a) For material models, firms should formulate the exceptions 23 they would allow for model use and model performance, and should implement formally approved policies and procedures setting out the escalation procedures to be followed and to manage these exceptions. (i) Exceptions for model use should be temporary, should be subject to post-model adjustments (PMAs), should be reported to and supported by stakeholders and senior management. (ii) For model performance exceptions, firms should have clear guidelines for determining a maximum tolerance on model performance exceptions (deviation from expectation), should be subject to appropriate risk controls (eg the use of alternative models, heightened review and challenge, and more frequent monitoring post-model adjustments) and mitigants (eg recalibrating or redevelopment of existing methodology) once defined triggers and thresholds are breached.
target_text: 23. Exceptions are defined here as using a model when not approved for usage by the appropriate oversight entity or not validated for use; a model is used outside its intended purpose; a model that displays persistent breach of performance metrics continues to be used; or back testing suggests the model results are inconsistent with actual outcomes.

question: When the PRA is determining what information to request in Phase 2 after reviewing Phase 1 submissions, what specific MREL-related information must a firm provide if it has been notified by the Bank of England that it is, or is likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements, and how does the PRA’s Phase 2 scoping approach affect that request?
gold_answer: A firm that has been notified by the Bank of England that it is, or is likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL above regulatory capital requirements is expected to provide MREL-related information as part of the PRA’s Phase 2 information request. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] In that notified-firm scenario, the expected content includes information on MREL resources, projected resources, and the characteristics of individual instruments. [#TGT:de6e936130cf1aef] This expectation sits within the PRA’s Phase 2 process, where the PRA reviews Phase 1 submissions and, together with the Bank of England, selects a preferred resolution strategy that then drives what information is requested in Phase 2. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA uses supervisory judgement to set the breadth and depth of Phase 2 information requests and, where possible, aligns those requests with other planned supervisory work to reduce duplication. [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9] The PRA also indicates that, given differences in firms’ legal, financial, and operational structures, it may require information beyond what is otherwise outlined for Phase 2, and it will notify firms when Phase 2 information needs updating (including as firms move closer to resolution). [#SRC:f6b88f60c0da27f9]
source_text: The PRA will review Phase 1 submissions and, in conjunction with the Bank of England, will determine a preferred resolution strategy for the firm. This will define the information that should be requested in Phase 2 . Supervisory judgement will inform the breadth and depth of the information firms will be requested to provide in Phase 2 and, where possible, this will be integrated with other scheduled supervisory initiatives (eg business model analysis reviews, liquidity reviews, operational risk reviews) in order to avoid duplication of effort. The PRA expects firms that are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources as specified in Chapter 2 section A4 of this statement. Given the diversity of legal, financial and operational structures across firms, firms may be required to provide information beyond that which is outlined in this supervisory statement. The PRA will notify firms where updates are required to Phase 2 information. As firms move closer to resolution the PRA may ask for data to be updated.
target_text: The PRA expects firms that have been notified by the Bank of England that they are, or are likely to be, subject to external or internal MREL in excess of regulatory capital requirements to provide information on MREL resources, projected resources, and individual instrument characteristics.

question: If the PRA is applying its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to the MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL, what does the PRA expect a firm to do with CET1 when it is meeting MREL and also holding CET1 for risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers?
gold_answer: In the context where the PRA applies its MREL buffer policy (Chapter 2) and Threshold Conditions policy (Chapter 3) to MREL set by the Bank for both interim and end-state MREL requirements, a firm is expected to meet MREL and also maintain CET1 in an amount that reflects its risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe] [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The PRA also expects the firm not to use the same CET1 amount to satisfy both objectives at the same time; in other words, CET1 should not be double counted toward MREL and toward the CET1 amount reflecting the buffers. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] The PRA’s position also makes clear that, while a firm can meet MREL with CET1, it is not required to meet MREL with CET1, which supports the idea that CET1 held for buffer reflection should not be assumed to be the same CET1 used for MREL. [#TGT:cf350995c5d698e1] These expectations apply within the policy setting described—namely, the PRA’s application of the Chapter 2 and Chapter 3 policies to Bank-set MREL for both interim and end-state requirements. [#SRC:140f409993eca2fe]
source_text: The PRA will apply the MREL buffer policy ( Chapter 2 ) and Threshold Conditions policy ( Chapter 3 ) in respect of MREL set by the Bank with respect to both interim and end-state MREL requirements.
target_text: The PRA expects firms to meet both MREL and maintain an amount of CET1 that reflects their risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. The PRA expects firms not to double count CET1 towards both MREL and the amount reflecting the risk-weighted capital and leverage buffers. While firms can meet MREL with CET1, they do not have to meet it with CET1. See ‘The Bank of England’s approach to setting MREL’ 5 for details.

question: If markets are stressed, do firms change the MA calculation method for TPs, and when can they add more to the fundamental spread than the amount worked out under 4.10–4.16 (including the kinds of add-ons mentioned in 4.16 and 4.17)?
gold_answer: When calculating TPs, the MA and FS are determined using the approach set out in Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook, and the PRA view is that the MA calculation method should stay the same even in stress conditions. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Even so, firms should actively consider whether the assumptions feeding into the MA and FS used for the TP calculation are still suitable under stress, including any extra amounts added to the FS (for example, additions connected to assets with HP cash flows under Matching Adjustment 4.16, or additions made for other reasons under Matching Adjustment 4.17). [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Separately, a firm is allowed to increase the fundamental spread above the level calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 if that increase is needed to make sure the fundamental spread covers all risks the firm keeps. [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1] Putting these points together: the method stays stable, but the firm should revisit assumptions and can raise the fundamental spread where necessary so retained risks are fully covered. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1]
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook (restating as rules the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations) sets out how the MA and FS should be calculated for the purpose of determining TPs. While the PRA considers that the MA calculation method should not change in stress conditions, firms should consider if the assumptions used to calculate the MA and FS for the TP calculation, including any additions to the FS (either for assets with HP cash flows as per Matching Adjustment 4.16 or for other reasons as per Matching Adjustment 4.17 ), remain appropriate in stress conditions.
target_text: A firm may increase the fundamental spread calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 where necessary to ensure it covers all risks retained by the firm .

question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission and uses the EVT to help with its attestation to the PRA, what does it need to do about its assumptions, and does it have to do this for each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole?
gold_answer: If the firm has a matching adjustment permission, it must provide an attestation to the PRA for each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole held by the firm. [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d] If the firm chooses to use the EVT for attestation purposes, the PRA expects the firm to work in line with the principles behind the EVT and to use its own assumptions that it considers appropriate when attesting that the MA can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets in the relevant portfolio. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] Because the attestation is required for each relevant portfolio “as a whole,” the firm should apply this EVT-based assumption-setting and analysis at the level of the whole relevant portfolio, not just a subset of assets. [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d] The assumptions the firm uses should not be weaker than the PRA’s published minimum parameters where those parameters apply. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] The firm also needs to think about retained risks other than the NNEG that the EVT does not assess, and factor that into how it supports the attestation. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] In practice, using the EVT is a choice about method, but the portfolio-wide attestation to the PRA is still required. [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d]
source_text: Where a firm chooses to use the EVT for attestation purposes, the PRA expects it to engage with the principles underlying the EVT and use its own assumptions that are judged to be appropriate when attesting that the MA can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets ( Matching Adjustment 9.1(1)(b) ). These assumptions should not fall below the PRA’s published minimum parameters where applicable, with additional consideration given to any retained risks other than the NNEG that are not assessed by the EVT.
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must provide to the PRA the attestation set out at (1) at the time set out in (2) by a person in (3) in the form set out in 12.1 in respect of each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole held by the firm .

question: If an institution uses an internal hedge (a credit derivative in the trading book) to hedge a non-trading book credit or counterparty risk exposure, what extra step is needed before it can count the exposure as hedged—and how does that fit with the rule that hedges against interest rate risks can be recognised, including internal hedges meeting Article 106(3)?
gold_answer: You can recognise the effect of hedges against interest rate risks, and that recognition can include internal hedges as long as they meet the requirements in Article 106(3). [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d] But if the hedge is an internal hedge using a credit derivative that is booked in the trading book and it is meant to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, the exposure cannot be treated as hedged for calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless you also buy matching protection from an eligible third party protection provider. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] That third-party protection must be a corresponding credit derivative that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] If you do buy and recognise that third-party protection as a hedge for capital requirement calculations, you must then make sure that neither the internal credit derivative nor the external credit derivative is included in the trading book for calculating capital requirements. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] So, internal hedges may be recognised for interest rate risk when they meet Article 106(3), but internal credit-derivative hedges for non-trading book exposures only “count” with the added third-party hedge and the required trading-book treatment for both derivatives. [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d][#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]
source_text: (iv) the recognition of the effect of hedges against those interest rate risks, including internal hedges that meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3) ;
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraphs 1 and 2 , when an institution hedges a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure using a credit derivative booked in its trading book using an internal hedge, institutions shall ensure that the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure shall not be deemed to be hedged for the purposes of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless the institution purchases from an eligible third party protection provider a corresponding credit derivative meeting the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Without prejudice to point (h) of Article 299(2), where such third party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge of a non-trading book exposure for the purposes of calculating capital requirements, institutions shall ensure that neither the internal nor external credit derivative hedge shall be included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements.

question: When seeking permission to apply an MA, what confirmation must the firm provide about meeting Matching Adjustment 13.3, and how does that sit alongside the restriction on using a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment for the same insurance or reinsurance obligations once the matching adjustment is applied?
gold_answer: A firm seeking permission to apply an MA must provide a specific confirmation that, if permission is granted, it will meet the requirements of Matching Adjustment 13.3. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] In addition, where the firm applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations, it is prohibited from also applying either a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or a volatility adjustment in respect of those same obligations. [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5] Taken together, the firm’s confirmation about meeting Matching Adjustment 13.3 should be framed and implemented in a way that is consistent with the operational constraint that the matching adjustment cannot be combined with those other adjustments for the obligations to which the matching adjustment is applied. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5] Practically, this means the firm should ensure its permission request and subsequent application of the MA reflect both: (i) readiness to comply with Matching Adjustment 13.3 upon grant of permission, and (ii) a clear approach for the relevant portfolio that avoids applying a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment to the same obligations covered by the matching adjustment. [#SRC:189b87c3fdc66970] [#TGT:9706839fe64ff0b5]
source_text: iv. confirmation that the firm will meet the requirements of Matching Adjustment 13.3 if permission to apply an MA is granted;
target_text: A firm that applies the matching adjustment to a relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations must not apply a risk-free interest rate transitional measure or volatility adjustment in respect of those obligations.

question: If a firm calculates its SCR using an internal model, what does the SCR measure need to match (confidence level and time period), and how will the PRA review the model differently when the firm’s risks are homogeneous versus only mostly homogeneous?
gold_answer: For an internal-model SCR, the model’s calibration needs to support an SCR that matches the required risk measure: the SCR must equal the value-at-risk of the firm’s basic own funds at a 99.5% confidence level over a one-year period. [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf] [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] This linkage matters because the internal model is required to be calibrated to the specified calibration standard, and the SCR definition fixes the confidence level and horizon the calibration must ultimately deliver. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf] The PRA’s review approach then depends on how similar the firm’s risks are to each other. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] If the risks are homogeneous, the PRA can use a quantitative assessment of how each individual risk is calibrated and how dependency structures are calibrated as an efficient way to spot potential problem areas suggesting the model is not calibrated adequately to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] If the risks are largely (but not totally) homogeneous, the PRA will adjust (tailor) its quantitative assessment to reflect the firm’s specific risk profile, while still using that work to judge whether calibration is adequate for producing an SCR consistent with the 99.5% one-year value-at-risk requirement. [#SRC:d370901666ca9511] [#TGT:cee08b3155b4ebbf]
source_text: Internal models are required to be calibrated to the standard specified in Solvency Capital Requirement – General Provisions 3.4 . Where risks are homogeneous, a PRA quantitative assessment of the calibration of individual risks and their dependency structures can give an efficient diagnosis of whether there are areas of potential concern where the model has not been calibrated adequately to meet the internal model requirements and calibration standards. Where the risks are largely (but not totally) homogeneous, the PRA will tailor its quantitative assessments to reflect a firm’s specific risk profile.
target_text: A firm’s SCR must correspond to the value-at-risk of its basic own funds subject to a confidence level of 99.5% over a one-year period.

question: For a subsidiary assessing its Senior Management Functions (SMFs) and maintaining governance documentation, how should it treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) in light of the fact that Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and what related documentation and allocation expectations apply?
gold_answer: A subsidiary should treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) as the Statements of Responsibilities required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and it should keep those SoR current as part of its broader senior management governance arrangements. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e] In practice, the subsidiary is expected to ensure it has an appropriate number of SMFs that reflects its size, complexity, and governance structure, and to do so consistently with the principles in SS28/15 on strengthening individual accountability in banking. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Alongside calibrating SMFs, the subsidiary should ensure that both its Management Responsibilities Maps and its SoR are up to date. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] It should also allocate responsibilities in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, using the up-to-date SoR and Management Responsibilities Maps as the key governance artefacts supporting that allocation. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Because the SoR are specifically the FSMA section 60(2A) Statements of Responsibilities, the subsidiary’s obligation to keep SoR current should be understood as maintaining those section 60(2A) documents in an up-to-date state within its accountability framework. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]
source_text: A subsidiary should ensure that they have an appropriate number of SMFs according to its size, complexity, and governance structure, in line with the principles outlined in SS28/15 ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’ . 34 Firms should particularly ensure that Management Responsibilities Maps and Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) are up to date and that responsibilities are allocated in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15 . 35
target_text: 35. Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60 (2A) of FSMA: https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/8/section/60 .

question: In the PRA’s expectation for assessing potential dividend payments, how should an insurer evidence that a planned dividend is appropriate, and how does that assessment extend to other forms of distributions such as returns of premiums to members of a mutual or loans to a parent or holding company?
gold_answer: An insurer should treat the PRA’s expectation as requiring a documented, evidence-based assessment showing that any planned dividend payment is justified by the insurer’s actual and projected business performance and by its current and future capital position, explicitly considered against the insurer’s documented risk appetite. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] To make that assessment complete, the insurer should apply the same type of evaluation not only to dividends but also to distributions to any capital providers, since the scope of “distributions” includes (among other examples) a return of premiums to the members of a mutual and a loan to a parent or holding company. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9] Practically, this means the insurer should be able to demonstrate, for each planned payment or transfer, how the decision aligns with both performance (actual and forecast) and capital considerations (current and forward-looking), and how those considerations were weighed in light of the risk appetite that has been documented. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] Where the proposed transaction is not a dividend but instead a return of premiums or an intra-group loan, it should still be assessed as a distribution to a capital provider and therefore evaluated using the same appropriateness framework. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]
source_text: When assessing potential dividend payments, 10 the PRA expects insurers to be able to demonstrate that any planned dividend payments are appropriate in relation to actual and projected business performance, as well as the current and future capital position of the insurer, taking account of its documented risk appetite.
target_text: 10. This would include here the assessment made for distributions to any capital providers, including for a return of premiums to the members of a mutual, or for a loan to a parent or holding company.

question: Under what circumstances may a managing agent allow a single syndicate it manages to carry on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business, and how should the managing agent approach applying the Composites Part requirements in that situation?
gold_answer: A managing agent is generally prohibited from allowing both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages, but this prohibition is expressly framed as subject to an exception (“except where”). [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] In the Composites framework, the baseline expectation is separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business, which in practice means separately managing syndicates that carry on general insurance business from syndicates that carry on long-term insurance business. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] Where, notwithstanding that baseline, a single syndicate carries on both types of business under the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2, the managing agent should use the guidance in paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites to help determine how the requirements of the Composites Part apply to the managing agent in that mixed-business syndicate scenario. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] Accordingly, the managing agent’s compliance approach is: treat combined general and long-term business within one syndicate as permissible only within the scope of the stated exception, and then apply the Composites Part by reference to the SS8/15 paragraphs identified for that purpose. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]
source_text: Composites 2.2 requires composite firms to maintain separate management of general insurance business and long-term insurance business. In practical terms, this requires that managing agents separately manage syndicates which carry on general insurance business from syndicates which carry on long-term insurance business. However, where a single syndicate carries on both general insurance business and long-term insurance business pursuant to the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2 , paragraphs 3.1 – 3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are intended to assist in determining how the requirements of the Composites Part will apply to managing agents.
target_text: A managing agent must not permit both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate managed by it, except where:

question: If a firm uses a service provider to do something the firm would normally do, how do you decide if it counts as ‘outsourcing’ (including if the work is done regularly or via sub-outsourcing), and what rules still matter if it ends up being a ‘third party arrangement’ instead?
gold_answer: To decide whether the relationship is ‘outsourcing’, the firm should apply the PRA Rulebook definition and then, if it does not fit, treat it as a ‘third party arrangement’ that is not covered by existing outsourcing requirements but is still governed by wider PRA expectations. [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2] The PRA Rulebook definition of ‘outsourcing’ is broad: it includes any arrangement where a service provider performs a process, service, or activity that the firm would otherwise undertake itself, and it can include performance done indirectly through sub-outsourcing. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] When checking whether a third-party relationship falls within that definition, the firm should look at whether the third party will carry out the function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis, since that helps determine whether it is outsourcing. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] If the arrangement does not meet the outsourcing definition, it may be a ‘third party arrangement’ and therefore outside the scope of existing outsourcing requirements and some of the detailed expectations in the supervisory statement. [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2] However, the firm still needs to manage it in line with the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations on business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management, including cyber risk. [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2]
source_text: Chapter 2 elaborates on the definition of ‘outsourcing’ in the PRA Rulebook. It also notes that there are arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside this definition (‘third party arrangements’) and are consequently outside of the scope of existing requirements on outsourcing and some of the detailed expectations in this SS. However, these third party arrangements are still subject to the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations on business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management (including but not limited to cyber risk).
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: For a derivative transaction that is mapped to the commodity risk category and has more than one material risk driver (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), how must an institution determine (i) whether the transaction is mapped once or multiple times across risk categories, and (ii) which risk driver basis is then used to assign the transaction to a hedging set within the commodity risk category?
gold_answer: An institution must first decide how many risk-category mappings are required for the derivative transaction, and then—once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category—assign it to a commodity hedging set using the appropriate risk-driver basis. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] For derivatives with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map the transaction to more than one risk category as a derogation from paragraph 2. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis for that single mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and the mapping within each category is based on the most material risk driver in that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] After the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), it must be assigned to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or—where applicable—the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When determining which Guidelines and Recommendations a firm or FMI should follow, how should it treat (i) predecessor committees’ Guidelines and Recommendations that are not listed in Appendices 1 to 3 and (ii) ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations issued after the end of the transition period, given that the SoP provides links to ESMA materials in place at the end of the transition period?
gold_answer: A firm or FMI should treat the Appendices 1 to 3 lists as non-exhaustive and, where relevant, continue to comply with predecessor committees’ Guidelines and Recommendations even if they are not listed, unless those materials have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] In parallel, for the purposes of this SoP, the relevant ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations are those in place as at the end of the transition period (with links provided), and any changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations or new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are treated as not relevant for this SoP. [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024] Practically, this means a firm or FMI should not assume that omission from the Appendices removes an obligation to comply where relevant, but it should also not treat post-transition ESMA updates as within scope for this SoP’s purposes. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024] The Bank and PRA’s acknowledgement of ESMA as the source of the linked materials supports using ESMA’s end-of-transition set as the reference point for what the SoP is addressing. [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024]
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials.

question: If you need the profit number to work out the ‘relevant amount’ for equity shares (11.6), which year’s profits do you use and what kind of accounts must those profits come from under 11.7, especially if the issuer’s accounts are not made under Accounts Directives rules?
gold_answer: For equity shares, the ‘relevant amount’ for the purposes of 11.6 is based on the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year that ends on or before the valuation date. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] Those profits must be taken from accounts that are publicly available and reported in accounts prepared in accordance with 11.8, and the amount used must be limited to what is attributable to the equity shares while also reflecting any changes caused by alterations in capital structure. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] Separately, for the purposes of 11.7, the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up under legislation implementing the Accounts Directives. [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3] If the issuer’s accounts are not drawn up under that Accounts Directives legislation, then the profits must instead be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice. [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3] Putting these together, you select the valuation-date-linked year and apply the equity-share attribution and capital-structure adjustment from 11.6, but you also ensure the profit figure is derived from accounts prepared under one of the accounting bases permitted by 11.7. [#SRC:a2a19cd5ab3c2b3f] [#TGT:68f79027ccb9b6a3]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.6 , the ‘relevant amount’ in relation to equity shares is the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the most recent financial year ending on or before the valuation date which is reported in accounts in accordance with 11.8 which are publicly available, in so far as attributable to those equity shares , taking account of the effect of any alterations in capital structure.
target_text: For the purposes of 11.7 , the issuer’s profits after taxation from its ordinary activities for the relevant financial year must be derived from accounts drawn up in accordance with legislation implementing the Accounts Directives or, if accounts are not so drawn up, from accounts drawn up in accordance with International Accounting Standards Committee accounting standards or US generally accepted accounting practice.

question: If a firm uses the TMTP method and does a transfer event (like a Part VII transfer or a 100% reinsurance change) that affects the technical provisions covered by TMTP, when is it allowed to update its TMTP methodology, and exactly when should it work out the ‘transferred TMTP’ compared with the effective date?
gold_answer: The firm is required to update its TMTP methodology when a transfer event causes a change in the technical provisions that the TMTP relates to, but that update is only allowed if the business being transferred or ceded was already within TMTP before the transfer happened. [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b] Once that condition is met, the timing for the transferred amount is specific: the ‘transferred TMTP’ should be calculated immediately before the effective date of the transfer or transaction. [#TGT:a7aad619cba8176e] This sits alongside the PRA’s expectation that the update is based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction, so the firm should use effective-date figures for the update while ensuring the transferred TMTP calculation point is just prior to that effective date. [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b] [#TGT:a7aad619cba8176e] Examples of transfer events that can trigger this include a transfer of business under Part VII of FSMA or the Friendly Societies Act 1992, a transfer of risk under a 100% reinsurance contract, certain amendments to such a contract where the reinsurer’s risk exposure volume changes, and cancellation/commutation/termination/expiration of a 100% reinsurance contract. [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]
source_text: Firms that use the TMTP method are required by Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6 to make an update to their TMTP methodology following a ‘transfer event’ which has resulted in a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates. They are also permitted to make revisions to the business designated to the dynamic portion in order to designate acquired business that is MA-eligible in respect of that firm.. Transfer events are: 1) transfer of business either under Part VII of Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) or the Friendly Societies Act 1992; 2) the transfer of risk under a 100% reinsurance contract; 3) an amendment to an existing 100% reinsurance contract if there has been a change to the volume of risk to which the reinsurer is exposed; and 4) cancellation, commutation, termination or expiration of an 100% reinsurance contract. Such an update would only be permitted if the business that has been transferred or ceded was subject to TMTP prior to the transfer. The PRA expects this update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction. 5
target_text: 5. The ‘transferred TMTP’ should be as calculated immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction.

question: When applying the expectations in this SS, which insurers are within scope, and how does the PRA’s supervisory framework model (as described in the March 2016 ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’) support that scoping decision, particularly in light of the PRA’s view on cost impacts for smaller insurers and the risk-profile expectations for larger firms?
gold_answer: The expectations in this SS are intended to apply only to significant firms, specifically Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms, rather than to all insurers. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] This scoping is justified by the PRA’s view that smaller insurers—often operating in a single locality or niche—would face disproportionate costs if they sought to meet the SS expectations, whereas larger firms with complex risk profiles should aim to meet or exceed those expectations when complying with regulatory requirements. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] The March 2016 document ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ provides the supervisory-framework linkage for this limitation by explaining that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model. [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3] Read together, the SS sets the practical application boundary (significant firms only) and the March 2016 supervisory approach supplies the definitional basis for treating Category 1 and 2 firms as “significant” for that boundary. [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6] [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]
source_text: The PRA takes the view that for smaller insurers (the majority of which operate in one locality or niche market) to seek to meet the expectations set out in this SS would have a disproportionate cost impact on these firms. Conversely, larger firms with complex risk profiles should seek to meet (or exceed) the PRA’s expectations as set out in this SS in complying with the regulatory requirements. The PRA therefore considers it appropriate to limit the application of the expectations as set out in this SS to significant firms only (Category 1 and 2 PRA-regulated firms). 9
target_text: 9. The ‘PRA’s approach to insurance supervision’ March 2016 explains that Category 1 and 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model; https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/-/media/boe/files/prudential-regulation/approach/insurance-approach-2016.pdf

question: If an entity established outside the United Kingdom has its own buffer that is bigger than its share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk, how does that difference affect the PRA’s consolidated group PRA buffer, and when would the PRA ignore the difference?
gold_answer: Where an entity established outside the United Kingdom has a buffer that exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applied at consolidated group level for the same risk, the PRA uses the amount of that excess as an input when it assesses the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] In other words, the PRA’s consolidated group assessment is informed by comparing the outside‑UK entity’s applicable buffer with the entity’s allocated share of the consolidated group buffer covering the same risk, and considering how much higher the entity-level buffer is. [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901] But the PRA would not reflect that difference in the consolidated group PRA buffer if the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8] So the difference matters for the assessment generally, yet it is not carried into the consolidated group PRA buffer outcome when consolidated group requirements already address and mitigate the underlying risk that drives the outside‑UK entity’s buffer. [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8]
source_text: The PRA’s assessment of the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk will be informed by the amount by which any buffer applicable on an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applicable at the consolidated group level to cover the same risk. 50 51
target_text: 51. The PRA would not reflect such a difference in the consolidated group PRA buffer where the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements.

question: If a society has already passed the Transfer Resolutions and now needs PRA confirmation before the transfer can take effect, what should the scrutineers’ report say about problems in the vote and invalid votes, and why is that relevant to the PRA’s confirmation application and hearing process?
gold_answer: Because a transfer cannot take effect until the PRA confirms it, and because the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation once the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the materials supporting the confirmation application need to address what happened in the voting process. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] The PRA expects the scrutineers’ report to do two main things: it should describe any procedural difficulties that occurred during the vote, and if the number of invalid votes seems significant it should also explain the reasons those votes were treated as invalid. [#SRC:1d201d12e7ea00d0] This matters for the confirmation stage because the PRA describes not only the form of application and public notice required, but also its view on interpreting the statutory Confirmation Criteria and the procedure it customarily follows when considering confirmation applications and hearing representations. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] In practice, that means the scrutineers’ report should be prepared in a way that clearly surfaces voting issues (including invalid-vote causes) so they can be understood alongside the confirmation application and any representations the PRA may hear as part of its customary process. [#SRC:1d201d12e7ea00d0] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]
source_text: The PRA expect the scrutineers’ report to comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant, give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid (see also section ‘ Confirmation ’).
target_text: No transfer can take effect until it has been confirmed by the PRA. This section first describes the form of application and public notice required. It then explains the PRA view of how the statutory Confirmation Criteria should be interpreted. Finally, it gives guidance on the procedure customarily followed by the PRA when considering confirmation applications and hearing representations. Sections 97(4)(d) and 98(2) of, together with Part II of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, provide that when the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in such manner as the PRA may direct.

question: In assessing a model’s complexity, how should the firm incorporate considerations of designer or data bias when the bias arises because some dataset elements (or model design choices) are more heavily weighted or represented than others, potentially creating ethical and/or social implications?
gold_answer: The firm should treat potential designer or data bias as a complexity-relevant risk factor and evaluate it specifically in terms of whether the dataset or model design over-weights or over-represents certain elements in a way that could lead to ethically or socially consequential outputs. [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] This bias-focused analysis should be integrated into the broader complexity assessment that considers inherent-risk drivers across the modelling process, including the nature and quality of input data, the choice of methodology and assumptions, implementation integrity requirements, and how frequently and/or extensively the model is used. [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253] In practice, the firm should (i) identify which dataset elements or design features receive disproportionate weighting/representation, (ii) assess how that imbalance could influence results and create ethical and/or social implications, and (iii) reflect those findings as part of the model’s complexity assessment, alongside other relevant complexity dimensions such as interpretability, explainability, and transparency where needed. [#TGT:330cb726532ca174] Where the model uses newly advanced approaches or technologies, the firm should be prepared to expand the complexity assessment to include these bias-related considerations explicitly, rather than limiting the review to conventional data-quality or methodological checks. [#SRC:81ef096859a0c253]
source_text: c) The assessment of a model's complexity should consider the risk factors that impact a model’s inherent risk 8 within each component of the modelling process, eg the nature and quality of the input data, the choice of methodology (including assumptions), the requirements and integrity of implementation, and the frequency and/or extensiveness of use of the model. Where necessary (in particular with the use of newly advanced approaches or technologies), the complexity assessment may also consider risk factors related to: (i) the use of alternative and unstructured data, 9 and (ii) measures of a model's interpretability, 10 explainability, 11 transparency, and the potential for designer or data bias 12 to be present.
target_text: 12. When elements of a dataset (or as a result of model design) are more heavily weighted and/or represented than others, producing results that could have ethical and/ or social implications.

question: When implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2), how should a firm plan for continuity of critical services during restructuring related to recovery or resolution, and how may the firm use its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ in doing so?
gold_answer: A firm implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2) should ensure it has the capability to maintain continuity of critical services through potential changes in service provision that arise from restructuring connected to recovery or resolution, and it may leverage its implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’ as a supporting resource for that work. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] The continuity capability is expected to be robust across whatever restructuring scenarios the firm might face, meaning the firm should not plan for only a single outcome but should consider multiple scenarios when designing its continuity approach. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] In practical terms, the firm can treat its existing work under the ‘Restructuring Planning’ Statement of Policy as an input to its Operational Continuity 3.1(2) implementation, using that implementation to inform how it anticipates and manages changes to service provision during restructuring. [#TGT:2adfa31e81fef236] [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6] The key compliance outcome is that, regardless of which restructuring scenario materialises, the firm remains capable of keeping critical services running while service provision changes are occurring. [#SRC:59c21b8c65ce33a6]
source_text: In implementing Operational Continuity 3.1(2), firms should have the capability to ensure continuity of critical services during possible changes to service provision resulting from restructuring related to recovery or resolution. 16 Firms should have the capability to ensure continuity irrespective of the scenarios that they may encounter during such a restructuring and should take different scenarios into account in planning for continuity.
target_text: 16. Firms may be able to draw on their implementation of the Bank of England Statement of Policy ‘Restructuring Planning’, available at: https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/financial-stability/resolution/resolvability-assessment-framework/resolvability-assessment-framework-policy-documents .

question: If the PRA is checking whether a home state supervisor is “equivalent,” what does it mainly look at (including what it gives extra weight to), and how is that different from the advice the PRA might give to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541?
gold_answer: For the PRA’s own purposes, the equivalence check is an overall, outcomes-based assessment used for PRA authorisation and supervision, and it is separate from any HM Treasury equivalence determinations made for other purposes. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581] In that PRA assessment, the PRA considers whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent and whether the home state regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in producing appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] The PRA looks at the relevant factors together, but it places considerable weight on how extensive and high-quality co-operation is with the home state supervisor. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] It also takes into account supervision of individual firms (including branches) and the consolidated group, and it considers the nature and scale of the firm’s activities in the UK as part of that overall judgement. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] Separately, the PRA may give advice to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541, but that advice is distinct from the PRA’s own equivalence assessment for authorisation and supervision. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]
source_text: The PRA will make an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, and whether its regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. 9 The PRA assesses these factors in their totality, but will place considerable weight on assessing the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor. The PRA will take into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and it will consider the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK.
target_text: 9. The PRA’s assessment of equivalence is based on the outcomes achieved and is for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, which is separate from advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes. The PRA may give advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541).

question: If a company is a large subsidiary under a UK parent group (or under a parent undertaking in a third country), does it have to publish remuneration policy information, and if so, should it do it on its own or at a sub-group level and which staff does the remuneration part need to cover?
gold_answer: If the company is a large subsidiary in one of the covered structures (under UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies, UK parent mixed financial holding companies, or under a parent undertaking established in a third country), it is required to disclose the information specified in the listed Articles, and it must do so either on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] Where the disclosure includes remuneration information, the remuneration part must cover the institution’s remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile, so the scope is tied to risk-material staff categories rather than the entire workforce. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] To comply, the company should first determine that it is within the “large subsidiary” scope described and then choose whether it will report at the individual entity level or at the sub-consolidated level for the required disclosures. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] It should then ensure the remuneration disclosure is written to address the relevant categories of staff identified by their material impact on risk profile, because that is the defined audience for the remuneration policy and practices information. [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0] The key linkage is that the reporting basis (individual vs sub-consolidated) comes from the large-subsidiary disclosure rule, while the staff coverage for the remuneration content comes from the remuneration disclosure requirement. [#SRC:d6dd201508b9a673] [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]
source_text: Large subsidiaries of UK parent institutions, UK parent financial holding companies or UK parent mixed financial holding companies and large subsidiaries of parent undertakings established in a third country shall disclose the information specified in Articles 437 , 438 , 440 , 442 , 450 , 451 , 451a and 453 on an individual basis or on a sub-consolidated basis.

question: If a firm is building downturn numbers for UK mortgage portfolios, what minimum house price drop should it use for downturn PPGD (from peak and from today’s price), and how does that fit with the PRA’s 40% sales-price drop reference point for downturn LGD that includes forced-sale discounts?
gold_answer: The firm should set downturn PPGD estimates so they properly reflect downturn conditions and meet the PRA’s minimum house price deflation expectations. [#SRC:12e0a6fed4bfdc7e] For the deflation component, the PRA expects the assumed fall in property value due to house price deflation to be no less than 25% from the previous peak price, and for downturn PPGD it also expects the estimate to be consistent with a decline that is no less than 5% from the current price. [#SRC:12e0a6fed4bfdc7e] At the same time, when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios, the PRA uses an average 40% reduction in property sales prices from the pre-downturn peak as an appropriate reference point and expects a firm’s rating systems to assume a reduction consistent with that reference. [#TGT:5bb0579cf870e51b] The firm should therefore ensure its downturn PPGD deflation floors (25% from peak and 5% from current) sit within a broader downturn sales-price reduction framework that is consistent with the 40% reference used for downturn LGD. [#SRC:12e0a6fed4bfdc7e] [#TGT:5bb0579cf870e51b] Because the 40% sales-price reduction is described as capturing both market value decline and a distressed forced sale discount, the firm should treat the deflation assumption as the market-value element rather than the full sales-price reduction. [#TGT:5bb0579cf870e51b]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure that PPGD estimates appropriately reflect economic downturn conditions. The PRA expects (as in paragraphs 13.8 and 13.9 above) downturn PPGD estimates to be consistent with a fall in the value of property due to house price deflation not lower than 25% from the previous peak price, and not lower than 5% from the current price.
target_text: The PRA believes that an average reduction in property sales prices of 40% from their peak price, prior to the market downturn, forms an appropriate reference point when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios and expects a firm’s rating systems to assume a reduction consistent with this. This reduction captures both a fall in the value of the property due to market value decline as well as a distressed forced sale discount. The PRA expects the assumption for the fall in the value of the property due to house price deflation not to be lower than 25%.

question: How should the maximum compensation sum be determined where a depositor has aggregate eligible deposits and also a temporary high balance, including the interaction between the general cap, the temporary high balance cap, and the personal injury or incapacity carve-out?
gold_answer: A depositor’s maximum compensation depends on whether the claim relates to aggregate eligible deposits, a temporary high balance, or both, and the applicable caps differ by category. For aggregate eligible deposits, the maximum compensation sum payable for each depositor is capped at £120,000, with the text also indicating that extra compensation may be available in cases covered by 4.3 or 4.4. [#SRC:336f75f8cdcde56e] For a temporary high balance, the maximum compensation sum is £1,400,000, but this figure is expressly stated to operate subject to 4.4. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] In addition, where the temporary high balance arises from a payment connected with personal injury or incapacity, the temporary high balance compensation is not subject to any limit. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] Accordingly, when assessing a depositor who has both ordinary aggregate eligible deposits and a temporary high balance, you apply the £120,000 cap to the aggregate eligible deposits while separately applying the temporary high balance rule (including the £1,400,000 cap, the “subject to 4.4” condition, and the no-limit carve-out for personal injury or incapacity payments). [#SRC:336f75f8cdcde56e] [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]
source_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: In a merger where a bonus is proposed to equalise reserves between a transferor society and a transferee society (and potentially also to pay a bonus to members of the transferee society), how should the societies determine which Merger Resolutions must include member approval of the bonus payments, taking into account the prudence condition and the prescribed-limit test based on total gross cost?
gold_answer: Member approval for any proposed bonus payment(s) must be obtained through the Merger Resolutions, and the resolution(s) that must carry that approval depend on which society’s funds are being distributed and whether the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] Where a bonus is used to address differing capital ratios—such as paying members of a transferor society that has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society to help equalise the reserves brought into the combined society—the proposal still needs to be structured so that any equalisation (including any decision to also pay a bonus to members of the transferee society) is only taken forward if it is prudent to equalise reserves at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6] Operationally, the Merger Resolutions should be drafted as follows: - Calculate the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, and compare it to the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording only in each Merger Resolution of the society whose funds are to be distributed (i.e., the paying society). [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording in each Merger Resolution of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - Ensure the rationale for any reserve equalisation (including paying both sets of members) aligns with the prudence constraint described for setting the combined society’s reserve level. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]
source_text: A bonus may, for example, be paid to the members of a transferor society with a higher capital ratio than the transferee society so as to equalise the reserves which both bring to the combined society. If it is thought desirable also to pay a bonus to the members of the transferee society, then the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the capital ratio of the transferee society, but only if it is prudent to do so. The statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society.
