question: If a firm values a financial liability using UK-adopted international accounting standards, can it change the value later because its own credit standing changes, and how does that compare to the rule for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking in Valuation 10.1?
gold_answer: No: once the financial liability has been initially recognised, the firm is not allowed to change the valuation later just because its own credit standing has changed, and that matches the Valuation 10.1 position for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] For context, the target rule applies where the firm is valuing financial liabilities that fall under UK-adopted international accounting standards, and it specifies that the valuation at initial recognition must be done in line with the referenced “5” requirement. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] The key restriction then applies after initial recognition: the firm must not make a subsequent adjustment that reflects changes in its own credit standing. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] The source text expresses the same outcome in the insurance/reinsurance setting by stating that there must be no valuation adjustment that takes account of a change in the own credit standing of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71] Putting both together, the practical compliance result is that own-credit changes are not a permitted reason to adjust the valuation after the initial recognition step, including for an insurance or reinsurance undertaking. [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6] [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71]
source_text: Subsequently, the second sentence of Valuation 10.1 ; there shall be no valuation adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking.
target_text: A firm must value financial liabilities, as referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards , in accordance with 5 upon initial recognition. A firm must not make any subsequent adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the firm after initial recognition.

question: When an insurer is setting up its risk monitoring metrics and determining any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, how do the investment and liquidity expectations described for UK Solvency II firms (and related entities) and for non-Directive insurers shape what that liquidity buffer is intended to achieve, including the conditions under which it is expected to operate?
gold_answer: In establishing the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and determining any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, the liquidity buffer should be framed as a stock of liquid assets designed to support meeting liabilities as they fall due, and the monitoring metrics should be capable of tracking that buffer and related liquidity characteristics. [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352] For a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents, the investment approach is described as needing to ensure the liquidity of the investment portfolio and to include consideration of whether assets are appropriate to meet obligations as they fall due. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] In addition, the described guideline expectations indicate the insurer should consider total liquidity needs (including an appropriate liquidity buffer), the level and monitoring of liquid assets, and potential haircuts that could apply on sale of those assets—elements that can be reflected in the design of risk monitoring metrics. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] For a non-Directive insurer, the stated standard is to maintain adequate liquidity so there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due, which aligns the purpose of any liquidity buffer(s) with that outcome. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0] Finally, the liquidity buffer is expected to be sufficient under both benign and stressed conditions, which should be incorporated into how the insurer calibrates and monitors the buffer within its metrics. [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: When determining the amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description by adjusting values under 19 to 23, how must the firm treat assets of that description that it has transferred by way of initial margin, and how does this interact with the baseline requirement for ascribing a value to assets of each description (including where no valuation provision exists)?
gold_answer: In determining the firm’s exposure to assets of each description, the firm must start by ascribing a value to assets of each description as an amount determined under the applicable rules in this Part, or—if there is no valuation provision for that description—an amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] The firm must then determine the amount of exposure by adjusting that ascribed value in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] As part of those adjustments, the value ascribed under 18 to 20 for assets of each description must be increased by an amount representing the value of any assets of that same description that the firm has transferred by way of initial margin. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] This means that, even where the initial ascribed value is derived from the Part’s valuation method (or a reasonable immediate-transfer consideration where no method is provided), the exposure calculation must incorporate an uplift reflecting initial-margin transfers for the relevant asset description when applying the 18 to 20 valuation steps within the 19 to 23 adjustment framework. [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 20 in respect of assets of each description must be increased by an amount representing the value of any assets of that description which have been transferred by the firm by way of initial margin .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: For a firm that has not elected monthly reporting of changes in close links under 3.1, what form must be used for the notification, what content must it include, who may submit it, and by when must it be made once the firm becomes aware it has begun to have or ceased to have close links with any person?
gold_answer: A firm that has not elected to report changes in close links on a monthly basis under 3.1 must ensure a notification is made using the Close Links Notification Form, and it must be submitted as soon as reasonably practicable and in any event no later than one month after the firm becomes aware that it has begun to have, or ceased to have, close links with any person. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] The firm may either make the notification itself or procure that another firm in its group makes it, but in either case the notification must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] In addition to using that form, the notification must include all relevant information specified in the Close Links Notification Form, meaning the submission is not complete unless it contains the information the form requires. [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5] Practically, this means the firm should treat the awareness date as the trigger for the one-month backstop, while also acting promptly rather than waiting until the end of the month, and should verify that every required field or item in the form has been populated with the relevant information before submission. [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9] [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5]
source_text: The notification submitted under 2.4 must be made by completing the Close Links Notification Form and must include all the relevant information specified therein.
target_text: Where a firm has not elected to report changes in close links on a monthly basis under 3.1 , it must make (or procure that another firm in its group makes) a notification by completing the Close Links Notification Form as soon as reasonably practicable and no later than one month after it becomes aware that it has begun to have or ceased to have close links with any person.

question: For a deposit-taker or PRA-designated investment firm that meets the definition of a significant firm, or for a firm with AMA permission, what operational risk data items must be completed and when must they be submitted, including how the firm should treat data already provided through the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme or other reporting channels?
gold_answer: A significant firm and any firm with permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach must complete the operational risk data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075, but only to the extent the required information has not already been provided to the PRA by another route. [#TGT:749a0bb00a1a5a55] For firms in scope, the operational risk Pillar 2 data items must be reported in line with Reporting Pillar 2, 2.3, unless the same data have already been submitted as part of the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] The submission timing is tied to the firm’s ICAAP process: firms are required to submit the relevant data with their ICAAP submissions. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify whether it is a significant firm (as defined by size, interconnectedness, complexity and business type) or holds AMA permission, (ii) complete FSA072–FSA075 for operational risk, and (iii) omit any elements already delivered via STDF or other means to the PRA, while ensuring the remaining required items accompany the ICAAP submission. [#SRC:d4df391897643422] [#TGT:749a0bb00a1a5a55]
source_text: The PRA already collects information on operational risk historical losses from firms participating in the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme. All significant firms and firms with AMA permission must report the data contained in the operational risk Pillar 2 data items in accordance with Reporting Pillar 2, 2.3 , unless those data have already been submitted as part of the STDF programme. Firms are required to submit the data with their ICAAP submissions. ‘Significant firm’ means a deposit-taker or PRA-designated investment firm whose size, interconnectedness, complexity and business type give it the capacity to cause significant disruption to the UK financial system (and through that to economic activity more widely) by failing or carrying on its business in an unsafe manner. The PRA may also request some firms that are not significant to report the same data and will notify the firms accordingly in advance of their submitting an ICAAP document.
target_text: A significant firm and any firm that is not significant but that has permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach must complete the data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075 for operational risk, unless the data required in that data item has already been reported to the PRA by other means.

question: If a firm’s MA portfolio includes a lot of less liquid assets, can it just use the same FS model it uses for corporate bonds, and what does it need to explain if it uses one model for all asset classes?
gold_answer: The firm should not assume that a corporate-bond FS model can be applied unchanged to less liquid assets when the firm has material exposure to those assets in its MA portfolio. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] Although the PRA’s expectations in the SS mainly focus on risks from corporate bond assets, the PRA expects firms to treat many of those expectations as more widely applicable across the MA portfolio unless the SS specifically says otherwise, and the SS also flags that it contains specific expectations for less liquid assets in certain places. [#SRC:938b2dd2653608ec] For firms with material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments), the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for those assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] A similar approach to the corporate bond method may be possible, but how much the firm adapts the core corporate bond methodology and calibration should depend on how similar the less liquid assets are to corporate bonds; in some cases the firm may need a more bespoke method. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a] If the firm uses one model without distinguishing asset classes, it should clearly justify that the model is appropriate for each asset class it covers, including the less liquid assets. [#TGT:2d65e0cf2883630a]
source_text: The PRA recognises that many firms hold a relatively wide range of assets in their MA portfolios. These assets will differ in terms of liquidity and complexity; many of them may not be traded assets. The PRA’s expectations set out in this statement primarily apply to the risks arising in respect of corporate bond assets within firms’ MA portfolios. However, many of the expectations apply irrespective of the assets held and the PRA would therefore expect firms to consider the expectations set out in the SS to be more widely applicable unless specifically stated otherwise. In a number of places (eg paragraphs 4.10 , 4.15 , 4.20 , 4.22 , 5.17 and 5.18 ) the SS sets out specific expectations in relation to less liquid assets. In future, the PRA may issue further, more bespoke, expectations for the SCR treatment of other assets within an MA portfolio, such as illiquid assets.
target_text: In the case of firms that have material exposure to less liquid assets (eg illiquid, direct investments) within the MA portfolio, the PRA expects a separate approach to be developed to model the FS for these assets. While an approach similar to that used for corporate bonds may be possible, the level of adaptation from the core corporate bond methodology and calibration should depend on the similarity of the assets in question to corporate bonds. In some cases a more bespoke methodology may be necessary. Where firms do not distinguish between asset classes in their modelling, then the appropriateness of the model for each asset class should be clearly justified.

question: When a competent authority requests information on hedging sets per risk category, how should an institution determine and report the relevant risk driver(s) for those hedging sets in light of the rule that certain derivative transactions with more than one material risk driver must be mapped to one or more risk categories?
gold_answer: An institution should respond by aligning its hedging-set reporting per risk category with the way it maps derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver across risk categories. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] Specifically, when the competent authorities request the number of hedging sets established for each risk category, the institution must make available that count together with the primary risk driver (or, for the relevant transactions, the most material risk driver in the given risk category) or, where applicable, the pair of risk drivers for each hedging set, and the number of transactions in each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce] To ensure the reported “most material risk driver in the given risk category” is coherent, the institution should use the mapping approach for multi-driver derivative transactions: if all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, the transaction is mapped once to that category based on the most material risk driver; if material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category based on the most material risk driver within that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] The institution’s disclosure of hedging sets and their risk driver(s) should therefore reflect the risk-category mapping outcomes and the associated transaction counts within each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]
source_text: Institutions shall make available upon request by the competent authorities the number of hedging sets established in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article for each risk category, with the primary risk driver, or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) , or the pair of risk drivers of each of those hedging sets and with the number of transactions in each of those hedging sets .
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When a firm has pooled asset exposures whose underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but show sufficient evidence of predictability, how may the firm treat event risks in the FS addition, and what economic-risk standard approach assumptions must still be used for cash flows and issuer behaviour?
gold_answer: For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks and there is sufficient evidence of predictability, the firm may propose applying the standard approach to the FS addition specifically for event risks. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] Even in that context, the economic-risk standard approach expectations for modelling cash flows remain relevant to the economic-risk component: the assumed cash-flow pattern should reflect a minimum investor yield outcome (ie “yield to worst”). [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] If the pooled assets’ features or contractual terms make another method more appropriate, the PRA indicates it can be considered case-by-case, but the alternative must preserve the assumption that the issuer will act in an economically rational manner. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] Separately, the FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for reinvestment risk and rebalancing costs. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] Taken together, the firm’s ability to propose a standard approach for event-risk FS addition in predictable pooled exposures does not remove the need to apply the economic-risk standard approach’s yield and issuer-behaviour assumptions for the economic-risk side of the exposure. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855][#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: Where assets are exposed to economic cash flow variability risks, the PRA expects that a standard approach would assume a pattern of cash flows where the yield for the investor is at a minimum (ie ‘yield to worst’). Where the features or contractual terms of an asset make an alternative method more appropriate, this could be considered on a case-by-case basis, provided that the method retains the assumption that the issuer will act in economically rational manner. The FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for the risk of reinvestment and rebalancing costs as set out in paragraph 5.20 above.

question: If the society has received a merger or takeover proposal, what does the board need to say about proposals in the declaration that goes with the written PRA application for a Schedule 16 Statement, and when must members be sent the prescribed particulars (AGM notice vs special meeting notice for Merger Resolutions)?
gold_answer: If the society is applying to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement, the application must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] In that declaration, the board should confirm the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should be aware of. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] The declaration should also cover whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (including confidential ones) and confirm that the information given about those proposals is correct. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] Separately, once a proposal of either kind has been received, the society must notify every member who is entitled to notice of a meeting by sending the prescribed particulars. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] That notification can be sent on its own or included with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Also, if the prescribed particulars have not already been sent, they must be included with every notice of the special meeting where Merger Resolutions will be moved. [#TGT:e13932686034a534] Together, this means the board’s declaration addresses proposal existence and accuracy for the PRA submission, while the member-notification rule controls the timing and packaging of prescribed particulars around AGM and special-meeting notices. [#SRC:b23ef312764c9a50] [#TGT:e13932686034a534]
source_text: Schedule 16 Statements must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports. An application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board, that the Statement is complete and includes all material information of which, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware. That declaration should say whether or not there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise see paragraph 3.89 – 3.90 ) and confirm that the information about them is correct. The application should be accompanied by the following documents:
target_text: If a proposal of either kind has been received, then notification of the prescribed particulars must be sent to every member entitled to notice of a meeting, either separately or together with every notice of the society’s annual general meeting, and (where such notification has not already been given) must be included with every notice of the special meeting at which Merger Resolutions are to be moved.

question: If a firm outsources a material function, what needs to be in the contract about inspections/audits, and what extra message does the PRA expect the firm to give the service provider about the Bank and PRA’s statutory powers (including what happens if the firm forgets to tell them)?
gold_answer: For a material outsourced function, the firm should ensure the outsourcing terms cover both contractual oversight and regulatory awareness. The contract should provide for the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider in relation to the material outsourced function. [#SRC:c8d1fead98534aaa] Separately, the PRA expects the firm to tell the service provider that, beyond the chapter’s later expectations on access, audit, and information rights, the Bank and PRA also have statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should explain that some of these statutory powers may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms, and it should use the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 as the basis for that awareness (while recognising those tables are not exhaustive). [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] The firm should also make clear that if it fails to provide this awareness, that does not affect whether the statutory powers and requirements apply in practice. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]
source_text: the rights of firms and the PRA to inspect and audit the service provider with regard to the material outsourced function (see Chapter 8 );
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: For an own funds item classified by a related Solvency II undertaking that is included in the calculation of the group solvency, when may the group classify that item in a different tier than the undertaking’s tier, and what group-level condition must still be satisfied?
gold_answer: An own funds item classified by a related Solvency II undertaking that is included in the calculation of the group solvency is generally expected to keep the same tier classification at group level, but only if the additional requirements for that same-tier approach are met. [#TGT:669a47dbe318f67a] However, there is a specific case where the group may classify the item differently: if the related Solvency II undertaking has placed the item in Tier 2 own funds even though the item would qualify for Tier 1 own funds under Own Funds 3E.1(11), that Tier 2 classification at the undertaking level does not prevent the group from classifying the same item in Tier 1 own funds at group level. [#SRC:d7efe71fb905e0c9] In that reclassification scenario, the group must still comply with the group-level quantitative limits referenced for Tier classification, namely the limits set out in Own Funds 4A.3 as applied at group level. [#SRC:d7efe71fb905e0c9] Accordingly, the compliance conclusion is that same-tier classification is the default framework for group solvency calculations when its additional requirements are met, but a Tier 2-to-Tier 1 uplift is permitted for an item meeting the Own Funds 3E.1(11) Tier 1 qualification, provided the Own Funds 4A.3 group limits are respected. [#TGT:669a47dbe318f67a] [#SRC:d7efe71fb905e0c9]
source_text: Notwithstanding 8A.1 , where a related Solvency II undertaking has included in Tier 2 own funds an own funds item which would qualify for inclusion in Tier 1 own funds in accordance with Own Funds 3E.1(11) , that classification shall not prohibit the classification of the same own funds item in Tier 1 own funds at group level, provided that the limits set out in Own Funds 4A.3 are complied with at group level.

question: For a TWD firm forecasting the impact of a TWD scenario from the reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period, what specific categories of information and analytical capabilities must be in place so that the firm can both project impacts on capital requirements/resources/liquidity and perform the required financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, including portfolio segmentation for alternative packaging of trades for novation?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should ensure it has both (i) the analytical infrastructure to forecast the TWD scenario’s effects on key prudential metrics over time and (ii) the underlying risk and trade data needed to run the required projections and sensitivity work, including portfolio segmentation that supports wind-down execution options. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] Specifically, the firm should have methodologies, models, and frameworks that enable it to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity, and to do so by making projections from the reference date of the TWD option through the wind-down period. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] To make those forecasts operational and support the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, the firm’s information set should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate those projections and sensitivities. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] The data should also be sufficient to segment the firm’s trading portfolios in multiple ways, including enabling alternative packaging of trades for novation, so that the projections can reflect different wind-down execution approaches. [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510] Together, these elements link the time-bounded forecasting requirement (from reference date through wind-down) with the concrete data and segmentation capabilities needed to compute and stress the projected impacts. [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e] [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]
source_text: This should include all risk and trade data necessary to calculate the financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis in paragraphs 4.25 - 4.51 , including information to support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways (for example, alternative packaging of trades for novation).

question: When calculating compensation for a joint account, how must the firm determine each depositor’s share for purposes of applying the maximum compensation sum for that depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits, and what default allocation applies if there is no contrary provision?
gold_answer: In calculating compensation where a joint account is involved, the depositor-level cap applies by first identifying each depositor’s separate share of the joint account and then applying the maximum compensation sum to that depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] The joint-account component must be treated as belonging to each depositor separately for the purpose of calculating the relevant limits, rather than treating the joint account as a single combined entitlement. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] Unless there is a contrary provision, the default method is to split the joint account equally among the depositors, with the resulting shares rounded to the nearest penny. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] Once each depositor’s share has been determined in this way, the maximum compensation sum payable for that depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits is £120,000. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] The cap is not necessarily the final amount in every case, because the text also notes that additional compensation may be payable where the cases described in 4.3 or 4.4 apply. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] Accordingly, the calculation sequence is: allocate the joint account to each depositor (equal split to the nearest penny by default), aggregate that depositor’s eligible deposits, and then apply the £120,000 maximum subject to any additional compensation scenarios referenced. [#SRC:b9d90150236df9ae] [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]
source_text: The share of each depositor of a joint account shall be considered separately in calculating the limits provided for in 4.2 and 4.3 , except where 5.5 applies. In the absence of contrary provision, the joint account shall be divided equally among the depositors to the nearest penny.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: When a firm validates its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria for Matching Adjustment purposes, how must that validation connect (i) identification and allowance for all sources of credit risk and (ii) the requirement that internal credit assessment outcomes fall within a CRA’s plausible range and show broad consistency and no bias at asset-type and portfolio levels?
gold_answer: A firm’s validation should be designed to demonstrate both methodological soundness and outcome comparability, so that the PRA can be satisfied the internal credit assessment process is appropriately validated and produces results consistent with the CRA-based benchmarks described for Matching Adjustment. The PRA expects validation to cover the firm’s internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how the firm has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether using qualitative or quantitative approaches. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] In addition, the validation should ensure the internal credit assessment outcomes meet the relevant outcome-focused expectations, which include being within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA and showing broad consistency and no bias versus CRA issue ratings at both the asset type and portfolio level. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] Practically, this means the firm should not treat validation as only a model-governance exercise; it must also test whether outputs align with the plausible CRA range and are broadly consistent and unbiased across assets and the portfolio. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] The PRA also expects the validation to ensure outcomes satisfy the points referenced in paragraph 2.4, linking the validation work to those outcome checks. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] While CRA sample assessments can help evidence broad consistency, the firm should avoid solely or mechanistically relying on credit ratings when assessing creditworthiness. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: For purposes of issuing meeting notices and validating votes on Transfer Resolutions, what member-eligibility checks must a society’s systems perform to identify who is entitled to vote, taking into account the statutory categories of membership and the voting restriction on minors?
gold_answer: A society must configure its systems so they can reliably determine which members are entitled to vote (and therefore should be treated as eligible recipients for meeting processes tied to voting), and this determination must reflect both operational eligibility checks and the statutory rule that minors cannot vote. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] In practice, the systems need to recognise members who meet the society’s qualifying shareholding and continuity conditions by aggregating share account balances across multiple account holders and checking continuity of shareholding, and they must also identify minors. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] This is necessary so that notices of the meeting are sent to all members entitled to receive them and so that scrutineers have adequate system support to validate votes cast on the Transfer Resolutions. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] When applying these checks, the society must also align its eligibility logic with the membership framework that a member must be either a shareholding member (holding a share, such as an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS) or a borrowing member (indebted on a loan fully secured on land, subject to any Rules variations described). [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e] Additionally, even though a minor may be a member, the system must flag that the minor may not vote on any resolution, so scrutineer validation should exclude such votes. [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e]
source_text: A society’s systems must also be capable of recognising those members who are eligible to vote by, for example, aggregating share account balances of multiple account holders to check that they have the requisite qualifying shareholding, by checking members’ continuity of shareholding, and by identifying minors (see paragraphs 3.108 , 3.109 and 3.110 ). This information is required to ensure that the notice of the meeting is sent to all the members entitled to receive it, and that the scrutineers have adequate systems to validate the votes cast on the Transfer Resolutions.
target_text: Paragraph 5 of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act provides that no person may be a member of a building society unless he or she is a shareholding member or a borrowing member. A shareholding member is a person who holds a share in the society (that is, an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS). A borrowing member is a person who is indebted to the society in respect of a loan fully secured on land. However, the Rules may provide that borrowing membership is conferred by a loan substantially secured on land, or shall cease if the loan is foreclosed or the land is taken into possession by the society. A minor (that is a person under 18 years of age) may be a member, but may not vote on any resolution.

question: When a firm is preparing the information it reports annually (including the assessments referred to in 3.2), how should it determine what must be submitted to the PRA, and what additional analysis is required if setting the matching adjustment or volatility adjustment to zero would cause non-compliance with the SCR?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that its annual reporting package to the PRA includes the specific assessments referred to in 3.2, because those assessments are required to be submitted as part of the information reported annually. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] In determining the overall scope of what it submits, the firm must provide the PRA with information that is necessary for the purposes of the PRA’s supervision of the firm, so the annual submission should be framed to meet that supervisory-necessity standard in addition to including the mandated assessments. [#TGT:bf73213345d9be15] If a stress in which the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment is reduced to zero would lead to non-compliance with the SCR, the firm must also include an analysis of the measures it could apply in that scenario. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389] That analysis must address how the firm could re-establish eligible own funds covering the SCR or, alternatively, how it could reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR, so that the PRA receives the information needed to supervise the firm’s resilience under that condition. [#SRC:8241a37abe32a389][#TGT:bf73213345d9be15]
source_text: A firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information reported annually in accordance with Reporting 2 . Where the reduction of the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR , the firm must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply in such a situation to re-establish the level of the e ligible own funds covering the SCR or to reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR .
target_text: A firm must submit to the PRA information which is necessary for the purposes of the PRA’s supervision of the firm .

question: For a credit union providing a subordinated loan, how do the requirements to assess the financial implications before providing the loan and to retain a written record for five years after the date of the loan interact, and what must be documented and kept?
gold_answer: A credit union must both (i) complete an assessment of the financial implications before it provides a subordinated loan and (ii) keep a written record of that assessment for a defined period after the loan is made. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] The precondition is that the credit union is in the process of providing a subordinated loan; in that case, the assessment must occur prior to provision, meaning it should be performed and finalized before the loan is made available. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] Once the subordinated loan has been made, the credit union must retain a written record of the assessment referenced in 3.14, and the retention period runs for five years following the date of the subordinated loan. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] Practically, this means the credit union should ensure the assessment exists in written form (or is captured into a written record) so it can be retained for the full five-year period measured from the loan date. [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2] The combined effect is a before-and-after control: the assessment is required as a prerequisite to providing the loan, and the written record must then be preserved for five years after the loan date to evidence that the pre-provision assessment was carried out. [#TGT:070e1e95885eea3e] [#SRC:33b846227c3ca9b2]
source_text: A credit union must retain, for a period of five years following the date of a subordinated loan, a written record of the assessment in 3.14 .
target_text: Prior to the provision of a subordinated loan, a credit union must carry out an assessment of the financial implications of making the loan.

question: When can the PRA tell a society to fix problems before it will confirm a merger, and what kinds of fixes can it demand even though it cannot decide whether the deal is a good one or change the approved terms?
gold_answer: The PRA can only decide a merger confirmation application by looking at whether, based on the facts, any of the Three Criteria apply; it is not allowed to judge whether the merger is a good deal or whether its terms are fair, and after members approve the merger and its terms the PRA cannot force changes to those terms. [#SRC:aba762e80d02874f] Even with that limited role, if defects covered by the Three Criteria would stop the PRA from confirming, it may direct the society to put those defects right. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] The direction can require concrete process fixes, including calling another meeting so members can vote again in light of a revised Schedule 16 Statement that adds material information that was previously left out. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] It can also require the society to correct defects in the systems used to send meeting notices and Statements and to validate votes. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] Once the society provides evidence and the PRA is satisfied the defects have been substantially remedied, the PRA must confirm; if the PRA is not satisfied, it must refuse confirmation. [#TGT:8ba3cc430698d0ee] These steps are about curing Three-Criteria defects, not renegotiating or altering the member-approved merger terms. [#SRC:aba762e80d02874f]
source_text: The PRA’s powers in connection with applications for confirmation of a merger are confined to considerations of whether, in the light of the facts, any of the Three Criteria apply. It is not for the PRA to consider, or make judgements about, the merits of a proposed merger or the fairness of its terms; these matters are first for the board of a society, and then for its members to decide. Once the members have approved the merger and its terms, the PRA has no powers to require a society to make any changes to those terms. The PRA’s discretionary powers are similarly confined to the matters described in paragraphs 3.157 and 3.158 .
target_text: Where the PRA would be precluded from confirming a merger by reason of any of the defects specified in the Three Criteria, 37 Section 95(6) provides that it may direct a society to remedy the defects. A direction under that subsection may require a society to call a further meeting; for example, to vote again in the light of a revised Schedule 16 Statement containing material information previously omitted, or after correction of defects in the systems for sending notices of meeting and Statements and validation of votes. If the PRA is then satisfied, having considered evidence furnished by the society, that the defects have been substantially remedied, it must confirm the merger. If not, then confirmation must be refused.

question: If a UK subsidiary is part of a group based outside the UK, what does it need to do about fire drill exercises and UK playbooks when getting ready to send its recovery plan to the PRA?
gold_answer: The UK subsidiary should link its UK recovery planning work on playbooks with the PRA’s expectations for fire drill exercises on the recovery plan. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Specifically, it should run a fire drill exercise that is a ‘live’ simulation where the firm acts out key parts of its response to a designed scenario, because this is used to test how effective the recovery plan is in a live setting. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] The PRA expects at least one such fire drill to be completed before each time the recovery plan is submitted to the PRA, and there must be at least one fire drill every three years even if submissions are less frequent. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f] Alongside that fire-drill planning, the subsidiary should consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced for UK subsidiaries of non-UK groups, and if the PRA explicitly asks for more detailed UK playbook work as part of UK recovery planning, the firm should contact its supervisor to discuss whether the request applies. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Because the PRA sets recovery plan submission frequency firm-by-firm (often annually for larger firms), the firm should align its fire drill timing to that PRA-determined cycle. [#TGT:2c1d7b1bf1be0e5f]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: Fire drill exercises are ‘live’ simulation type exercises where firms act out key parts of a response to a designed scenario. This is a useful way to test the effectiveness of the recovery plan in a ‘live’ situation. The PRA expects each firm to carry out at least one fire drill exercise on its recovery plan prior to each submission of the recovery plan to the PRA, subject to a minimum of one fire drill taking place every three years. The PRA determines the frequency with which firms should submit their recovery plan on a firm-by-firm basis, with larger firms tending to submit their plans on an annual cycle.

question: If a group report covers more than one firm using an internal model, what is the AoC.01 template for, what information has to be in it, and what timing and rulebook/instruction references apply when sending it to the PRA?
gold_answer: For a group report that includes more than one firm using an internal model, the required submission is the PRA’s AoC.01 analysis of change template, which firms complete with key information about the movement in SCR. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] This AoC.01 submission must be made to the PRA every year. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] The template must set out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, so it is not limited to numbers alone. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] In addition to using the AoC.01 template for SCR movement information, the submission must follow the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] It must also be submitted in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, which are the rulebook provisions tied to how the PRA expects AoC.01 to be submitted. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies reporting information on a group which includes more than one firm using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: If a participating Solvency II undertaking wants to keep only some of the Conditions Governing Business 11C documentation/data directory for 11.1D, what exactly can it keep, and what must it still account for because best estimates have to be net of intra-group transactions (including intra-group reinsurance contracts)?
gold_answer: For 11.1D, the participating Solvency II undertaking can reduce the Conditions Governing Business 11C documentation and directory of data so that it keeps only the data that it actually uses to calculate the adjustments to the best estimate referred to in 11.1E. [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366] However, the best estimates used for 11.1D must be prepared on a net basis, meaning they must exclude the effects of any intra-group transactions for the participating Solvency II undertaking and for each related undertaking that is within the listed undertaking types. [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] As a result, even if the undertaking limits the 11C documentation/data directory, it still needs to retain (within that limited set) the data that is used to ensure the best-estimate adjustments it calculates are consistent with netting out intra-group transactions. [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366] [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] The same linkage applies to intra-group reinsurance contracts: because the text states that adjustments must be made in relation to those contracts, the undertaking’s restricted documentation/data directory must still include the data it uses to make those intra-group reinsurance adjustments where they affect the best-estimate adjustments being calculated. [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd] [#SRC:653a9391c7e21366]
source_text: For the purposes of 11.1D , the participating Solvency II undertaking may restrict the documentation and the directory of data referred to in Conditions Governing Business 11C to the data used in the calculation of the adjustments of the best estimate referred to in 11.1E .

question: Where a firm excludes exposures under the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook, and those exposures are not included in MREL reporting as specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’, what notification is required and which June 2018 Bank of England webpage is identified for SS 19/13?
gold_answer: A firm that has excluded exposures using the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook must notify the PRA when those excluded exposures are not included in MREL reporting in the manner specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] This notification trigger is tied specifically to the combination of (i) use of the resolution exemption for Large Exposures and (ii) the fact that the exposures are not captured in MREL reporting as SS 19/13 sets out, so the firm should treat the absence from MREL reporting (as specified in SS 19/13) as the condition that makes the PRA notification necessary. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] The referenced SS 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’ is identified with a June 2018 link on the Bank of England website at www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/resolution-planning-ss. [#TGT:695e320d362f1655] Accordingly, the firm’s compliance action is to notify the PRA in the stated circumstances, and the SS 19/13 reference point for the MREL reporting specification is the June 2018 Bank of England webpage provided. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] [#TGT:695e320d362f1655]
source_text: Firms that exclude exposures pursuant to the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook should notify the PRA if those exposures are not included in MREL reporting as specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’ . 5
target_text: 5. June 2018: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/resolution-planning-ss .

question: When documenting the risks that must be addressed for SCR purposes, how should a firm align the requirement to cover both (i) the risks included in the SCR calculation and (ii) the risks not, or not fully, included, with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account (including at least the listed underwriting, market, credit, and operational risks)?
gold_answer: A firm should structure its SCR risk documentation so it both maps what is captured by the SCR calculation and explicitly identifies any exposures that are outside, or only partially inside, that calculation, while ensuring the overall calibration approach is designed to capture all quantifiable risks the firm faces. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] In practice, this means the firm should (i) list the risks that are included in the SCR calculation as required, and (ii) separately describe the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, rather than treating the SCR calculation as exhaustive. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] At the same time, the firm’s calibration must be set so that all quantifiable risks to which it is exposed are taken into account, and this includes at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The linkage is that the “not, or not fully, included” category should be used to highlight any quantifiable exposures that the calibration objective would otherwise require the firm to consider, even if they are not fully reflected in the SCR calculation itself. [#SRC:c2d9c82eaebd8586] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]
source_text: (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: When meeting the expectations in this Chapter on planning for a solvent exit, how should a firm use scenarios, and which specific recovery-planning sources are identified as relevant for developing or adapting those scenarios?
gold_answer: A firm should approach the Chapter’s expectations by considering realistic circumstances that could plausibly result in the firm needing to carry out a solvent exit, and it should use scenario work to inform that assessment. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] In doing so, the firm is permitted to draw on and tailor scenarios that were developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, rather than starting from scratch, provided those scenarios are used to help identify circumstances that could trigger the need for a solvent exit. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] The recovery-planning materials explicitly identified as relevant to those recovery planning expectations are Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook and the ‘(a) Design’ element within ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17. [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a] Accordingly, to align solvent-exit planning with the referenced recovery-planning framework, the firm should ensure its solvent-exit scenario thinking is informed by (and, where appropriate, adapted from) scenario design and scenario testing concepts drawn from those two sources. [#SRC:8eda73d6e20d0f02] [#TGT:de09666c846b7d6a]
source_text: In meeting the expectations in this Chapter, a firm should take account of plausible circumstances that could lead to it needing to execute a solvent exit (see Box A for illustrative examples). A firm may draw on and adapt scenarios developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations 19 to inform it of such circumstances.
target_text: 19. Chapter 2 of the Recovery Plans Part of the PRA Rulebook; and ‘(a) Design’ under ‘(iv) Scenario testing’ of SS9/17.

question: In the relatively rare case that a firm considers including complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, what advance steps are expected internally and with the PRA, and how should the firm address the PRA’s expectation to discuss eligibility-impacting complexity in advance despite any post-notification treatment for other instruments?
gold_answer: If a firm considers it necessary to include complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, the PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to inform the firm’s board in advance of the issuance and to evidence why the instrument cannot be issued without the proposed complex feature(s). [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] The relevant SMF is also expected to evidence that, notwithstanding the proposed complexity, they consider the instrument compliant with the objective of the Own Funds (CRR) Part. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] In parallel, where a firm proposes new or complex features that could affect eligibility, the PRA expects the firm to raise and discuss those features with its usual supervisory contact in advance, and to do so as early as possible once the relevant terms and conditions (including any side agreements) are drafted, with a clear explanation of how the features comply with PRA rules and supervisory expectations. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] This advance-discussion expectation applies even though Tier 2 instruments are described as subject to post-notification, because the PRA still expects pre-issuance discussion when complexity could affect eligibility. [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741] Overall, the firm should align board-level pre-issuance governance led by the relevant SMF with early supervisory engagement on the eligibility implications of the complex features. [#TGT:acd7b7086471f868] [#SRC:cd48a3e0ac792741]
source_text: The PRA is likely to need more time to review a notified instrument with complex feature(s) (as set out in paragraphs 2.3 to 2.5 above), or issuances with new features, for example, instruments marketed as ‘Green’, ‘Social’, or ‘Environmental, Social, Governance (ESG)’. The PRA expects the firm to engage with its usual supervisory contact as early as possible (for example, once the relevant terms and conditions including any side agreements are drafted) with a clear explanation of how the proposed features comply with the letter and objective of the PRA rules and supervisory expectations. Notwithstanding that Tier 2 instruments are subject to post-notification, where a firm is proposing to include new or complex features that could affect eligibility, the PRA expects to discuss these in advance.
target_text: The PRA expects the relevant Senior Management Function (SMF) to take responsibility for ensuring the quality of the capital structure overall. This includes being accountable for the quality of notifications to the PRA under Definition of Capital Part Rule 7A to 7D , acknowledging that the act of signing and submitting any notification form may be delegated. In a relatively rare case where it may be necessary for a firm to include complex feature(s) in its CET1 instruments, the PRA expects the relevant SMF to inform the firm’s board in advance of the issuance, evidencing why the instrument cannot be issued without the proposed complex feature(s) and that, notwithstanding the proposed complexity, they consider the instrument compliant with the objective of the Own Funds (CRR) Part . For the purpose of this paragraph and paragraph 2.6 , the relevant SMF means the individual with:

question: When applying the PRA expectation to limit investment where there is insufficient data to quantify risks (as referenced to paragraph 3.14), how should a firm treat assets that are invested to cover technical provisions for linked long-term contracts of insurance, and does the position change where the assets cover additional technical provisions for policyholder liabilities (including guarantees)?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the PRA’s expectation to limit investment appropriately when there is insufficient data to quantify the risks for a category of asset or an individual asset, in the context of considering the nature and quantification of those risks (including the cross-reference to paragraph 3.14). [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8] However, the firm must first determine whether the relevant parts of the chapter (paragraphs 3.4 to 3.24) apply to the assets in question, because those paragraphs do not apply to firms investing in assets covering technical provisions for linked long-term contracts of insurance. [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6] The position changes where the assets are held to cover additional technical provisions in respect of policyholder liabilities, including liabilities for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit provided under those linked long-term contracts; in that case, the carve-out from paragraphs 3.4 to 3.24 does not apply, so the firm would treat those assets as within scope of the chapter’s requirements and therefore align its approach with the PRA expectation on limiting investment when risk quantification data are insufficient. [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6] In practice, this means the firm should distinguish between assets covering baseline linked-contract technical provisions (generally outside paragraphs 3.4–3.24) and assets covering additional technical provisions for guarantees/guaranteed benefits (within scope), and apply the PRA’s limiting-investment expectation accordingly when data gaps prevent adequate risk quantification. [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8] [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]
source_text: Paragraphs 3.4 to 3.24 of this chapter do not apply to firms investing in assets covering technical provisions (TPs) for linked long-term contracts of insurance, except where the assets are held to cover the additional TPs in respect of policyholder liabilities, including those for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit provided under those contracts.
target_text: In considering the nature and quantification of the risks associated with each category of asset and with individual assets (see paragraph 3.14 of this SS), the PRA expects a firm to limit its investment appropriately where there is insufficient data to quantify the risks.

question: If a depositor has eligible deposits and some interest has built up but hasn’t been added to the account by the compensation date, does the FSCS pay that interest, and does it still have to stay within the £120,000 maximum for the depositor’s total eligible deposits (unless 4.3 or 4.4 applies)?
gold_answer: Yes—subject to an exception, the FSCS pays that unpaid interest, and the payment is still constrained by the depositor-level maximum for aggregate eligible deposits. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] Specifically, the FSCS must reimburse interest owed on eligible deposits that had accrued by the compensation date but had not yet been credited, except where the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] Separately, the maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, although additional compensation may be payable where 4.3 or 4.4 apply. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] Putting these together, if the temporary high balance exception does not apply and the FSCS reimburses accrued-but-uncredited interest, that interest payment cannot cause the compensation to exceed the limit referenced in 4.2. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] Therefore, the FSCS’s interest reimbursement obligation operates within the overall cap for the depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits, unless the depositor is in a case where additional compensation is available under 4.3 or 4.4. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]
source_text: Except where the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance , the FSCS shall reimburse interest owed on eligible deposits which had accrued, but has not been credited, at the compensation date . The limit provided for in 4.2 shall not be exceeded by the payment of any such interest.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: When drafting written agreements for material outsourcing, how should a firm reflect the PRA’s minimum areas for such agreements while also ensuring outsourced service providers are informed about the Bank and PRA’s statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, given that these powers are described as independent of later access, audit, and information rights expectations?
gold_answer: A firm should structure its written agreements for material outsourcing to cover, at a minimum, the areas the PRA expects such agreements to address, and it should also ensure the outsourced service provider is made aware of the Bank and PRA’s statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers. [#SRC:7ee6ded449cc3c29] The minimum agreement scope is framed by the PRA’s expectation that written agreements address specified areas, with particular emphasis later in the guidance on data security, access/audit/information rights, sub-outsourcing, and business continuity and exit strategies. [#SRC:7ee6ded449cc3c29] In parallel, and explicitly not dependent on the later discussion of access, audit, and information rights, the firm is expected to communicate to service providers that the Bank and PRA have statutory powers to gather information and investigate, and that some of these powers may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] Practically, this means the firm should (i) ensure the agreement’s content addresses the minimum areas the PRA expects, including the detailed topics signposted for later chapters, and (ii) separately brief or notify the service provider about the powers and requirements described in Tables 6 and 7 (noting those tables are not exhaustive). [#SRC:7ee6ded449cc3c29] [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b] Even if the firm does not make the service provider aware, the applicability of those statutory powers is unchanged, so the notification is an expectation but not a condition of the powers applying. [#TGT:a387300e34c8188b]
source_text: Chapter 6 lists the areas that the PRA expects written agreements relating to material outsourcing to address as a minimum. The following four areas are then examined in detail in Chapters 7–10: data security ( Chapter 7 ); access, audit, and information rights ( Chapter 8 ); sub-outsourcing ( Chapter 9 ); and business continuity and exit strategies ( Chapter 10 ).
target_text: Independent of the expectations on access, audit, and information rights set out later in this chapter, the Bank and PRA have a range of statutory information-gathering and investigatory powers, some of which may apply directly to outsourced service providers as well as firms. The PRA expects firms to make service providers aware of the powers and requirements as set out in Tables 6 and 7 below, which are not exhaustive. However, failure to do so will not affect their applicability.

question: If you are checking how the PRA calculates the ultimate forward rate for a currency, what long-term expectations does it use (and when), and what kind of extra “risk add-on” is it not allowed to include?
gold_answer: To check the PRA’s calculation of the ultimate forward rate for a currency, you should confirm both what inputs it uses and what it explicitly leaves out. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] On the input side, for each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, but only if those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] On the exclusion side, the ultimate forward rate is not designed to include a term premium that would compensate for the additional risk of holding long-term investments. [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d] This matters for monitoring changes over time: the PRA maintains stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only change it when long-term expectations change, so you should not expect changes that are driven by adding (or adjusting) a term premium. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] The PRA also uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024, so your review should align to that methodological approach while still confirming the “no term premium” feature. [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d]
source_text: For each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, provided those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. The PRA will maintain stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only make changes where there are changes in long-term expectations. The PRA uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024. 4
target_text: The ultimate forward rate does not include a term premium to reflect the additional risk of holding long-term investments.

question: If a society isn’t publicly quoted and is setting up or checking its corporate governance arrangements, what code(s) should it look at, and if it uses the Combined Code, which time period does that Combined Code cover?
gold_answer: When a society that is not publicly quoted is putting in place its corporate governance arrangements, or later reviewing them, it should take into account a recognised governance code—either the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code—whichever is appropriate for its situation. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] If the society chooses to have regard to the Combined Code, the Combined Code being referred to is the Combined Code on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] That referenced Combined Code is also limited by timing: it applies to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] So, the society’s decision about which code to consider happens in the context of establishing or reviewing its governance arrangements, and the Combined Code option is specifically the Financial Reporting Council committee’s version with the stated accounting-period start-date boundary. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] This links the society’s governance-review activity to a clearly identified Combined Code and its defined time scope. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0]
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: If someone asks why the PRA will publish reports on the MA framework and what they will include, what should you say, and how do you point them to the exact Solvency II Review reference mentioned in the consultation response?
gold_answer: You should explain that the PRA plans to publish regular reports on the MA framework to improve transparency and to put into effect the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] You should also say what the reports will cover and when they start: they will be published alongside the PRA Annual Report, they will include application review timelines and decision rates, and the first report is planned for 2025. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] To point to the exact Solvency II Review reference, you should direct the reader to paragraph 1.17 of the document titled ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’ (available at the government consultation link), because that is the specific place identified for the Solvency II Review reference. [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3] Bringing both points together, the PRA’s stated reporting package (regular MA framework reports with those metrics, starting in 2025) should be presented as the transparency mechanism that supports implementing the outcome of the HMT Solvency II Review that is cross-referenced via paragraph 1.17 in the consultation response. [#SRC:39a4eb87d14f02a4] [#TGT:e036eff0bbda3fb3]
source_text: In order to promote transparency in the regulatory regime, and to implement the outcome of HMT’s Solvency II Review 15 , the PRA will publish regular reports on the MA framework alongside the PRA Annual Report, covering application review timelines and decision rates, with the first report to be published in 2025.
target_text: 15. Paragraph 1.17 of ‘Review of Solvency II: Consultation - Response’: www.gov.uk/government/consultations/solvency-ii-review-consultation .

question: For a firm using an internal model, what must be included in template AoC.01 and how must it be submitted to the PRA, taking into account both the PRA’s description of AoC.01 and the annual submission requirement and instructions referenced for internal models?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model is required to provide the PRA with template AoC.01 on an annual basis, and that submission must follow the specific instructions identified for AoC.01. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] AoC.01 is the PRA’s analysis of change template that firms complete with key information about movements in the SCR, and it is to be submitted in line with the relevant provisions cited for submission in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] In terms of content, the annual AoC.01 submission must set out the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] Operationally, the firm should (i) complete AoC.01 with the key information regarding movement in SCR, (ii) ensure the template includes the quantitative elements and the accompanying qualitative analysis required for internal model reporting, and (iii) submit it to the PRA annually using the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] The submission should also be made in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, as referenced for AoC.01. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When documenting changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts—particularly where the change involves integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society—how should PIBS 26 be characterised based on the definition provided?
gold_answer: PIBS 26 should be treated as a specific instrument whose nature is defined as “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and it is further characterised as a type of deferred share; that characterisation should be used when describing or assessing changes to the terms and conditions that apply to PIBS 26 within the broader set of products listed. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The relevant change scenario includes any amendments to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and it expressly encompasses changes arising from integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] Accordingly, when the integration of product lines results in revised terms for PIBS 26, the documentation should reflect that the affected product is a permanent interest-bearing share (i.e., a deferred share type), rather than treating it as an undefined or generic account product. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] This ensures the change description aligns the product-specific definition of PIBS 26 with the scope of term-and-condition changes contemplated for integration between the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]
source_text: (a) any changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts, including the integration of the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society;
target_text: 26. Permanent interest-bearing shares, a type of deferred share.
