question: If a firm looks at the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management (under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3), what does it have to send in its annual report, and what extra write-up is needed if setting the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would make it fail the SCR?
gold_answer: When the firm’s work includes assessing the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3, that VA-focused assessment sits within the set of assessments tied to 3.2 for reporting purposes. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] The firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information it reports annually in line with Reporting 2. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] If, in addition, reducing the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would cause the firm to be non-compliant with the SCR, the firm has to provide more than just the assessment itself. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] In that case, it must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply to deal with the shortfall—either by re-establishing the level of eligible own funds covering the SCR or by reducing its risk profile so that SCR compliance is restored. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] Practically, the annual package should therefore include the VA effect assessment (as part of asset-liability management) and, where the zero-adjustment scenario would break SCR compliance, a clear analysis of the firm’s potential corrective measures. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]
source_text: (c) the assessment of the effect of the VA as a part of the firm’s asset-liability management ( Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3 ).
target_text: A firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information reported annually in accordance with Reporting 2 . Where the reduction of the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR , the firm must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply in such a situation to re-establish the level of the e ligible own funds covering the SCR or to reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR .

question: If a firm has already done end-to-end mapping of its important business services under Chapter 4, how can it use that work to help write down what it needs (people, processes, technology, facilities and information) to deliver each important business service, including intragroup and other dependencies?
gold_answer: The firm can use its Chapter 4 end-to-end mapping as a practical foundation for the documentation it must produce for each important business service. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] The required documentation must identify the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information needed to deliver each important business service, so the firm should structure its write-up to capture those items for every service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] It may then extend or align that same mapping output to document and map intragroup and other dependencies, so that dependencies are recorded alongside (and connected to) the people, processes, technology, facilities and information that enable delivery. [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd] [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] Put another way, the firm should treat the end-to-end mapping under Chapter 4 as the mechanism to connect “what is necessary to deliver the service” with “which intragroup and other dependencies support those necessary elements,” ensuring both are documented for each important business service. [#TGT:b33e7a291295fbdf] [#SRC:47c57621ff7696dd]
source_text: Firms may also leverage their end-to-end mapping of important business services under Chapter 4 of the Operational Resilience – CRR Firms and Operational Resilience – Solvency II Parts of the PRA Rulebook to document and map their intragroup and other dependencies.
target_text: As part of its obligation under 3.1 , a firm must identify and document the necessary people, processes, technology, facilities and information required to deliver each of its important business services .

question: If an institution that acts as a clearing member is working out its CVA own-funds requirement under Title VI using the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5, and it also uses the Section 5 method for its exposures to a client, what maturity factor can it use for that client calculation?
gold_answer: In that situation, the institution that acts as a clearing member can use a maturity factor of 0.21 when it applies the Section 5 method to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] This sits alongside (and does not replace) the separate permission for a clearing member to use a reduced exposure at default—specifically, the reduced exposure at default that results from the calculations in paragraphs 3, 4 and 5—when calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk under Title VI. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] So, the combined approach is: use the reduced exposure at default from paragraphs 3–5 for the Title VI CVA own-funds calculation, and, when the calculation step concerns exposures to a client under the Section 5 method, apply the 0.21 maturity factor within that Section 5 computation. [#SRC:e0f6e3ca4abbfbea] [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e] The 0.21 maturity factor is explicitly allowed as a derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) for that Section 5 client-exposure calculation. [#TGT:f6e5657c2d3e0f5e]
source_text: An institution that acts as a clearing member may use the reduced exposure at default resulting from the calculations set out in paragraphs 3 , 4 and 5 for the purposes of calculating its own funds requirements for CVA risk in accordance with Title VI.
target_text: By way of derogation from point (d) of Article 282(4) , where an institution that acts as a clearing member uses the method set out in Section 5 to calculate the own funds requirement for its exposures to a client , that institution may use a maturity factor of 0.21 in that calculation.

question: If a society is preparing for a meeting with Transfer Resolutions, what should its systems do to work out who can vote and help scrutineers check votes, especially where someone is a member but is under 18?
gold_answer: The society’s systems should be set up to identify which members are eligible to vote and to support both sending meeting notices to the right people and enabling scrutineers to validate votes on the Transfer Resolutions. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] To do that, the systems must be able to recognise eligible members by combining share account balances for multiple account holders to test whether they meet the required qualifying shareholding, checking continuity of shareholding, and identifying minors. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8] These operational checks must be applied within the statutory membership categories: a person can only be a member if they are a shareholding member (holding a share, including an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS) or a borrowing member (indebted on a loan fully secured on land, with the Rules potentially adjusting when borrowing membership is conferred or ends). [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e] Because a minor may be a member but cannot vote on any resolution, the system’s “eligible to vote” output should exclude minors even if they otherwise appear as members, so scrutineers can reject any votes cast by them. [#TGT:fc30977c5a30e80e] This combined approach ensures notices go to those entitled to receive them and that vote validation is properly supported. [#SRC:9fd911ad237f25a8]
source_text: A society’s systems must also be capable of recognising those members who are eligible to vote by, for example, aggregating share account balances of multiple account holders to check that they have the requisite qualifying shareholding, by checking members’ continuity of shareholding, and by identifying minors (see paragraphs 3.108 , 3.109 and 3.110 ). This information is required to ensure that the notice of the meeting is sent to all the members entitled to receive it, and that the scrutineers have adequate systems to validate the votes cast on the Transfer Resolutions.
target_text: Paragraph 5 of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act provides that no person may be a member of a building society unless he or she is a shareholding member or a borrowing member. A shareholding member is a person who holds a share in the society (that is, an investment in a share account, CCDS, PPDS or PIBS). A borrowing member is a person who is indebted to the society in respect of a loan fully secured on land. However, the Rules may provide that borrowing membership is conferred by a loan substantially secured on land, or shall cease if the loan is foreclosed or the land is taken into possession by the society. A minor (that is a person under 18 years of age) may be a member, but may not vote on any resolution.

question: When maintaining a model inventory that must document a model’s operating boundaries, how should the firm describe those boundaries and the risk implication of using the model outside them, given the definition of operating boundaries as a sample data range (including multivariate variance-covariance relationships)?
gold_answer: The model inventory should record each model’s operating boundaries as part of documenting the model’s purpose and use, and it should do so in a way that reflects that operating boundaries are the conditions under which model performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] In describing those operating boundaries, the firm should characterize them as the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of the statistical model, including (where relevant) the empirical variance-covariance relationships in multivariate settings. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] The inventory entry should also link the boundary description to the model’s intended versus actual use by indicating whether the model is being applied within that sample data range or is being extrapolated beyond it. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd] Where the model is used beyond its operating boundaries—such as in shock or stressed economic conditions reflected by macroeconomic indices—the inventory should flag that this extrapolation should be assumed to involve increased model risk. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] This boundary-and-risk articulation should sit alongside the other required inventory elements (assumptions/limitations, validation findings, and governance details) so that boundary exceedances can be understood in context and tracked for remediation where applicable. [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]
source_text: c) The types of information the model inventory should capture include: (i) the purpose and use of a model. For example, the relevant product or portfolio, the intended use of the model with a comparison to its actual use, and the model operating boundaries 7 under which model performance is expected to be acceptable; (ii) model assumptions and limitations. For example, risks not captured in model and limitations in the data used to calibrate the model; (iii) findings from validation. For example, indicators of whether models are functioning properly, the dates when those indicators were last updated, any outstanding remediation actions; and (iv) governance details. For example, the names of individuals responsible for validation, the dates when validation was last performed, and the frequency of future validation.
target_text: 7. Operating boundaries is defined here as the sample data range (including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case) used to measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk. estimate the parameters of a statistical model. While not a measure of model performance per se, extrapolating beyond a model's ‘operating boundaries’ (such as macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk.

question: If someone has two different life events that create temporary high balances at the same authorised entity, how do you apply the THB limit for each event, and what changes if one of the balances comes from a payment linked to personal injury or incapacity?
gold_answer: You should treat THB protection as applying to each depositor on a per-event, per-authorised-entity basis, so separate life events can be claimed separately rather than being merged into one combined cap. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] This approach is intended to apply to natural persons (individuals), and where a trust is involved the relevant person is the underlying beneficiary who must be an individual (with trustees able to claim for the trust as a whole where beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest, including discretionary trusts). [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] For the amount payable, the maximum compensation sum for a THB is £1,400,000. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] However, if a THB arises from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity, there is no maximum limit for that THB compensation. [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87] Putting these together, if a depositor has two qualifying life events, you would assess compensation for each event separately, applying the £1,400,000 maximum to each event unless one event is personal-injury/incapacity-related, in which case that event is not capped. [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef] [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]
source_text: The PRA considers that the THB protection limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 applies to each depositor on a ‘per event per authorised entity’ basis and is intended to apply to natural persons only (ie individuals) and not all eligible depositors (eg not companies). Where the depositor is a trust, the PRA considers that it is the underlying beneficiary that is required to be an individual. This includes a beneficiary who is absolutely entitled to the deposit (under a bare trust). Trustees of a trust where individual beneficiaries have less than an absolute beneficial interest may make a THB claim on behalf of the trust as a whole. This includes where the trust involves the exercise of discretion (under a discretionary trust). If an individual or a trustee has eligible deposits in excess of £85,000 as a result of more than one of the life events set out in Depositor Protection 10.2 , a claim may be made for compensation in respect of both of those events and the limit in Depositor Protection 4.3 would apply separately to each event. For example, if an individual had a deposit of £750,000 from an inheritance and a deposit of £750,000 from a house sale, then they would be able to claim up to £750,000 in each case.
target_text: Subject to 4.4 , the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, save that no limit shall apply to the compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity.

question: For an asset that has both economic cash flow variability risks and event risk exposures, what standard approach should a firm apply, and what cash-flow/yield assumption and FS addition elements must be reflected when the dominant risk is economic?
gold_answer: A firm should apply the standard approach that corresponds to the dominant risk when an asset has both economic and event risk exposures; if economic risk is dominant, the economic-risk standard approach is the relevant one. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] Under that economic-risk standard approach, the PRA expects the assumed cash-flow pattern to be based on the investor receiving at least the minimum yield outcome (ie a “yield to worst” assumption). [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] If the asset’s features or contractual terms make a different method more appropriate, the firm may use an alternative on a case-by-case basis, but only if the method still assumes the issuer behaves in an economically rational manner. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] In addition, the FS addition within this approach should incorporate an appropriate de minimis allowance for reinvestment risk and rebalancing costs. [#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e] This linkage matters because the dominant-risk selection determines which standard approach framework applies, while the economic-risk framework specifies the yield-to-worst cash-flow assumption and the required de minimis allowance in the FS addition. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855][#TGT:272595de1a61eb4e]
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: Where assets are exposed to economic cash flow variability risks, the PRA expects that a standard approach would assume a pattern of cash flows where the yield for the investor is at a minimum (ie ‘yield to worst’). Where the features or contractual terms of an asset make an alternative method more appropriate, this could be considered on a case-by-case basis, provided that the method retains the assumption that the issuer will act in economically rational manner. The FS addition should include an appropriate de minimis allowance for the risk of reinvestment and rebalancing costs as set out in paragraph 5.20 above.

question: If a firm gets staff from an intragroup service company and treats that as outsourcing, what written contract is expected for critical or important operational functions or activities, and does outsourcing change who is responsible for meeting PRA rules and FSMA-related obligations for UK Solvency II firms?
gold_answer: Where staff provision through an intragroup service company is treated as outsourcing, the firm should pay close attention to that relationship and, if the arrangement involves outsourcing critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm should put in place a written agreement with the service provider that clearly defines the rights and obligations of both parties. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a] However, outsourcing does not shift the firm’s accountability: if the firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it still remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA, and other laws, rules, regulations, and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms. [#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] The practical linkage is that the contract can allocate tasks and clarify expectations with the intragroup service company, but it cannot be relied on to reduce the firm’s own regulatory responsibilities. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a][#TGT:c0c1ed2e69073245] Separately, the firm should also consider whether entering into this kind of written agreement creates a need under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the authorised firm’s balance sheet. [#SRC:699d49de3bdbcc6a]
source_text: Firms should also pay particular attention to relationships with intragroup service companies, where provision of staff can be regarded as having been outsourced to the service company for the purposes of Conditions Governing Business 7 . The Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook requires that, where a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or activities, a written agreement should be entered into between the firm and the service provider which clearly defines the respective rights and obligations of each party. 5 Firms should consider whether a written agreement of this nature leads to a requirement under IAS 19 to recognise the pension scheme on the balance sheet of the authorised firm.
target_text: If a firm outsources a function or any insurance or reinsurance activity, it remains fully responsible for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules, FSMA and any other laws, rules, regulations and administrative provisions deriving from FSMA that apply to UK Solvency II firms .

question: When setting a rate of interest for the purposes of 11.1, how do the limits based on (i) the adjusted overall yield on assets and (ii) the assumed yield on an individual asset attributed to the long-term insurance business (including the 2.5% reduction) interact, and what practical cap should be applied to ensure compliance across both the portfolio and asset levels?
gold_answer: To comply when determining a rate of interest for the purposes of 11.1, the rate must be constrained by both a portfolio-level ceiling and an asset-level ceiling, so the practical cap is the most restrictive outcome produced by applying both limits. [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] At the portfolio level, the rate of interest determined for 11.1 is not permitted to be higher than the adjusted overall yield on assets, where that adjusted overall yield is computed as a weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets (with those reduced yields being the figures arrived at under 11.2). [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb] In parallel, for each asset attributed to the long-term insurance business, the assumed yield used for 11.1 (before any tax-effect adjustment) must not be higher than the yield on that asset calculated under 11.3 to 11.13, after reducing that calculated yield by 2.5% of itself. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] Practically, this means you should (i) ensure each asset’s assumed yield respects the “11.3–11.13 yield minus 2.5% of that yield” limit, and then (ii) ensure the overall 11.1 rate does not exceed the weighted-average adjusted overall yield derived from the reduced individual-asset yields. [#TGT:82f678b5a7efdda8] [#SRC:3a577ffac5cf0ceb]
source_text: (1) In no case must a rate of interest determined for the purposes of 11.1 exceed the adjusted overall yield on assets calculated as the weighted average of the reduced yields on the individual assets arrived at under 11.2 .
target_text: For the purposes of 11.1 , the assumed yield on an asset attributed to the long-term insurance business , before any adjustment to take account of the effect of taxation, must not exceed the yield on that asset calculated in accordance with 11.3 to 11.13 , reduced by 2.5% of that yield.

question: If an international bank or UK trading bank wants to change its booking arrangements in a big way and that change could affect risk management, what does the PRA expect the firm to do, and how does this relate to being ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption to critical services?
gold_answer: For international banks and UK trading banks, the PRA expects the firm to inform the PRA when it plans material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] This sits within the PRA’s wider expectations that booking arrangements should be organised to meet the threshold condition on prudent conduct of business and to support the General Organisational Requirements connected to risk management and resolvability. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] The connection to Fundamental Rule 8 is that the firm must prepare for resolution so that, if needed, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with minimum disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] Because booking arrangements can affect both risk management and resolvability, the firm should view the planned-change notification as part of maintaining readiness to achieve the orderly-resolution outcome required by Fundamental Rule 8. [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680] [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]
source_text: The PRA has a number of expectations concerning how international banks and UK trading banks should organise their booking arrangements in order to meet the threshold condition on the prudent conduct of business, their obligations under Fundamental Rules 3 , 5 , 6 and 8 , and under the General Organisational Requirements (GOR) relating to risk management and resolvability. The PRA also has an expectation under Fundamental Rule 7 and General Notification Requirement 2.3(1) that a firm should inform the PRA when it plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: How should a firm structure its booking governance so that (i) it has a clear booking taxonomy covering remote booking, split desks/shared desks, and branch bookings, and (ii) each individual booking can be traced to a responsible individual while maintaining segregation between trade entry and independent checking?
gold_answer: A firm should implement booking governance that combines a documented booking taxonomy with clear accountability for who may book and who is responsible for the correctness of each booking. The firm should first identify and classify the booking types it uses and maintain a clear, comprehensive taxonomy that defines key terms such as remote booking (in both legal-entity and geographic senses), split desks, shared desks, and the classification of branch bookings. [#TGT:670172cefe48eb87] In parallel, the firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking, including whether the trader is solely responsible, and it should articulate any distinctions between traders, sales, and sales traders. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The governance should also cover individuals booking into legal entities and branches, including traders based overseas booking into UK branches, and align those scenarios to the taxonomy’s treatment of remote and branch bookings. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traceable to at least one (and preferably only one) responsible individual, usually the trader, which should be reflected in the firm’s booking definitions and controls. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703] Finally, the firm should ensure trade entry is distinct from independent checking and is performed in line with segregation of duties controls, so that the taxonomy and responsibility model do not blur execution/entry with verification. [#SRC:03d5f6afa7925703]
source_text: Booking responsibilities: A firm should define and record who is permitted to book and what constitutes a booking including whether the trader is solely responsible. This should articulate the distinction, if any, between traders, sales and sales traders. This should also cover those individuals booking into legal entities and branches including traders based overseas booking into UK branches. The PRA expects the correctness of any given booking to be traced to at least one, and preferably only one, responsible individual, which will usually be the trader. Trade entry is different from the independent checking of the trade and should be performed in line with the firm’s segregation of duties controls. 37
target_text: Booking taxonomy: A firm should identify and classify the types of booking they employ and develop a clear and comprehensive taxonomy to assist with this. This should clearly define the use of terms such as remote booking (legal entity and geographic sense), split desks, and shared desks. The classification of branch bookings should also be covered. The PRA recognises that firms have already developed their own independent taxonomies to describe booking practices and is not seeking to impose common definitions for booking taxonomies at the current time. However, a set of illustrative examples have been provided in the Annex that the PRA considers to be an approximation of current industry practice and represent how the PRA has used certain terms throughout this statement.

question: If a firm is in a 2.1(3) group, when does it have to make sure the group’s strategies, processes and systems meet Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3, and when are 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 switched off because the parent’s head office is in a designated overseas jurisdiction under the IRPR regulations?
gold_answer: If the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), it is within the scope of a rule that requires the firm to ensure the group’s strategies, processes and systems comply with the obligations in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 (with the stated carve-out for Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3), and with 2.1(3) described as being subject to 22.5). [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] However, for a 2.1(3) group there is also a separate condition that can turn off the application of 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4: those provisions do not apply if the group parent undertaking’s head office is in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] So you need two checks: (1) confirm the firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3) to identify the group-level operational resilience compliance duty, and (2) confirm the overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to decide whether 22.2–22.4 are disapplied for that firm. [#TGT:df26169200bb5c19] [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , with the exception of Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3.1(3) , the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member comply with the obligations set out in Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 3 .

question: If a G-SII decides to use the option to publish the Article 441 information somewhere different from the standalone document in Article 434(1), what is the normal “one place, electronic” rule for Titles II and III disclosures, and what can count as that one place?
gold_answer: If a G-SII uses the derogation, it is allowed to put the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location rather than in the standalone document referred to in Article 434(1). [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] Normally, institutions must publish all information required under Titles II and III electronically and in a single medium or location. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] That single place must be set up in one of two ways: it can be a standalone document that gives users a readily accessible source of prudential information, or it can be a clearly identifiable distinctive section that is included in or appended to the institutions’ financial statements or financial reports and that contains the required disclosures. [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa] Putting these together, the G-SII can follow the general approach of having Titles II and III disclosures in one electronic location that meets the required format, while still using the derogation to locate the Article 441 information separately from the Article 434(1) standalone document. [#SRC:f339ea4b3db2ad76] [#TGT:8422ed9edcda5caa]
source_text: By way of derogation from Article 434(1) , where a G-SII relies on the derogation in paragraph 1 , it may disclose the information required under Article 441 in a separate medium or location from the standalone document mentioned in Article 434(1) .
target_text: Institutions shall disclose all the information required under Titles II and III in electronic format and in a single medium or location. The single medium or location shall be a standalone document that provides a readily accessible source of prudential information for users of that information or a distinctive section included in or appended to the institutions' financial statements or financial reports containing the required disclosures and being easily identifiable to those users.

question: When calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts for an institution’s trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3), how must the institution determine the exposure values to be summed, and what framework governs that exposure-value calculation before applying the risk weight?
gold_answer: For the purposes of Article 92(3), an institution must compute the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by first determining the exposure values for those trade exposures, then summing those exposure values, and finally multiplying that sum by the applicable risk weight. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] The exposure values that feed into this sum are not determined ad hoc; they must be calculated in accordance with the specified rule framework, namely Sections 1 to 8 of the relevant Chapter and, where applicable, Section 4 of Chapter 4. [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6] In addition, the source calculation method requires that the exposure values used in the sum are those calculated in accordance with the internal paragraph-based method referenced for exposure values (paragraphs 2 and 3 of the same Article), before applying the risk weight determined under the referenced paragraph 1. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] Accordingly, the institution’s process is: calculate exposure values under the prescribed Sections/Chapter framework (and the referenced paragraph method), aggregate those exposure values across its CCP trade exposures, and apply the risk weight to the aggregate to obtain the risk-weighted exposure amount. [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40] [#TGT:325217a9dca51ff6]
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: An institution shall calculate exposure values of its trade exposures with a CCP in accordance with Sections 1 to 8 of this Chapter and with Section 4 of Chapter 4, as applicable.

question: If a firm updates its model change policy after checking that its internal model still fits its risk profile, when does it need the PRA’s permission, and what is the September 2016 link given for the document it should look at?
gold_answer: A firm is expected to check its model change policy regularly to see whether it is working well, so that the internal model keeps reflecting the firm’s risk profile and continues to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] If the firm then wants to change the model change policy itself, it needs to separate simple administrative edits from other updates, because any change that is not administrative is described as needing the PRA’s permission. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] The text also points the reader to SS12/16, “Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms,” and the specific reference provided is a September 2016 publication located at http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss. [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998] So, in a compliant workflow, the firm should (1) perform the regular review for continued fit and standards, (2) classify the intended policy change as administrative or not, and (3) if it is not administrative, treat it as requiring PRA permission while using the cited SS12/16 link as the referenced source for further information. [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224] [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998]
source_text: The PRA encourages firms to review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure that the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and meets the internal model requirements and calibration standards. Firms are also reminded that changes to the model change policy itself, other than administrative changes, are subject to the PRA’s permission. Readers also are referred to SS12/16, ‘Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms’ . 16
target_text: 16. September 2016: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss .

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how should the firm determine whether it must ensure group-level strategies, processes and systems support assessing impact tolerance for important group business services during a severe but plausible disruption, given the condition under which 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply?
gold_answer: A firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) must ensure that group-level strategies, processes and systems allow the firm to assess whether important group business services could stay within the impact tolerance during a severe but plausible disruption to the firm’s operations. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] However, when determining the overall rule set that applies to that same 2.1(3) group context, the firm must also check whether the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and whether paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies. [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] If those conditions are met, then 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply to the firm in that scenario, even though the firm remains within the population described as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3). [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8] Practically, the firm should (i) confirm it is in scope as a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), and (ii) separately evaluate the third-country/overseas-jurisdiction designation and regulation 14(3) condition to determine whether the 22.2–22.4 provisions are disapplied while still maintaining the group-level capability to assess impact tolerance for important group business services. [#SRC:43a647fe4cce5cd9] [#TGT:b6b6500b2b9939c8]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) the firm must ensure that the strategies, processes and systems at the level of the group of which it is a member enable the firm to assess whether important group business services at the level of the group could remain within the impact tolerance in the event of a severe but plausible disruption to its operations.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.

question: If a firm is using the IFRS 9 transitional arrangements, what does the PRA look at when deciding whether the firm needs a bigger capital buffer, and how does that connect to when IFRS 9 started applying and what older standard it replaced?
gold_answer: Where a firm is using IFRS 9 transitional arrangements, the PRA’s decision on whether the firm should hold a larger buffer or strengthen its capital position is based on a combination of prudential factors and a time-limited transitional assessment. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] The PRA expects firms to increase buffers or strengthen capital where necessary in light of factors including the firm’s leverage ratio, Tier 1 and total capital ratios, risks associated with double leverage, and whether potentially significant risks are not fully captured by the stress test. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] In addition, up to the end of 2023, the PRA will assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for IFRS 9 when firms are using those arrangements. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] This transitional focus is tied to IFRS 9’s role as the accounting standard for financial instruments: IFRS 9 set new accounting rules for financial instruments and replaced IAS 39, and it is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018 (after EU endorsement). [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1] So, for firms using the transition, the PRA’s capital-buffer judgement can reflect both the usual capital/risk indicators and the specific IFRS 9 transitional assessment through end-2023, in the context of IFRS 9’s post-2018 replacement of IAS 39. [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary based on other factors. These include, but are not limited to: the firm’s leverage ratio; Tier 1 and total capital ratios; risks associated with double leverage; and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not captured fully as part of the stress test. Until the end of 2023, the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9, 53 where firms are using these arrangements.
target_text: 53. IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and sets out new rules for accounting for financial instruments, replacing the rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39. Following endorsement for use in the EU, IFRS 9 is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018. The PRA’s communications to firms on IFRS 9 are available on the Bank’s website at https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/letter/2017/transition-disclosures-for-ifrs9-financial-instruments .

question: When complying with the requirement to mark eligible deposits so they can be immediately identified, may a firm satisfy this by marking the accounts of eligible depositors, and if an account marked in this way later has a nil or negative balance, is the firm expected to remove the marker?
gold_answer: A firm can meet the immediate-identification objective for eligible deposits by applying the marker at the account level for eligible depositors, provided that approach results in eligible deposits being immediately identifiable. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] The PRA indicates that, for the purpose of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1, marking may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors that contain eligible deposits, which supports using an account marker as the operational method to achieve identification. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] Once an account has been marked in this way, the PRA does not expect the firm to remove the eligible deposit marker merely because the account has a nil balance or the balance becomes negative. [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5] In practice, the firm should implement its marking so that eligible deposits are immediately identifiable through the marker, while maintaining marker continuity on accounts even if the balance later reaches zero or goes below zero. [#TGT:60b306349873ce31] [#SRC:91baf6dd072390d5]
source_text: For the purposes of meeting Depositor Protection 11.1 , the PRA considers the marking of eligible deposits may be achieved by marking accounts of eligible depositors which contain eligible deposits. For the avoidance of doubt, where such an account has a nil balance, or the balance becomes negative, the PRA does not expect firms to remove the eligible deposit marker.
target_text: A firm must mark eligible deposits in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits .

question: If the PRA external audit rules apply to an undertaking’s SFCR, does the auditor need to cover how big the matching adjustment’s effect is, and how does the example about calculating the impact of changing the MA to zero (and its link to Life Technical Provisions) help explain what must be in scope?
gold_answer: Yes. When the PRA’s external audit rules apply, the scale of the matching adjustment (MA)—i.e., the extent to which it affects technical provisions—is within the audit scope. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] The reason given is that the MA’s impact sits within the SFCR “relevant elements” that external auditors are required to form a view on. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] The target text provides a concrete illustration of what that means in practice: it identifies as a relevant element the quantification of how the undertaking’s financial position would be affected if the MA were changed to zero. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] That example helps connect the general “relevant elements” concept to a specific MA-related calculation that is expected to be covered. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] The target text also states that the MA directly affects Life Technical Provisions, and that those Life Technical Provisions are within scope of the External Audit rule, which aligns with the source’s focus on the MA’s impact on technical provisions as audit-scoped. [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf] [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] Taken together, these points indicate the auditor’s scope should include both the MA’s effect on technical provisions and the SFCR-relevant quantification of the “MA to zero” impact on financial position. [#SRC:428012445d83f28d] [#TGT:a160cf63fb8299cf]
source_text: The scale of the matching adjustment (ie the extent to which the MA impacts on technical provisions) is within scope of audit where the PRA’s external audit rules apply. 6 This reflects the fact that the impact of the MA falls within the ‘relevant elements’ that external auditors of the SFCR are required to form a view on. 7
target_text: 7. For example, the quantification of the impact of a change to zero of the MA on that undertaking’s financial position is specified as a relevant element of the SFCR (External Audit 2.2(1) and Rules 3.4(1)(a) and (b) in the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. In addition, the MA has a direct effect on Life Technical Provisions which are within scope of the External Audit rule.

question: If the PRA does not feel confident about the home country’s resolution setup for a bank branch, what might the PRA require for a bank that already has a UK branch, and how does the Bank’s ability to resolve a branch on its own in some cases connect to that?
gold_answer: When the PRA cannot get enough comfort that the home resolution authority’s regime will produce outcomes that meet the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority, the PRA says it is likely unwilling to host a branch from that jurisdiction. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] If the bank is already in the UK through an existing branch, the PRA indicates it may require the firm to set up a UK subsidiary instead. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] The PRA also explains that, where assurance over home state resolution arrangements is insufficient, the firm may need to be supervised more on a standalone basis in a way that matches an MPE approach to resolution. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] This focus on being able to deal with the branch or UK operations separately connects to the Bank’s stated powers: the Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including resolving branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances. [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55] So, the PRA’s potential move toward subsidiarisation and standalone supervision for an existing branch aligns with the idea that the Bank can, where circumstances apply, take branch-level resolution action on a standalone basis. [#SRC:aed1e5a5beeec125] [#TGT:5b8d0f16006f4c55]
source_text: The PRA’s preferred approach is to gain assurance that the home resolution authority’s resolution regime will deliver the appropriate outcomes for the PRA’s and the Bank’s objectives as UK resolution authority. In the absence of adequate levels of assurance, the PRA will likely not be prepared to host such a branch from that jurisdiction. 53 In the case of an international bank operating through an existing branch, it may be required to establish a UK subsidiary. If there is insufficient assurance over the home state resolution arrangements, this may in turn mean that it would be necessary for the firm to be supervised on a more standalone basis consistent with a MPE approach to resolution.
target_text: 53. The Bank has certain resolution powers over branches, including the power to resolve branches on a standalone basis in certain circumstances.

question: When establishing indicator monitoring to support decision-making on a solvent exit, may a firm rely on its existing management information framework and the indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations rather than creating a new indicator set, and what specific monitoring dimensions are expected for those indicators?
gold_answer: A firm may use and tailor its existing management information framework and its indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations to meet the relevant expectations, and it does not have to create and monitor an entirely new set of indicators solely for this purpose. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] However, whichever indicators the firm uses (including those adapted from existing frameworks), it should actively monitor both projected and actual levels, and also track the trend of those indicators. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] The monitoring is not an end in itself: the indicators, together with other relevant information, are expected to enable clear and timely decision-making about a solvent exit. [#TGT:30201d932e512926] In practice, this means the firm should (i) select indicators from its existing frameworks that can be adapted to the solvent-exit context, (ii) ensure the monitoring covers forward-looking projections and observed outcomes, and (iii) review directional movement over time so that decisions can be made promptly and with clarity. [#SRC:123f8b7afeb33b32] [#TGT:30201d932e512926]
source_text: To meet the expectations in paragraphs 2.7 and 2.8 , a firm may draw on and adapt its existing management information framework, and indicator framework developed under the PRA’s recovery planning expectations, 24 without necessarily creating and monitoring a new set of indicators.
target_text: A firm should monitor the projected and actual levels of these indicators, as well as their trend. These indicators, alongside other relevant information, 23 should support clear and timely decision-making regarding a solvent exit.

question: For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, how should the recovery plan be structured for usability by boards and business areas, and what additional steps should the firm take regarding UK playbooks where the PRA may request more detailed work as part of UK recovery planning?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside the UK should structure its recovery plan so it is readily usable by both the board and the specific business areas that would need to use it, because the board must be able to navigate and understand the plan quickly in order to take key decisions during a stress. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] In addition, such UK subsidiaries should consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks referenced in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii), and treat this as relevant input when shaping the plan’s practical usability for decision-makers and users. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Where the PRA explicitly asks the firm to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of its UK recovery planning work, the firm should engage with that request and contact its supervisor to discuss whether this applies to it. [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e] Taken together, this means the firm should (i) design the recovery plan’s structure to support rapid board navigation and comprehension and to be workable for the business areas that will execute it, and (ii) be prepared to deepen UK playbook work—aligned to the referenced fire drill/playbook guidance—when the PRA signals that more detailed UK playbook work is expected. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] [#SRC:f4ab9388eafb627e]
source_text: (vii) UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK should also consider the guidance on fire drills and playbooks set out in Chapter 2 (vi) and (vii) . In some cases, the PRA may explicitly ask firms to undertake more detailed work on UK playbooks as part of their UK recovery planning work. Firms should contact their supervisor to discuss whether this applies.
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If a firm is working out surplus funds and checking whether something counts as Tier 1 own funds, what does it need to look at in Own Funds 3A and 3B, and when does it have to treat certain basic own funds items as Tier 1 (using the 3.5 and 3.6 references)?
gold_answer: The firm should connect its surplus-funds calculation work with the PRA Rulebook’s Own Funds structure, and then apply the rule that forces Tier 1 classification for certain basic own funds items when the full 3B feature set is met. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Specifically, the firm should use the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and when deciding whether it meets the criteria for Tier 1 own funds. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] Within that, Own Funds 3A is the place to identify the relevant own funds items, while Own Funds 3B is the place to check the features that determine whether an item is classified as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] For the “basic own funds items” described, the firm must treat those items as substantially having the characteristics in 3.5, assessed by taking into account the features in 3.6, and it must classify them as Tier 1 own funds when the items display all of the features set out in 3B. [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4] So the practical sequence is: identify the item in 3A, test it against the Tier 1 feature set in 3B, and if it is one of the basic own funds items and it meets all 3B features (with the 3.5/3.6 framing), classify it as Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e][#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]
source_text: Firms should have regard to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook when calculating surplus funds and considering whether they meet the criteria for classification as Tier 1 own funds. In particular, Own Funds 3A sets out a list of own funds items and Own Funds 3B the features determining classification as Tier 1 own funds.
target_text: The following basic own funds items shall be deemed to substantially possess the characteristics set out in 3.5 , taking into consideration the features set out in 3.6 , and a firm must classify them as Tier 1 own funds , where the following items display all of the features set out in 3B :

question: When constructing a matching adjustment (MA) portfolio that includes in-payment income protection claims, how should a firm reconcile the PRA’s view that in-payment elements may be eligible where separately identifiable and managed separately with the rule that insurance or reinsurance obligations must not be split into different parts except for an eligible element, and what underwriting risk exposure limits apply to recovery time risk in that context?
gold_answer: A firm may only treat part of an income protection contract separately for MA portfolio composition where that part qualifies as an eligible element, and the PRA’s discussion of “in-payment elements” is framed as potentially eligible only when they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately (including in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations). [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] The general rule for this Part is that insurance or reinsurance obligations under a contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio, except in the case of an eligible element, so any separation of an in-payment element must fit within that exception rather than being a general permission to split obligations. [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379] In that setting, the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, described as the risk that policyholders receiving income protection payments take longer than expected to recover from sickness. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] Unlike mortality risk, the PRA indicates there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios, but it also states it does not expect recognising recovery time risk to justify bringing in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: If a firm wants to use an insurance-group transaction (like a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset so it can go into the MA portfolio, what does the PRA expect the firm to check about (1) whether the unrestructured asset stays suitable over the life of the restructuring as conditions change, and (2) whether the unrestructured asset already fails Solvency II requirements (including the PPP)?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation is that a firm should only rely on an insurance-group transaction (including a loan or derivative) to restructure an asset for MA portfolio inclusion if the restructured asset can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions, and the firm should consider the underlying asset when judging whether those conditions will be met. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] As part of assessing the suitability of the restructuring arrangements, the firm is expected to start by asking whether the asset in its unrestructured form is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and anticipates that operating conditions may change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] The PRA also indicates a restriction: it would not expect firms to use arrangements described in paragraph 2.55 (or arrangements that effectively do the same thing) for assets that, before restructuring, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including PPP requirements. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] Finally, because some assets may be inherently infeasible to restructure into MA-eligible assets, the firm should be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to ensure the MA eligibility conditions continue to be satisfied over time. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: The extent to which transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can be used to restructure assets in order to include them in the MA portfolio depends on whether the restructured assets thereby created can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects firms to have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when they consider whether the MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied. The PRA would not expect firms to apply arrangements as set out in paragraph 2.55 above, or arrangements that in substance have that effect, to assets that, in unrestructured form, would in any event not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP. The PRA notes that some assets by their very nature may have characteristics that make it infeasible to restructure them as MA eligible assets, and expects firms to be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed upon restructuring arrangements to ensure the continuing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions.

question: If the PRA puts off a class A2 member’s recapitalisation payment levy share because paying now would harm the firm’s liquidity or solvency, how long can that delay last, can it be extended, and when does the firm have to pay the deferred amount?
gold_answer: The deferred amount has to be paid when paying it no longer puts the firm’s liquidity and solvency at risk, and the PRA’s deferral cannot last more than six months at a time, although it can be renewed if the firm requests it. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] In other words, the payment timing is linked to the firm’s financial condition: once the payment would not jeopardise liquidity and solvency, the contribution becomes due. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA can defer the obligation (fully or partly) only where it considers the contribution would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and this applies to a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The six-month limit is a hard cap on any single deferral period, but the firm can ask for a renewal, which allows the deferral to continue beyond six months through renewed periods. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] So the firm should track both (i) whether the liquidity/solvency risk has ended (which triggers payment) and (ii) the end date of the current six-month deferral period (which may require a renewal request). [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: When a firm is preparing the report that must be submitted periodically under Chapter 3 and then summarised for periodic publication under Chapter 4, how should it determine what the PRA expects for the report’s content and format, and how does the PRA handle the timing of the submission and disclosure?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the report it must submit periodically under Chapter 3 as a report whose content and format are governed by the PRA’s expectations set out in the chapter addressing that Chapter 3 report, and it should plan its submission and related disclosure around dates the PRA will provide in advance. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] Specifically, firms have an obligation to submit reports on a periodic basis under Chapter 3 and to publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4, so the reporting and disclosure cycle includes both submission and a separate summary publication step. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] For the Chapter 3 report itself, the relevant expectations for what the report should contain and how it should be presented are set out in the chapter that describes the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3. [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c] In operational terms, the firm should align its internal drafting and review process to those content/format expectations for the Chapter 3 report, and then schedule both the Chapter 3 submission and the Chapter 4 summary publication using the expected dates that the PRA will communicate ahead of time. [#SRC:67e3fc728b0c6db8] [#TGT:64f5e172de569a7c]
source_text: Firms are required to submit reports periodically under Chapter 3 of the rules and publish a summary of that report periodically under Chapter 4 of the rules. The PRA will communicate the expected dates for firms’ submission and disclosure in advance.
target_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations on the content and format of a firm’s report required under Resolution Assessment Chapter 3.

question: For a composite firm that is required to maintain separate accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business, what statement must the firm prepare on the basis of those accounts regarding eligible own funds and the notional MCRs for each business line?
gold_answer: A composite firm that keeps distinct accounts for its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business must use those accounts as the basis for preparing a statement that distinguishes the eligible own funds supporting each business line’s notional minimum capital requirement. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] Specifically, the firm must prepare a statement (based on the relevant accounts) that identifies the eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and, separately, the eligible own funds covering the notional general insurance MCR. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3] This means the statement should not present a single combined figure for eligible own funds across both activities; instead, it should reflect the separation implied by maintaining separate accounts for the two types of business and then map eligible own funds to each corresponding notional MCR. [#TGT:eac60971cab72fc0] The required content of the statement is therefore twofold: (i) eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR, and (ii) eligible own funds covering the notional general insurance MCR, each identified on the basis of the accounts. [#SRC:0b09948a10ceade3]
source_text: The firm must prepare a statement on the basis of the accounts referred to in 3.2 identifying the eligible own funds covering the notional long-term insurance MCR and the notional general insurance MCR , respectively.
target_text: A composite firm must maintain separate accounts for each of its long-term insurance business and its general insurance business to show the sources of the results for each activity separately.

question: For a firm acting as an originator, original lender and/or sponsor in a securitisation that is subject to the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, what must the firm be able to demonstrate to the PRA on request regarding its compliance arrangements, and how should the firm evidence that it meets the ongoing 5% material net economic interest retention requirement (including how and when that interest is measured)?
gold_answer: A firm acting as an originator, original lender and/or sponsor in a securitisation within scope of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook must be able to show the PRA, if asked, that it has adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms to comply with the specified requirements in the Securitisation Part (including Articles 6, 7, 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4–6). [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614] In evidencing those arrangements for the retention obligation, the firm should be able to demonstrate that the originator, sponsor or original lender retains, on an ongoing basis, a material net economic interest in the securitisation of at least 5%. [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012] The firm’s demonstration should also cover the measurement basis and timing for that retained interest: it is measured at origination, and for off-balance-sheet items it is determined by reference to notional value. [#TGT:faa1ca2e4ad51012] Taken together, this means the firm’s compliance framework should be capable of producing, upon PRA request, clear evidence that the 5% minimum is established at origination using the required measurement approach and is maintained on an ongoing basis, as part of the broader set of arrangements supporting compliance with the relevant Securitisation Part provisions. [#SRC:82ecd83bdfb2b614]
source_text: The PRA expects firms which act as originators, original lenders, and/or sponsors in a securitisation that are subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook to be able to demonstrate to the PRA, on request, that they have in place adequate arrangements, processes and mechanisms in order to comply with Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The originator , sponsor or original lender of a securitisation shall retain on an ongoing basis a material net economic interest in the securitisation of not less than 5%. That interest shall be measured at the origination and shall be determined by the notional value for off-balance-sheet items.

question: When an institution is calculating exposure values for OTC derivatives under the methods in Sections 3, 4 and 5, how should it treat two perfectly matching OTC derivative contracts that are in the same netting agreement, and how does that treatment interact with whether the institution may calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement or must calculate exposures separately per transaction?
gold_answer: An institution can, when applying the exposure-calculation methods in Sections 3, 4 and 5, combine two OTC derivative contracts that are both (i) included in the same netting agreement and (ii) perfectly matching, by treating them as though they were one contract with a notional principal of zero. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] In parallel, the institution’s ability to compute one exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement depends on whether all conditions in Article 274(1) are satisfied; if they are, a single exposure value may be calculated for the whole agreement, and if they are not, an exposure value must be calculated separately for each transaction and each such transaction is treated as its own netting set. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Read together, the “perfectly matching” treatment is a specific calculation approach available within the Section 3–5 methods for two matching OTC derivatives in the same netting agreement, while the broader question of whether exposures are aggregated across the contractual netting agreement or split by transaction turns on meeting (or not meeting) the Article 274(1) conditions. [#SRC:14f4743e51835715] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: In calculating the exposure value in accordance with the methods set out in Sections 3 , 4 and 5 , institutions may treat two OTC derivative contracts included in the same netting agreement that are perfectly matching as if they were a single contract with a notional principal equal to zero.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: For a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK (or part of a UK-based group) and conducts investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas, how should it determine whether the PRA’s high-level expectations for managing booking arrangements for trading activity apply to it, and what is the stated purpose of those expectations?
gold_answer: A firm that is a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm should first assess whether it falls within the category described as ‘UK trading banks’, which covers firms headquartered in the UK or in a UK-based group that have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas; for those firms, the sections in Chapter 4 on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements apply. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] Once within scope, the firm should treat the Chapter 4 expectations as the PRA’s high-level expectations for how booking arrangements for trading activity should be managed. [#TGT:99aa362d479338d6] The purpose of these high-level expectations is to ensure that the firm’s booking arrangements are transparent and well-controlled. [#TGT:99aa362d479338d6] In applying this, the firm should use the statement’s delineation of which Chapter 4 paragraphs and related materials comprise the relevant expectations for UK trading banks (including the specified paragraph ranges and the Annex on Context and definitions), and note that the statement indicates it will specify in the relevant sections when expectations apply only to international banks versus when they apply to both international banks and UK trading banks. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a] For terminology describing the scope of application for the booking expectations, the firm is directed to the summary referenced in paragraph 4.24B. [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. We make clear in the relevant sections where the expectations apply to international banks alone, and where they apply to international banks and UK trading banks. See paragraph 4.24B for a summary of the terminology used to describe the scope of application for the booking expectations.
target_text: The PRA has a number of high-level expectations of how firms should manage their booking arrangements for trading activity, as set out in Chapter 4 . These are aimed at ensuring that a firm’s booking arrangements are transparent and well-controlled.

question: When describing the statutory basis for a statement of policy on approvals, how should the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) explain (i) the FSMA provision that requires the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue statements of their respective policies and (ii) the FSMA sections that set out the PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals?
gold_answer: The PRA should present the statement of policy as being issued under the FSMA provision that imposes a duty on both the PRA and the FCA to publish statements describing their respective policies, and it should separately identify the FSMA sections that contain the legal power to vary approvals. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] Specifically, the statement should be framed as issued in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA), which is described as requiring the PRA and the FCA to issue statements of their respective policies. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] In addition, when the statement addresses the topic of varying approvals, it should point to the statutory location of that power by noting that the PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals is set out in sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA. [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a] Read together, this means the document can distinguish between (a) the section that provides the requirement to issue policy statements (section 63ZD) and (b) the sections that provide the underlying power being discussed in the policy (sections 63ZA/63ZB). [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a]
source_text: This statement of policy is issued by the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) as amended by the Financial Services (Banking Reform)Act 2013, 1 and the Bank of England and Financial Services Act 2016, which requires the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue a statement of their respective policies on:
target_text: 2. The PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals are set out in Sections in sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA.

question: When adjusting the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description, how must a firm treat assets it is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under (i) an option and (ii) a futures contract, and how does this relate to the adjustment described as occurring from 18 to 19?
gold_answer: A firm must adjust the value ascribed under 18 for each asset description by reflecting deemed acquisitions or disposals arising under both options and futures contracts, and it must apply those adjustments in the manner described for the movement from 18 to 19. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] Specifically, the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for assets of each description is required to be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] In parallel, the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description is required to be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract. [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] Read together, these provisions mean the firm’s adjustment mechanism for values ascribed under 18 must capture deemed transactions under both instrument types, with the option-based deemed acquisitions/disposals explicitly framed as affecting the value ascribed “under 18 to 19,” while the futures-based deemed acquisitions/disposals are framed as affecting the value ascribed “under 18.” [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] The practical effect is that, for each description of assets, the firm must increase or decrease the relevant ascribed value by the corresponding value of assets deemed acquired or disposed of under either an option or a futures contract, applying the adjustment consistently with the referenced 18/19 ascription context. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
