target_text: The value ascribed under 18 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract.

question: If a ring-fenced body wants to outsource something to another company in its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, what does it need to do about (1) the deal terms and (2) the way it records and documents intragroup dependencies using operational continuity and OCIR records?
gold_answer: It needs to do two things in parallel: make sure the transaction itself is on arm’s length terms, and use (where relevant) existing operational continuity and OCIR documentation to show it understands and can evidence the intragroup dependencies created by the outsourcing. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] On the deal terms, a ring-fenced body is only permitted to enter into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate if the terms are arm’s length, so the outsourcing-related transaction must be structured accordingly. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] On documentation and governance, the PRA indicates that firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other regulatory areas to help meet obligations for intragroup outsourcing arrangements; for some banks this can include Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook, and this may help meet expectations around business continuity and exit plans. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] The PRA also expects firms to consider using elements of OCIR record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, as long as the information is clear and readily available to the PRA on request. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]
source_text: Where relevant, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations in respect of their intragroup outsourcing arrangements. For instance, for some banks, intragroup outsourcing arrangements may be subject to the requirements in Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook. Compliance with these requirements may also mean those banks meet certain expectations in this SS in respect of intragroup outsourcing arrangements (for instance, in respect of business continuity and exit plans (see Chapter 10 )). The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document their intragroup dependencies, as long as relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request. 23
target_text: A ring-fenced body must enter into a transaction with a member of its group which is not a ring-fenced affiliate only on arm’s length terms.

question: When a firm has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits and must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views, what is the FSCS required to do after it receives the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, and what are the relevant timeframes for both the firm’s submission and the FSCS’s response (including the purpose tied to compensation time limits in 9.2)?
gold_answer: A firm that has received a Part 4A permission to accept deposits is required to deliver single customer views and exclusions views to the FSCS within three months of receiving that permission. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] Once the FSCS has received the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 (which would include the information the firm provides from its SCV system), the FSCS must, within six months of receiving that required information, advise the PRA on two specific points: first, whether the information produced by the firm’s SCV system is capable of being submitted to the FSCS; and second, whether that information is compatible with the FSCS’s systems. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] The FSCS’s assessment is explicitly linked to operational readiness to enable the FSCS to pay compensation within the time limits set out in 9.2, so the advice to the PRA must address capability and compatibility in that context. [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74] In practical terms, the combined timing framework is that the firm’s three-month delivery obligation starts from receipt of the Part 4A permission, while the FSCS’s six-month period starts from its receipt of the information required by 12.2 or 12.5, and culminates in a formal communication to the PRA. [#TGT:01013ac4ba4ac357] [#SRC:615a56bb461bcd74]
source_text: The FSCS must, within six months of receiving the information required by 12.2 or 12.5 , advise the PRA whether the information provided by a firm’s SCV system is capable of being submitted to the FSCS and whether it is compatible with the FSCS’s systems to enable it to pay compensation within the time limits contained in 9.2 .
target_text: A firm must provide the FSCS with single customer views and exclusions views within three months of receiving a Part 4A permission to accept deposits .

question: For a firm that is a UK ISPV, who must sign the record referred to in 5.4 (including each updated version), given that 5.4 applies with a modified meaning for “key function holder”?
gold_answer: For a firm that is a UK ISPV, the signature requirement for the 5.4 record applies, but the person described as the “key function holder” is treated as a PRA senior management function holder for this purpose. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] Accordingly, the record in 5.4 and every updated version must be signed by (i) the relevant PRA senior management function holder (standing in for the key function holder) and (ii) an appropriate representative of the firm. [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715] This means the firm should ensure that, whenever the 5.4 record is created or updated, the required two signatories are obtained: one being the PRA senior management function holder (because the UK ISPV modification changes who counts as the key function holder), and the other being an appropriate representative of the firm. [#SRC:72db45975ca3958c] The obligation extends to each updated version, so the firm must repeat the signing process on updates rather than relying only on the original signatures. [#TGT:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]
source_text: The requirements in 5.4 and 5.6 apply to a firm that is a UK ISPV as if any reference to a key function holder were a reference to a PRA senior management function holder .
target_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .

question: When a TWD firm is working out its projected exit costs from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, what numbers does it compare to calculate the exit cost for positions it plans to novate, terminate, or liquidate under the TWD scenario?
gold_answer: To project exit costs as part of its wind-down planning, a TWD firm should calculate exit costs using the specific comparison set out for the TWD scenario and then ensure those amounts can be projected from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310] For any positions that the firm expects to novate, terminate, or liquidate under the actions, arrangements and measures of the TWD scenario, the exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under that TWD scenario and the accounting book value of those positions. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] Practically, this means the firm first identifies which positions fall within the planned TWD actions (novation, termination, or liquidation) and then computes the difference between the scenario-based expected exit value and the book value for each such position. [#TGT:de5e0b682bbd3308] Those calculated gaps are the exit-cost amounts the firm should be able to project over time from the assumed reference date through the wind-down period, alongside its projections for operational costs, capital resource impacts and requirements, liquidity and funding, and RBLs. [#SRC:80164e310f0e8310]
source_text: TWD firms should be able to project their exit costs, 24 operational costs, 25 capital resource impacts and requirements, 26 liquidity and funding, 27 and RBLs from the assumed reference date 28 of the TWD option through the wind-down period.
target_text: 24. An exit cost is the gap between the expected exit value under the TWD scenario and accounting book value for positions to be novated, terminated or liquidated under the actions, arrangements and measures for the TWD scenario.

question: If a society wants to send the transfer notification statement to its members, what does it need to do to get PRA approval, and what will the PRA send back to show approval (and what extra copies might the society be asked to provide later)?
gold_answer: The society must ensure the transfer notification statement is approved by the PRA before it is sent to members, so the approval process needs to be completed first. [#SRC:fd3cb3782a25a1b2] In general, the society’s application for approval should follow the procedure described in paragraphs 4.97 to 4.103, and the final draft of the statement should be submitted together with the relevant documents listed in paragraph 4.102, adjusted to fit the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to include. [#SRC:fd3cb3782a25a1b2] The PRA’s approval of the Transfer Statement is then evidenced by the PRA returning to the society one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement that includes the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA, with the PRA’s statement of approval given as set out in Appendix 1. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be] After the printed materials are available, the society will be asked to provide 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and any Transfer Summary to the PRA. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be] Separately, while there is no statutory requirement to put the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary on the society’s public file, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and Transfer Statement (if printed separately) to be placed on the public file because they are public documents. [#TGT:05aab10da9a991be]
source_text: The transfer notification statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraphs 4.97 to 4.103 , and the final draft of the statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 4.102 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain.
target_text: The PRA’s statement of approval of the Transfer Statement will be given as is set out in Appendix 1 . The PRA’s approval of the Transfer Statement will be confirmed by returning to the society one authenticated copy of the Transfer Statement with the PRA’s certificate of approval signed by an authorised signatory for the PRA. The society will be asked to give 50 copies of the printed Transfer Document and Transfer Summary, if any, to the PRA when they are available. There is no statutory requirement for copies of the Transfer Statement and Transfer Summary to be placed on the public file of a society but, because they are both public documents, the PRA will arrange for copies of the Transfer Document and Transfer Statement, if printed separately, to be placed on the public file.

question: If the transferor society(ies) and the transferee or successor society integrate their product lines and this leads to changes in the terms for PIBS 26, what is PIBS 26 and how should that affect how you describe the change?
gold_answer: You should describe the change to PIBS 26 as a change to “Permanent interest-bearing shares,” and note that this product is a type of deferred share, because that is the definition given for PIBS 26. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] The change you are describing falls within the stated scope of “any changes to the terms and conditions” for CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26, and share and deposit accounts, and that scope explicitly includes changes connected to integrating the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203] So, when integration causes PIBS 26 terms to be updated, the write-up should not treat PIBS 26 as just another account label; it should reflect that the affected item is a permanent interest-bearing share (a deferred share type) whose terms and conditions are being amended as part of the integration. [#TGT:91aeec4ad31299e3] This links the product definition to the integration-driven term changes that the text identifies as in scope. [#SRC:3bbbda00879e9203]
source_text: (a) any changes to the terms and conditions of CCDS, PPDS, PIBS 26 and share and deposit accounts, including the integration of the product lines of the transferor society(ies) into those of the transferee or successor society;
target_text: 26. Permanent interest-bearing shares, a type of deferred share.

question: If 2.1(3) applies and the parent is an insurance holding company with no head office in the UK or Gibraltar (or a third country insurance/reinsurance undertaking), what do you do in the group solvency calculation for 20.1, and how does that connect to which rule blocks (4–14, 16–19 and External Audit 2–4) apply at the parent level unless there’s an exception?
gold_answer: When 2.1(3) applies, the group solvency calculation for the purpose of 20.1 must be done by having the relevant insurance group undertaking treat the parent undertaking—where it is an insurance holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking—as a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies, but only for that calculation. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] At the same time, the framework for what applies at the parent level is that, when 2.1(3) applies, modules 4 to 14, 16 to 19 and External Audit 2 to 4 apply with any necessary changes at the level of that parent undertaking, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8] So you link the two by (i) using the “treat as a UK Solvency II firm” approach to run the 20.1 group solvency computation, and (ii) recognising that the parent-level compliance baseline includes those specified modules and external audit provisions (subject to the “unless” carve-out), even though the solvency treatment is expressly limited to the calculation context. [#SRC:9faaabced2ba31fb] [#TGT:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]
source_text: When calculating the solvency of a group falling within 2.1(3) for the purpose of 20.1 , a relevant insurance group undertaking must treat the parent undertaking (being an insurance holding company which does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar or a third country insurance undertaking or a third country reinsurance undertaking ), solely for the purposes of that calculation, as a UK Solvency II firm to which 2.1(1)(a) applies.

question: If an insurer is thinking about paying a dividend, what does the PRA expect it to be able to show, and does the same kind of check apply if the payment is instead a return of premiums to members of a mutual or a loan to a parent/holding company?
gold_answer: The insurer should be able to show that any planned dividend payment makes sense when compared to (1) how the business has performed and is expected to perform and (2) the insurer’s capital position now and in the future, and it should do this while taking its documented risk appetite into account. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] This is not limited to dividends in a narrow sense: the same assessment is meant to cover distributions to any capital providers, which can include returning premiums to the members of a mutual and making a loan to a parent or holding company. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9] In practice, the insurer should prepare an explanation (and supporting analysis) that links the planned payment or transfer to actual and projected business performance and to current and future capital strength, and shows how those factors were considered against the risk appetite that has been documented. [#SRC:7acd5cecad84d469] If the transaction is a return of premiums or a loan to a parent/holding company, it should still be treated as a distribution to a capital provider and assessed using the same appropriateness logic. [#TGT:6edb0118e73ad6e9]
source_text: When assessing potential dividend payments, 10 the PRA expects insurers to be able to demonstrate that any planned dividend payments are appropriate in relation to actual and projected business performance, as well as the current and future capital position of the insurer, taking account of its documented risk appetite.
target_text: 10. This would include here the assessment made for distributions to any capital providers, including for a return of premiums to the members of a mutual, or for a loan to a parent or holding company.

question: When increasing a firm’s exposure amount to assets under the rule that adds in dependants’ exposures, how must the exposure of each dependant be determined, and how does that determination feed into the firm-level increase?
gold_answer: To increase the firm’s exposure to a given asset description, the firm must add an amount that represents any exposure its dependants have to assets of that same description, but the dependant exposures used for that increase must be computed in a specific way. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] In particular, for the purposes of the firm-level mechanism that brings dependants into the exposure amount, each dependant’s exposure is not taken as a raw figure; instead, it must be calculated by applying the same asset-exposure determination provisions (18 to 22) to that dependant as though the dependant were itself a firm to which those provisions apply, regardless of whether it actually is. [#SRC:d0975ff530ed6e30] This creates a two-step linkage: first, determine the firm’s own exposure to assets in accordance with 18 to 22; second, determine each dependant’s exposure to assets of that description using 18 to 22 applied to the dependant on a “treat as a firm” basis, and then increase the firm’s amount by the resulting dependant exposure amount (if any). [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] [#SRC:d0975ff530ed6e30]
source_text: For the purposes of 23.1 , the exposure of each dependant must be calculated by applying 18 to 22 to that dependant as if it were a firm to which those provisions apply (whether it is or not).
target_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.

question: If a society has already passed the Transfer Resolutions, what must it do before the transfer can take effect, and what should the directors do (with external auditors or other advisers) to make sure the society can meet the PRA’s expectations when applying for approval of the Transfer Statement and later seeking confirmation?
gold_answer: Once the Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the way the PRA directs, and the transfer cannot take effect unless and until the PRA confirms it. [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] To support that process, the directors should first check—together with the society’s external auditors or other advisers—that the society’s systems can produce the required information, because the PRA will ask for an assurance about that systems capability when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] The directors should also plan for the confirmation stage as a separate PRA decision point, because the PRA considers (among its confirmation criteria) whether any relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not met, which means gaps in process or information readiness can matter at confirmation even if the society is already moving through the application steps. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5] Practically, this means sequencing internal assurance work so it is available for the Transfer Statement approval application while also ensuring the overall transfer process is compliant before the PRA considers confirmation and any representations. [#SRC:6f71cdabf69e733c] [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]
source_text: The directors of a society contemplating a transfer must satisfy themselves, in consultation with their external auditors, or other advisers, that the society’s systems are capable of delivering the information described above. The PRA will require an assurance on this point when the society applies for approval of the Transfer Statement. One of the criteria which the PRA has to consider at the confirmation stage is whether some relevant requirement of the 1986 Act or the Rules was not fulfilled (see section ‘ Confirmation ’).
target_text: No transfer can take effect until it has been confirmed by the PRA. This section first describes the form of application and public notice required. It then explains the PRA view of how the statutory Confirmation Criteria should be interpreted. Finally, it gives guidance on the procedure customarily followed by the PRA when considering confirmation applications and hearing representations. Sections 97(4)(d) and 98(2) of, together with Part II of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, provide that when the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in such manner as the PRA may direct.

question: If the PRA makes a supervisory decision and it ends up issuing a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, what does the PRA normally do about publishing, and what details does it have to publish about the notice?
gold_answer: If a supervisory decision results in a Decision Notice or a Final Notice, the PRA will usually publish the action taken, but it still looks at the circumstances of each case and this usual approach is limited by the “subject to paragraph 7 above” condition. [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6] Separately, the PRA has a legal duty to publish information about the matters that the notice is about, and it can choose the way it publishes that information. [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] Putting these together, publication is not just about announcing that action happened after the supervisory decision; it also involves publishing notice-related information describing the matters covered by the Decision Notice or Final Notice (and, more generally, a Supervisory Notice). [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02] [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6] So, when the PRA reaches the stage of issuing a Decision Notice or Final Notice, it should (i) apply its normal practice of publishing the action unless the paragraph 7 qualification changes that outcome, and (ii) ensure that what it publishes includes information about the matters to which the notice relates, using a publication method it considers appropriate. [#SRC:5550fe5863fdebc6] [#TGT:3f4677fb85844f02]
source_text: The PRA will consider the circumstances of each case, but, subject to paragraph 7 above, will ordinarily publish action in relation to supervisory decisions when this has led to the issue of a Decision Notice, as well as where it has led to the issue of a Final Notice.
target_text: Section 391 of the Act also requires the PRA to publish – in such manner as it considers appropriate – information about the matters to which a Supervisory Notice, 22 a Decision Notice, and a Final Notice relate.

question: Where an institution is a client and seeks to calculate own funds requirements for its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member under Article 306 (subject to the stated conditions), how does the rule for a multi-level client structure constrain a lower-level client’s ability to apply the relevant treatment, and what must be true across the structure for the calculation approach to be available?
gold_answer: An institution that is a client may use the Article 306 calculation approach for own funds requirements on its trade exposures for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member only if the specified conditions for that approach are satisfied, and this is not displaced by the separate rule on multi-level client structures. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] Where the institution is a lower-level client accessing CCP services through a higher-level client in a multi-level client structure, the institution’s ability to apply the relevant treatment is constrained by an “all levels” condition: it may apply the treatment referenced for lower-level clients only if the conditions attached to the applicable paragraph are met at every level of the multi-level structure. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] In practice, this means the institution cannot treat compliance at its own level as sufficient; it must ensure that the conditions required by the relevant treatment paragraph are satisfied not just for itself, but also for each intermediary level through which it accesses the CCP. [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b] Accordingly, when the institution is relying on the client-based calculation approach for CCP-related transactions with its clearing member, it must also check whether it sits within a multi-level client structure and, if so, confirm that the paragraph-specific conditions are met throughout the chain, because the treatment is only available on that basis. [#TGT:f48ac02bd8cb89e1] [#SRC:d88f25a3c77baa2b]

question: If a merger includes a payment to members that might count as a bonus, what has to be written in the Statement and what member approvals are needed in the Merger Resolutions, especially when the total gross cost (before any corporation tax recovery adjustment) is above or below the prescribed limit?
gold_answer: If the merger involves a payment to members that is treated as a bonus, you need to cover it in two places: the Statement and the Merger Resolutions, and the number of societies whose resolutions must include the approval depends on the prescribed-limit test. The Statement has to spell out the bonus (if any) that will be paid to members as consideration for the merger. [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] Separately, members must approve bonus payments as part of the Merger Resolutions, and the PRA’s view on what may constitute a bonus is referenced in that context. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] To decide how widely the approval must be included, use the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) and do not reduce it for any expected corporation tax recovery. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If that gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval only needs to appear in each Merger Resolution of the society whose funds are being distributed; if it is over the limit, the approval must be included in each Merger Resolution of every participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This ensures the Statement’s required disclosure matches the resolutions needed to authorise paying the bonus. [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]
source_text: Paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act requires the Statement to specify the bonus, if any, to be paid to members in consideration of the merger. The PRA’s views on what may, or may not, be regarded as bonus are given in paragraphs 3.41 to 3.42 , and the statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: When setting priorities for investment and designing recovery and response arrangements using impact tolerances, how should a firm align its regular testing in severe but plausible disruption scenarios so that the testing approach matches what impact tolerances are intended to measure (including what the testing should not concentrate on)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat impact tolerances as the board and senior management’s benchmark for prioritising investment and for shaping recovery and response arrangements, and then design its regular testing to demonstrate it can stay within those tolerances during severe but plausible disruption scenarios. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] Because impact tolerances are framed on the assumption that a disruption has already happened, the firm’s testing should be oriented to operating within the tolerance during an incident rather than being built around incident-prevention objectives. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] In practice, this means the firm should use the same tolerance standard that guides investment prioritisation and recovery/response planning as the yardstick for scenario tests, so the tests evidence whether the planned recovery and response arrangements are sufficient to keep the firm within tolerance when disruption occurs. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55] During real operational disruptions, impact tolerances can also inform decision-making alongside other incident-management information; the testing approach should therefore support that decision-use by focusing on recovery and response performance under disruption conditions. [#SRC:51a4e8e33523d5d5] The PRA’s expectation to focus on recovery and response arrangements reinforces this alignment between how tolerances are used for planning and what scenario testing is intended to validate. [#TGT:2ff0a61603b1ca55]
source_text: Impact tolerances provide a standard which boards and senior management should use for prioritising investment and making recovery and response arrangements (see Chapters 4 to 6 of this SS). They may be helpful in informing decision-making during operational disruptions, when they would be considered alongside other information relevant to managing an incident effectively.
target_text: The Operational Resilience Parts 22 require firms to test regularly their ability to remain within impact tolerances in severe but plausible disruption scenarios. Impact tolerances assume a disruption has occurred, and so testing the ability to remain within impact tolerances should not focus on preventing incidents from occurring. The PRA expects firms to focus on recovery and response arrangements.

question: When a firm is calculating surplus funds and deciding whether an own funds item qualifies as Tier 1 own funds, how should it use the PRA Rulebook’s Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts together with the requirement to classify certain basic own funds items as Tier 1 where they display all of the features set out in 3B (and are deemed to substantially possess the characteristics in 3.5 taking into account 3.6)?
gold_answer: A firm should approach Tier 1 classification in a way that links its surplus-funds calculation work to the PRA Rulebook’s Own Funds framework, and then apply the specific Tier 1 classification trigger for basic own funds items that meet the 3B feature set. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] In practice, when calculating surplus funds and assessing Tier 1 eligibility, the firm should refer to the Surplus Funds and Own Funds Parts of the PRA Rulebook, using Own Funds 3A to identify the relevant own funds items and Own Funds 3B to evaluate the features that determine whether an item is Tier 1. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e] For basic own funds items, the firm must treat the listed items as substantially having the characteristics described in 3.5, assessed with the features in 3.6 in mind, and must classify those items as Tier 1 own funds when (and only when) the items display all of the features set out in 3B. [#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4] This means the firm’s item identification step (Own Funds 3A) and its feature-based Tier 1 determination (Own Funds 3B) should be applied consistently with the mandatory classification outcome for basic own funds items that satisfy the full 3B feature set. [#SRC:e91fa3d6305dd52e][#TGT:6b2cbcf4cc3413b4]

question: When setting the absolute minimum level of financial resources for a solvent exit, how should a firm treat the possibility of using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg the Discount Window Facility), and what cost categories must be considered alongside any asset-sale losses below book value?
gold_answer: In setting its absolute minimum level of financial resources for a solvent exit, the firm should treat the anticipated use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility) as a relevant planning assumption that triggers consultation of the Bank of England Market Operations Guide for further detail on those facilities. [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073] At the same time, the firm must still identify a minimum financial-resources level below which there is no reasonable prospect of successfully executing the solvent exit, and it should do so by recognising that the solvent exit itself is likely to generate additional costs beyond any funding considerations. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] In particular, the firm should account for potential losses (or “haircuts”) arising from selling assets or portfolios below book value, and it should also include other exit-related cost categories such as fees for specialist services, redundancy and retention payments, contract termination penalties, and pension fund deficits. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] The practical implication is that even if the firm expects to access a Bank of England facility, the minimum resources threshold should be calibrated to cover these identified exit costs and not be set so low that a solvent exit would no longer be reasonably achievable. [#SRC:34d82b030223f2b2] [#TGT:0bca7830398dd073]
source_text: The firm should take into account that the solvent exit itself is likely to lead to additional costs. In addition to costs to cover possible losses (or ‘haircuts’) on the sale of assets or portfolios below book value, these costs may include fees for specialist services, redundancy and retention payments, contract termination penalties, and pension fund deficits. The firm should also identify the absolute minimum level of financial resources needed, below which there would be no reasonable prospect of successfully executing a solvent exit. 29
target_text: 29. If the firm anticipates use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg Discount Window Facility), see more details in the ‘Bank of England Market Operations Guide’: www.bankofengland.co.uk/markets/bank-of-england-market-operations-guide .

question: In a model write-up, what do you need to say about the model’s “operating boundaries,” and what does it mean for model risk if the model is used outside that range (for example, in a stressed economy)?
gold_answer: In the model write-up, you need to describe the model’s purpose and use, including what product or portfolio it relates to, how the model is meant to be used versus how it is actually used, and the model operating boundaries within which performance is expected to be acceptable. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] Here, “operating boundaries” should be set out as the sample data range used to measure model performance, and if the model is multivariate that range also covers the empirical variance-covariance relationships present in the sample. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] You should then link this boundary definition to the intended/actual use comparison by stating whether actual use stays inside the sample data range used for performance assessment or whether it goes beyond it. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f] If the model is used by extrapolating beyond its operating boundaries, that use should be treated as involving increased model risk, including where the extrapolation relates to macroeconomic indices under shock or stressed economic conditions. [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] This makes the boundary description actionable: it is not just a label, but a condition for when performance expectations apply and when risk is assumed to rise. [#SRC:eee778735c44195f]

question: How should institutions perform risk-category mapping for a derivative transaction when applying the rule that mapping is based on the primary risk driver, but the transaction has more than one material risk driver across one or multiple risk categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must reconcile the instruction to map on the basis of the primary risk driver (which is defined as the only material risk driver) with the derogation that addresses transactions with more than one material risk driver. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1] Specifically, the mapping approach in the derogation applies when a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, requiring mapping to more than one risk category. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers for that transaction fall within a single risk category, the institution maps the transaction only once to that category, using the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for the mapping. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the institution maps the transaction once to each risk category in which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, and for each such category uses the most material risk driver in that category to determine the mapping. [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In contrast, where mapping is conducted on the basis of the primary risk driver, the mapping is based on that primary risk driver and the primary risk driver is treated as the only material risk driver of the derivative transaction. [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.
target_text: Institutions shall conduct the mapping referred to in paragraph 1 on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction. The primary risk driver shall be the only material risk driver of a derivative transaction.

question: If a firm wants to use a matching adjustment when working out the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations, what permission does it need first, and what key confirmations/evidence should be in its initial MA application so the PRA can be satisfied?
gold_answer: Before a firm uses a matching adjustment in the calculation of the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations (by applying it to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure), it must have a matching adjustment permission. [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d] The way to get to that point is through an MA application under the IRPR regulations, where the PRA must be satisfied that the firm meets the MA eligibility conditions in regulation 4 of the IRPR regulations and Chapter 2 of the Matching Adjustment Part. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] In its initial MA application, the firm must include written confirmation that it complies with the MA eligibility conditions. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] The text also indicates that, for regulation 4(4) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 2.2(6), firms are expected to provide this written confirmation. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] For the other MA eligibility conditions, the firm is expected to add documentary evidence that backs up its written confirmation. [#SRC:706be7f8963a27d5] Taken together, the firm should view the permission as a prerequisite: it cannot apply the matching adjustment in the best estimate calculation unless and until that permission is in place. [#TGT:78efaa111a0c4a1d]
source_text: In order for a firm to apply an MA under the IRPR regulations, the PRA must be satisfied that the firm meets the MA eligibility conditions as set out in regulation 4 of the IRPR regulations and Chapter 2 of the Matching Adjustment Part . As required by Matching Adjustment 3.1 , a firm's initial MA application must contain written confirmation of its compliance with the MA eligibility conditions. For regulation 4(4) of the IRPR regulations and Matching Adjustment 2.2(6) , firms are expected to provide this written confirmation. For other MA eligibility conditions, firms are expected to provide documentary evidence to support their written confirmation, including:
target_text: A firm must not apply a matching adjustment to the relevant risk-free interest rate term structure to calculate the best estimate of its insurance or reinsurance obligations unless it has a matching adjustment permission .

question: If a firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3), does it still have to follow Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 for its important group business services when 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply because the parent undertaking is based in an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 (linked to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations) and regulation 14(3) applies?
gold_answer: Yes—the text sets up two different effects that you must apply together: one creates an operational resilience compliance duty for important group business services, and the other removes the application of certain numbered provisions in a specific overseas-supervision situation. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] When the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) (noting the “subject to 22.5” wording), the firm must also comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 in relation to its important group business services. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] Separately, for a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] Putting these together, you should not treat the non-application of 22.2–22.4 as cancelling the stated requirement to comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 for important group business services; instead, you apply the operational resilience duty based on the group coverage, while separately recognizing that 22.2–22.4 are switched off only when the overseas-jurisdiction and regulation 14(3) conditions are met. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , the firm must also comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 in relation to its important group business services .

question: When assessing whether a firm has adequate financial resources to execute a solvent exit and meet depositor (and other creditor) liabilities, how should the firm treat the possibility of using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg the Discount Window Facility) alongside its capital, funding, and liquidity analysis, including realistic exit valuations and sensitivity analysis?
gold_answer: In assessing whether it has sufficient financial resources to complete a solvent exit and satisfy liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), the firm should treat anticipated use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility) as a relevant consideration within its overall funding and liquidity planning, rather than ignoring it. [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890] The assessment itself must cover financial resources in the round—capital, funding, and liquidity—at a level that can absorb the full costs of the solvent exit and meet all such liabilities, using realistic exit valuations of assets and liabilities. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] To make that assessment credible, the firm should perform appropriate analysis, including sensitivity analyses of factors that could change the resources needed, and specific analysis of balance sheet items that may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] Where the firm anticipates drawing on Bank of England facilities, that expectation should be incorporated into the funding and liquidity element of the resources assessment so the firm can evaluate, through its sensitivity work and exit valuations, whether the combined resources (including any anticipated facility usage) remain sufficient to cover exit costs and liabilities under realistic conditions. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890]
source_text: financial resources, including capital, funding, and liquidity, 55 to absorb the full costs of the solvent exit and meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), with realistic exit valuations of assets and liabilities and appropriate analysis conducted (such as sensitivity analyses of factors that may impact the resources needed, and an analysis of any balance sheet items which may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of)
target_text: 55. This includes whether the firm anticipates the use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg Discount Window Facility). See the ‘Bank of England Market Operations Guide’ for further details.

question: When applying Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook (including Rule 4.6), how should a firm treat the fundamental spread component—specifically the portion reflecting risks retained by the firm—given that the fundamental spread is calculated under rules 4.10 to 4.17?
gold_answer: A firm must exclude from the matching adjustment any fundamental spread element that reflects risks retained by the firm, even where the fundamental spread itself is determined using the calculation approach in rules 4.10 to 4.17. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] This exclusion is framed within Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, where Rule 4.6 (restating relevant IRPR provisions) establishes that the matching adjustment is not permitted to include the fundamental spread to the extent it represents risks the firm keeps. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0] In practice, the firm may still calculate the fundamental spread in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17, but it must ensure that the matching adjustment outcome does not incorporate the part of that fundamental spread that corresponds to retained risks. [#TGT:9bbf6a9cc239d53c] The compliance focus is therefore on the composition of the matching adjustment (what it includes or excludes), not on altering the prescribed method for calculating the fundamental spread under 4.10 to 4.17. [#SRC:9242ee9283fd69c0]
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, which restates the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations, sets out (at Rule 4.6 ) that the matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread reflecting the risks retained by the firm.
target_text: The matching adjustment must not include the fundamental spread (as calculated in accordance with 4.10 to 4.17 ) reflecting the risks retained by the firm .

question: Where a firm must have policies and procedures to ensure compliance by its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or tied agents) and to counter financial crime risk, what specific governance responsibility is described for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm)?
gold_answer: The firm’s compliance framework should combine (i) firm-wide policies and procedures designed to secure regulatory compliance and reduce financial crime risk, and (ii) a clearly assigned governance responsibility for the compliance function itself. The firm must have adequate policies and procedures that are sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm, including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or, where applicable, tied agents), with obligations under the regulatory system, and that also address the risk the firm could be used to further financial crime. [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304] In addition to that firm-wide control environment, there is an explicit responsibility for safeguarding the independence of the compliance function and overseeing its performance. [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789] This oversight responsibility extends to monitoring the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm, and it is framed as being carried out in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K). [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789] Taken together, the policies/procedures obligation sets the baseline for compliance and financial crime controls across relevant personnel, while the governance responsibility ensures the compliance function remains independent and effectively supervised, including where an FCA-approved individual performs compliance oversight for the firm. [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304] [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789]
source_text: (16) responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function, including the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm , in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K) ;
target_text: A firm must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents ) with its obligations under the regulatory system and for countering the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime .

question: In solvent exit planning, what must a firm do regarding deposits and timing/resources, and how does this interact with the position that a solvent exit may not involve liquidation—particularly where the firm is a building society that will cease to meet the principal purpose test and may need dissolution steps under the Building Societies Act 1986?
gold_answer: A firm’s solvent exit planning should be structured to ensure it can stop its PRA-regulated deposit-taking in an orderly way while remaining solvent, and it should treat the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits as a core deliverable of that process. [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] In practice, the firm should build in sufficient time and resources so it can meet liabilities as they fall due while it transfers and/or repays all deposits, and it should plan for the solvent exit to conclude with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission or the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (i.e., removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). [#SRC:a9dcecc8a5a3b33a] At the same time, the firm should not assume that completing a solvent exit necessarily means liquidation, because whether liquidation occurs depends on the circumstances. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654] Where the firm is a building society, it should explicitly link its deposit transfer/repayment plan to the consequence that doing so will cause it to cease meeting the principal purpose test, and it should therefore also take into account any steps necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986. [#TGT:401295982d2ab654]
source_text: A solvent exit means the process through which a firm ceases its PRA-regulated activities while remaining solvent. 2 The firm should transfer 3 or repay (or both) all deposits as part of its solvent exit. 4 In the firm’s solvent exit planning, it should build in sufficient time and resources to support the firm in meeting liabilities when they fall due and in transferring and/or repaying all deposits. At a point after this, a solvent exit will end with the removal of deposit-taking activity from the firm’s Part 4A permission, or with the cancellation of the firm’s Part 4A permission (hereinafter referred to as the removal of the firm’s Part 4A PRA permission). 5
target_text: 4. A solvent exit does not necessarily result in the liquidation of the firm, as it depends on the circumstances. If the firm is a building society, the transfer and/or repayment of all deposits will mean it ceases to meet the principal purpose test. Therefore, a building society should also take into account steps which are necessary for it to be dissolved under the Building Societies Act 1986.

question: If a firm wants to back TPs with an intragroup loan to another group company, what does it need to show about how the asset is invested, and why does the PRA say it is hard to prove this kind of loan is suitable?
gold_answer: To use an intragroup loan as an asset backing TPs, the firm needs to be able to show that the asset is invested in a way that matches the nature and duration of the firm’s insurance and reinsurance liabilities and that it is in the best interests of all policyholders, while also considering any disclosed policy objectives. [#SRC:afb7633ef682266c] The PRA highlights that intragroup loans (and similar participations or arrangements) can be problematic under this standard because they may benefit shareholders without necessarily benefiting policyholders. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] The PRA also notes a specific risk: the issuer of the loan may be less willing or able to enforce repayment, particularly for upstream loans, which can undermine the case that the arrangement protects policyholders’ interests. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] Because of these concerns, the PRA expects there is a high hurdle for firms to demonstrate that intragroup loans and participations are in policyholders’ best interests, and therefore a high hurdle to demonstrate they are appropriate for covering TPs. [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024] This means the firm’s explanation must satisfy both the general investment standard for TP-backing assets and the PRA’s heightened scrutiny for intragroup transactions. [#SRC:afb7633ef682266c] [#TGT:19e81bc332eae024]
source_text: In respect of assets backing TPs, the PPP requires that these must be invested ‘in a manner appropriate to the nature and duration of the firm’s insurance and reinsurance liabilities and in the best interests of all policyholders, taking into account any disclosed policy objectives’. 39
target_text: The requirement for assets backing TPs to be invested in policyholders’ best interests has particular implications for certain intragroup transactions such as intragroup loans and participations or arrangements to that effect. Investments in, or loans to, other group companies may be in the interests of shareholders but they may not necessarily be in the best interests of policyholders. For example, the issuers of loans may be less willing or able to enforce repayment, particularly where loans are upstream. The PRA expects that it would be a high hurdle for firms to demonstrate that intragroup loans and participations are in the best interests of policyholders and, as such, a high hurdle to demonstrate that they are appropriate for covering TPs.

question: If a firm’s MA asset gets upgraded, can it keep the asset in the MA portfolio, and how much of the asset’s cash flows can it still count when its ‘sufficient compensation’ test is built around matching the relevant MA liabilities and being able to buy a replacement asset of at least the original quality?
gold_answer: Yes, the PRA indicates the firm would not necessarily have to take the upgraded asset out of the MA portfolio, but that depends on whether the firm’s own ‘sufficient compensation’ criteria are set up to handle foreseeable events like an upgrade and are effective for judging whether compensation is sufficient. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] The PRA also describes a way those criteria may be constructed: by linking them to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows and to the firm’s ability to buy a replacement asset of at least as good quality as the original if the issuer changes the cash flows, so the matching can continue. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3] Under that approach, the firm may recognise only part of the asset’s cash flows—specifically, it can continue to recognise cash flows up to the level of the contractual compensation payable—so that compensation remains sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match the relevant MA eligible liabilities. [#SRC:3c15a9bfcd564fbd] The firm is expected to be able to show the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in the earlier assessment referenced in the TARGET passage, and the partial-recognition approach is described as being subject to the partial-recognition considerations referenced there. [#TGT:af842f40700e6ff3]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to consider how their own criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ cater for foreseeable events such as an asset being upgraded. The PRA considers that in such upgrade events, a firm would not necessarily need to remove the asset from the MA portfolio, if its own criteria provide for this (and to the extent that those criteria were effective in assessing whether compensation would be sufficient, taking into account paragraph 2.37 above). For example, where sufficiency of compensation criteria follow the approach described in paragraph 2.41 above, the firm might continue to recognise the asset’s cash flows up to the level of the compensation payable, ie so that the asset’s compensation would remain sufficient to replace the cash flows needed to match relevant MA eligible liabilities.
target_text: The PRA’s view is that it may be possible for firms’ criteria for assessing ‘sufficient compensation’ to be devised by reference to the relevant MA liabilities being matched by the recognised asset cash flows, together with the ability to purchase an asset of at least as good quality as the original to replace these cash flows in the event they are changed by the issuer, ie to ensure that this matching continues. The PRA expects a firm to be able to demonstrate the same level of confidence in its ability to replace cash flows as in its assessment in paragraph 2.39 above. This may, in practice, mean that the firm would recognise part of the asset’s cash flows up to the level of contractual compensation payable, subject to the considerations relating to partial recognition set out in paragraphs 2.15 to 2.16A above.

question: For a general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006, how should the insurer integrate its PRA Rulebook obligations (including ORSA) with the PRA’s stated approach in SS3/14, and what specific SS3/14 document identification details must be used to ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied?
gold_answer: A general insurer in run-off proposing a scheme of arrangement under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006 should treat its PRA Rulebook duties—specifically the Risk Management chapter in the Conditions Governing Business Part, including the requirement to carry out an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA)—as continuing compliance obligations, while also applying the PRA’s supervisory approach set out in SS3/14, because the two supervisory statements are intended to be read together for that population. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] To ensure the correct supervisory statement is being applied, the insurer should identify SS3/14 by its full title and publication details: “The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006,” issued as PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14 in April 2014, with the referenced web location provided for that statement. [#TGT:8d6a107327860924] In practice, this means the insurer should not treat the scheme process as displacing PRA Rulebook expectations (including ORSA), but instead align scheme planning and execution with the PRA’s scheme-focused supervisory approach described in SS3/14, using the specified SS3/14 identification details to avoid applying the wrong document. [#SRC:23f45218074bd197] [#TGT:8d6a107327860924]
source_text: Insurers must comply with relevant provisions in the PRA Rulebook including the Risk Management chapter of the Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook, which includes requirements to undertake an Own Risk and Solvency Assessment (ORSA). This supervisory statement complements another PRA supervisory statement – SS3/14 ‘The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to Schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006’ 1 and the two should be read together for general insurers in run-off.
target_text: 1. PRA Supervisory Statement 3/14, ‘The Prudential Regulation Authority’s (PRA’s) approach to schemes of arrangement proposed by PRA-authorised insurers under Part 26 of the Companies Act 2006’, April 2014; www.bankofengland.co.uk/pra/Pages/publications/schemesss.aspx .

question: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies so that specified requirements must be applied “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, how should a firm ensure its risk-management system addresses risks both individually and on an aggregated basis, and which referenced requirement set is being applied at group level to support that outcome?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the firm must apply the listed requirement sets “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, meaning the firm should treat those requirements as operating on a group-wide basis rather than only on a solo-entity basis. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] In that group-level context, the firm’s risk-management system must be designed and maintained so it can identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks continuously both for each relevant unit (individual level) and across the group as a whole (aggregated level), including how risks interact with each other (interdependencies). [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] Practically, this means the group-level application should be used to ensure the risk-management system includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that work across the group and can produce both entity-specific and consolidated risk views on an ongoing basis. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] The referenced requirement sets that are expressly to be applied at group level include, among others, Conditions Governing Business (including 2.2 to 2.6 and 2A.1 to 2A.6), Fitness and Propriety (including 2.1 to 2.3, 4.1, 4.3 and 4.4), Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: How should a firm populate and structure the single customer view and exclusions view when certain data items in the required information set are not held by the firm or are not applicable, given the obligation that each view must contain all information set out in the table?
gold_answer: A firm should build each single customer view (SCV) and exclusions view so that it includes the full set of fields corresponding to the required information, while leaving particular fields blank only where the firm does not hold the data or the data item does not apply. [#TGT:ad978d8ce164b1e0] Where data required for inclusion are not held or are not applicable, the firm should keep the relevant fields present in the SCV and exclusions view file but leave those fields empty, so the files remain standard in length. [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] The firm should also maintain a consistent field sequence: fields should always appear in the same order as set out in Depositor Protection 12.9, even when some fields are empty. [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] At the same time, the firm must complete all fields that are mandatory, and must also complete fields where the data are applicable and held by the firm; completion of all fields is mandatory unless the field is indicated as not applicable or not held (where not mandatory). [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa] In practice, this means the firm satisfies the requirement that each SCV and exclusions view contains all the information set out in the table by ensuring every required field exists in the file structure, while using empty values only for permitted “not held/not applicable” cases and fully populating mandatory and applicable-held data items. [#TGT:ad978d8ce164b1e0] [#SRC:697a55e1d316e0fa]
source_text: Where firms do not hold the data required to be included in the SCV or exclusions view file or the data are not applicable, corresponding fields in the SCV and exclusions view file should remain empty. Even if these fields are empty, the PRA expects these fields to remain in the SCV file and the exclusions view file, so that the files are standard in length. Fields should always appear in the same order set out in Depositor Protection 12.9 . Completion of all fields is mandatory unless otherwise indicated (ie not applicable or not held by the firm (where not mandatory)). Firms must complete all fields where data are mandatory, or where applicable and held by the firm.
target_text: A firm must ensure that each single customer view and exclusions view contains all the information set out in the table below.

question: When adjusting the value ascribed to assets under 18 to 19, in what circumstances must a firm treat assets as being deemed acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option, and how does that deemed treatment affect the increase or decrease applied for assets of the relevant description?
gold_answer: A firm must adjust the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for each asset description by adding or subtracting the value of assets of that description that the firm is treated as having acquired or disposed of under an option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] For the purposes of 20.1, that deemed acquisition or disposal arises only where, at the relevant date, the firm is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume the option will be exercised, and the option is of the type described in the rule. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] In practice, this means the firm first identifies whether, at the relevant date, it meets the option-party and prudent-assumption conditions that trigger deemed acquisition/disposal under 20.1. [#SRC:bd531cb4e2558157] If those conditions are met, the firm must then reflect the resulting deemed position directly in the 18 to 19 valuation by increasing or decreasing the value ascribed for the corresponding asset description by the value of the assets deemed acquired or disposed of. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124] The direction of the adjustment (increase versus decrease) follows whether the firm is deemed to have acquired or to have disposed of assets pursuant to the option. [#TGT:edaf68ec91a76124]
source_text: For the purposes of 20.1 , the firm must be deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets pursuant to an option if, at the relevant date , it is a party to an option and it is prudent to assume that the option will be exercised and the option is one which:
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .

question: If a firm uses its own internal credit assessments, what does the PRA expect the firm to validate about its method (including credit risk sources), and what checks must the results pass against CRA-style ratings (plausible range and no bias) so the PRA can be comfortable with the basic FS?
gold_answer: The PRA expects a firm to validate both how its internal credit assessment is built and what it produces, so the PRA can gain assurance about the appropriateness of the basic FS. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] On the “how,” the firm should validate its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, using qualitative and/or quantitative approaches. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] On the “what,” the internal credit assessment outcomes must sit within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have been produced by a CRA, and they must be broadly consistent and not biased versus CRA issue ratings when viewed at the asset type level and across the portfolio. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721] The PRA also expects the firm’s validation work to ensure the outcomes satisfy the points referenced in paragraph 2.4, meaning the validation should explicitly confirm the outcomes meet those stated expectations rather than stopping at methodology review. [#SRC:4f0228446ac0d767] Using sample assets assessed by a CRA can help show broad consistency, but the firm should not rely on credit ratings alone or in a purely mechanical way when judging creditworthiness. [#TGT:5fd5739308652721]
source_text: The PRA expects that, as part of the requirement for a firm to have an internal credit assessment process that is subject to appropriate validation as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(4) , the firm will have validated its internal credit assessment methodology and criteria, including how it has identified and allowed for all sources of credit risk, whether qualitatively or quantitatively. In addition, the PRA expects the firm’s validation to ensure that the internal credit assessment outcomes have satisfied the points in paragraph 2.4 above.
target_text: [First sentence moved to 2.4B ] As part of demonstrating that internal credit assessments are of a comparable standard to a credit rating as per Matching Adjustment 7.1(1) , Matching Adjustment 7.2(2) requires that internal credit assessment outcomes lie within the plausible range of issue ratings that could have resulted from a CRA. Matching Adjustment 7.2(3) also requires broad consistency and no bias within the plausible range between firms’ internal credit assessment outcomes and CRA issue ratings at an asset type and the portfolio level. These requirements will help to give the PRA some assurance that the basic FS is appropriate. Having sample assets assessed by a CRA will additionally help demonstrate broad consistency between a firm’s internal credit assessment outcomes and comparable CRA issue ratings. Nevertheless, firms should not solely or mechanistically rely on credit ratings for assessing the creditworthiness of an entity or financial instrument. 12

question: When forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, what is the auditor’s responsibility regarding (i) assessing whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA and (ii) opining on the validity of approvals, waivers, or other supervisory determinations, and how should those determinations be treated in the audit framework (including in the context of transitional measures on technical provisions)?
gold_answer: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, the auditor does not have to test whether the firm satisfies the eligibility conditions for use of the MA, and the auditor is also not expected to validate the correctness of any approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] Instead, approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations issued by the competent authority are inputs to the basis on which the audit opinion is formed, rather than matters the auditor re-adjudicates. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] This means the auditor’s work is framed around applying the audit opinion to the relevant reporting framework while accepting those supervisory outcomes as given. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] For transitional measures on technical provisions specifically, the framework the auditor uses should also incorporate Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital that are calculated under the previous regime, treating those amounts as part of the same framework against which the audit opinion is provided. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] Taken together, the auditor’s role is to deliver the required Rules 2.1 and 4.1 opinion without reassessing MA eligibility or second-guessing supervisory decisions, while still reflecting those decisions (and relevant transitional-measure elements) in the framework used for the opinion. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]
source_text: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, auditors are not required to assess whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA. As noted in paragraph 3.4 , auditors are not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination.
target_text: The auditor is not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination. Instead approvals, waivers and supervisory determinations provided by the competent authority should be considered as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given. For the purposes of transitional measures on technical provisions, Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities and capital calculated in accordance with the previous regime, should be treated as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given.

question: If a firm is working out the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business, what should it do when it has at least one past financial year to look at, and what amount applies if it is too new to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The firm should start by checking whether it has a preceding financial year, because that determines whether it uses an income-based table or a fixed amount. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm does have one or more preceding financial years, it must look back across those years and find its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business, then match that highest income level to the table so it can take the minimum guarantee fund amount shown for that income band. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm is too new to have a preceding financial year, it cannot apply the table method that depends on identifying the highest annual contribution income in a preceding year; in that case, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] This means the same firm could have different minimum guarantee fund outcomes depending on whether it has historical annual contribution income data from a preceding financial year (table-based) or lacks that history (the £90,000 default). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]
source_text: Subject to 6.2 , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is the amount in column 2 of the following table, which corresponds to the firm’s highest annual contribution income in respect of that business in any preceding financial year , as shown in column 1 of the table:
target_text: If a firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year , the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is £90,000.

question: When allocating responsibilities within a firm’s senior management arrangements, how should the firm treat a person who performs an FCA designated senior management function (noting the “subject to 3.6(1)” qualifier) in light of the prohibition on allocating a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function?
gold_answer: A firm must treat the prohibition as applying specifically to individuals who perform an “FCA other overall responsibility senior management function,” and it must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to such a person. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] Separately, the population of individuals who may be relevant to the firm’s senior management arrangements includes those who perform a PRA senior management function and those who perform an FCA designated senior management function, with the latter category expressly framed as being “subject to 3.6(1).” [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] In practice, this means the firm should first identify whether the individual in question is within the senior management function categories described (PRA senior management function or FCA designated senior management function, as qualified). [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903] If the individual also performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function, the firm is prohibited from allocating any prescribed responsibility to that individual, regardless of their status as a PRA senior management function holder or FCA designated senior management function holder. [#TGT:afb87828d72640b4] The “subject to 3.6(1)” wording signals that the FCA designated senior management function category is not unconditional, so the firm should apply that qualifier when determining whether the person is treated as performing that function for these purposes. [#SRC:3a4602dcc6094903]
source_text: (1) performs a PRA senior management function or, subject to 3.6 (1), an FCA designated senior management function ; and
target_text: (1) A firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function .
