question: In an amalgamation where a society is preparing its formal application to the PRA (including approval of a Schedule 16 Statement), what early-stage draft clearances are expected with the FCA and PRA, and what specific signed documents and number of copies must be sent when applying to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act?
gold_answer: For an amalgamation, the societies should treat the formal PRA application (including approval of a Schedule 16 Statement) as the endpoint of an iterative process in which PRA staff have reviewed drafts of the Statement alongside drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and related prudential information, and the societies should also have cleared the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society with both the FCA and the PRA. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] In parallel, because the FCA must be satisfied about the proposed Rules, Memorandum, and the successor society’s name, the amalgamating societies are advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] When the societies apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, they must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to both the PRA and the FCA. [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724] This sequencing links the early draft-clearance expectation (with FCA and PRA) to the later, formal submission requirement (three signed copies to each regulator) as part of progressing the amalgamation through PRA confirmation and related regulatory review. [#TGT:b82c2ae32466a535] [#SRC:4c98e92939aed724]
source_text: In the case of an amalgamation, the FCA is required to be satisfied as regards the proposed Rules, Memorandum and name of the successor society. The amalgamating societies are, therefore, advised to clear drafts of the proposed Rules and Memorandum with the FCA at an early stage (see paragraph 3.96 ). When they apply to the PRA for confirmation under Section 93(2) of the 1986 Act, the amalgamating societies must send three signed copies of the Rules and Memorandum to the PRA and the FCA (Section 93(2)(d)). If the FCA is satisfied on these matters it will, upon confirmation by the PRA , register the successor society and issue to it a certificate of incorporation specifying the date (the specified date) from which the incorporation takes effect, and will return to it one copy each of the Rules and Memorandum together with a certificate of registration. Copies are placed on the public file of the successor society.
target_text: A society’s formal application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement is likely to be the culmination of many weeks of discussion with the PRA’s staff who will have reviewed and commented upon a draft or successive drafts of the Statement, having had regard also to drafts of the Instrument of Transfer (or amalgamation agreement) and the prudential information described in ‘Preliminary matters’ . Societies should also have cleared any proposed Rule changes or, in the case of an amalgamation, the proposed Memorandum and Rules of the successor society, with the FCA and the PRA.

question: If a derivative has several material risk drivers, and one of them is a climatic conditions variable, when do you map it only once and when do you map it to more than one risk category?
gold_answer: You map the transaction to the commodity risk category when the climatic conditions variable is the primary risk driver (or the most material risk driver within a given risk category for the relevant transactions). [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] At the same time, because the transaction is a derivative with more than one material risk driver, you must map it to more than one risk category unless all of its material risk drivers fall within a single risk category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers belong to the same risk category, you map the transaction only once to that category, and you do so using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis for the mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers belong to different risk categories, you map the transaction once to each risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and for each category you use the most material risk driver in that category as the basis. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] In that multi-category case, the climatic conditions variable still drives a commodity mapping (because it is a climatic conditions variable and is primary/most material as described), while the other material drivers trigger mapping to their respective categories under the derivative multi-driver rule. [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]
source_text: (b) where the primary risk driver of a transaction, or the most material risk driver in a given risk category for transactions referred to in paragraph 3 , is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When giving notice of an application under the Business Transfers Regulations, how should the firm(s) structure the accompanying statement and summary so recipients can understand the scheme’s effect, and what must be made available on request (including whether the internet may be used), given that the notice must go to specified categories of policyholders and certain reinsurers and should explain how and when representations are to be made to the court?
gold_answer: The firm(s) should treat the application notice as a package that both reaches the required recipients and equips them to understand the scheme and participate effectively in the court process. The notice must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose reinsurance contracts are proposed to be transferred, unless the court directs otherwise. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] Alongside that notice, it would normally be appropriate to include a statement setting out the scheme’s terms and summarising the scheme report, drafted so that each recipient can grasp in broad terms how the scheme is likely to affect them; this is best achieved by a clear, concise summary that still contains enough detail, avoiding an overly long or hard-to-understand summary. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201] The notice and related communications should also explain how and when affected parties’ representations should be made so the court can consider them. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] In addition, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone who requests them, and the internet may be used to provide access where it is suitable for the person making the request. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]
source_text: It would normally be appropriate to include with the notice referred to in 2.49 above a statement setting out the terms of the scheme and containing a summary of the scheme report. Ideally every recipient should understand in broad terms from the summary how the scheme is likely to affect them. This objective will be most nearly achieved if the summary is clear and concise while containing sufficient detail for the purpose. A lengthy summary or one that was hard to understand would not be appropriate. The Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them. The internet can be used for this purpose if it is suitable for the person making the request.
target_text: Under the Business Transfers Regulations, unless the court directs otherwise, notice of the application must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) any of whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme. It may also be appropriate to give notice to others affected, for example, to anyone with an interest in the policies being transferred who has notified the transferor of their interest. This notice, along with other communications and advertising by or and on behalf of the firm(s), should provide details of how and when any representations by affected parties should be made in order to be considered by the court.

question: If a firm does both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, does it need one solvency margin or two, and how does that fit with the rule that (subject to 2.3) a firm must keep its margin at least as big as the required margin?
gold_answer: If a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business, it should apply the solvency-margin requirement as two separate margins—one for each kind of business—rather than one combined figure. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b] That approach is how the general duty to maintain a margin of solvency at least equal to the required margin is meant to operate for a dual-business firm: the firm must meet the “equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency” standard separately for long-term insurance business and for general insurance business. [#SRC:a1a38574845ced8b][#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] The rule that sets out the “must maintain” obligation is introduced with “Subject to 2.3,” so the obligation is stated as applying within that qualifier rather than being presented as unconditional in every case. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690] Also, the rule explicitly says it applies to a firm “other than a flat rate benefits business friendly society,” so that excluded category is not covered by the stated requirement. [#TGT:a6802aa70f056690]
source_text: Where a firm carries on both long-term insurance business and general insurance business , 2.1 has effect as if the requirement to maintain a margin of solvency were a requirement to maintain separate margins in respect of the two kinds of business.
target_text: Subject to 2.3 , a firm (other than a flat rate benefits business friendly society ) must maintain a margin of solvency equal to or greater than the required margin of solvency .

question: If a related undertaking’s items are treated as not effectively available to cover the group SCR (including when the related undertaking is a third country insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company), what does that mean for whether the related Solvency II undertaking’s own funds can be counted in the group solvency calculation?
gold_answer: If items of a related undertaking are assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR, that assumption frames the availability assessment for group SCR coverage across several types of related undertakings, including Solvency II undertakings, third country insurance undertakings, third country reinsurance undertakings, insurance holding companies, and mixed financial holding companies. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] Where, in that setting, certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which group solvency is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the group solvency calculation. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] The only stated exception is narrow: the own funds may be included only if, and only to the extent that, they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking itself. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] Operationally, you would (1) confirm the entity is a “related undertaking” within the types listed for the non-availability assumption, and (2) treat any own funds that are not effectively available for group SCR as excluded unless they still qualify for the related undertaking’s SCR coverage. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] This ensures group solvency reflects only own funds that are effectively available for group SCR purposes, with limited carry-through based on the related undertaking’s SCR eligibility. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]
source_text: Subject to 9.4A and 9.4B , where certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking (other than those referred to in 9.2 and 9.3 ) cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which the solvency of a group is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the calculation of the group solvency of the group unless they are, and only in so far as they are, eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking .
target_text: The following items of a related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking , third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking , insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company shall be assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR :

question: For a ring-fenced body that is considering an intragroup outsourcing arrangement that would involve entering into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, how should it align (i) the arm’s length requirement for that transaction and (ii) the PRA’s expectation that firms leverage existing operational continuity requirements and OCIR record-keeping to document intragroup dependencies and make information readily available on request?
gold_answer: A ring-fenced body should treat the proposed intragroup outsourcing as both (1) a group transaction that must be structured on arm’s length terms when the counterparty is a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, and (2) an arrangement where it may be able to use existing operational continuity frameworks and OCIR record-keeping to evidence and manage intragroup dependencies. [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] In practice, this means the firm should: (i) ensure the transaction terms with the relevant group member are arm’s length, because that is a condition on entering into the transaction at all; and (ii) where relevant, leverage compliance work already performed under Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook to help meet expectations for intragroup outsourcing (including business continuity and exit planning). [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c] [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067] To support both strands, the PRA expects firms to consider using elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, provided the relevant information is clear and can be made readily available to the PRA upon request. [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]
source_text: Where relevant, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations in respect of their intragroup outsourcing arrangements. For instance, for some banks, intragroup outsourcing arrangements may be subject to the requirements in Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook. Compliance with these requirements may also mean those banks meet certain expectations in this SS in respect of intragroup outsourcing arrangements (for instance, in respect of business continuity and exit plans (see Chapter 10 )). The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document their intragroup dependencies, as long as relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request. 23
target_text: A ring-fenced body must enter into a transaction with a member of its group which is not a ring-fenced affiliate only on arm’s length terms.

question: When explaining why SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA may not fully capture non-credit risks in securitisation, how should a firm describe the role of the framework’s “non-neutrality,” including what it means in RWA terms and which pre-defined inputs and mechanisms drive its level?
gold_answer: A firm should explain that SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA are designed to recognise only a defined set of items in calculating capital requirements, with the emphasis mainly on credit risk, so they can miss the presence of non-credit risks associated with securitisation. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] It should then link this limitation to the framework’s “non-neutrality,” noting that some additional non-credit risks arising from securitisation are, to a degree, reflected through that non-neutrality, but the extent of the effect is determined by pre-defined inputs such as STS status. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] In RWA terms, “non-neutrality” should be described as the typical outcome that the total RWAs for the securitisation tranches exceed the RWAs that would have been calculated for the same underlying portfolio if it had not been securitised. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] The firm should also identify the specific mechanisms by which SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA introduce this non-neutrality: a risk weight floor that differs by STS classification (10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions) and the supervisory “p” factor. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] Together, these points connect the methods’ credit-risk focus with the way non-neutrality can partially reflect other securitisation-related risks, while remaining driven by preset parameters. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]
source_text: The SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their calculation of capital requirements, primarily focused on credit risk. These methods may fail to recognise the presence of non-credit risks. To an extent some additional non-credit risks which can arise from securitisation are reflected in the ‘non-neutrality’ of the securitisation capital framework. 1 However the level of non-neutrality is driven by pre-defined inputs (eg STS status).
target_text: 1. ‘Non-neutrality’ of the framework here means that typically the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation will be higher than the RWAs calculated for the underlying portfolio had it not been securitised. In the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, this non-neutrality is introduced primarily through the application of a risk weight floor (10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions) and the supervisory ‘p’ factor.

question: How should a bank incorporate the possibility that the Bank may change its preferred resolution strategy into its forward planning, specifically in relation to anticipating when it will come into scope of operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) and identifying where OCIR sits in the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: A bank should treat growth-driven changes in the Bank’s preferred resolution strategy as a forward-planning trigger to anticipate when it will newly fall within the scope of additional resolvability-related policies, and then plan an orderly transition to meet them in advance. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] In particular, because the Bank may shift its preferred resolution strategy to a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy as the bank grows, the bank should proactively assess when that shift could occur and when it would therefore come into scope of operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] The bank should also ensure it can locate and use the relevant rule source for OCIR by referencing the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook (available at the specified PRA Rulebook link). [#TGT:bde23c337e322fa8] As part of this approach, the bank should remain aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and use that awareness to inform its forward planning and transition work. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] The practical compliance outcome is that the bank plans well in advance for the point at which OCIR becomes applicable and prepares to transition to meet OCIR expectations by using the Operational Continuity Part as the rulebook anchor for that policy area. [#SRC:782c0514fa3d2263] [#TGT:bde23c337e322fa8]
source_text: As a bank grows, the Bank can change its preferred resolution strategy to either a partial transfer or a bail-in resolution strategy. Banks should be aware of the PRA’s and the Bank’s Resolvability Assessment Framework (RAF) and, as part of their forward planning, anticipate when their preferred resolution strategy may change and when they will come into scope of different policies, for example the MREL 70 or operational continuity in resolution (OCIR). 71 72 Banks should plan for this well in advance and consider how they will transition to meet these policies.
target_text: 72. Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook: http://www.prarulebook.co.uk/rulebook/Content/Part/320890 .

question: For a large institution whose non-performing loans and advances ratio is at least 5%, when must it begin making the additional annual disclosures using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of UK CQ4 and UK CQ5, and how does the “two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date” condition affect the first disclosure reference date?
gold_answer: A large institution with a non-performing loans and advances ratio equal to or above 5% is required to make the specified additional disclosures on an annual basis using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 (with the related Annex XV templates and Annex XVI instructions). [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] The point at which it must commence that disclosure is when it has reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters within the four quarters preceding the disclosure’s reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] For the first disclosure reference date, the institution must disclose the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if it meets the threshold on that first disclosure reference date, even as the commencement trigger is framed by the prior two-consecutive-quarters test. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] In practice, this means the institution should (i) determine whether it is a large institution and whether its ratio meets or exceeds 5%, which establishes that the annual template set applies, and (ii) check the prior four quarters to confirm two consecutive quarters at or above 5% to identify when disclosure must start, while ensuring that on the first reference date it discloses the threshold-subject templates if it is at or above 5% on that date. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: When calculating the compensation sum for a depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits (subject to the £120,000 maximum), must the FSCS also reimburse interest that has accrued but not yet been credited at the compensation date, and how does the temporary high balance exception affect that treatment and the cap?
gold_answer: The FSCS must include reimbursement of certain unpaid interest in the compensation sum, but it must do so within the overall maximum compensation framework and subject to a specific exception. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] For eligible deposits, the FSCS is required to reimburse interest that had accrued by the compensation date but had not yet been credited, unless the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] In parallel, the maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, with the possibility of additional compensation only in cases where 4.3 or 4.4 apply. [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e] Accordingly, where accrued-but-uncredited interest is reimbursed (i.e., the temporary high balance exception does not apply), that interest payment cannot be used to push the depositor’s compensation above the applicable limit referenced in 4.2. [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f] The practical outcome is that interest reimbursement is part of the compensation calculation for eligible deposits at the compensation date, but it is constrained by the depositor-level maximum for aggregate eligible deposits (absent any separate entitlement to additional compensation under 4.3 or 4.4). [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]
source_text: Except where the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance , the FSCS shall reimburse interest owed on eligible deposits which had accrued, but has not been credited, at the compensation date . The limit provided for in 4.2 shall not be exceeded by the payment of any such interest.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: For a pooled asset exposure where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but the firm has sufficient evidence of predictability, how should the firm justify proposing use of the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks, given the PRA’s view on how event-driven cash flow variability risks should be represented and what provision is broadly equivalent to an 85th-percentile target?
gold_answer: A firm may propose applying the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks for a pooled asset exposure only where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks and there is sufficient evidence of predictability; the proposal should be framed as an approach to event risk within an exposure that is otherwise economically driven. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] In justifying that proposal, the firm should explain how its treatment of event-driven cash flow variability aligns with the PRA’s view that such risks are more likely to be captured by fatter-tailed distributions, rather than assuming thin-tailed behaviour. [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c] Where the firm is relying on more complete credible data to support more sophisticated modelling alongside (or to evidence the appropriateness of) the standard approach proposal, it should articulate how a provision equal to one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is being used as a benchmark that is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution. [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c] This linkage helps demonstrate that, even when using the standard approach for the FS addition for event risks in a predictable pooled exposure, the firm is making an adequate provision for additional retained cash flow variability risks associated with event-driven outcomes. [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855] [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: The PRA considers that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be best represented by fatter-tailed distributions. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA considers that a provision of one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution and that this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks.

question: For an assigned asset that does not use published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks, and that has a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1–5, what must a firm with a matching adjustment permission do to ensure the basic fundamental spread reflects differences in credit quality by rating notch, and what related adjustment requirement is referenced alongside this notch-based treatment?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must ensure that, for an assigned asset with a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5, the fundamental spread is adjusted from the credit quality step attributed to the asset so that it reflects the corresponding rating notch, and it must do so following the approach specified in 6.3 and 6.4. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This notch-based adjustment is part of the broader requirement to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic fundamental spread (where possible and appropriate) for assigned assets that do not use published fundamental spread tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] In the same context, the framework also points to a related requirement under Matching Adjustment 6.1 that the probability of default is adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, aligning the PD treatment with the basic fundamental spread’s notch sensitivity. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] Accordingly, when the asset falls within credit quality steps 1–5 and is not in the category using published government/central bank tables, the firm’s compliance outcome is to implement a rating-notch-reflective adjustment to the fundamental spread while also recognizing that the PD is expected to be notch-adjusted under 6.1 on the same “where possible and appropriate” basis. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1]
source_text: Firms are required to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic FS (where possible and appropriate) for all assigned assets that do not use published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. Matching Adjustment 6.1 requires the PD to be adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch. Firms are also required to reflect such differences in the basic FS, which can be done by either:
target_text: Where an assigned asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard (within the meaning of 7.1(1) ) mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), a firm with a matching adjustment permission must make an adjustment to the fundamental spread derived from the credit quality step attributed to that asset in order to reflect the corresponding rating notch , in accordance with 6.3 and 6.4 .

question: When a firm seeks the PRA’s permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for calculating best estimate liabilities, what must the firm submit under the SoP, and how does that submission requirement interact with the chapter’s description of the PRA’s approach to considering, granting, and varying that permission (including any indication of streamlined treatment in certain circumstances)?
gold_answer: A firm applying for the PRA’s permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for calculating its best estimate liabilities should expect the PRA to assess the request under the chapter that describes the PRA’s approach to considering, granting, and varying that permission, while still meeting the SoP’s application submission requirements. [#TGT:c07c55d3c6994e3a] Specifically, the PRA will require the firm to submit a written application in the form set out in Chapter 2 of the SoP, and that application must be accompanied by documentary evidence. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567] If the request is a change in scope application, the firm must also include the changes that are signposted in the manner described in paragraph 2.18 of the SoP. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567] In terms of process expectations, the chapter frames the PRA’s handling of these requests as covering consideration, granting, and variation of permission to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for best estimate liabilities, and it also indicates that Chapter 3 discusses how the same approach could be applied more flexibly and in a streamlined way in certain circumstances. [#TGT:c07c55d3c6994e3a] Accordingly, even where a streamlined approach may be discussed for certain circumstances, the baseline submission package remains a written application with supporting evidence, plus the paragraph 2.18 signposting for change in scope cases. [#SRC:974d2778f8f27567]
source_text: The PRA will still require firms to submit a written application as set out in Chapter 2 of this SoP, including accompanying documentary evidence and, for a change in scope application, changes signposted as described in paragraph 2.18 of this SoP.
target_text: This chapter outlines the PRA’s approach to considering, granting and varying permission for a firm to apply the MA to the relevant risk-free rate term structure for calculating its best estimate liabilities. Chapter 3 goes on to discuss how this approach could be applied in a more flexible, streamlined manner in certain circumstances.

question: When the PRA conducts an equivalence assessment for the purposes of authorisation and supervision, how should it frame that assessment in terms of (i) the outcomes and consistency with the UK regulatory framework, and (ii) the separation between the PRA’s own assessment and any advice it may provide to HM Treasury under Regulation 4 of SI 2019/541?
gold_answer: The PRA should treat its equivalence assessment as an outcomes-focused, PRA-specific judgement used to support the PRA’s own authorisation and supervision functions, while keeping that assessment distinct from any advice it may separately provide to HM Treasury for HM Treasury’s equivalence determinations made for other purposes. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581] In forming the PRA’s own overall assessment, the PRA evaluates whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent and whether the home state regime aligns with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] The PRA assesses the relevant factors in the round, but it gives considerable weight to the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor, and it also considers supervision at both the individual-firm level (including branches) and at the consolidated group level, taking into account the nature and scale of the firm’s UK activities. [#SRC:8e5451c44f63e11a] Separately, the PRA may provide advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541), but that advisory role does not convert the PRA’s authorisation-and-supervision assessment into HM Treasury’s determination process. [#TGT:b4c97c646d738581]
source_text: The PRA will make an overall assessment of whether the home state supervisor is sufficiently equivalent, and whether its regime is consistent with the UK regulatory framework in delivering appropriate outcomes that meet the PRA’s objectives. 9 The PRA assesses these factors in their totality, but will place considerable weight on assessing the extent and quality of co-operation with the home state supervisor. The PRA will take into account the supervision of individual firms (including branches) and their consolidated group, and it will consider the nature and scale of a firm’s activities in the UK.
target_text: 9. The PRA’s assessment of equivalence is based on the outcomes achieved and is for the purposes of authorisation and supervision by the PRA, which is separate from advice the PRA may provide to HM Treasury where HM Treasury may make determinations of equivalence for other purposes. The PRA may give advice to HM Treasury pursuant to Regulation 4 of The Equivalence Determinations for Financial Services and Miscellaneous Provisions (Amendment etc.) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 (SI 2019/541).

question: If you are writing a PRA policy statement about varying approvals, which FSMA section do you cite for the requirement that the PRA and FCA publish their policy statements, and which FSMA sections do you cite for the power to vary approvals?
gold_answer: You should cite one FSMA section for the obligation to publish the policy statement, and different FSMA sections for the legal power that the policy statement is discussing. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] For the publication requirement, the PRA’s statement of policy is described as being issued in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA), and that section is described as requiring the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue statements of their respective policies. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] For the underlying power on the specific topic of varying approvals, you should cite sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA, because those are identified as the sections where the PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals is set out. [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a] Using both references together makes the explanation complete: section 63ZD supports why the PRA and FCA are issuing policy statements at all, while sections 63ZA/63ZB identify where the power being covered (varying approvals) sits in FSMA. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a]
source_text: This statement of policy is issued by the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) as amended by the Financial Services (Banking Reform)Act 2013, 1 and the Bank of England and Financial Services Act 2016, which requires the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue a statement of their respective policies on:
target_text: 2. The PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals are set out in Sections in sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA.

question: If a firm is working out the value under 18 for each type of asset, what changes does it have to make for assets it is treated as buying or selling under an option and under a futures contract, and where does the text mention the step from 18 to 19?
gold_answer: The firm has to adjust the value it assigns under 18 for each type of asset by adding or subtracting the value of assets it is treated as having acquired or disposed of under both an option and a futures contract, and the option rule is explicitly tied to the move from 18 to 19. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] For options, the requirement is that the value ascribed under 18 to 19 for assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] For futures contracts, the requirement is that the value ascribed under 18 for assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description that the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract. [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] Putting these together, the firm’s calculation for each asset description must incorporate deemed acquisitions/disposals from both instruments by adjusting the relevant ascribed value upward or downward by the corresponding asset values. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d] The linkage to “18 to 19” appears in the option provision, which frames the adjustment as part of the value ascribed under 18 to 19, while the futures provision frames the adjustment as part of the value ascribed under 18. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:ff6fa125bd63370d]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: The value ascribed under 18 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to a futures contract.

question: If a firm has worked out an amount under 7.8 and needs to show it as a percentage of the amount under 7.7 (1) or (2), does it have to subtract reinsurance recoveries from the 7.7 amount first, and which reinsurance contracts count?
gold_answer: Yes. The firm’s output must show the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), so the 7.7 amount is the figure the percentage is based on. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] Before using that 7.7 figure for the percentage calculation, the firm must deduct, from the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Only reinsurance contracts that were ceded during the relevant period are included in the deduction described, because the deduction is defined by reference to contracts ceded during that period. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Putting the two requirements together, the firm first adjusts the 7.7 (1) or (2) amount by removing the specified reinsurance recoverables, and then expresses the 7.8 amount as a percentage of that (deducted) 7.7 amount. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] This approach follows directly from the instruction to deduct recoverables “from” the 7.7 amount and the separate instruction to use the 7.7 amount as the base for the percentage expression of 7.8. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23]
source_text: A firm must express the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2).
target_text: From the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), a firm must deduct the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period.

question: If a firm with a matching adjustment permission decides to use the EVT when preparing the attestation it must provide to the PRA, how must it set and apply assumptions for that attestation, and how does this apply across the firm’s relevant portfolio(s) of assets?
gold_answer: When a firm with a matching adjustment permission prepares the attestation it is required to provide to the PRA for each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole, and it chooses to use the EVT for that attestation, the firm must align its approach to the EVT’s underlying principles while applying its own assumptions that it judges appropriate to support the attestation that the MA can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets in the relevant portfolio. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] The portfolio scope is not optional: the attestation must be provided in respect of each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole held by the firm, so the EVT-based assumptions and analysis need to be applied at that portfolio level rather than only to selected assets. [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d] In setting those assumptions, the firm must ensure they do not go below the PRA’s published minimum parameters where those parameters apply. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] In addition, the firm must give extra consideration to retained risks other than the NNEG that are not assessed by the EVT, so that the attestation remains appropriately supported even where the EVT does not capture those risks. [#SRC:bac9c4bd1480db48] This EVT-based approach is therefore a method the firm may choose to use within the required attestation process that must be delivered to the PRA for each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole. [#TGT:e4cd8736edad498d]
source_text: Where a firm chooses to use the EVT for attestation purposes, the PRA expects it to engage with the principles underlying the EVT and use its own assumptions that are judged to be appropriate when attesting that the MA can be earned with a high degree of confidence from the assets held in the relevant portfolio of assets ( Matching Adjustment 9.1(1)(b) ). These assumptions should not fall below the PRA’s published minimum parameters where applicable, with additional consideration given to any retained risks other than the NNEG that are not assessed by the EVT.
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must provide to the PRA the attestation set out at (1) at the time set out in (2) by a person in (3) in the form set out in 12.1 in respect of each relevant portfolio of assets as a whole held by the firm .

question: If an institution is publicly disclosing the Titles II and III information under this Title, what does it need to do with the written explanation that goes with Article 431 quantitative templates so people can understand the numbers, and where should that explanation be placed?
gold_answer: When an institution is publicly disclosing the information referred to in Titles II and III in line with the provisions of this Title, it must treat the accompanying explanation for Article 431 quantitative disclosures as part of making the disclosure usable to the public. [#TGT:8764079e3800c628] The qualitative narrative and any other supplementary information that is needed alongside the quantitative disclosures must be written clearly and in a sufficiently complete way so that users can understand what the quantitative disclosures show. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] The institution also has to position that narrative and supplementary information next to the templates that it is describing, so the explanation sits alongside the relevant quantitative tables rather than being detached from them. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] This is the required presentation approach when the institution is carrying out the public disclosure obligation for Titles II and III information under this Title (noting that the obligation is expressed as being subject to exceptions referred to in Article 432). [#TGT:8764079e3800c628]
source_text: The qualitative narrative and any other necessary supplementary information accompanying quantitative disclosures in accordance with Article 431 of the CRR shall be adequately clear and comprehensive, enabling users of information to understand the quantitative disclosures and shall be placed next to the templates, which they describe.
target_text: Institutions shall publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in accordance with the provisions laid down in this Title, subject to the exceptions referred to in Article 432 .

question: When a firm uses transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) to restructure an asset for inclusion in the MA portfolio, how should it assess whether the unrestructured asset remains an appropriate match over time (consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and changing operating conditions), and what limits apply where the unrestructured asset would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements (including the PPP)?
gold_answer: A firm should treat intra-group restructuring (including via loans or derivatives) as acceptable for MA portfolio purposes only to the extent the resulting restructured asset can meet the MA eligibility conditions, and it should base that assessment on the nature of the underlying asset being restructured. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] In doing so, the firm is expected to evaluate the suitability of the restructuring arrangements by first considering whether the asset in its unrestructured form is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that aligns with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and accounts for potential changes in operating conditions. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] The PRA also draws a clear boundary: it would not expect firms to use arrangements of the kind described in paragraph 2.55 (or arrangements that have the same substantive effect) to bring into the MA portfolio assets that, in unrestructured form, would not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including PPP requirements. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] Additionally, where an asset’s inherent characteristics make it infeasible to restructure into an MA-eligible form, the firm should be able to demonstrate that it can place sufficient reliance on the restructuring arrangements to support ongoing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions over time. [#TGT:85a09058df3cecad] This time-horizon focus links directly to the PRA’s expectation to test continuing appropriateness of the unrestructured asset against the restructuring duration and changing conditions. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: The extent to which transactions within the insurance group (including loans or derivatives) can be used to restructure assets in order to include them in the MA portfolio depends on whether the restructured assets thereby created can satisfy the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects firms to have regard to the underlying assets being restructured when they consider whether the MA eligibility conditions will be satisfied. The PRA would not expect firms to apply arrangements as set out in paragraph 2.55 above, or arrangements that in substance have that effect, to assets that, in unrestructured form, would in any event not meet all applicable Solvency II requirements, including those of the PPP. The PRA notes that some assets by their very nature may have characteristics that make it infeasible to restructure them as MA eligible assets, and expects firms to be able to demonstrate that sufficient reliance can be placed upon restructuring arrangements to ensure the continuing satisfaction of the MA eligibility conditions.

question: When the PRA is assessing a firm’s proposed change(s) affecting the MA, how should the firm prepare to respond to PRA requests that both (i) seek additional items/evidence and (ii) require an explanation of the likely impact on the MA, including the specific operational focus indicated for the requested evidence?
gold_answer: In an assessment of proposed change(s) affecting the MA, the firm should be prepared for the PRA to make two distinct types of requests and to respond to both in a coordinated way. [#SRC:9433858d4605eaac] First, the PRA may ask for extra materials beyond what has already been provided, including additional items referenced elsewhere in the same framework, and the firm should be ready to supply them when requested. [#SRC:9433858d4605eaac] Second, the PRA may request additional evidence that is specifically relevant to how the MA portfolio operates, so the firm’s readiness should include being able to produce operationally relevant evidence on demand. [#TGT:ab0339d478011847] Alongside producing those items/evidence, the PRA may also require the firm to explain what effect the proposed change(s) are likely to have on the MA, meaning the firm should be able to articulate the anticipated impact as part of the assessment dialogue. [#SRC:9433858d4605eaac] Practically, this implies the firm should maintain materials that can both substantiate the operation of the MA portfolio and support a clear explanation of the expected MA impact of the proposed change(s), so that it can provide them promptly when the PRA requests them during its assessment. [#TGT:ab0339d478011847]
source_text: The PRA may also request the additional items set out in paragraph 2.11 above as part of its assessment. It may also ask the firm to explain the likely impact on the MA of the proposed change(s).

question: When a firm’s assessment covers the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3, how must that assessment be reported annually, and what additional analysis is required if reducing the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would cause non-compliance with the SCR?
gold_answer: A firm that performs an assessment of the effect of the VA as part of its asset-liability management under Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3 must treat that assessment as one of the “assessments referred to in 3.2” for annual reporting purposes. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] The firm must submit those 3.2 assessments as part of the information it reports annually in accordance with Reporting 2. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] In addition, if a scenario in which the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment is reduced to zero would lead to non-compliance with the SCR, the firm must also submit an analysis addressing how it could respond to that situation. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] That additional analysis must cover measures the firm could apply either (i) to re-establish the level of eligible own funds covering the SCR or (ii) to reduce its risk profile so that compliance with the SCR is restored. [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389] Accordingly, the annual submission should include both the VA effect assessment (as part of asset-liability management) and, where the specified zero-adjustment scenario would breach the SCR, the firm’s documented response options focused on restoring SCR compliance. [#SRC:4b628eed64a26759] [#TGT:8241a37abe32a389]
source_text: (c) the assessment of the effect of the VA as a part of the firm’s asset-liability management ( Conditions Governing Business 3.2 and 3.3 ).
target_text: A firm must submit the assessments referred to in 3.2 as part of the information reported annually in accordance with Reporting 2 . Where the reduction of the matching adjustment or the volatility adjustment to zero would result in non-compliance with the SCR , the firm must also submit an analysis of the measures it could apply in such a situation to re-establish the level of the e ligible own funds covering the SCR or to reduce its risk profile to restore compliance with the SCR .

question: When a firm notifies the PRA that a person has become a notified non-executive director, how should the firm determine whether it must submit all fitness and propriety assessment information, particularly where the person ceases to perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function upon becoming a notified non-executive director, and (if the firm is a designated investment firm) whether designated additional information must accompany the submission?
gold_answer: A firm’s baseline position is that, when it notifies the PRA that a person has become a notified non-executive director, it must provide the PRA with all information needed to assess whether that person is fit and proper; and if the information is provided by a designated investment firm, it must be accompanied by the designated additional information. [#TGT:f38f6326407a41cb] However, where the notification is about a person who, on becoming a notified non-executive director, stops performing a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function, the firm is not required to provide the fitness and propriety assessment information unless there has been a change in the fitness and propriety information previously provided to the PRA or the FCA when the approval application for that senior management function was made. [#SRC:329854445e828dde] In practice, the firm should (i) identify whether the individual’s change to notified non-executive director status coincides with ceasing one of the specified senior management functions, and (ii) compare current fitness and propriety information against what was submitted at the time of the relevant approval application to the PRA or FCA to determine whether any changes exist. [#SRC:329854445e828dde] If changes exist, the firm should provide the information needed for the PRA’s fit and proper assessment, and a designated investment firm should include the designated additional information with that submission. [#TGT:f38f6326407a41cb]
source_text: If the notification referred to in 4.2 is in respect of a person who, on becoming a notified non-executive director , ceases to perform a PRA senior management function or an FCA-designated senior management function , the firm is not required to provide information needed to assess the fitness and propriety of that person unless there has been a change in the information provided in respect of that person regarding fitness and propriety provided to the PRA or the FCA at the time the application for the approval for performance of the PRA senior management function or the FCA-designated senior management function was made.
target_text: A firm must notify the PRA when a person becomes a notified non-executive director and shall provide the PRA with all of the information needed to assess whether that person is fit and proper. The PRA directs that when such information is provided by a designated investment firm , it must be accompanied by the designated additional information .

question: When a firm is assessing whether a with-profits annuity contract can contribute liabilities to an MA portfolio under Matching Adjustment 2.3, how should it treat a premium structure that is an initial sum followed by smaller instalments, and what must the firm demonstrate about the included liability component and its separability under regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations?
gold_answer: A firm should not treat an instalment-style premium arrangement as a basis to notionally divide a single insurance contract into multiple parts for Matching Adjustment purposes, except in the limited cases referenced in the SOURCE text. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] Matching Adjustment 2.3 allows only a “component” of a with-profits annuity contract to be included in an MA portfolio where that component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within the contract and can be organised and managed separately in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] In practice, this means the firm’s analysis must focus on whether the component is contractually guaranteed and separable for management purposes, rather than relying on a payment schedule (initial premium plus later instalments) to justify splitting the contract. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e] The PRA expects a detailed assessment showing that the only liability elements included in the MA portfolio are guaranteed and not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance, and the firm should also articulate a clear policy on where future attaching bonuses will be added (within the MA portfolio or elsewhere). [#TGT:0bace533be32cdc7] The underlying rationale is that notional splitting would undermine the insurer’s ability to manage the MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, which is a requirement tied to regulation 4(6)(b) as referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:4d0f75998fee0e4e]
source_text: Some contracts of insurance include an option for the premium to be paid as an initial sum followed by a series of further (smaller) instalments. Except in the limited cases set out in paragraphs 3.5A , 3.5B and 3.5C above, the PRA does not view any approach that notionally splits a contract into parts as being compatible with Matching Adjustment 2.3 . The PRA’s view is that such a treatment would also undermine the ability of the insurer to manage its MA portfolio separately from the rest of the business, as required by regulation 4(6)(b) of the IRPR regulations.
target_text: Matching Adjustment 2.3 sets out that a component of a with-profits annuity contract may be eligible for inclusion in an MA portfolio, provided that the component is legally established and identifiable as guaranteed within an insurance contract, is capable of being organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations, and otherwise meets the MA eligibility conditions. The PRA expects that for a firm to include such components of liabilities within an MA portfolio, it will provide a detailed assessment to demonstrate that the only elements of the liabilities included are contractually guaranteed and are not dependent on future premiums or future investment performance. The PRA also expects that the firm should set out a clear policy regarding the addition of future attaching bonuses in the MA portfolio or elsewhere.

question: If an assigned asset is not using the published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks, and it has a credit rating (or internal credit assessment) that maps to credit quality steps 1–5, what does a firm with a matching adjustment permission need to do so the basic FS reflects the rating notch, and what other notch-related adjustment is mentioned?
gold_answer: For an assigned asset with a credit rating or internal credit assessment mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5, a firm with a matching adjustment permission must adjust the fundamental spread that comes from the asset’s credit quality step so it reflects the corresponding rating notch, applying the method set out in 6.3 and 6.4. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] This requirement sits within a broader expectation that firms reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic fundamental spread (where possible and appropriate) for all assigned assets that do not use published fundamental spread tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] Alongside adjusting the basic fundamental spread, the text also highlights that Matching Adjustment 6.1 requires the probability of default to be adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch, so the notch concept is applied consistently beyond just the fundamental spread. [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1] In practice, when both conditions apply (no use of the published government/central bank tables, and a mapping to steps 1–5), the firm should implement the notch-reflective fundamental spread adjustment under 6.3 and 6.4 and recognize the parallel notch-based PD adjustment requirement under 6.1. [#TGT:9fdf13a401180fa3] [#SRC:5376e785ce2625b1]
source_text: Firms are required to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch in the basic FS (where possible and appropriate) for all assigned assets that do not use published FS tables for assets issued by governments and central banks. Matching Adjustment 6.1 requires the PD to be adjusted (where possible and appropriate) to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch. Firms are also required to reflect such differences in the basic FS, which can be done by either:
target_text: Where an assigned asset has a credit rating or internal credit assessment of a comparable standard (within the meaning of 7.1(1) ) mapping to credit quality steps 1 to 5 (inclusive), a firm with a matching adjustment permission must make an adjustment to the fundamental spread derived from the credit quality step attributed to that asset in order to reflect the corresponding rating notch , in accordance with 6.3 and 6.4 .

question: When a related undertaking is included in consolidated data under points (1) or (3) of 11.1A and its contribution to the consolidated group SCR must reflect diversification effects, what constraint applies to the allocation of percentages across all related undertakings included in the consolidated calculation?
gold_answer: When a related undertaking is included in the consolidated data pursuant to points (1) or (3) of 11.1A, its contribution to the consolidated group SCR is required to reflect diversification effects and to be calculated on that basis. [#TGT:f0367d1134b80463] In applying that contribution calculation across the consolidated group, the allocation of the relevant percentages across the population of related undertakings included in the consolidated calculation is constrained: for all related undertakings that are Solvency II undertakings, insurance holding companies, or mixed financial holding companies included in the consolidated calculation, the combined total of the percentages referred to in 9.4D(1) and 9.4D(2) must add up to exactly 100%. [#SRC:7ea086354fb4a782] Practically, this means that once you have identified the related undertakings that fall within those categories and are included in the consolidated calculation, you must ensure the percentage inputs used for the 9.4D(1) and (2) references collectively exhaust the full 100%—no under-allocation or over-allocation—while still using those percentages within a contribution approach that reflects diversification effects for the consolidated group SCR. [#TGT:f0367d1134b80463] [#SRC:7ea086354fb4a782]
source_text: In each of 9.4D(1) and (2) , the sum of the percentages referred to for all the related undertakings that are Solvency II undertakings , insurance holding companies or mixed financial holding companies included in the consolidated calculation must equal 100%.
