question: If a firm runs a quick “call everyone together” test of its governance arrangements, what should it be checking about the recovery plan so the board can make key decisions in a stress, and how does the plan’s “playbook” idea fit into that?
gold_answer: In a short-notice governance test, the firm should be checking that the recovery plan is genuinely usable for the people who must act, especially the board, because the board will be taking the key decisions in a stress and needs to be able to navigate and understand the plan quickly. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] The plan should also be structured so it is readily usable by the specific business areas that would need to use it, not only by the board. [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d] The test itself can include assembling the right people at short notice and then seeing whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions, rather than just discussing it in the abstract. [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc] This is where the “playbook” concept matters: the exercise is meant to test the usefulness of that playbook-style element of the recovery plan—whether it supports fast, practical decision-making by the assembled group—while also aligning with the expectation that the board can quickly find and understand what it needs during stress. [#SRC:45bb4478c8468dcc] [#TGT:a3cffd0082b9333d]
source_text: testing the governance arrangements. This might include assembling the right people at short notice and understanding whether they can use the recovery plan to take strategic decisions. This would test the usefulness of the ‘playbook’ (see ‘ (vii) Playbooks and structure of recovery plans ’ below);
target_text: The PRA expects recovery plans to be structured so that they are readily usable by both boards and the specific business areas of firms that would need to use them. It is important that the board can quickly navigate and understand the recovery plan as they will be taking the key decisions in a stress.

question: If you’re writing a short note on SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, how do you explain (1) what “non-neutrality” usually does to total RWAs compared with the underlying portfolio, and (2) why that doesn’t mean the methods fully pick up non-credit risks—especially given the STS/non-STS floors and the “p” factor?
gold_answer: You should say that “non-neutrality” usually means the total RWAs for the securitisation tranches come out higher than the RWAs that would have been calculated for the underlying portfolio if it had stayed unsecuritised. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] You should then connect that to how SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA work: they can only recognise a defined number of items in their capital calculation and are mainly focused on credit risk, so they may fail to recognise non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] The linkage is that some additional non-credit risks from securitisation are reflected to an extent through this non-neutrality, but the size of that effect is driven by pre-defined inputs such as STS status rather than a broad capture of all non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965] To make the mechanism concrete, explain that in SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA the non-neutrality is introduced mainly by applying a risk weight floor—10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions—together with the supervisory “p” factor. [#TGT:dbb9be39416dec17] This shows why higher tranche RWAs can occur while still leaving gaps in recognising non-credit risks. [#SRC:b660733416fb3965]
source_text: The SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA methods can only recognise a defined number of items in their calculation of capital requirements, primarily focused on credit risk. These methods may fail to recognise the presence of non-credit risks. To an extent some additional non-credit risks which can arise from securitisation are reflected in the ‘non-neutrality’ of the securitisation capital framework. 1 However the level of non-neutrality is driven by pre-defined inputs (eg STS status).
target_text: 1. ‘Non-neutrality’ of the framework here means that typically the total RWAs calculated for the tranches of a securitisation will be higher than the RWAs calculated for the underlying portfolio had it not been securitised. In the SEC-SA and SEC-IRBA, this non-neutrality is introduced primarily through the application of a risk weight floor (10% for STS positions and 15% for non-STS positions) and the supervisory ‘p’ factor.

question: If a firm has a record that was made under SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and existed on 31 December 2015, how long does it need to keep each version, when does the clock start, and what does it need to do if the PRA asks for it?
gold_answer: If the firm has a record that was created in line with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook and is within the scope described as at 31 December 2015, the firm must follow the 5.8 requirement for that record. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] Under that approach, each version of the record must be kept for ten years, and the ten-year period starts on the date that version is replaced by a newer, more up-to-date record. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] The same rule is stated to apply to each version of the management responsibilities map, so the firm should keep version histories for both items using the supersession date as the retention trigger. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] In addition to keeping the versions for the full period, the firm must be able to provide the retained versions to the PRA if the PRA requests them. [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2] This ties the specific “record created … as at 31 December 2015” population to a concrete retention-and-production outcome: ten-year retention per version, measured from supersession, plus readiness to deliver to the PRA on request. [#SRC:6663c8b6cce3b3fe] [#TGT:1d83951b815d3de2]
source_text: A firm must comply with 5.8 in relation to any record created in accordance with SYSC 2.2.1R of the PRA Handbook as at 31 December 2015.
target_text: Each version of both the management responsibilities map and the record in 5.4 must be retained for a period of ten years from the date on which it was superseded by a more up-to-date record, and must be provided to the PRA on request.

question: If an auditor is giving the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1, do they need to check whether the firm qualifies to use the MA, and do they need to judge whether an approval or waiver is valid? If not, how should those approvals/waivers be used when the audit also involves transitional measures on technical provisions?
gold_answer: When giving the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, the auditor does not need to evaluate whether the firm meets the eligibility conditions to use the MA. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] The auditor is also not expected to give a view on whether an approval, waiver, or other supervisory determination is valid. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] Rather than being re-tested by the auditor, approvals, waivers, and supervisory determinations from the competent authority are treated as part of the framework the auditor uses to form the audit opinion. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] In practical terms for transitional measures on technical provisions, the auditor should also treat Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities, and capital that are calculated under the previous regime as part of that same framework for the audit opinion. [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6] So, the auditor’s job is to apply the audit work to the framework that already includes those supervisory outcomes and transitional-measure elements, without separately deciding MA eligibility or re-validating supervisory decisions. [#SRC:7bd251a3e64bccff] [#TGT:15d29d4311dd73f6]
source_text: In forming the opinion required by Rules 2.1 and 4.1 of the External Audit Part of the PRA Rulebook, auditors are not required to assess whether a firm meets the eligibility conditions for use of the MA. As noted in paragraph 3.4 , auditors are not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination.
target_text: The auditor is not expected to express an opinion on the validity of an approval, waiver or other supervisory determination. Instead approvals, waivers and supervisory determinations provided by the competent authority should be considered as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given. For the purposes of transitional measures on technical provisions, Pillar 1 and 2 assets, liabilities and capital calculated in accordance with the previous regime, should be treated as part of the framework against which the audit opinion is being given.

question: If a firm has little data at the start of an investment and wants to use a simple standard method for the FS, when can it avoid building a term structure and use one flat (uniform) allowance instead?
gold_answer: Even if a firm cannot create a robust method for the addition to the FS at the point of initial investment (for example because data are scarce), it may propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS and include safeguards to reduce risks to the quality of matching. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] However, firms are generally expected to model a term structure for the addition to the FS, so using a single flat (uniform) allowance is only acceptable where the firm can demonstrate that doing so would not cause material impacts in specific areas. [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] Specifically, the firm must be able to show that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for risks arising from cash flow uncertainty. [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] It must also show that a uniform allowance would not materially affect either (i) the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or (ii) the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests. [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] This demonstration is what connects the firm’s practical need to start with a standard method (given initial-investment constraints) to the term-structure expectation; the PRA also indicates it does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as referenced in the earlier paragraph. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c]
source_text: The PRA understands that, at the point of initial investment, in many cases it may not be possible to develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS, for example due to data scarcity. Firms may therefore propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, together with any safeguards that could mitigate the risks to the quality of matching. The PRA does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as set out in paragraph 5.21 above.
target_text: Firms should model a term structure for the addition to the FS unless it can be demonstrated that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for the risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests.

question: For a firm that is subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules and is considering the TWD option as part of its recovery plan, what expectations apply to that option and where is the interaction between those expectations, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS described?
gold_answer: A firm subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules must maintain a recovery plan that includes a range of executable recovery options, and the TWD option is treated as one of those recovery options. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] Because the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply to it. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] In practical terms, this means the firm should align the TWD option within its recovery plan to the SS9/17 expectations that cover areas such as governance, information and reporting requirements, and the use of fire drills and playbooks, as part of the overall recovery planning framework. [#SRC:79cc8d3f5662f4d8] To ensure the TWD option is implemented consistently with the broader policy framework, the firm should also use the document that explains how SS9/17 expectations interact with other relevant PRA policies and with this SS. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e] That interaction is described in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down Statement of Policy (SoP), which sets out how the SS9/17 expectations, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS fit together for the TWD option. [#TGT:cdec50384b35267e]
source_text: All firms subject to the PRA’s recovery planning rules are required to have a recovery plan containing a range of executable options. SS9/17 sets out expectations for recovery planning relating to governance, information and reporting requirements, fire drills and playbooks, amongst other areas. 7
target_text: 7. As the TWD option is a recovery option, the expectations in SS9/17 apply. The interaction between the expectations in SS9/17, other relevant PRA policies, and this SS is set out in the PRA’s Trading activity wind-down SoP.

question: If a liability is secured on property, when can it still be written down because the security is a floating charge, and how should the plan describe the order of writing it down compared with lower-ranking liabilities?
gold_answer: Even if a liability is secured on property, it can still be eligible for write-down where the security is a charge that, when created, was a floating charge, because FSMA section 377B treats other property-secured amounts as excluded liabilities but does not treat floating-charge-secured amounts the same way. [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc] The write-down plan should then connect that eligibility to the PRA’s expectation that write-down plans broadly respect the creditor hierarchy so that the overall outcome for policyholders and other creditors is better than if no order were made. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] The plan should also reflect the PRA’s concern that floating charges are often granted to inward reinsurance creditors who are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority), and that writing down floating-charge-secured liabilities is intended to prevent those creditors from receiving an inappropriate and unintended priority. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96] As a result, where a floating-charge-secured liability is not subordinated in that way, the plan should generally state that it would be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in line with the creditor hierarchy. [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]
source_text: The PRA anticipates that write-down plans will broadly respect the creditor hierarchy in order to ‘lead to a better outcome for the insurer’s policyholders and other creditors (taken as a whole) than not making the order.’ 7 The PRA also recognises that while liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities, 8 and may therefore be written-down, this is intended to ‘avoid creating an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors, who are often granted a floating charge but contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority)’. 9 Accordingly, liabilities secured by floating charges which are not subordinated in this way would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in accordance with the creditor hierarchy.
target_text: 8. Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA treats ‘an amount secured on property of any kind, other than an amount secured by a charge which, as created, was a floating charge’ as an excluded liability (the term ‘floating charge’ is then defined in section 377B(2) of FSMA).

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract, under what circumstances may a retrospective calculation be used instead of the default prospective calculation, and what demonstration (if any) is required to justify that choice?
gold_answer: The default position is that the amount of the long-term insurance liability is to be calculated prospectively for each contract, meaning the starting assumption is a prospective calculation on a contract-by-contract basis. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] A retrospective calculation is permitted only as an exception to that default, and only in limited circumstances tied to the feasibility and prudence of the prospective approach. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Specifically, a retrospective calculation may be used where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, which links the contract-level determination requirement to a contract/benefit-type limitation on method selection. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Alternatively, even if a prospective method could be applied, a retrospective calculation may be used where it can be demonstrated that the liabilities produced would be no lower than the amount that would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; in that case, the justification hinges on demonstrating a non-lower outcome relative to a prudent prospective benchmark. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] In all cases, the prospective calculation remains the baseline method for determining the long-term insurance liability for each contract, and the retrospective approach is only available within the stated exception conditions. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: For a shareholding members resolution, how should a society determine the relevant qualifying shareholding date when the voting date is after the society’s AGM in that financial year, and what limitations apply to using an overdrawn share account to satisfy any shareholding or membership condition on that date or during any required period?
gold_answer: Where the voting date is after the society’s AGM in the same financial year, the qualifying shareholding date is set by reference to the period tied to the meeting: it is the first day of the period that starts 56 days before the meeting date (rather than the last day of the preceding financial year). [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] This timing point matters because any entitlement test that requires holding shares on a specified date or over a specified period must be met through actual shareholding, not by pointing to a share account that is overdrawn. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] In addition, if the entitlement test includes being a member on a given date (for example, a membership condition like the one referenced at paragraph 3.111(a)), that membership condition likewise cannot be satisfied by relying on an overdrawn share account. [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407] Accordingly, when applying the society’s Rules that include the shareholding and continuity concepts described in paragraph 3.110 to determine whether a person is entitled to vote on a shareholding members resolution after the AGM, the society should (i) anchor the assessment to the qualifying shareholding date defined by the 56-day lookback from the meeting, and (ii) disregard any attempt to meet shareholding or membership-on-a-date requirements via an overdrawn share account. [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60] [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407]
source_text: There is no requirement for continuity of shareholding between paragraphs 3.111(a) and (b) (In contrast, in the case of an ordinary or special resolution, membership at paragraph 3.111(a) may be satisfied by either borrowing or shareholding membership provided the shareholding member satisfies the other conditions of paragraph 3.111(b) to (d) in order to vote in his or her capacity as a shareholder). Note also that a person cannot meet a requirement for holding shares on a given date, or during a given period, by relying on his holding of a share account with an overdrawn balance; and a person cannot meet a requirement for being a member on a given date (for example, at paragraph 3.111(a) ) by relying on his holding of such a share account.

question: For a firm using an internal model, how should it meet the annual requirement to provide template AoC.01 on the analysis of change, and what additional narrative documentation must accompany that submission, including any flexibility on the format used?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model must make an annual submission to the PRA of template AoC.01 that presents the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A, and it must prepare that template in line with the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] In addition to the AoC.01 template content (which includes quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis), the firm is also required to submit supporting narrative documentation tied to Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and to Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] The firm has discretion over the format for that supporting narrative documentation, meaning it may choose the format in which it provides those narratives, while still ensuring the narratives are submitted as required. [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3] Practically, this means the annual AoC.01 package should combine: (i) the AoC.01 template completed per Chapter 10 instructions, and (ii) the additional supporting narrative documentation required by the Reporting Part provisions, with the narratives delivered in a firm-selected format. [#TGT:13a55e684b224a20] [#SRC:14262772fd571ec3]
source_text: Firms are also required to submit the supporting narrative documentation, in accordance with Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook, in a format they choose.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When submitting the Merger Document (including the Schedule 16 Statement) and the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments, what interim financial-position disclosure must the board make because the financial information period ends before approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, and what is the stated regulatory consequence of failing to disclose such changes?
gold_answer: In preparing and submitting the Merger Document that includes the Schedule 16 Statement (together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referenced alongside it), the board must address the fact that the financial information necessarily covers a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] Specifically, the board is required to state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim between the end of that financial-information period and the approval date. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] If a material change has occurred and its effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members understand it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] This interim-change disclosure is therefore a necessary complement to the Merger Document package (including the Schedule 16 Statement and the associated explanations) being put forward. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] A failure to disclose such interim material changes is not treated as immaterial: it will be relevant to the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: How should an institution treat the recognition of hedges when it uses an internal hedge booked in the trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, and how does this interact with the requirement to recognise hedges against interest rate risks (including internal hedges meeting Article 106(3))?
gold_answer: An institution may recognise the effect of hedges against interest rate risks, and that recognition can include internal hedges provided they meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3). [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d] However, where the institution uses an internal hedge in the form of a credit derivative booked in its trading book to hedge a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure, the non-trading book exposure must not be treated as hedged for risk-weighted exposure amount calculations unless the institution also buys a corresponding credit derivative from an eligible third party protection provider that meets the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] If that third-party protection is purchased and is recognised as a hedge of the non-trading book exposure for capital requirement calculations, the institution must then ensure that neither the internal credit derivative hedge nor the external credit derivative hedge is included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements. [#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11] In practice, this means that even though internal hedges can be recognised in the interest rate risk context when they satisfy Article 106(3), the specific derogation for internal credit-derivative hedges requires additional third-party protection and imposes a trading-book exclusion for both legs once the hedge is recognised for capital purposes. [#SRC:a3928dbde609c77d][#TGT:6d35a8a720702e11]
source_text: (iv) the recognition of the effect of hedges against those interest rate risks, including internal hedges that meet the requirements laid down in Article 106(3) ;
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraphs 1 and 2 , when an institution hedges a non-trading book credit risk exposure or counterparty risk exposure using a credit derivative booked in its trading book using an internal hedge, institutions shall ensure that the non-trading book exposure or counterparty risk exposure shall not be deemed to be hedged for the purposes of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts unless the institution purchases from an eligible third party protection provider a corresponding credit derivative meeting the requirements for unfunded credit protection in the non-trading book. Without prejudice to point (h) of Article 299(2), where such third party protection is purchased and recognised as a hedge of a non-trading book exposure for the purposes of calculating capital requirements, institutions shall ensure that neither the internal nor external credit derivative hedge shall be included in the trading book for the purposes of calculating capital requirements.

question: If a firm’s participation in a financial and credit institution is big enough that it must be taken off basic own funds in full (because it is over 10% of the listed 3A.1(1) items), what should the firm do if it cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a simple way to work out where the deduction goes?
gold_answer: When calculating basic own funds, the firm must subtract the full value of a participation in a financial and credit institution if that participation exceeds 10% of the items included in 3A.1(1)(a), 3A.1(1)(b), 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f). [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] To carry out the calculations required by Own Funds 3K that underpin this reduction, the firm should use Guidelines 4 and 5 as calculation support. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] If the subtraction is a deduction from own-funds and the firm cannot apply Own Funds 3K.5 in a straightforward manner, it should use Guideline 6 to decide which tier of own-funds the adjustment should be applied to. [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e] In practice, the firm (i) checks whether the participation exceeds the 10% threshold against the specified 3A.1(1) items, (ii) reduces basic own funds by the full value once the threshold is exceeded, and (iii) uses Guideline 6 to allocate the deduction to the correct own-funds tier when Own Funds 3K.5 cannot be applied simply. [#TGT:0627964a494e4b18] [#SRC:f70061d7218c187e]
source_text: Firms should observe Guidelines 4 and 5 which support the carrying out of the calculations required by Own Funds 3K . Where a deduction from own-funds is necessary, and where a straightforward application of Own Funds 3K.5 is not possible, firms should follow Guideline 6 to identify the tier of own-funds to which the adjustment should apply.
target_text: A firm must, for the purpose of determining its basic own funds , reduce its basic own funds by the full value of participations , as referred to in 3K.6 , in a financial and credit institution that exceeds 10% of items included in 3A.1(1)(a) , 3A.1(1)(b) , 3A.1(1)(d) and 3A.1(1)(f) .

question: When an Institution changes how it calculates the exposure value of derivative positions by moving between a single exposure value for transactions within a contractual netting agreement and separate exposure values per transaction, what notification to competent authorities is required, and what calculation approach applies depending on whether the Article 274(1) conditions are met?
gold_answer: An Institution that starts using, stops using, or switches between calculation methods for the exposure value of its derivative positions must notify the competent authorities of the relevant method it uses or ceases to use, as applicable, where that method is one of those set out in Section 4 or 5. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] In applying the calculation itself, the Institution may compute a single exposure value covering all transactions within a contractual netting agreement only when all conditions in Article 274(1) are satisfied; if those conditions are not met, it must instead compute an exposure value separately for each transaction. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Where separate calculation is required, each transaction is treated as its own netting set, which means the exposure value is determined on a transaction-by-transaction basis rather than aggregated under the contractual netting agreement. [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c] Accordingly, the compliance action is twofold: (i) determine whether the Article 274(1) conditions permit a single exposure value across the contractual netting agreement or require separate exposure values per transaction, and (ii) notify the competent authorities of the Section 4 or 5 method being used or discontinued in connection with that exposure-value calculation for derivative positions. [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]
source_text: Institutions shall notify the competent authorities of the methods set out in Section 4 or 5 that they use, or cease to use, as applicable, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If a firm wants to restructure assets using a wholly owned special purpose vehicle (SPV), what does the PRA expect the firm to check about the original (unrestructured) asset over time, and when does the PRA think using this kind of restructuring is acceptable instead of options like pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows?
gold_answer: Using a wholly owned special purpose vehicle (SPV) to restructure assets may be acceptable, but only if the firm can show both that the underlying asset remains suitable for the MA portfolio liabilities over the relevant period and that the SPV approach is being used because other approaches are not viable. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] On the asset-suitability side, the PRA expects the firm first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to stay appropriate over time, in a way that matches the duration of the restructuring arrangement and reflects that operating conditions might change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] On the “when acceptable” side, the PRA highlights that restructuring adds complexity and consequential risks, so it expects firms to use these arrangements only where they have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, such as pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] The firm should also ensure the restructure is properly recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, and that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] In practice, the firm should connect the time-based review of the unrestructured asset to the justification for choosing an SPV only after alternatives have been ruled out. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: If a firm keeps using a model even though back testing shows the results don’t match actual outcomes, what does that count as, and what should the firm’s approved process require for handling it (including escalation and any extra controls)?
gold_answer: If back testing indicates a model’s results are inconsistent with actual outcomes, that situation is treated as an “exception” under the definition provided. [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818] For a material model, the firm should have formally approved policies and procedures that spell out which exceptions it will allow and the escalation procedures it will follow to manage those exceptions. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] Because the issue arises from model performance, the firm should also have clear guidelines for setting a maximum tolerance for performance deviations from expectation. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] Once the firm’s defined triggers and thresholds are breached, the exception should be subject to appropriate risk controls and mitigants. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] The controls and mitigants described include using alternative models, applying heightened review and challenge, increasing monitoring after post-model adjustments, and recalibrating or redeveloping the existing methodology. [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933] This links the back-testing-based exception definition to the firm’s required escalation and control framework for material model exceptions. [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818] [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933]
source_text: a) For material models, firms should formulate the exceptions 23 they would allow for model use and model performance, and should implement formally approved policies and procedures setting out the escalation procedures to be followed and to manage these exceptions. (i) Exceptions for model use should be temporary, should be subject to post-model adjustments (PMAs), should be reported to and supported by stakeholders and senior management. (ii) For model performance exceptions, firms should have clear guidelines for determining a maximum tolerance on model performance exceptions (deviation from expectation), should be subject to appropriate risk controls (eg the use of alternative models, heightened review and challenge, and more frequent monitoring post-model adjustments) and mitigants (eg recalibrating or redevelopment of existing methodology) once defined triggers and thresholds are breached.
target_text: 23. Exceptions are defined here as using a model when not approved for usage by the appropriate oversight entity or not validated for use; a model is used outside its intended purpose; a model that displays persistent breach of performance metrics continues to be used; or back testing suggests the model results are inconsistent with actual outcomes.

question: If a firm is a small CRR firm (or a small third country CRR firm), can it say it benefits from a derogation “on the basis of” 12.2 or 15A, and if it is reporting a derogation, what details does it have to give about the staff and pay affected?
gold_answer: A firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm should not state that it benefits from a derogation “on the basis of” 12.2 or 15A, because those provisions are described as not applying to that type of firm. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] Separately, when the institution is required to indicate that it benefits from a derogation for the relevant reporting purpose, it must provide specific information about the derogation’s use and impact, not just a rule reference. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] The required details include: which remuneration principles the derogation(s) are applied to; the number of staff members who benefit from the derogation(s); and the total remuneration of those staff, split into fixed remuneration and variable remuneration. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] This means the firm must align any “basis” it cites with the rules that actually apply to it, while still giving the full staff-and-remuneration breakdown for any derogation it reports. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6]
source_text: For the purposes of point (k) of the first subparagraph of this paragraph, institutions that benefit from such a derogation shall indicate whether they benefit from that derogation on the basis of the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 5.3 , and/or 12.2 (second subparagraph), and 15.A1 (3) . They shall also indicate for which of the remuneration principles they apply the derogation(s), the number of staff members that benefit from the derogation(s) and their total remuneration , split into fixed and variable remuneration .
target_text: 12.2 , 15.15 to 15.19 , 15.20 (2) and (3A), 15.20A to 15.23 and 15A do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm .

question: If the parties disagree about the value of the technical provisions being transferred, which value should be used to check whether the PRA’s run-off scheme thresholds are met, and what does the PRA say about doing an s166 assessment before naming the independent expert?
gold_answer: When the parties have different valuations for the technical provisions being transferred, the value used to test whether a threshold is met is the higher valuation. [#TGT:6859654d7bfc4b42] Using that higher figure, the scheme should then be assessed against the PRA’s stated conditions for when it generally intends to commission an s166 assessment: the scheme must involve a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, the gross technical provisions must be more than £100 million, and the scheme must increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] If those conditions are met (as determined using the higher valuation where there is disagreement), the PRA indicates it intends in most cases to use its powers under s166 of FSMA to assess whether the transferee is operationally ready to accept the scheme. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] The PRA also states the sequencing for that work: the assessment would be commissioned before the independent expert is nominated. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8] An exception is also described: the PRA may decide it can satisfy itself by other means, such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. [#SRC:5ae53f838b30c1a8]
source_text: Where a scheme involves a book of non-life insurance business in run-off, with gross technical provisions of more than £100 million, 10 and where the scheme will increase the transferee’s technical provisions by more than 10%, the PRA intends to exercise its powers under s166 of FSMA in order to assess the operational readiness of the transferee to accept the scheme in most cases, except where it is able to satisfy itself by other means such as a recent s166 assessment in the same area or an equivalent assessment by an independent body or regulator. This assessment would be commissioned prior to the nomination of the independent expert.
target_text: 10. If the parties have differing valuations of the technical provisions being transferred, the higher valuation will be used in determining whether the threshold is triggered.

question: When applying to the PRA for approval of a Merger Notification Statement before sending it to members within the specified time limit, what written application content and board-level declaration is expected, and how should the statement address any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society?
gold_answer: The applicant should treat the approval request as a written submission to the PRA that both supports timely member communication and demonstrates completeness and transparency, while ensuring the Merger Notification Statement contains the required compensation particulars. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] Specifically, the Merger Notification Statement must be approved by the PRA before it is issued to members and it must be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] In making the application, it must be in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board stating that the Statement is complete and contains all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should know. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also state whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm the accuracy of the information about them. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] In addition, the Merger Notification Statement itself must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application should also be accompanied by documents, and (for Merger Notification Statements) the final draft should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed for that purpose, adapted to the case and the less extensive information required in the statement. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application for a Schedule 16 Statement is likewise described as being accompanied by documents. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]
source_text: The Merger Notification Statement must have been approved by the PRA before it is sent to the members, and must be sent within the specified time limit. Applications for approval should, in general, follow the procedure described in paragraph 3.73 , and the final draft of the Merger Notification Statement should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed in paragraph 3.98 , but as appropriate to the particular case and the less extensive information the statement is required to contain. The statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society to which the PRA has given its consent under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act.
target_text: Schedule 16 Statements must be prepared to the same standards as apply to financial statements and directors reports. An application to the PRA for approval of a Schedule 16 Statement must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board, that the Statement is complete and includes all material information of which, in the opinion of the directors, the members should be aware. That declaration should say whether or not there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise see paragraph 3.89 – 3.90 ) and confirm that the information about them is correct. question: If the rules don’t say how to value a certain type of asset, what value should be used, and how should that value be changed if the firm is treated as having bought or sold that asset type because of an option when working out its exposure using the 19 to 23 adjustments?
gold_answer: If there is no specific valuation provision for a particular description of assets, the firm must still ascribe a value, using the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] That ascribed value is the basis for calculating exposure, because the firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23. [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff] When the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of assets of a given description pursuant to an option, the value ascribed for assets of that description (under 18 to 19) must be increased or decreased by the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] So, even where the initial valuation is based on a reasonable immediate transfer price (because the rules are silent for that asset type), the firm must still apply the option-driven increase or decrease to the ascribed value for that asset description as part of the overall adjustment process used to determine exposure under 19 to 23. [#SRC:edaf68ec91a76124] [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]
source_text: The value ascribed under 18 to 19 in respect of assets of each description must be increased or decreased by the value of assets of that description which the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of pursuant to an option .
target_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .

question: If an asset type isn’t covered by the valuation rules, how do you pick its value, and after you adjust that value to get the firm’s exposure, do you also need to add anything for the firm’s dependants?
gold_answer: You must first assign a value to the assets and then calculate the firm’s exposure by adjusting that value, and after that you must add any relevant exposure of the firm’s dependants for the same asset description. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] Where the rules in this Part do not provide a valuation method for a particular asset description, the value used must be the amount that would reasonably be paid as consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of those assets. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] The firm’s exposure to assets of each description is determined by taking the asset value and applying the required adjustments under the specified provisions (19 to 23). [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] After the exposure amount has been determined in accordance with 18 to 22, that exposure must be increased by an amount representing any exposure of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description, unless 23.2 or 23.3 applies. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] Practically, this means the dependant-related amount is not part of the initial valuation step; it is an additional increase applied to the exposure figure that results from the valuation-and-adjustment process, and it is tied to the same asset description you are measuring for the firm. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6]
source_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .
target_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.

question: If an insurance business transfer scheme under Part VII of FSMA has two transferors, do they pay one £25,000 fee or more than one, and by when does it have to be paid (linked to the PRA application to appoint an independent expert)?
gold_answer: For a Part VII FSMA insurance business transfer scheme where the transferor is seeking regulatory consent, the regulatory transaction fee is £25,000 and it must be paid on or before the date of any application to the PRA to appoint an independent expert. [#TGT:c75df87775893198] When the scheme involves more than one transferor (or more than one transferee), the PRA can choose to treat it as a single scheme so that only one fee is charged for the overall scheme rather than separate fees per party. [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1] Even if only one fee is applied, having more than one transferor changes who is responsible: the transferors are jointly and severally liable, meaning each transferor can be held responsible for the full fee until it is paid. [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1] In practice, the transferors should coordinate payment so the £25,000 is received by the deadline tied to the independent-expert appointment application, while understanding that the PRA may look to any one of the transferors for the entire amount if payment is not made. [#TGT:c75df87775893198] [#SRC:fff1aa5511edabb1]
source_text: For the purposes of 4.8 an insurance business transfer scheme involving more than one transferor or transferee may, at the PRA’s discretion, be treated as a single scheme to which only one fee will be applied. Where there is more than one transferor they will be jointly and severally liable for the fee.
target_text: The transferor seeking regulatory consent for an insurance business transfer scheme under Part VII of FSMA pays a regulatory transaction fee of £25,000, the due date for payment being on or before the date of any application to the PRA for the appointment of an independent expert.

question: When calculating the percentage required for the amount determined under 7.8 relative to the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), how must a firm treat sums recoverable under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period, and at what stage does that deduction affect the denominator used for the percentage expression?
gold_answer: A firm must present the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), meaning the 7.7 amount is the reference base (denominator) for the percentage expression. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] In establishing that 7.7 reference base, the firm must first reduce the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2) by deducting the total sum that is recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts that were ceded during the relevant period. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] Accordingly, the deduction for reinsurance recoverables is applied to the 7.7 amount before the firm uses that 7.7 figure to express the 7.8 amount as a percentage. [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72] [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] This sequencing matters because the rule on expressing 7.8 as a percentage explicitly ties the percentage to the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), while the reinsurance rule specifies an adjustment that must be made “from” that 7.7 amount based on recoverables under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period. [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23] [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]
source_text: A firm must express the amount determined under 7.8 as a percentage of the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2).
target_text: From the amount determined under 7.7 (1) or (2), a firm must deduct the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period.

question: For a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), how do you determine whether the firm must comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 for its important group business services, given the stated non-application of 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 when the group’s parent undertaking is headquartered in an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations and regulation 14(3) applies?
gold_answer: A firm in a group covered by 2.1(3) should treat the Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 obligation for its important group business services as a separate compliance requirement that applies where the group falls within the stated scope, while also recognizing that certain provisions (22.2, 22.3 and 22.4) may be switched off in a specific third-country supervision scenario. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] Specifically, the operational resilience duty is triggered because the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) (noting the text’s “subject to 22.5” qualifier) and it is framed as an additional requirement the firm “must” meet in relation to its important group business services. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] Separately, if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies, then 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] In practice, you therefore (i) confirm the group is within 2.1(3) for the operational resilience scope, and (ii) assess whether the third-country designation and regulation 14(3) conditions are met to determine the non-application of 22.2–22.4, without treating that carve-out as removing the operational resilience requirement stated for important group business services. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , the firm must also comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 in relation to its important group business services .

question: For a firm with a matching adjustment permission, how should the firm treat uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from assets with highly predictable cash-flows when determining the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed and reflecting those risks in the SCR calculation, including any stress-driven changes to the FS and MA?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission should treat uncertainty in the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable as a risk source that must be identified and then assessed for its effect on the FS and MA within the SCR framework. [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35] The SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed, and the SCR calculation should allow for changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] In practice, the firm should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed (including the identified cash-flow timing/amount uncertainties), evaluate how those risks could affect the FS and MA, and assess how that impact is captured within the SCR calculation. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] The firm should also ensure that stress-condition changes to the FS include changes to any additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including additions made as part of the attestation process. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1] For assets with highly predictable cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets and any changes to FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment, linking the identified uncertainty to the stress impacts modelled in the SCR. [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]
source_text: A firm’s SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks 6 to which it is exposed. The calculation of the SCR should therefore allow for any changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. In doing this, firms should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed, how these risks could affect the FS and MA and assess how this impact is captured within the SCR calculation. Changes to the FS in stress conditions should include any changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including those made as part of the attestation process. For assets with HP cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets as well as any changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment 8 .
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty regarding the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable .

question: If a merger plan includes payments to directors or other officers because they are losing their job or income, and it also includes bonus payments, what member votes are needed and where do the bonus votes have to appear if the bonus total is within the prescribed limit versus above it?
gold_answer: You need two coordinated member-approval tracks: a separate special resolution for the loss-of-office/loss-of-income compensation, and Merger Resolutions that include the required approval for bonus payments, with the scope of those Merger Resolutions depending on the prescribed-limit test. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] If the merger terms provide for compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or of income, the proposed payments must be approved by a separate special resolution. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] Separately, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] To decide which societies’ Merger Resolutions must carry that bonus approval, you look at the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If that gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the bonus approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If it exceeds the prescribed limit, the bonus approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This keeps the compensation vote separate while ensuring the bonus vote is placed in the correct Merger Resolutions based on the limit. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]
source_text: If the terms of a merger include provision for the payment of compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or of income, then the proposed payments must be approved by a separate special resolution. A further special resolution may also be required if there is to be a distribution to members which exceeds the limits described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If the PRA is reviewing a firm’s ICAAP stress testing in the SREP (and major UK firms also face the Bank’s annual stress test (AST)), what does the review look at in the firm’s stress results and plans to deal with the stress?
gold_answer: The PRA’s review of a firm’s ICAAP stress testing is performed as part of the SREP, and for major UK firms this SREP assessment is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). [#SRC:7a56cad9ade1c41e] In carrying out that assessment, the PRA looks at whether the firm’s projected stress results are credible and reasonable, and whether the assumptions used to build the stress projections are themselves credible and reasonable. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] The review focuses on the parts of the stress scenario that harm the firm’s capital position, meaning the areas where the scenario reduces capital resources and increases capital requirements. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] It also considers the nature and severity of the scenario that the stress results are based on, as part of understanding why the projections look the way they do. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4] In addition, the PRA assesses whether the mitigating actions the firm proposes to mitigate the impact of the stress are reasonable, tying the firm’s response plans to the projected capital effects identified in the stress results. [#TGT:d39f337dea52ffb4]
source_text: The PRA carries out an assessment of firms’ ICAAP stress testing as part of the SREP. 40 For the major UK firms this is supplemented by the Bank’s annual stress test (AST). 41
target_text: The assessment considers the credibility and reasonableness of firms’ projected stress results and the underlying assumptions on which the stress projections are build. The assessment focusses on the areas where the stress scenario adversely impacts firms’ capital positions (ie reducing capital resources and increasing capital requirements), the nature and severity of the scenario on which the stress results are based and the reasonableness of mitigating actions firms propose to mitigate the impact of the stress.

question: How should a firm determine whether an arrangement with a third party is ‘outsourcing’ under the PRA Rulebook (including the relevance of recurrent/ongoing performance and sub-outsourcing), and if the arrangement falls outside that definition as a ‘third party arrangement’, what PRA expectations still apply to it?
gold_answer: A firm should first assess whether the arrangement meets the PRA Rulebook definition of ‘outsourcing’, and if it does not, treat it as a ‘third party arrangement’ that is outside the scope of existing outsourcing requirements but still within broader PRA expectations. [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2] Under the PRA Rulebook, ‘outsourcing’ covers any form of arrangement where a service provider (whether a supervised entity or not) performs a process, service, or activity that the firm would otherwise carry out itself, including where performance occurs indirectly through sub-outsourcing. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] In applying that definition to a third-party relationship, the firm should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis, as this is a key factor in deciding whether the arrangement falls within the outsourcing definition. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] If, after this assessment, the arrangement is instead a ‘third party arrangement’ outside the outsourcing definition, it is consequently outside the scope of existing requirements on outsourcing and some detailed expectations in the supervisory statement. [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2] Even then, the firm must still manage it under the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations relating to business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management (including cyber risk). [#SRC:b8e1a28348d8aad2]
source_text: Chapter 2 elaborates on the definition of ‘outsourcing’ in the PRA Rulebook. It also notes that there are arrangements between firms and third parties that fall outside this definition (‘third party arrangements’) and are consequently outside of the scope of existing requirements on outsourcing and some of the detailed expectations in this SS. However, these third party arrangements are still subject to the PRA Fundamental Rules and other PRA requirements and expectations on business continuity, governance, operational resilience, and risk management (including but not limited to cyber risk).
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: If a third country branch and its outsourcing service provider are in the same group, what can the branch take into account about control or influence for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11, and what information does it need to be ready to give the PRA (or another relevant competent authority) if asked about the outsourced work?
gold_answer: When the third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch may consider how much it controls the service provider or can influence what the provider does, but only for the specific purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] That group-based control or influence is the relevant factor the branch is permitted to take into account in that context. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] Even with that group connection, if the PRA or any other relevant competent authority requests it, the branch should make available all information needed so those authorities can supervise whether the outsourced activities are being performed in line with the requirements of the regulatory system. [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1] So the branch should be able to (1) describe its control/influence over the service provider for the purposes of the listed sections, and (2) provide the necessary information about the outsourced activities so supervisors can assess compliance performance. [#SRC:ba066540a6b4af47] [#TGT:5c89c9f008f3d8f1]
source_text: If a third country branch and the service provider are members of the same group, the branch may, for the purposes of 8.6 to 8.8 and 8.10 and 8.11 , take into account the extent to which the branch controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.
target_text: A third country branch should make available on request to the PRA and any other relevant competent authority, all information necessary to enable the PRA and any other relevant competent authority to supervise the compliance of the performance of the outsourced activities with the requirements of the regulatory system.

question: When submitting the Merger Document that includes the Schedule 16 Statement, what specific contractual-conflict disclosure must be included in that Schedule 16 Statement, and how does the requirement apply across the societies and their connected undertakings (noting the Merger Document is submitted unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society)?
gold_answer: The Merger Document submission must include a Schedule 16 Statement, and that Schedule 16 Statement must contain an explicit disclosure addressing contractual conflicts. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] Specifically, the Schedule 16 Statement must state whether the merger will or will not conflict with any contractual obligations, and this assessment must cover contractual obligations (including agency agreements) of either society as well as their connected undertakings. [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca] This means the disclosure is not limited to one party: it must speak to both societies and extend to connected undertakings, and it must not omit agency agreements from the scope of contractual obligations considered. [#TGT:42a09cff8c333fca] In preparing the overall Merger Document package, the Schedule 16 Statement is included as part of that document (unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society), and it is submitted together with the specified accompanying explanations referenced for the Merger Document. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1]
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: The PRA will require the Schedule 16 Statement to include a statement as to whether or not the merger will conflict with any contractual obligations, including agency agreements, of either society or their connected undertakings.

question: If a firm has client accounts or trust accounts held for beneficiaries that might have eligible deposits, how should those accounts be labelled, and what does the PRA expect the firm to be able to send to the PRA or the FSCS (and by when) if asked?
gold_answer: The firm needs to label (mark) beneficiary-held accounts—specifically including client accounts and trust accounts—so that those accounts can be spotted right away as accounts that contain or may contain eligible deposits. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] Beyond putting that marking in place, the PRA expects the firm to be able to produce account information that separates eligible accounts from ineligible accounts, so the two categories are clearly distinguished in what is provided to supervisors or the compensation scheme. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] The firm must be able to provide those details to the PRA or the FSCS in a format that matches the relevant rule and the PRA’s statement, rather than in an arbitrary internal format. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Timing is also part of the expectation: once the PRA or the FSCS asks for the information, the firm must be able to make the separately identified eligible and/or ineligible account details available within twelve hours from the point of that request. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] In practice, the marking requirement and the twelve-hour delivery capability work together to support immediate identification and rapid reporting for these beneficiary-held accounts. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: How should a TWD firm design and use sensitivity analysis for key assumptions in its TWD scenario so that senior management can understand the plausible range of impacts on capital and liquidity projections, given the expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should build sensitivity analysis into its TWD capabilities so it can quantify how alternative key assumptions (relative to those used in the TWD scenario) would change projected outcomes, and it should present results in a way that helps senior management understand plausible ranges of impact on capital and liquidity after executing the TWD option. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] This sensitivity analysis should be capable of setting upper and lower bounds for the firm’s key assumptions, so the analysis does not just provide a single-point estimate but instead frames a range of plausible impacts for decision-makers. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The analysis capability should also be able to assess at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are included in the TWD scenario (and may include other factors as well), ensuring the sensitivity work is anchored to the scenario’s core drivers. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] In designing this capability, the firm should do so in a manner consistent with the expectation that its overall TWD capabilities are constructed on the basis of a full wind-down of its trading activities, so that the sensitivity ranges and bounds are evaluated within that full wind-down context rather than a partial trading continuation. [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]
source_text: TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario. TWD firms should be able to use their sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out the upper and lower bounds for TWD firms’ key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on TWD firms’ capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option. This sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors (see paragraphs 3.6 - 3.15 for more detail).
target_text: This does not impact the expectation (set out in more detail in Chapter 4 ) that a TWD firm’s TWD capabilities should be built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities.

question: When a society applies to the PRA for confirmation, what reports must be obtained from the scrutineers, what specific voting information must those reports cover, and how does this interact with the chairman’s responsibility to manage procedural resolutions such as an adjournment at the meeting?
gold_answer: For a society’s application for confirmation, the PRA expects scrutineer reporting both to support the application and to evidence that voting procedures were valid, and the meeting chair’s procedural control (including any adjournment) should facilitate obtaining that reporting in a compliant way. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] The chairman of the meeting should be properly prepared on the society’s Rules and the general law on procedural resolutions (including how to adjourn a meeting), because the meeting may need to be adjourned to enable the scrutineers to provide their initial report to the society at the meeting. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] [#TGT:5624262c20121461] In support of the confirmation application, the PRA will require a scrutineers’ report covering the vote outcome and key metrics, including a split between votes cast in person and by proxy, the total number of members eligible to vote, and the proportion of eligible members represented by votes cast. [#TGT:5624262c20121461] Separately, the PRA will also require a confirmatory report from the scrutineers addressing the validity of the voting procedures, reinforcing the need for strict adherence to statutory procedural requirements and the society’s own Rules on meetings and resolutions. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] Together, these elements mean the chair should manage meeting procedure so that scrutineer reporting can be produced and relied on for the PRA confirmation process. [#SRC:03526eddeb1eff14] [#TGT:5624262c20121461]
source_text: Experience has demonstrated the need for societies to take the greatest care to ensure that they comply strictly with the statutory procedural requirements and their own Rules on meetings and resolutions. The chairman of the meeting should ensure that he or she is well briefed and aware of the Rules and the general law relating to procedural resolutions, such as resolutions to adjourn the meeting. The PRA will require a confirmatory report from the scrutineers on the validity of the voting procedures when the society applies for confirmation (see paragraph 3.146 ).
target_text: The scrutineers initial report will be made to the society at the meeting (which may be adjourned for this purpose).
