question: Who has to appoint the compliance officer, and how does that role connect to the rule that senior management must get written reports (at least once a year) that say whether fixes were made when problems were found?
gold_answer: The management body must appoint a compliance officer, and that compliance officer must be responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required for the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] Separately, the firm must make sure its senior management receive written reports frequently and at least annually on the matters covered by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] To connect these requirements in practice, the compliance officer’s responsibility for compliance reporting should be used to drive the preparation and delivery of those written reports to senior management on the required schedule. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] The written reports to senior management must also indicate whether appropriate remedial measures were taken when deficiencies occurred, so the reporting overseen by the compliance officer needs to include both identification of deficiencies and an update on whether remediation has been completed. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] In short, appointment by the management body establishes who owns compliance reporting, and the senior-management reporting rule sets the minimum frequency and the requirement to report on remediation status. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3]
source_text: (2) a compliance officer is appointed by the management body and that compliance officer is responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required in relation to its obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7 ;
target_text: A firm must ensure that its senior management receive on a frequent basis, and at least annually, written reports on the matters covered by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts . Such written reports must indicate whether the appropriate remedial measures have been taken in the event of any deficiencies.

question: When making the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities that have not fallen due for payment before the valuation date, how must the determination integrate (i) generally accepted actuarial principles and policyholders’ reasonable expectations and (ii) an assessment of the nature/term and valuation of the assets representing those liabilities, including provision for future asset-value changes?
gold_answer: For long-term insurance liabilities that have not fallen due for payment before the valuation date, the determination must be performed using generally accepted actuarial principles, must take due account of the reasonable expectations of policyholders, and must make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include suitable margins for adverse deviation. [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62] In addition, that same determination must explicitly factor in the assets that represent those liabilities by considering the nature and term of those assets and the value attributed to them. [#SRC:77cfb62c67129fc6] The prudence required for the liabilities must be complemented by a prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of those assets, so that the liability amount is not set without regard to asset-value volatility. [#SRC:77cfb62c67129fc6] Practically, this means the actuary’s valuation approach and assumptions (including margins for adverse deviation) should be applied in a way that is consistent with both (a) policyholder expectations and full liability coverage and (b) the risk that asset values may change over time, given the assets’ term and characteristics. [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62] The scope limitation is that the described actuarial-principles and policyholder-expectations framework applies to liabilities other than those already due for payment before the valuation date. [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62]
source_text: The determination referred to in 6.1 must take into account the nature and term of the assets representing those liabilities and the value placed upon them and must include prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of the assets on:
target_text: In accordance with 6.2 to 6.4 , the determination of the amount of long-term insurance liabilities (other than liabilities which have fallen due for payment before the valuation date ) must be made in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles and have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders and make proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation.

question: When a firm proposes restructuring assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group (ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV)), what assessment must it perform about the unrestructured asset’s ongoing appropriateness for the MA portfolio liabilities, and how does that assessment interact with the PRA’s expectation that such restructuring should be used only where no viable alternative approach (eg pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows) is available?
gold_answer: A firm considering restructuring assets through a wholly owned subsidiary set up for this purpose (ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV)) should treat acceptability as conditional and should not proceed unless it can both justify the need for the restructuring and demonstrate that the underlying (unrestructured) asset remains an appropriate match for the MA portfolio liabilities over the relevant period. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] Specifically, in assessing the suitability of the arrangements, the PRA expects the firm first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, in a way that aligns with the duration of the restructuring arrangement and takes account of how operating conditions might change. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] In parallel, because restructuring adds complexity and consequential risks, the PRA expects these arrangements to be used only where the firm has not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, such as pairing/grouping or partial recognition of cash flows. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] The firm should also ensure the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including recognising any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation, while ensuring proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33] Taken together, the firm’s decision-making should link the time-based suitability assessment of the unrestructured asset to the rationale for using an SPV restructure only as a last resort relative to the identified alternatives. [#SRC:0a3517a57344a4ca] [#TGT:c2928336a8c67d33]
source_text: In assessing the suitability of arrangements set out in paragraphs 2.55 to 2.56 above in this context, the PRA expects firms first to consider whether the unrestructured asset is likely to remain appropriate over time, consistent with the duration of the restructuring arrangement, and as operating conditions might change. Examples of assets that may not be a suitable match for the liabilities of the MA portfolio include:
target_text: Restructuring of assets through a subsidiary company set up for this purpose and wholly owned within the insurance group, ie a special purpose vehicle (SPV), 22 may be acceptable, provided that proposals comply with applicable MA eligibility conditions. It is important, however, that the restructure is appropriately recognised within the firm and the group, including any changes in the risk profile of entities affected by the asset transformation. Given the additional complexity and consequential risks that restructuring gives rise to, the PRA’s expectation is that these arrangements will only be used in cases where firms have not been able to identify a viable alternative approach, for example pairing/grouping, or partial recognition of cash flows.

question: When a firm is estimating PDs as long-run averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, how should it choose and use a data series of appropriate length so that the estimate reflects a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, and in what circumstances should the firm change (or not automatically update) that long-run estimate as additional years of experience become available?
gold_answer: A firm should build its long-run PD estimate using a data series that is long enough to support a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, and it should use that series in a way that captures a representative mix of both good and bad economic periods rather than relying only on the firm’s realised historic average. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] In practice, this means the “appropriate length” is not just about adding more years mechanically; it is about ensuring the observation window and any adjustments produce expected default rates for each obligor grade or pool that reflect conditions across the cycle. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] The firm should change the long-run estimate when there is a reason to believe the existing long-run estimate is no longer accurate, because the objective is a reasonable long-run default rate estimate rather than a static figure. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] However, the firm should not automatically update the long-run estimate simply to incorporate additional years of experience, since those extra years may not be representative of the long-run average even if they extend the data series. [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea] This approach aligns the requirement for an appropriately long data series with the expectation that the estimate be cycle-representative and only revised when accuracy is in doubt. [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]
source_text: Principle 3: a firm should use a data series of appropriate length in order to provide a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate referred to in paragraph 10.13 ; and
target_text: In order to estimate PDs that are long-run averages of one year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects firms to estimate expected default rates for the grade/pool over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply taking the historic average of default rates actually incurred by the firm over a period of years. The PRA expects that a long-run estimate would be changed when there is reason to believe that the existing long-run estimate is no longer accurate, but that it would not be automatically updated to incorporate the experience of additional years, as these may not be representative of the long-run average.

question: When a firm is applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR for illiquid assets, how should it treat the Chapter 4 expectations on risk identification and internal model calibration/validation, including the example expectations for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans, and what must it do if it decides those expectations are not applicable to other assets with similar features?
gold_answer: A firm applying the MA within the calculation of the SCR should treat the PRA’s Chapter 4 expectations as the relevant framework for conducting the risk identification exercise and for calibrating and validating internal models for illiquid assets. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08] In that context, the example expectations described for Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans should be used as a reference point, and the firm should actively assess whether those example expectations are suitable for other relevant illiquid assets in its portfolio given the heterogeneity of such assets. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] If the firm concludes that the IPRE-related expectations are not applicable to assets that have similar features to IPRE, it must be able to provide a justification explaining why they are not applicable, and it must provide that justification upon request. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] The PRA’s approach to seeking assurance against these expectations is described as proportionate and is linked to using similar criteria to those discussed in paragraph 2.6 of this SS, which informs how the firm should anticipate supervisory review of its Chapter 4 work. [#TGT:4abb726bc4a4f4e9] Overall, the firm should align its MA/SCR internal model work for illiquid assets with these Chapter 4 expectations and be prepared to evidence applicability decisions and any non-applicability rationale. [#SRC:19764d3f3782ec08]
source_text: Chapter 2 of this SS clarifies the PRA’s expectations where internal credit assessments are used as part of determining the basic FS, including some expectations that are specific to restructured assets (including ERMs). Chapter 3 then sets out some principles to be applied when assessing the risks from guarantees embedded within ERMs, for the purposes of verifying the appropriateness of the FS (including any FS additions); these apply to both restructured ERM notes and un-restructured ERMs that may be included in the MA portfolio under the limited proportion of assets with highly predictable cash flows. Chapter 4 sets out the PRA’s expectations regarding the risk identification exercise and the risk calibration and validation of internal models for illiquid assets.
target_text: This chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations of firms regarding the risk identification exercise and the risk calibration and validation of internal models (particularly in respect of the application of the MA within the calculation of the SCR) for illiquid assets. It includes, as an example, several expectations, specific to Income Producing Real Estate (IPRE) loans. Given the heterogeneity of illiquid assets, the PRA expects firms to consider whether these expectations are applicable to other relevant assets within their portfolios. Where firms consider the expectations are not applicable to assets with similar features to IPRE, the PRA expects them to provide, upon request, a justification of why this is the case. The PRA will seek assurance against these expectations in a proportionate way, using similar criteria to those discussed in paragraph 2.6 of this SS.

question: When a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is following the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 for an acquisition or disposal of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity, how should the content and accompanying documents of the section 178 notice be determined, and which form may be used for that notice?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the section 178 notice must be prepared by reference to the Controller’s Form requirements, and the investment manager may use the specific Controller’s form identified by the PRA for this context. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Where the controller or proposed controller is an investment manager and is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with acquiring or disposing of listed shares as part of its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] Consistently, the PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by the documents required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Accordingly, for an investment manager in the listed-shares fund management context described, the notice’s information content and supporting documents should be those required by the Controller’s Form applicable to the application, and the form that may be used is the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]
source_text: Where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with the acquiring or disposal of listed shares in the course its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5 .
target_text: The PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by such documents as are required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application.

question: If an insurer wants to put an asset in its liquidity buffer, what does “unencumbered” mean, and how does that fit with the PRA’s expectation that the asset should be easy to sell and value (including in stressed markets)?
gold_answer: For an asset to be suitable for the liquidity buffer, it needs to meet the PRA’s expectation that buffer assets are unencumbered, high credit quality, readily marketable, and reliable sources of liquidity in stressed market conditions. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9] “Unencumbered” specifically means the asset is free of material legal, regulatory, contractual, or other restrictions that would limit the insurer’s ability to liquidate, sell, transfer, or assign it. [#TGT:bb68fdf1ed7da148] Putting these together, the insurer should check both market features and restriction-free ownership/control. On the market side, the asset should be easy to value with a high degree of certainty and should be either listed on recognised exchanges or tradable on large, deep and active cash or repurchase markets with many participants and observable prices. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9] On the restriction side, even if an asset looks liquid in the market, it would not be “unencumbered” if a material legal, regulatory, contractual, or similar limitation could prevent or materially hinder the insurer from selling or transferring it when needed. [#TGT:bb68fdf1ed7da148] Because assets can differ in how quickly they can be realised in stress, the insurer can use these checks to support whether an asset is more consistent with primary or secondary liquidity within the buffer. [#SRC:f1b87547e6bfc4d9]
source_text: The PRA considers that assets included in the liquidity buffer should be unencumbered, 18 of a high credit quality, readily marketable, and have a proven record as a reliable source of liquidity during stressed market conditions. Such assets should be easy to value with a high degree of certainty (ie low likelihood of material disagreement between transacting parties in a sale) and will either be listed on recognised exchanges or tradable on large, deep and active cash or repurchase markets with a large number of participants, low concentration, high trading volume and timely and observable market prices. Even assets of ‘high credit quality’ may have differences in the speed at which they may be realisable, particularly during stressed market conditions. The PRA considers two classifications for assets in the liquidity buffer to emphasise this distinction: assets of primary liquidity and assets of secondary liquidity.
target_text: 18. ‘Unencumbered’ means free of material legal, regulatory, contractual or other restrictions on the ability of the insurer to liquidate, sell, transfer, or assign the asset.

question: Where an institution indicates it benefits from a derogation by reference to the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 12.2 (second subparagraph) and/or 15.A1(3), how should it treat that indication if it is a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm for which 12.2 and 15A do not apply, and what specific remuneration-related information must still be provided about the derogation’s use?
gold_answer: An institution should not present itself as benefiting from a derogation “on the basis of” PRA Rulebook provisions that are stated not to apply to it; in particular, if it is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm, it should not rely on 12.2 or 15A as the basis for its derogation indication because those provisions are disapplied for that category of firm. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] However, where the institution is making the required derogation-related disclosure for the relevant reporting purpose, it must still provide the specified detail about how any derogation is used, rather than only naming rulebook references. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] In practice, the institution’s disclosure should cover: (i) which rulebook bases it is using for the derogation indication (limited to those that apply to it); (ii) which remuneration principles the derogation(s) are applied to; (iii) how many staff members benefit; and (iv) the beneficiaries’ total remuneration, broken down between fixed and variable components. [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6] This approach links the applicability carve-out for small CRR firms/small third country CRR firms with the separate obligation to provide granular information about the scope and impact of any derogation claimed. [#TGT:a4ec0f032fd53c03] [#SRC:709d7a650b1d24f6]
source_text: For the purposes of point (k) of the first subparagraph of this paragraph, institutions that benefit from such a derogation shall indicate whether they benefit from that derogation on the basis of the Remuneration Part of the PRA Rulebook at 5.3 , and/or 12.2 (second subparagraph), and 15.A1 (3) . They shall also indicate for which of the remuneration principles they apply the derogation(s), the number of staff members that benefit from the derogation(s) and their total remuneration , split into fixed and variable remuneration .
target_text: 12.2 , 15.15 to 15.19 , 15.20 (2) and (3A), 15.20A to 15.23 and 15A do not apply to a firm that is a small CRR firm or a small third country CRR firm .

question: When a firm is valuing assets (including an asset description not expressly covered by the valuation rules) and then determining its exposure by adjusting those values, how must the firm treat any exposure of the firm’s dependants to assets of the same description when calculating the final exposure amount?
gold_answer: In calculating the final amount of the firm’s exposure to assets of a given description, the firm must (i) ascribe a value to the assets and (ii) determine exposure by adjusting that value, and then (iii) add any applicable dependant exposure on top of the exposure amount produced by those steps. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] For valuation, the firm must use an amount determined under the applicable rules in this Part; if the asset description has no specific valuation provision, the firm must instead use an amount that would reasonably be paid for an immediate assignment or transfer of the assets. [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] The firm’s exposure to assets of each description is then determined by adjusting the asset value in accordance with the specified adjustment provisions (19 to 23). [#SRC:596695fe437c2dff] Once the firm has determined the amount of exposure to assets in accordance with 18 to 22, that exposure amount must be increased by an amount representing any exposure of the firm’s dependants to assets of that same description (subject to 23.2 and 23.3). [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6] This means the dependant-related increase is applied after the exposure has been determined under 18 to 22 (which itself relies on the valuation and adjustment approach described above), and it is calculated by reference to the same asset description used for the firm’s own exposure calculation. [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6]
source_text: A value must be ascribed to assets of each description which must be an amount determined in accordance with this Part or, where the assets are of a description for the valuation of which no provision is made in those rules, an amount which would reasonably be paid by way of consideration for an immediate assignment or transfer of such assets. The amount by which the firm is exposed to assets of each description must be determined by adjusting the value of the assets in accordance with 19 to 23 .
target_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, what does an institution need to do so it can correctly provide the competent authorities (on request) the number of hedging sets per risk category and the risk driver information for each hedging set?
gold_answer: To be able to provide the requested hedging-set information, the institution needs to map multi-risk-driver derivative transactions to risk categories in the way required, and then report hedging sets consistently with that mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] When the competent authorities ask, the institution must make available (for each risk category) the number of hedging sets it has established, plus the relevant risk driver information for each hedging set (the primary risk driver or, for the relevant transactions, the most material risk driver in that risk category, or the pair of risk drivers), and also the number of transactions in each hedging set. [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce] For transactions with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map them to more than one risk category, except that if all material risk drivers are in the same risk category it maps the transaction only once to that category using the most material risk driver. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, it maps the transaction once to each relevant risk category using the most material risk driver within each category, which then supports reporting the “most material risk driver in the given risk category” alongside the hedging-set counts and transaction counts. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] [#SRC:83d0ae2a5dfdf3ce]
source_text: Institutions shall make available upon request by the competent authorities the number of hedging sets established in accordance with paragraph 2 of this Article for each risk category, with the primary risk driver, or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) , or the pair of risk drivers of each of those hedging sets and with the number of transactions in each of those hedging sets .
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: What does it mean for a firm to “prepare for resolution” under Fundamental Rule 8, and how does that connect to the PRA and the Bank as resolution authority talking to the home state supervisor and/or home resolution authority and then asking the firm for more information?
gold_answer: Preparing for resolution under Fundamental Rule 8 means the firm must get itself ready so that, if resolution is needed, it can be handled in an orderly way and with as little disruption as possible to critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] The resolution planning information the firm provides should therefore describe preparations that support that outcome, because the purpose of the preparation is to enable an orderly resolution with minimal disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] The PRA and the Bank as resolution authority play an active role in reviewing and testing whether the firm’s information is sufficient: they will discuss the firm’s resolution preparations with one or both of the home state supervisor and the home resolution authority. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] After those discussions, they will consider whether they need any additional information from the firm. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] So, the firm should be ready not only to provide initial resolution planning information, but also to respond if the PRA and the Bank as resolution authority decide—based on engagement with the relevant home authorities—that more information is required to assess the firm’s readiness for orderly resolution and continuity of critical services. [#SRC:b277461e673dbd9a] [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]
source_text: resolution planning, including information regarding the group’s preparations for resolution consistent with Fundamental Rule 8 (the PRA, and the Bank as resolution authority, will discuss with one or both among the home state supervisor and home resolution authority, and then consider if any additional information is required from the firm).
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: If a firm holds assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, what does it need to do about extra risks and FS increases, and what should it write down to show it has covered cash flow variability and uncertainty?
gold_answer: If a firm’s MA portfolio includes assets with HP cash flows, it should assume these assets can add extra risk and therefore plan for increases to the FS for those assets to cover the additional risks they introduce. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] To work out what those FS additions should be, the firm should look for extra risks coming from sources of cash flow variability and make sure the required FS additions capture those risks, using the guidance in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of the chapter. [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6] At the same time, the firm must identify every source of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for each one, so the FS work should not focus only on variability but also on timing/amount uncertainty. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] The PRA expects the firm to document the details of these uncertainty sources and describe how it has allowed for them, which should be consistent with the firm’s approach to ensuring the FS additions are sufficiently captured under the paragraph 5.17 to 5.29 guidance. [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121] [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: Assets with HP cash flows are likely to introduce additional risks into firms’ MA portfolios and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required (in accordance with Matching Adjustment 4.16 ) to provision for these additional risks. As required by Chapter 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part , firms must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for these. The PRA expects firms to document details of these sources of uncertainty and how they have allowed for them.

question: If a firm has a contract with an organisation to provide a product or service, how can the firm tell whether the PRA Rulebook/MODR outsourcing requirements apply, using both the meaning of “third party” and the test for “outsourcing” (including the idea of work done on a recurrent or ongoing basis)?
gold_answer: The firm should not assume the outsourcing requirements apply just because it has a contract with an external organisation; the SS treats a “third party” broadly as any organisation in a business relationship or contract to provide a product or service. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928] Instead, the firm must determine whether the arrangement is “outsourcing,” because the existing outsourcing requirements (including Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook) apply only to outsourcing as defined, and do not apply to other third‑party arrangements outside that definition. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928] Under the PRA Rulebook definition, outsourcing exists where a service provider (whether supervised or not) performs a process, service, or activity—directly or through sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise perform itself. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] When making that call for an arrangement with a third party, the firm should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis, as this helps indicate whether the arrangement falls within the outsourcing definition. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b]
source_text: Existing requirements on outsourcing, including Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook, only apply to ‘outsourcing’ as defined in paragraph 2.1 . They do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties which fall outside the definition of outsourcing. In line with the definition in the G7 Third Party Elements and EBA ICT GL, this SS defines a ‘third party’ as ‘an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service’.
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: When a credit union invests surplus funds under Rules 6.5 and 6.6 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, what specific risk considerations and decision documentation are expected, and how long must the credit union retain the written record of the relevant assessment?
gold_answer: A credit union investing surplus funds is expected to make and document investment decisions in a way that demonstrates active consideration of key financial risks and alignment with its own risk appetite, and it must keep the written assessment record for a defined retention period. In particular, when investing surplus funds, the credit union is required to consider and document its decisions and to account for counterparty, concentration, liquidity, and interest rate risk under Rules 6.5 and 6.6 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:b0d16647ea0d1e00] The PRA also expects the credit union to weigh the risk/return trade-off carefully and to ensure the investment decision reflects the credit union’s risk appetite, including (where used) setting exposure limits for different counterparties based on their risk profile as part of the risk appetite statement. [#SRC:b0d16647ea0d1e00] Separately, for the assessment referenced in 6.5, the credit union must retain a written record for five years after the date of the investment, which sets the minimum period for keeping the documented assessment supporting the investment decision. [#TGT:9a674e73f8cecd3e]
source_text: Credit unions investing their surplus funds are required to consider and document their decisions and account for counterparty, concentration, liquidity, and interest rate risk under Rules 6.5 and 6.6 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook. When making investment decisions, the PRA expects credit unions to carefully consider the risk return trade-off and to ensure investment decisions reflect the credit union’s risk appetite. Credit unions should consider setting exposure limits for different counterparties based on their risk profile, as part of their risk appetite statement.
target_text: A credit union must retain, for a period of five years following the date of the investment, a written record of the assessment in 6.5 .

question: If problems in another part of the group (like intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements) could stop the firm delivering key services, how do you decide whether to call those services “important business services” or “critical operations,” and which types of UK firms does each label relate to?
gold_answer: You should treat group-wide issues—including those coming from intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements—as part of the operational resilience assessment, because they can affect whether the firm can keep delivering its most important services. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] To choose the right label for the services at risk, use the service concept that matches the UK entity type described. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Important business services” is the term used for services defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook, and that approach applies to CRR firms, described here as UK subsidiaries of international groups. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Critical operations” is the term used for services defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Principles for Operational Resilience (March 2021), and that approach is relevant for UK branches. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] So, when you identify a group-originated risk that could disrupt delivery, you should (1) link it to the affected service(s), (2) note whether the disruption pathway is via intragroup outsourcing or another inter-affiliate arrangement, and (3) classify the service as an “important business service” for a CRR firm (UK subsidiary) or a “critical operation” for a UK branch, so the resilience assessment uses the correct service definition. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf]
source_text: the operational resilience of the firm and group, including risks arising elsewhere in the group that may affect the ability of the firm to deliver its important business services or critical operations (such as those provided through intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements); 25
target_text: 25. Important business services refers to services as defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook which applies to CRR firms – ie UK subsidiaries of international groups. Critical operations refers to services as defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s ‘Principles for Operational Resilience’ (March 2021): https://www.bis.org/bcbs/publ/d516.pdf , and is relevant for UK branches.

question: When assessing whether Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook apply to a firm’s arrangement with an external organisation, how should the firm distinguish between (i) an arrangement that is ‘outsourcing’ and (ii) a non-outsourcing third‑party arrangement, and what role does the ‘recurrent or ongoing basis’ consideration play in that determination?
gold_answer: Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook apply only where the arrangement meets the applicable definition of “outsourcing”; they do not apply to other firm–third party arrangements that fall outside that definition. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928] To make that distinction, the firm should start from the PRA Rulebook definition: outsourcing is any arrangement (with a service provider, supervised or not) under which the provider performs a process, service, or activity—directly or via sub-outsourcing—that the firm would otherwise carry out itself. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] The firm should then use the “recurrent or ongoing basis” consideration as a practical test when deciding whether an arrangement with a third party falls within that outsourcing definition, i.e., whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part of it) on a recurrent or ongoing basis. [#TGT:b7ac6dbd1a20206b] Separately, the SS defines a “third party” broadly as an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service, but that label alone does not determine whether the arrangement is outsourcing for purposes of the MODR/PRA Rulebook requirements. [#SRC:ae60277c11940928]
source_text: Existing requirements on outsourcing, including Articles 30–32 of MODR and Conditions Governing Business 7 in the PRA Rulebook, only apply to ‘outsourcing’ as defined in paragraph 2.1 . They do not apply to other arrangements between firms and third parties which fall outside the definition of outsourcing. In line with the definition in the G7 Third Party Elements and EBA ICT GL, this SS defines a ‘third party’ as ‘an organisation that has entered into a business relationship or contract with a firm to provide a product or service’.
target_text: The PRA Rulebook defines ‘outsourcing’ as ‘an arrangement of any form between a firm and a service provider, whether a supervised entity or not, by which that service provider performs a process, a service or an activity, whether directly or by sub-outsourcing, which would otherwise be undertaken by the firm itself’. This definition derives from Article 2(3) of MODR (Commission Delegated Regulation on organisational requirements and operating conditions). In line with the EBA Outsourcing GL, when considering whether an arrangement with a third party falls within the definition of outsourcing, firms should consider whether the third party will perform the relevant function or service (or part thereof) on a recurrent or an ongoing basis.

question: If a managing agent is thinking about running both general insurance business and long-term insurance business in the same syndicate, what is the default rule, and what extra material is meant to help work out how the Composites Part applies when an exception allows it?
gold_answer: The default position is that a managing agent must not allow both general insurance business and long-term insurance business to be carried on together through any syndicate it manages, unless an exception applies. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] Consistent with that, the Composites requirements expect composite firms to keep the management of general insurance business separate from the management of long-term insurance business, which in practical terms means the managing agent should manage syndicates carrying on general insurance business separately from syndicates carrying on long-term insurance business. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] If the managing agent is in the specific situation where a single syndicate carries on both types of business under the exceptions referred to at Composites 6.2, then paragraphs 3.1–3.3 of SS8/15 on Composites are identified as intended to help determine how the Composites Part requirements apply to managing agents in that mixed syndicate case. [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8] So, the agent should treat “one syndicate doing both” as only possible within the stated exception, and then use the SS8/15 paragraphs to guide how to apply the Composites Part in practice. [#TGT:022fa162b8d30cb6] [#SRC:112b43b1150a4cf8]

question: If the PRA lets a transferee society do the merger by board resolution (so it doesn’t have to put Merger Resolutions to members or send them a Schedule 16 Statement), what should the societies do early on with the PRA about the timetable, and what dates do members still have to be told in the Merger Document?
gold_answer: If the PRA has consented to the transferee society proceeding by board resolution, the transferee society is treated as exempt from the requirement to put Merger Resolutions to its members and from sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members. [#SRC:98fdd2a7fe5b0420] Even in that scenario, the societies should run the merger using an agreed timetable and should engage the PRA early: as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger, the societies should meet with the PRA’s staff and agree a provisional timetable. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] That provisional timetable can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved, which provides a point at which the schedule is settled for orderly execution. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] For planning expectations, the overall process from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, general meeting, confirmation hearing, and then to the effective date is generally unlikely to be completed in under six months. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] Members must still be notified in the Merger Document of the date provisionally set for the confirmation hearing and the proposed date of completion of the merger. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]
source_text: The probable sequence of events is described more fully in section ‘ Timetable ’. The case where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution, and thereby exempting it from the requirement to put Merger Resolutions, and sending a Schedule 16 Statement, to its members, is described in paragraphs 3.149 – 3.152 .
target_text: The time taken to complete a merger will vary from case to case. As a general rule of thumb, it is unlikely that a merger can proceed from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, general meeting and confirmation hearing, to the effective date, in less than six months. It is essential to the good and orderly management of a merger that the societies concerned meet with the PRA’s staff as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger, and agree upon a provisional timetable. This can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. The members can then be notified, as they must be, of the date provisionally set for the confirmation hearing and of the proposed date of completion of the merger in the Merger Document.

question: If a Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm wants to use proportionality when setting pay rules, can it drop Chapter 3A, and what does it still have to build into the remuneration policy’s design about the firm and its risks?
gold_answer: No—using proportionality does not let a Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm drop (disapply) Chapter 3A when setting its remuneration policies; the PRA still expects appropriate compliance with Chapter 3A. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] Instead, the firm should use judgement so that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 are applied in a proportionate way and adjusted where needed to reflect the size and nature of the business. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] Even while tailoring implementation in that way, the firm must ensure the remuneration policy is designed to take into account the firm’s internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business. [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c] Put together, this means the firm’s proportional modifications to Solvency II staff arrangements should be consistent with (and informed by) how the firm is organised and how complex and large its risk profile is, rather than being used as a reason to remove Chapter 3A controls. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c]
source_text: The PRA will still expect smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) to comply appropriately with Chapter 3A when setting their remuneration policies. The application of proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 does not equate to smaller firms being able to disapply the Chapter 3A requirements. These firms should be exercising appropriate judgement to ensure that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff contained in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 are applied proportionality and modified where required to reflect the size and nature of their businesses.
target_text: A firm must ensure that the remuneration policy is designed in such a way as to take into account the internal organisation of the firm , and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business.

question: If a firm’s recovery plan has to cover severe stress scenarios (including system-wide events and stress affecting individual legal persons and groups), what should a TWD firm be able to do with sensitivity analysis so senior management can see the range of capital and liquidity outcomes, and how many scenarios must G-SIIs and O-SIIs analyse at a minimum?
gold_answer: The recovery plan should cover a range of severe macroeconomic and financial stress scenarios that fit the firm’s own conditions, including system-wide events and stress that is specific to individual legal persons and to groups. [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2] For a TWD firm, sensitivity analysis should be used as a practical tool within that planning to quantify how different key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) would change results. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The firm should be able to use those sensitivity results to set upper and lower bounds for its key assumptions, so senior management can understand the plausible range of impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] The sensitivity analysis capability should also be able to analyse at least the minimum baseline set of factors that are part of the TWD scenario, while also being able to consider other factors. [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f] Separately, if the firm is a global systemically important institution (G-SII) or an O-SII, SS9/17 indicates it should include analysis of at least four scenarios in its recovery plan. [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2]
source_text: TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario. TWD firms should be able to use their sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out the upper and lower bounds for TWD firms’ key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on TWD firms’ capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option. This sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors (see paragraphs 3.6 - 3.15 for more detail).

question: How should an insurer integrate its regular review of limits (including the minimum annual review expectation for an insurer other than a small non-Directive insurer) into the requirement to establish, implement and maintain written policies and adequate procedures for risk management and related governance functions?
gold_answer: An insurer should embed its limits-review process within its written risk management policy framework and supporting procedures, so that limit setting and adjustment are governed, repeatable, and demonstrably maintained. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] The review should be performed regularly, with adjustments made when the insurer’s risk tolerances change or when broader market conditions shift, because the limits are expected to remain aligned to the insurer’s risk profile and external environment. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] For an insurer other than a small non-Directive insurer, the limits review should occur at least annually, and it should be conducted as part of the broader review of the insurer’s risk management policies. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] To connect the annual (or more frequent) limits review to the written-policy requirement, the insurer should ensure its documented policies and procedures cover: (i) how limits are reviewed and approved; (ii) what triggers interim adjustments (e.g., changes in risk tolerances or market conditions); and (iii) how this activity is maintained within the overall governance system that includes internal control, internal audit, and, where relevant, outsourcing. [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72] This approach ties the expected periodic limits review to a maintained, written, and procedurally supported risk management framework. [#SRC:a810e349d072127d]
source_text: An insurer is expected to regularly review its limits and make appropriate adjustments when its risk tolerances or broader market conditions change. An insurer, other than a small non-Directive insurer, 14 should review these at least annually as part of the broader review of its risk management policies as required under Conditions Governing Business 2.4(4) and Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance 3.4(4) .

question: When assessing how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could adversely affect an insurer, how should the insurer treat “sleeper collateral,” and what specific counterparty action involving sleeper collateral is identified as a potential stress transmission channel?
gold_answer: In evaluating how liquidity stresses at counterparties and other market participants could harm the insurer, the insurer should treat “sleeper collateral” as an unposted but contractually committed collateral amount that may become payable if and when the counterparty calls it. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] This matters because the passage identifies “recalling sleeper collateral” as a concrete counterparty action that can occur under stress and that could adversely affect the insurer’s liquidity position. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] The combined implication is that the insurer’s assessment should not view sleeper collateral as irrelevant simply because it has not been posted; instead, it should recognize it as a contingent liquidity demand embedded in contractual obligations that can be activated by counterparty behavior. [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74] In the same stress context, the insurer should consider that counterparties may take other actions—such as selling similar assets affecting market prices, not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes—that can compound liquidity pressures alongside a sleeper-collateral recall. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] Overall, sleeper collateral should be incorporated as a potential call-driven outflow risk specifically linked to the identified recall action under liquidity stress. [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404] [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]
source_text: actions of counterparties, and other market participants experiencing liquidity stresses that could adversely affect the insurer, for instance by selling similar assets to those that the insurer may rely on for liquidity and affecting market prices, recalling sleeper collateral, 17 not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes.
target_text: 17. Sleeper collateral refers to the value of collateral that an insurer is contractually obliged to post to a counterparty, but has not yet posted as it has not yet been called by the counterparty.

question: If someone sends a written representation to the PRA, what will the PRA do next for that person, and why is that consistent with what the appendix says it is for (including people in oral confirmation hearings)?
gold_answer: After someone makes a written representation to the PRA, the PRA will take steps that both confirm receipt and provide procedural direction. Specifically, it will acknowledge that it has received the representation or notice, and it will send the representer a copy of Appendix 5, which covers merger confirmation procedures. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e] That action fits the appendix’s stated purpose because the appendix is intended for people making written representations to the PRA and/or those taking part in oral confirmation hearings, and it explains the procedures the PRA plans to follow. [#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6] In other words, the PRA’s acknowledgement plus sending the appendix ensures that a representer is not only told their submission arrived but is also given the procedural framework the PRA expects to apply, which is the kind of guidance the appendix is designed to provide to written representers and hearing participants. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e][#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6] In addition, the PRA will pass on copies of all written representations to the societies concerned and give those societies a chance to comment, which is part of the procedure the appendix is meant to describe. [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e][#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6]
source_text: The PRA will acknowledge the receipt of each representation or notice and will send a copy of Appendix 5 , on merger confirmation procedures, to each representer. It will send copies of all written representations to the societies concerned and will afford them an opportunity to comment on them.
target_text: This appendix is for the use of those making written representations to the PRA and/or those participating in oral confirmation hearings. It sets out the procedures which the PRA intends to follow.

question: For a smaller firm (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm) setting its remuneration policies, how should it apply proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 while still meeting the requirement that the remuneration policy’s design reflects the firm’s internal organisation and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks in its business?
gold_answer: A smaller firm (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firm) should treat proportionality as a way to tailor how Chapter 3A is implemented, not as a basis to switch Chapter 3A off, while also ensuring the remuneration policy is designed to reflect how the firm is organised and the risk profile of its business. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] In practice, the PRA’s expectation is that these firms comply appropriately with Chapter 3A when setting remuneration policies, and that proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 does not mean the firm can disapply Chapter 3A requirements. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] At the same time, the firm must design the remuneration policy so it takes into account the internal organisation of the firm and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business. [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c] To fuse these requirements, the firm should use judgement to apply the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 proportionately, modifying those arrangements where needed to reflect the firm’s size and nature, while ensuring the overall policy design remains aligned to its organisational set-up and risk complexity. [#SRC:a1a186c5cfc66eed] [#TGT:07a05eb1c221e73c]
source_text: The PRA will still expect smaller firms (Category 3-4 PRA regulated firms) to comply appropriately with Chapter 3A when setting their remuneration policies. The application of proportionality under Conditions Governing Business 3A.3 does not equate to smaller firms being able to disapply the Chapter 3A requirements. These firms should be exercising appropriate judgement to ensure that the specific arrangements for Solvency II staff contained in Conditions Governing Business 3A.2 are applied proportionality and modified where required to reflect the size and nature of their businesses.
target_text: A firm must ensure that the remuneration policy is designed in such a way as to take into account the internal organisation of the firm , and the nature, scale and complexity of the risks inherent in its business.

question: If you need PRA approval before sending a Merger Notification Statement to members on time, what should your written application include (especially the board declaration), and what specific detail about payments to directors or officers must appear in the statement?
gold_answer: You should submit a written application to the PRA that includes a board-backed completeness declaration, and you must ensure the Merger Notification Statement itself contains the required compensation information before it is sent to members within the time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The Merger Notification Statement cannot be issued to members until the PRA has approved it, and it must be sent within the specified time limit. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The application for approval must be made in writing and should include a declaration made on behalf of the board that the Statement is complete and includes all material information that, in the directors’ opinion, members should be aware of. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] That declaration should also say whether there have been any other merger or takeover proposals (confidential or otherwise) and confirm that the information about those proposals is correct. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50] Separately, the Merger Notification Statement must include particulars of any compensation payable to directors or other officers of the transferor society where the PRA has consented to that compensation under paragraph 2(1) of Schedule 8A to the 1986 Act. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The submission should be supported with accompanying documents: for Merger Notification Statements, the final draft should be accompanied by the relevant documents listed for that purpose, adjusted to the case and the less extensive information required. [#SRC:187d02e014c602dc] The Schedule 16 approval application is also described as being accompanied by documents. [#TGT:b23ef312764c9a50]

question: If you normally have to work out the long-term insurance liability using a forward-looking (prospective) calculation for each contract, when are you allowed to use a backward-looking (retrospective) calculation instead, and what do you need to show?
gold_answer: You generally must determine the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a prospective calculation, so the standard method is forward-looking and applied at the individual contract level. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] You may switch to a retrospective calculation only in specific situations that relate to whether a prospective method can be used and whether the retrospective result is at least as conservative as a prudent prospective result. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] First, a retrospective calculation is allowed where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit; this is an exception that depends on the nature of the contract or benefit, even though the liability is still being determined for each contract. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] Second, even if a prospective method could be applied, you may use a retrospective calculation if you can demonstrate that the liabilities it produces would be no lower than what would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; the key requirement is the demonstration of a non-lower outcome against that prudent prospective benchmark. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Outside these conditions, the prospective calculation remains the required approach for determining the long-term insurance liability for each contract. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: If the PRA isn’t directly checking firms against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC, why would a TWD firm still implement them when Fundamental Rule 8 says it must be ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption to critical services?
gold_answer: A TWD firm would implement the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC because they are described as helping the firm build real capability to meet the outcome expected by Fundamental Rule 8, even though the PRA does not directly supervise against those SoPs. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52] Fundamental Rule 8 sets the core expectation: the firm must prepare for resolution so that, if resolution becomes necessary, it can be carried out in an orderly manner and with minimum disruption of critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0] The SOURCE explains that the PRA is consulted when these Bank policies are developed and that the Bank’s approach promotes the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8 in the Fundamental Rules Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52] It also states that implementing the SoPs will help TWD firms develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring. [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52] Putting these points together, the firm can justify implementation as a way to strengthen its resolution preparedness (including the ability to carry out a post-resolution restructuring option) in line with Rule 8’s focus on orderly resolution and protecting critical services. [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]
source_text: The PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC. However, the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies. The Bank’s approach acts to promote the PRA’s safety and soundness objective and Rule 8 in the Fundamental Rules Part of the PRA Rulebook. Implementing these Bank’s SoPs will help TWD firms to develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: If the Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary is supposed to go out with the meeting notice, what happens if someone who should get it doesn’t receive it? When is that treated as an “accidental omission,” and when is it not (for example, if there’s a computer mailing-list problem or management decides not to send to a group)?
gold_answer: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the meeting notice to every person who is entitled to receive it, so a missing delivery is assessed in the same overall context as notice delivery. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] For meeting validity, the scrutineers’ report may properly take into account that an accidental failure to give notice, or a person’s non-receipt of the notice, does not automatically invalidate what the meeting does. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] But the society should not treat every mistake as “accidental.” [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] The “accidental omission” idea does not include systemic failures to send notices, such as not sending to new shareholders or borrowers, or leaving out a whole group/class because a computer programme fault caused them to be missing from the mailing list. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] Also, authority indicates that “accidental” and “non-receipt” do not cover all “error,” including a management mistake where management wrongly decides not to send notices to particular persons or groups. [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0] So, isolated accidental lapses may be treated differently from systemic or management-driven exclusions when evaluating notice compliance and reporting. [#SRC:f846f8a8fd9e4856] [#TGT:5cf84dc0540e0fc0]
source_text: The Transfer Statement or Transfer Summary must be sent in or with the notice to every person entitled to receive it (paragraphs 2 and 4 of Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act). Accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to any person entitled to receive it does not invalidate the proceedings at the meeting. However, ‘accidental omission’ does not include a systemic failure to send notices (eg omitting to send notices to new shareholders or borrowers, or omission of a group or class of members from the mailing list arising from a fault in a computer programme), nor all cases of error by management – see also paragraph 4.153 .
target_text: In relation to the notice of the meeting, the scrutineers’ report may properly have regard to the provision of paragraph 22(3) of Schedule 2 to the 1986 Act that ‘accidental omission to give notice of a meeting to, or non-receipt of notice of a meeting by, any person entitled to receive notice of the meeting does not invalidate the proceedings at that meeting’. It should be noted, however, that there is authority to the effect that ‘accidental’ and ‘non-receipt’ would not cover all cases of ‘error’ on the part of the society, for example an erroneous decision of management not to send notices to particular persons or groups of persons.

question: When checking the PRA’s under-£130 million limit for FSCS covered instant access deposits at branches, what does “instant access account” mean, and which balances should be counted?
gold_answer: When you check the PRA expectation for branches, you should count only the retail and small company instant access account balances that are covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme, and the total of those counted balances is expected to stay under £130 million. [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] An “instant access account” is one where customers can take money out unconditionally, so they can withdraw without having to give notice and without having to pay penalties. [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3] Put together, this means you identify retail and small company accounts that meet the unconditional-withdrawal test (no notice and no penalties) and then include their FSCS-covered balances in the branch total for the £130 million expectation. [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] The withdrawal-condition definition is what determines whether an account is in scope for the “instant access” part of the PRA expectation, so it directly affects which balances you add up against the cap. [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3]
source_text: (a) FSCS covered instant access deposits: the PRA expects branches to have under £130 million of retail and small company 55 instant access 56 account balances covered by the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (FSCS);
target_text: 56. An instant access account means accounts from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, without providing notice or paying penalties.

question: While waiting for a change in control to happen after a section 178 notice is sent, what should a UK domestic firm keep checking about the controller or proposed controller, and when does it have to tell the PRA if it thinks the notice information might be wrong or has materially changed?
gold_answer: In that interim period, the UK domestic firm has two linked responsibilities: keep itself up to date on the relevant person’s situation and escalate problems to the PRA without delay when certain warning signs appear. During the period referred to in 3.6, the firm must take reasonable steps to stay informed about the circumstances of the controller or proposed controller that the notification was about. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] Separately, in the period between submitting a section 178 notice and the occurrence of the change in control, the firm must notify the PRA immediately if it becomes aware, or has information that reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have given the PRA information that was or may have false, misleading, incomplete, or inaccurate, or that the information has or may have changed in a material particular. [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e] The practical linkage is that the ongoing “reasonable steps” monitoring is what positions the firm to detect the kinds of potential inaccuracies or material changes that trigger the immediate notification duty during that same pre-change window. [#SRC:e4f64412bd209979] [#TGT:adb285c8c0a8613e]
source_text: During the period referred to in 3.6 , a UK domestic firm must take reasonable steps to keep itself informed about the circumstances of the controller or the proposed controller to which the notification related.
target_text: (1) A UK domestic firm must notify the PRA immediately if, in the period between a section 178 notice being submitted and the occurrence of the change in control , the firm becomes aware, or has information which reasonably suggests, that the person submitting the notice has or may have provided the PRA with information which was or may have been false, misleading, incomplete or inaccurate, or has or may have changed in a material particular.

question: When a firm is assessing whether it has sufficient credible recovery options to restore capital and liquidity in or after a stress, how should it incorporate both (i) the likely actions of peers (including potential constraints on issuing equity in a market-wide stress) and (ii) scenario testing to demonstrate the recovery plan works across different stresses and that plan elements interact appropriately?
gold_answer: A firm should assess recovery options in a way that both (1) evidences it can restore capital and liquidity to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress and (2) uses scenario testing to show the recovery plan remains usable across different stress types and that its components work together. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] In practice, the firm should treat peer behaviour and market-wide conditions as key assumptions when judging the real capacity of its options, and then validate those assumptions through scenario testing that exercises the plan end-to-end. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] Operationally, this means the firm should: (i) identify credible options intended to restore capital and liquidity positions; (ii) assess each option’s capacity under stress while explicitly considering likely peer actions; and (iii) reflect market-wide stress constraints, such as reduced ability to issue equity, when evaluating feasibility. [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d] The firm should then run scenario testing across a range of different types of stress to demonstrate the recovery plan is suitable for use, and to test how indicators, governance, and options would interact under those stresses (including the peer-action and equity-issuance constraints embedded in the option capacity assessment). [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450] [#SRC:1a86a372e2d7e31d]
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure they have sufficient credible options to restore their capital and liquidity positions to appropriate levels in, or following, a stress. In assessing the capacity of these options, firms should take into account the likely actions of peers in a stress. For example, firms should assess whether their ability to issue equity will be diminished in a market wide stress. See also ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below.
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.
